GAME: Power Grid
RANK: 26
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Power Grid is, at its core, an accounting exercise, but, as strange as it might sound, it can be a *fun* accounting exercise. You have to optimize your energy production through a careful choice of the power plants you want to run, taking into consideration their power output, their cost (you have to bid for them) and the resources it takes to run them. Throw in a nice economical system for resource pricing, a bit of positional play when you choose the cities you supply with electricity and that's almost it. Not exactly a gateway game, rules are functional but somewhat fiddly and it can be quite long, but it also offers interesting decisions and just a bit of luck. It can feel dry and I don’t consider it a game for every crowd, but it surely deserves at least a try.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Beautiful mechanics. I actually enjoy the calculation part which seems to turn some people off. The theme is very refreshing after lots of "let's build random stuff set in a nondescript medieval period" games (don't get me wrong - I love those!), and way more exciting than it might sound. It's also quite easy to understand, rule-wise, so the basic principles can be explained to others in no time at all. This game just *works* for me.

Updated after more plays and I've got to say that I love this game.

RATING: 10

More comments to come....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game has lots of things I like; courtesy of the rubber band effect, it stays close till the end (but I understand why it's annoying to make any inroads before the end only to have them erased and with experienced players, it's just a jockeying for positional bounce). It has area influence/control elements in terms of route building and pricing of the locations. The nuance of the auction in terms of both bidding and nominating is fantastic. It's a game that rewards those who understand how to ride (and abuse) the turn order system, and can do long budgeting (much more so than other auction/econ games). I generally enjoy playing it, but I just don't get jazzed about the game; I don't request it, and I admit, I'll sort of think of whether I want to dedicate that sort of time to it if asked. It's a game where if someone said "you have 4 hours, would you rather play 1 game of Indonesia or 2 of Power Grid" I'd say Indonesia hands down, but if I only have 90-120 minutes, then I'd consider Power Grid. It fits in that smaller time frame.

RATING: 7
Great game. Wish I could get it to the table more often.

UPDATED 5-28-14: Bumped it down to a 7 from an 8. Still like this game, but we have noticed that, at least in a 2 player game, the last round is absent of any surprise element once the bidding phase is over. You know exactly how many cities you can power as well as your opponent, and so at that point if one person has the advantage, the game is over.

UPDATE 6-17-15: Traded with Power Grid for Smash Up in Dice Tower Con Math Trade.

RATING: 10
The godfather of the economic simulation, Power Grid is an excellent medium weight, mathy game that can lead to very intense scenarios, particularly at the bidding table. Although the running time is a little long, especially with groups prone to analysis paralysis (like mine) it is still a stellar addition to my gaming collection I would always be happy to play!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Many people seem to love this kind of theme and mechanics.
I really prefer pure & simple mechanics instead of the lots of tables & numbers that are present in this game. Despite its complexity on the surface, delving deeper it seems that there's not a lot to strategize here if you play with a lot of players. (Tried with 6.) You won't be able to predict a lot in this case.
Lots of money calculations needed. I have enough of this in real life...
Also the 'player order' mechanism always tries to push the last players forward and tries to keep the best players from expanding too quicly (they can only buy more expensive resources and buy towns last).
This creates a nice illusion of a 'close race' but for me it felt like being on a rollercoaster: thrilling, but a fixed experience determined by complex numerical mechanics. And still not a lot of chance of catching on by e.g. pulling off a nice plan once you fall behind the others.

Keeps growing on me. It's now a 9.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Solid German game. I think the theme is better connected to the mechanics than Puerto Rico. Though I can't ever imagine myself saying "why doesn't someone make a game on buying power plants and the rights to power up cities", this game works and works pretty well if you're into the theme. There's great tension in the bidding process and the ever-changing available power plants. The map boards seem to create interesting dilemmas of position and placement. Overall, the game pieces are deluxe and nicely done with one exception: why the rules aren't in color is beyond me. I do have a creative design critique: why make the different types of wooden goods in strange shapes as non-cubes tend to roll around. I would have been satisfied with just different colored cubes but I'm more of a "functional gamer." I disagree with some reviewers with their belief that it's too mathematical as one can play most of this game without decisions being bogged down in equations. The very end-game (last couple of turns) can get math-heavy but the decisions are few at this point. It is an economic game with a focus on using your cash wisely and that's not going to appeal to everybody. This one should see plenty of play in our gaming group. 

Update: Lowering my rating from 8.5 to 6.5. I was wrong as the game is too math heavy for my taste. To play it well, you have to be planning at least a full turn ahead and calculate your money down to the last dollar. It has a run-away leader problem as there's very little you can do (without destroying yourself) to reign someone in if they get lucky in auctions. The auction mechanism can unbalance the game. Players may over pay for what are visible plants only to see a fresh plant pop up late in a turn that gives the loser of earlier auctions a golden opportunity (broken auction mechanism to me). It's also better to place later on the board for starting positions as there's no where to hide without hurting yourself and it's better to respond to player's positions than to try and stake one out. And how many auction games does the world need?

RATING: 8
A really excellent game.  The learning curve is a little more difficult than other games I've played, however it's really rewarding once you get the hang of it.  When you get near the end of the game and all the resources are in short supply it can be really exciting, and often you won't know who will win right up to the last turn.  This should be a must play for anyone into strategy board games. Just make sure you have a lot of time to play it because with 3 people on my first full playthrough we were at it for about 4 hours.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
This is an economic efficiency game. I love the theme and the cartoony artwork (I work in the nuclear power industry), and the game is fun. It has simple rules, is easy to learn, and scales great with any number of players. I usually don't care for efficiency exercises, but I think the modern setting and theme make it more interesting for me.

The game does tend to get pretty mathy and analytical, though, which can be undesirable depending on my mood. The last turn tends to bog down as everyone starts really thinking about their every expenditure and counting everything, as that last turn is the one that really counts. It's one of the better Eurogames, but I'm usually in the mood for a game with more craziness and less math.

RATING: 9
Several clever play mechanics mesh together to create a fairly smooth-playing, balanced game. Highly enjoyable and deeper than it first appears, with interesting tactical decisionmaking. Player interaction is present in almost all phases of the game.

Update: having owned this for several years now, I always have fun playing this, despite having to always check the rules "just to make sure".

The strategy is fairly subtle, however, and if you're a person who likes to play all-out in whatever game you play, then this game isn't for you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've read a lot that 2 player is the worst way to play it and I can see the potential with more, but I've enjoyed several 2 player games of this. Would be interested to try it with the Robots expansion to enhance the competitive aspects. I love the mechanic with regards to goods availability and pricing. The imagery is nice on the cards. It's a shame that the theme won't appeal to everyone at a first glance. If not for the theme I think this would be very accessible.

Games with three and four players have confirmed that this is a great Euro-style game merging route-planning, a nice little catch-up mechanic, an enjoyable auction phase, and some neat resource management. Not a short game, but worth investing time in. It has become one of my favourite games.

RATING: 9
played many times(10+), 3,4,5,6 players.

LIKE: This is the game for me. I enjoy the auction mechanism and different maps. The auctions get some good table-talk, because buying just the right priced power plant can be quite powerful. 
DISLIKE: Can be math heavy at times. Calculators help, but slow the game down. The power plant expansions don't always work with some maps (japan seemed broken, but ok with germany). 

OVERALL: Fun theme, lots of strategies, highly interactive.

RATING: 7.5
Superlative. It truly deserves the rank on the 'Geek. There's a few odd moments in the rules, but when you play, it's butter. My only take back from that is the computational energy needed to play - great computing minds will likely win the day. And this in turn falls into somewhat of a 'sameness' to play. For a mathy game - a genre I generally dislike - I find it surprisingly fun.

RATING: 8.1
Juego de subastas de centrales eléctricas, unión de las distribuidoras, y gestión económica y mercado de recursos para abastecerlas. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Rating may change in time.

A real thinker.  Like Age of Steam, there's plenty going on to think about, but it's thankfully a wee bit less cut-throat and desperate...maybe not by a lot, though.

So many decisions to make that it can get a bit analytical and mathematical - which is maybe a reason for knocking off a point here.  Having said that, the analysis thankfully comes in lots of small chunks which means the game flows quickly and there's not much down time between turns.

I found Steps 1 and 2 fun, but step 3 ended too soon and in fact the whole game can move from middle to end very quickly, leaving you feeling slightly anti-climactic.

Further plays may remove some of these problems, anmd I can see that it's a great game with lots of variation.  I like the artwork too, and the it's got a more meaningful theme than many Euros.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Power Grid is a good game, and I can see why it's a popular classic of modern Euro games.  That said, having played many other Euros before finally giving it a play, it's nothing special to me.  It has a good level of strategy and replayability seems good, but it has some warts.

My biggest gripe about the game is the end game.  Granted I've only played it twice, but both games ended up with a tie for most powered cities and thus came down to cash on hand.  With cash being the first tiebreaker over total number of cities, there's very little incentive to expand to more cities than you can power in the end game, which to me is a mistake because it doesn't recognize any advantages a tied player has in board position at the end of the game.  Perhaps it is just a misalignment of expectations on my part to think that final board position should have some bearing on the game outcome, but it just feels to me like the number of cities should trump cash on hand as a tiebreaker.

Additionally, the fact that games tend to have close finishes also feels unsatisfying to me since it feels like the final outcome is something of a crapshoot that can be decided by a player bidding up one plant more than another.

Which brings me to another complaint, the kingmaker factor.  Going into the final round, there can be players who have no chance of winning, and yet their presence in the auction on the last round can give them the ability to help determine the winner by driving up the price of one plant or another.

All of this is not to say that Power Grid is a bad game.  I recognize that it is actually a good game and I have enjoyed my plays of it.  However, I just feel that, if it was initially released today, it would not have nearly the popularity it is.  I consider its popularity a product of its time, when it had less competition and could stand out from the field more easily.  For me personally, it doesn't come close to my top 10, and doesn't even crack my top 50.

TLDR: It's a good game, but these days there are just so many other games available that I enjoy more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Bought on trip to Kansas City - 

3/28/13 - Finally played. not that great. 

Very mathy. Each player on their turn has to make sure to have enough money to buy a power plant, raw materials, and a new city network, while at the same time trying to figure out the most efficient and economical way to do all three. This definetly favors those who are good with numbers.

There are also lot of ways to screw other people over. You can block people off from expanding their network, force them to overspend, or dump plants on the in the auction. Force them to overspend on resources.Frustrating for a game that will run over an hour to play.

The Board and the cards look great, but the money is terribly cheap and flimsy. All the other components are functional if lackluster, (the oil bits are annoying though. They're round and tend to roll everywhere.

Overall, I could really take or leave this one. The only reason I have to hold onto it is because I got it in KC.

RATING: 7
Surely I am not the only person on this planet who has a special dislike for a special person, thing, or board game, that, after closer inspection turns out to be really irrational (please say yes?). I am, for example really bad with people. Repeatedly, I run into people who I believe to be arrogant, weird, self-centered or stupid (or combinations therof), and after a certain time of being forced to actually interact with them I find out that I would love for them to be among my best friends. And it seems to be the same with boardgames. But, to cite Game of Thrones, a man can only admit when he was wrong, and ask forgiveness.  So, I do admit that I was wrong. For the last five years I was convinced that Funkenschlag  was a horrible game. Turns out it is actually lots of fun to play.  It is nicely balanced, and even while it has a lot of "exchange stuff for other stuff" mechanics, it uses them in a very convincing way.
Even so, I still don't like Friedemann Friese for his F-fanatism. But, of course, I may be wrong here.

RATING: N/A
3-6 spelare
120 minuter
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game! Combine the auction mechanic of games like Masterpiece with the resource management and territory control of Catan, and you get close to Power Grid.

It's very well balanced, and it does something very unique to maintain fairness and fierce competition: the players who have the most cities get to bid first, but the play order reverses during the resource purchasing and expansion stages of the round, meaning the players in last place get first dibs on the market. It sounds wonky, but it works remarkably well.

I really enjoy the theming, workmanship of the materials, and (most importantly), the game itself.

RATING: N/A
[4]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played it 2 times now, both times with 3 players. Even though it was at first fun to play, the game is flawed at least for only 3 players. Both times, the game was decided before the 5th round was played. From then on, the leader couldn't be caught anymore. After the 10th round, all players had the necessary power plants to play the game to the end. With minimal planning, the leader can just full up his resources one time and then, with one free rousource power plant, run the game to the very end, connecting a city each move. 
In either case, we stopped playing around the 12th move, because there was simply no point in playing anymore.
Maybe this game functions with more players, but with 3 or less players the rules need a makeover, or just play for 7 cities (not 17).

Update: Now I played it with 5 players, same result. About at the end of step 1 (after 7 cities) you can't catch the leader anymore. The income is always big enough to connect at least one city, even if the leader can't power all his cities or doesn't want to. At about this time the leader also has enough power plants to power all cities that he needs to win the game. So the only thing to stop him would be the resources, but money doesn't matter at this point and resources were plenty enough.
So the rules ***ARE*** flawed, and we didn't finish the game ***AGAIN*** because it was pointless. 
Nevertheless, the game still deserves a "6", since up to the 7th or 8th move the game definitely is fun. After that, don't waste your time and play something else, because it becomes repetetive, boring and frustrating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I played this twice at gaming group and loved it.  I think it appeals to the Thermodynamics nerd in me, even though it doesn't involve thermo equations.  If it did, it would be a 9.  If it had dinosaurs and thermo and spaceships, it would be a 10.  Just imagine:

Player 1: My power plant generates 230 MW of power.  I will power these two cities.
Player 2: You better re-calculate that.  My T-Rex just crushed one of your turbines.
Player 1: Yes, but my Warbird unleased 3 distruptor bolts and destroyed the city that you are trying to power.

We can wish, can't we?  Oh well, take it for what it is: one of the better Euros out there.

8/24/08 - Upgraded from a 7 to an 8.  I still don't have a handle on strategies, but I'm enjoying the game more and getting a better feel for it. 5/05/13 - So tempted to upgrade this to a 9.  I love it!  Among the expansion maps, I easily have +20 plays, probably more like +40.  Such an excellent game!  I still don't like the gaminess of the turn order, but at least now I know how to use it to my advantage.

9/04/13 - Upgraded to a 9.  The more I play this game, the more I appreciate it.  There are quite a few layers to it and they combine to produce a really exquisite game that can be played by novice and/or experienced players.

STRATEGY

A self-explanatory title. Buy power plants, fuel them with resources, build houses, and then power the homes with the plants. The rule book was intimidating for me, but after Maggie and I played through this once, everything clicked. I look forward to playing this with 3 or more players, which should make the power plant auctions more interesting. :)

Wonderful player aids are available in the files section.

Recommended with 3-6 players (best 4-5). 120 mins.

RATING: 4
So far I really like the bidding, like the resource market, kind of neutral on the positional play (haven't really engaged with that yet) and sort of dislike the snowballing aspect. I haven't seen a lot of jockeying for turn order yet.

There are important decisions to make, some of them kind of subtle like when to under-fire, but most of them are fairly automatic. The plant market can be pretty damn random. 

The rulebook sucks and contradicts itself in some places. Seriously, how hard is it to have a functional rulebook in eight pages by your nth printing?

[-]I like this more than my other 7s and a couple of my 8s but I just don't think it's as mechanically sound as, say, Puerto Rico so I don't rate it higher. The thing I like the most is the bidding and I suspect there are better bidding games.[/-] I won because of a fortuitous plant draw last time and it really soured me. This is a solid seven, perhaps dropping with more play.

update: I haven't played in a while but I just don't feel a need to play. The route building is underwhelming compared to 1830 and auctions aren't as intense as Chicago Express. The resource market is really cool but I wish it were bolted on to a better game. 

The best short description of this game is that it its relentlessly one-note.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My biggest issue with PG is it's unforgiving runaway factor. The last time we played, I took a 2 city lead early, dominated the game, and blew out everyone else by 5 cities in the end over the course of 2+ hours. You'd think that would be fun for me, but I actually found it to be extremely dull and boring. Since I had more money than everyone else, I could purchase the best card at auction and leave everyone else to fight over the scraps. And I didn't have to worry about resource costs because I could still purchase them at a high price (and that's if I didn't already have "green" power).

You could argue that more experienced players are at a distinct advantage over newbies, but in this case, we were all at a similar level. I tend to agree with the general consensus on BGG that the player that takes the lead ends up winning. 

I prefer games that: let players "gang up" to slow down the leader, let even the weakest player have a participatory role (nothing like playing C&K of Catan and not being able to do anything for 2.5 hours), and allows the possibility for a different player take the lead.

Played Power Grid several times before I started tracking my games played (approx. 3-7 times). 

*** UPDATE 1: My opinion has changed on this one for the following reasons: (a) relativity to other games I've been playing - it is clear now that PG is simply well done in comparison to most games, (b) the new maps are a delight and Benelux is a great intro board, (c) the new power plant deck and rules make the game more forgiving. ***

*** UPDATE 2: Yeah, I find this game very long, drawn out, and plain dull. The maps all look the same - it could be anywhere. In fact, you don't ever need to know the city names or where they are. I do think PG is a great economy and auctioning game - but if it played in half the time, I would like it way better. ***

Tracked on family game list (grooven).

RATING: 9

There can be some luck of the draw issues with the power plant draws but that just means that you can't expect that each game will progress the same as the last so you have to maintain some flexibility in your strategy. A solid game at the heavier end of the game weight spectrum.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
Fun resource management game with a real world feel.  This really well depicts the fuel supply/demand market, which makes it a really neat game (maybe b/c I work for an oil company).  Players turn order determines which order they auction off power plants & buy resources, which is a big deal since the first player who can buy resources (coal, oil, trash, or uranium) gets to buy it at the cheapest prices, while the next players have to pay more since the supply market is shrinking.  Also, this games is very easy to learn and get a grasp of, since each turn occurs in the same order of steps, so you really get a chance to start working on your strategy in game 1.

2010-10
After more plays, the game starts to lose its appeal.  It sill plays well, but each game feels the same and the same strategies are present, only tweaking to deal with the difference in other players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the most consistently competitive games I have played.  It's an economic game of efficiencies where players battle in three arenas (for territory on the map, for resources on the board, and for power plants on the market) while a unique balancing mechanic manipulates turn order to allow players who have fallen behind to charge back in.  The only randomness comes from the power plant market, but this has enough of an impact to keep the game fresh every time you play, as a strategy that worked for you before may not be feasible the next time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The objective of Power Grid is to supply the most cities with power when someone's network gains a predetermined size. In this new edition, players mark pre-existing routes between cities for connection, and then bid against each other to purchase the power plants that they use to power their cities.

However, as plants are purchased, newer, more efficient plants become available, so by merely purchasing, you're potentially allowing others access to superior equipment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.4
Christmas gift, 2012.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Category: Eninge Building;
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
It took a while after getting into the hobby before I had a chance to play this one, and had only ever seen positive reviews about it and heard positive things, from friends. So, perhaps it was just overhyped for me. Maybe with another play, my rating will improve.

It wasn't bad, but it wasn't exceptional either.

I had been expecting something that gave a sense of powering a grid of cities, but the mechanisms really made no sense for that. It felt entirely like a bag of mechanisms, and that was a bit disappointing for a game that seems to be so loved.

The area control system seemed a bit funky, making it too easy to block others in. I had played (and own) the game, Medieval Merchants, which inspired Power Grid's expansion mechanism, and found the original version to be better since there's still a chance to get in on a city before it gets cut off, and many more routes to take around it if I am too late. It seemed like it would have been better if I was only allowed to reserve cities one past a powered city, so that you couldn't swamp territory and box others in so easily (I felt bad fencing one player into a corner for one full step).

In terms of economic simulation, I didn't find it terribly interesting, nor the auctions. In terms of a race to upgrade my business, Viticulture does it with more flavor and multiple possible routes to victory.

It seems like a pretty decent gateway game, to charm people away from Monopoly (much better than Catan). But, to accomplish that, I would expect very streamlined and simple mechanisms. Instead, there's quite a bit of fiddliness to provide the correct range of power stations as the players level up, while still keeping it a bit random. And there's quite a bit of fiddliness with the rules for advancing through "steps". For a game which amounts to "Buy the most cost effective item on the market" and "Try to land-grab cheap, while blocking off your neighbors", it feels like there should have been a way to provide those two mechanisms with far less fuss. While it may not have been developed with the intent of being a gateway game, it feels like - by this point - the designer should have gone back into it and cleaned it up a bit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'd never suggest it again in my life, but thankfully all the people I game with adore it. Perhaps I would suggest it semi infrequently if that wasn't the case, but that's a bridge I haven't had to cross yet. It has the best interactive game play of any Euro I've played.

Very intuitive, but appears to be very dense at first. Don't play this with people who don't like conflict.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like the theme and empire building character of the game, but I've noticed that those who are in the lead are not always the ones who are going to win. The one in the lead is placed in the most disadvantage position in every phase. Basically I do not object to this, since it gives lesser players an opportunity to keep up and this keeps the game fun for everyone. This is probably the main reason for the popularity of this game.

However I have noticed that the lesser gods are able to ruin the game for those in the lead. For example by buying all specific fuel, so that there is nothing left for you. With far too dramatic results. Or the bidding limit of one power plant per turn. There is actually little bidding and the last player always can take the plant he wants. Of course this is all legitimate, but I believe this is not in the spirit of the game.

Although annoyments happen now and then, I still play this game with enthousiasm.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Perhaps a bit dry, but one of the best economic games I know of. The combination of the auction mechanic for power plants with the supply-demand market mechanic for fuels works wonderfully and creates multiple viable strategies. The only downside is that buying and fueling plants is so compelling that new players can be distracted from the real victory condition, which depends on powering cities.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2-6 players. Keep 2018
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
:arrowE: [u]Synopsis[/u]:
Power Grid is the single game responsible for my going from person who casually plays board games on occasion to hobby board gamer. 

Game-driven market economy for fuel and player-driven auctions for power plants lead to a wonderful blend of strategic and tactical play. Buy power plants, fill them with fuel, expand your energy network, and power cities for cashmonies. Take that capital and invest in better plants, stock up on fuel to hedge against the market and screw other players. Plot your network to ensure strong income and long-term placement. The game ends when a set number of cities are connected in any player's network, but only the player who can power the most cities [i]at that immediate point in time[/i] wins. 

:arrowE: [u]What I like most[/u]:
This game requires both sound play on the table and reading the players around the table. Seeing as auctions have no set limit to how much can be bid or how many times, there is no set "best" way to bid for anything, so optimal play rests on the discernment of players on the fly. This fits directly with monitoring available power plant output and the efficiency therein. Is it worth holding onto a clunker oil refinery to stockpile lots of fuel from the market, or ignore potential blocking by going straight for hyper-efficient plants, instead? From there, breaking into or crashing certain fuel markets can swing the game into new direction based on the plants already in play.

:arrowE: [u]What I like least[/u]:
As with most economic games, players without much experience can bid poorly and throw the game. This can also coincide with network expansion which severely hampers a singled-out player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Thanks to Secret Santa, 2009
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Impressive game.  Finely balanced between the auctions, acquisition of resources, costs for expansion, managing the changing turn-order and generating income, with money being so tightly constrained.

But it is incredibly dry and with loads of downtime due to the mathy-ness.  Not that it's complex, it just needs a lot of addition and subtraction to plan an effective strategy.

I'm glad I had a chance to play it, and I can appreciate why it is arted so highly, but I'm unlikely ever to request it again - it's just not really my style of game, which tends toward shorter games with a strong thematic flavour.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5

It has a bit of a chaotic feel with more than 4, you can get screwed without doing anything wrong, and the calculation necessary to play at a high level is intimidating f2f.

RATING: 8.5
2015/12/17
先聲明，電力公司不是我的最愛，我沒有要幫它說話，純粹是就「機制單純或複雜」一事聊聊一些想法。

我個人是覺得，遊戲機制單純或複雜，各有它的優點也有缺點，但如何各自在單純或複雜的領域調味，就要看廚師如何炒菜。

既然單純或複雜各有優缺點，那單純或複雜對設計師來說，應該就是一個選擇而已，而這樣的選擇並不會決定了這遊戲的品質高低。就像披頭四早期選擇了相對其他音樂的單純編曲，但在安排的巧妙下，成品就是悅耳的，遊戲設計也是同理可證，

回頭到電力公司的遊戲機制與流程，相對現在機制拼盤的遊戲來說是單純的，核心機制也是現在常見，但它的在平衡調整以及細部的設定上，有它值得玩味的地方。

比如說
。發電廠賺錢的邊際效益，是隨數量慢慢遞減。
。發電廠需要的燃料市場是會根據供需間的關係而有所浮動。
。玩家順位是每回合浮動的，藉以平衡領先者與弱後者的差距。
。遊戲分成三個階段，各有細微的調整，獲勝不是單純比量或是比大，也就是不是比誰買的東西多或是誰賺得錢多，所以獲勝條件是有其玩味之處。

RATING: 8
Hmmm...a game that really feels like a pleasant, atmospheric gaming experience.  More so than in almost any game I have played, with Power Grid, I sense the very strong hand of a game designer who is quite skilled at delivering you into his chosen world (the Power Grid world) complete with an affecting, somewhat discomfiting, euro-minimalist aesthetic.  Quirky thing this Power Grid. Sure it's competitive and money/resource calculation intensive, but it is the aesthetic and feel of this game, and strong hand of the designer (last place must be given some advantage...every turn...ok), that I really feel uniquely with this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Simplemente un gran juego, luego de un par de partidas te das cuenta de lo bien hechas que están las mecánicas, y lo realmente destacable de ellas que hace que ningún jugador se escape de forma excesiva de los demás.

Es un juego de gestión de recursos, si, pero sobre todo es un juego de optimización. Optimización entre las plantas que compras, su capacidad de iluminar, los recursos que requiere y puedes comprar, y para donde puedes expandir tu red eléctrica (y a que costo!). Si no te gusta calcular mucho, este no será tu juego, pero si eso no te detiene tendrás uno de los grandes, con subastas, demanda de recursos, entre otros.

Eso si, es un eurogame puro y duro, por lo que no tiene mucha inmersión, aún cuando las subastas y la compra de recursos te da la sensación de estar en los negocios de cierta forma, pero es un juego "excel" al fin el al cabo.

RATING: 9
Behold the awesome POWER of Funkenschlag! Besides the really hilarious movie featuring Friedemann Friese himself (at www.boardgameswithscott.com <- go see that) it explaines the full game and it's extremely hilarious/retarded. The game mechanic with a Powerplant market (4 power plants available with different stats) intertwined with the resource market it makes a really cool game. Both the markets make this one of the very best games that incorporate economic systems. 

Though the game is a little bit light compared to the medium-heavy weight German-games like Puerto Rico and Caylus, it is very good, and very simple to play and explain. Therefore this is one of the top german games. Easy to explain, fun to play, hard to master.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
{1 play, 5 player} I'm giving this the same rating as Funkenschlag... but after only one play, I think I may prefer the original.  Power Grid is certainly a nicer production, and though I like the streamlined game (especially paying for connections rather than drawing them), this "shorter" version (still two+ hours) just feels like it's missing something.  Perhaps it's because I've played the original - newcomers won't know the difference so maybe their ratings should carry more weight? - but there's no sense of building here, for me... no sense of shifting and growing from turn to turn.  In Power Grid, I bought 5 plants total (and won, by the way), which means I ended the game with one of my "original" plants.  That'd be pretty tough to pull off in Funkenschlag, where you really FEEL the differences between the 3 phases.  Not that we even came close to Phase 3 in Power Grid (when the game ended in Phase 2, I checked the deck - the Phase 3 card was 5 deep!)  Of course, you could just play to more cities or readjust the newer bigger payouts to the smaller old school method.  And I have only played it the one time, so far.  Regardless of my misgivings, it's a novel system - novel series of systems.  And they still mesh well together in this quite interesting game.

*** UPDATE March 2008 ***

Well, prolly 3-4 years later, and I take some of that back.  Not that I think I'm wrong: the original Funkenschlag still *feels* more epic than the streamlined Power Grid, but the Grid is just as satisfying to me now, maybe even moreso.  Once I accepted the new ebb and flow of the game, I dug it.  In fact, I've only played original Funkenschlag once since Power Grid came out.  I'm sure part of that is me - my lack of interest now in any of the Crayon Rails games.  But I also think PG has more player interaction (partly because it's faster, maybe?) and the faster, smoother system makes each move count more (or at least it feels that way to me), so I find this version to be the better one now.  Plus the various different maps are cool.  And the expansion deck rocks.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a fantastic game.  Some brief reasons:
1.  Simple to learn, even for casual gamers.
2.  Nice bits, artwork, simple and effective theme.
3.  Self-correcting play, where the leader is at a disadvantage.  Newbies have as good a shot as experienced players.
4.  High player interaction - even though there is little direct confrontation, everyone is competing for the same scarce resources - territory, markets, etc.  Minimizes downtime because you need to watch what others are doing.
5.  Unique and elegant mechanisms make this a different game each time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not difficult to learn while being a deep experience. Mark of the greats.

RATING: 6
Very very good game.  I enjoy how the game forces the players to have around the same number of cities.  It doesn't actually punish the leader, but only because the leader is not usually the person with the most cities -- power plants and money are far more important in determining who is in the lead.

Update after many plays: not that much game here.  Everything depends on how the power plants fall out of the auction, and how much the other players hurt you.  The remaining decisions are all fairly obvious.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This would have to be my favorite modern classic game to date.  When I say modern classic I mean it could easily be picked up and played as a family game much like family games we grew up playing.  This has probably the best auction phase in a game that I have played and the resource management can get very cutthroat as well.  Many ways you can essentially screw your neighbor over in this game which is what a lot of modern board games are lacking.  Player interaction.  Seriously, if you haven't played it find someone that owns it and try it out.  It is worth your time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
strange to come full circle on this one.  surprisingly accessible game, and one of my first eurogames.  i thought i liked it a lot, but my next couple plays made the endgame seem more and more deterministic.  "i can afford to do that, you can afford to do that, so i can run this up to..." and that sort of thing.  the multiplayer shutouts where people have no hope of winning because of plant limitations isn't fun either.  i thought hidden money would fix it, but it didn't, and having played so many more games since then i liked it so much worse.  my turn was still just a math puzzle, how many connections can i afford, how many resources should i buy based on those connections, etc.  the endgame was still hosed plant-wise, but instead of knowing on the money tiebreaks i just had to run up the auction a bit and have a best guess as to whether or not i had the most money.  this is one of the most beautiful games i've ever seen.  it's so inviting when i look at it, so it pains me to say that i'm not sure it's very good.

RATING: 5
After first play (5 players), so take this with a grain of salt:  

The game works OK, but it felt cumbersome due to the constant mechanics interruptions such as restocking fuel, the quirky management of what plants are up for auction, and the abominable transitions to phase 2 and 3 (I realize they are essential to make the game work properly, but seriously, what a mess!).  Despite the fact that the mechanics worked out in the end, by somewhere mid-game amidst the mental arithmetic and jockeying to go last in the turn order, I realized I really wasn't having any fun, and most decisions felt like they lacked much tension.  Might need to try it again to solidify my opinion on the matter, but I can't say I'm really looking forward to a second play.

RATING: 8

RATING: 8.25
This game is amazing. The auctions are fun, and planning your connections to minimize cost involves some definite thought. Really this game all boils down to financial efficiency, and I think it makes for a fascinating game. There is also a lot of player interaction as you fight over plants at auction, drive up the price of resources, and fight for space on the board. The only negatives I have about this game are that the last couple turns can really bog down, people prone to AP can really make this game a chore, and there are certain types of people that can make the game pretty unbearable (those who calculate costs and forget one minute later). Having said all that, this is definitely one of my absolute favorite games.

Az erőmű licitet sokkal agresszívebbnek hittem, így abban csalódnom kellett, mert hiába veszünk meg valamit nagyon drágán, az ellenfélnek úgy is jut jól használható erőmű (van hogy harmad/negyed annyiért), ergo nem érdemes nagy licitharcokba bonyolódni. A piac mechanizmusa jól működik, és az építkezés is érdekes tud lenni, főleg, ha 3 főnél többen játszuk. Egyenlőre nem kedvenc, de nagyon jó játéknak tartom, annak ellenére, hogy a mai modernebb játékokkal összevetve picit rosszul öregedett.

RATING: 7
Great game.  Intense, lots of things to keep track of and unpredictable.  It does feel a little patched together and fiddly so print out some player aids from BGG before tackling it for the first time.

My rating has dropped a little.  The rules are badly written and formatted so getting back into the game after not playing for a while is tedious.  Also, the game is advertised as being suited to two players but after a couple of plays with two I disagree entirely.

For me Age of Steam has replaced Powergrid.  AoS is a tighter and more exciting game in my opinion.

Update: Rating getting completely hammered by AoS.. Unless the new expansion radically changes Powergrid I'm unlikely to want to play again.

RATING: 9
I give first place to this game. It is important to have a good game *host*. Real *alive* money in this game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The more you dive into this game, the more there seems to explore. Everything --- from player order, what plants others own, where people are located, the phase, seating order, etc --- impacts the valuation and creates something that feels different/fresh every time you play. And it's a game where the strongest player isn't always evident as players often try to position themselves behind others, to gain advantages, in order to force the end and project themselves to the front; not only does this create a lot of tension throughout the game, it truly is a challenge to orchestrate and pull off. Overall, a truly enjoyable gem. 

The biggest concern about this game is that it can be arithmetically-heavy if players decide to math-out each turn. Personally, I don't mind playing competitively if everyone is on the same page. But it can really tank/slow-down the game and sour the experience for more casual gamers looking for a more fluid experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's a well designed game and I love any game with a geographical component, yet It's a bit too mathy for my tastes.

RATING: 7.5
An elegant design, but with some end game issues.

Amusingly, in my third game (first for a long while so I needed to relearn) against five 'experts', I found I was underpowered but, in pole position, and consequently unable to get better generators.  However I did have just enough cash to buy a 14th US city, 3 more than the next person, to end the game 'early' and to a chorus of 'you do realise that will end the game don't you!' and 'Kingmaker'.  Yes, but if I'm going to lose I would rather do so quickly and, to be fair, I haven't bothered to work out which king I was making.

Lack of resources arising from turn order can also hinder powering up in the final turn and a loss in an otherwise winning position.

RATING: 9
Ennek a játéknak a dobogón van helye! Nagyon letisztult a mechanizmusa, és bár önmagukban a szabályok nem túl komplexek, mégis elég komoly dilmmák elé állítanak végig a játék alatt. Nagyon lassan fut fel a jövedelmünk, szinte mértani pontossággal együtt mozog az egyre drágább erőművek és nyersanyagok árával. Így végig azt érezhetjük, hogy nagyon ki van centizve minden egyes vásárlásunk, a végén pedig nüanszok döntenek. Az már csak a ráadás, hogy a városok bekötése önmagában felér egy operációkutatási feladattal. Mohó játékosoknak gond lehet, hogy nem elég önmagában a legnagyobb kapacitással rendelkeznünk, üzemeltetni is tudnunk kell a döntő pillanatban. 
A szerencse szerepe nem nagy (az új licitálandó elemeknél jelenik meg), a licitek és a térkép miatt elég interaktív a játék. Maga a hangulata nagyon bejön. Bármikor szívesen játszanék vele!
---
Helyesbítek: a szerencse szerepe igenis nagy tud lenni a licitnél, az új lapka felhúzásánál.
---
15 parti után még mindig egyre jobban és jobban tetszik ez a játék, az utóbbi időben szinte minden parti nagyon drámai véget ért! Az egyik legizgalmasabb Eurogém!! Zseniális!

Solo variant is free of late game destructive luck.

RATING: 8
Update: 27 Oct 2007
This game is starting to grow on me quite a bit.  For the amount of depth there is in the game, it is pretty simple.  What used to bother me a lot was the jockying for position.  It feels weird that it is more profitable to hold your company back than growing and expanding.  I can forgive Power Grid of this since, it is the only game I have that does this.  I really like the fact that there is no seat position binding.  The game is a bit fiddly but I think they are worth it.  Giving this one more point to 8.

-an additional "Step 3" card (as replacement)

Excellent Soloplay variant available.

RATING: 9
Appreciate: the tight balance throughout the entire game (and the turn order mechanics that maintains it); the resource market mechanics that nicely simulates a real supply-demand market; winning is based on the ability to "get it right" in the last round, sometimes leading to unexpected winners; the strategic option of blocking others from getting resources (not so nice when it backfires, thoughs).

Don't appreciate: most decisions are based on exact calculation, leading to a lot of annoying adding all the time.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I enjoy the element of timing in this game, even if it is a little "gamey". It is always a challenge to precisely pick the right time to rapidly expand and yield turn order. Expand too soon, and the loss of priority during building and resource purchasing chokes you. Expand too late, and you don't have enough income to compete during the end game.

Depending on the group you are playing with, the timing of the game can vary significantly. Some groups slowly and evenly play through Phases I, II, and III. Other groups spend several rounds jockeying for position in Phase I before exploding through Phase II and going straight to game end.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Beautiful game with plenty of expansion maps.  Unlike Age of Steam, the rules for each map are only slightly tweaked (with the exception of Korea and China.)  Although I mostly enjoy the original Power Plant Deck, I dislike how the randomness of the power plants can sometimes make or break the game.  Standard Power Grid can get really boring if the end game power plants do not show up until Step 3!  Perhaps the biggest downside to Power Grid is the effort it takes to play the game correctly during each and every step of the game.  More than once have we had to refer back to the rules and/or player aids.  Power Grid is at its best when an experienced player takes care of the Power Plant maintenance.   

[b]USA[/b] 
11 plays!

[b]GERMANY[/b] 
5 plays!


[b]Deck 2 Power Plants[/b]
6 plays!

The new expansion Deck of Power Plants is more efficient than the original.  I prefer using this expansion for the game is now less likely to break or slow down to a grinding halt. 

[b]EXPANSIONS[/b]
France, 4 plays!
Italy, 3 plays!
C. Europe, 2 plays!
Benelux, 6 plays!
Korea, 2 plays!
China, 5 plays!
Brazil, 1 play!
Spain & Portugal, 1 play!
Russia, 1 play!
Baden Wuert, 1 play!
NOrthern Europe, 1 play!

China is my favorite map.  I love that the beginning plants appear in the same order for each and every game.  I also like that there is 1 less plant than the number of players up for auction.  Bidding is more intense!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Since playing this face to face my respect for Power Grid has risen significantly.  There is a lot going on in this game and a great deal to pay attention to as the game progresses.  It is one of those games where you don't want to lead throughout the game, rather sit back in the weeds lurking until it is the right time to strike.  Of course, when everyone else is doing it as well, it makes for some very interesting decisions.

The game is played through three stages and each round has several different goals to complete.  Each round starts with the auctioning of Power Plants, buy resources, connect cities and finally fire plants to earn the cash.  The balance between power and cities, cash and spending, and resources and the renewal of them creates havoc throughtout.

While at first, the decisions and "fiddliness" of this game may overwhelm some at first, but push through the initial stress to find a wonderful game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The combination of auctions, futures market with resources, and strategic play make this a strong favorite. There is plenty math calculations, which means play with a timer!  The theme is interesting and appropiate for the mechanics. I like the classic box art and the board art is adequate. The various maps available are nice, just wish they had a Latin America map.

RATING: 10
I've been wary about rating this as I was worried that I'm enthralled by the new. The lustre hasn't worn off after 6/7 plays. Reasonably heavy yet easy to teach to intelligent non-gamers, this is just awesome fun.

Update: As much as it keeps the excitement and variation there, the luck of the power plant draw is just too high to make this a perfect 10.

Re-update: Sod it, it's going up to 10. This game just feels perfect in so many ways: the luck factor is spot on, there's just the right level of variation between the maps and expansions (reasonably priced and double sided - more games should copy this), it doesnt always play out identically and it never seems to drag.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun game, but lots of little fiddly rules to remember (which can irritate people when you honestly forget them, like I often do), but it's a really good time.  It seems like it can get pretty vicious, depending upon how nasty the players play.  It seems to me that it would get exponentially more cruel with each player you add to the game.  I'm very much looking forward to my next playing of this.

***UPDATE*** 
Just played first game with 5 people.  The board really fills up quick, but it also seems that the steps progress quicker, too, so it's not like people get completely bitchslapped by getting trapped by other players.

The end of the game still seems kind of unsatisfying.  Games seem to end "not with a bang, but a whimper."  We think that by making the money closed information, that this will help make the games more exciting.  If nobody knows how much money people have, someone is less likely to storm through and go crazy by building cities right at the end to prematurely end the game.

****UPDATE*****
After playing this game with hidden money, I'll never play any other way.  Makes the end-game vastly more exciting and fun.  This game is a lot of fun: requires constant involvement by all players, which is great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Recommendation 2005[/SIZE][/COLOR]

[i]Posted: 9/26/05, Rated: 9[/i]
{2P: ?, 3P: ?, 4P: 9, 5P: ?, 6P: ?}

I tried several times to read through the rules, but just couldn't make heads or tails out of them.  Deciding to forge ahead, I got a couple of games in with some friends of mine, and experienced that "aha!" moment as the rules fell into place.

I sat in wonder as I watched the commodity markets rise and fall.  I struggled to find the "perfect bid" to either buy a power plant, or to make its cost of acquisition dear enough to an opponent to preclude him from trumping my bid and also being able to connect to another city.  Hoarding resources in an unused power plant just to suck money away from my competition by forcing them to buy at a higher cost.  Using city placement as a weapon for map control.

[i]Power Grid[/i] is a lot of fun to play.  I'll dock it one point for the constant need to recalculate connection and resource costs that really bogs down the auction phase.  I am eagerly awaiting my next opportunity to play!


[i]Refreshed: 5/19/15, Rated: 9[/i]

Perhaps I should have waited the full ten years before revisiting this score, but I recently played [thing=155873]the deluxe version[/thing] and wanted to update my comments here while the memory is fresh.

The formula still works after all this time.  I think the greatest testament to the game is that the theme just works: when I look at the board after completing a game, a critical eye wonders if this is some sort of area control game like [i][thing=491][/thing][/i]/[i][thing=18100][/thing][/i] (it isn't), or else a "chain game" like [i][thing=475][/thing][/i] (it isn't that, either).  The theme is so well integrated that I can't deconstruct it into various mechanics: I feel like I just managed a power company and enjoyed every minute of it.

Calculating acceptable auction prices gets easier with practice.  I still agree with a rating of "9," although my reason for withholding that final point has changed.  The interaction between the power plant market and the "steps" in the game is fiddly.  When the game is cruising it is seamless, but then there's this jarring aspect of trying to remember what to do when advancing to the next step.  It is easy to forget things, and I don't like game results with asterisks due to misplayed rules.


[url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=35]BGWS Review[/url]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
It took a long time for me to finally play this modern day classic. It lived up to the hype. I enjoy the auctions and the way the energy market works and fluctuates. I always enjoy games where you build a route/network. The game works best with three plus. The fact that there are so many maps means the re-playability is endless. The graphic design isn't anything fancy and some of the maps could be a little clearer, but I think it is appropriate. There is quite a bit of strategy involved as to when you want to be in first place versus last place as it effects your turn order for certain actions. Also, it can be quite cutthroat if you so desire. My only disappointment with the game personally is that it doesn't play well at 2 players. Robot expansion doesn't help with this enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very tight economic game. The theme is interesting and the graphics and bits are good. Would probably have rated it higher if you didn't need a math degree to win. I feel my math degree makes it easier for me to determine the correct amount to bid on a given plant while leaving enough for resource purchase advantage.

I'm lucky my wife enjoys the theme although she hasn't won yet (due to my calculating the numbers better).

If it weren't for this one issue, I would probably have rated it a 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(2-6 Players, 120 min, CLASSIC) The bestselling game about running an energy company. The rules are simple: invest in emerging power plant technologies at auction (both fossil fuels and renewable alternatives), buy fuel resources on the open market, then pay for infrastructure to extend your coverage to as many cities as possible, earning more revenues with each connection. The key is doing so better than your competitors. Contains dozens of country maps and optional variations.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Power Grid is in some ways a great game, yet in other ways plagued by (what I view as) design problems. As an economist, I will start by saying that the resource market is great. The price mechanism integrating supply and demand is wonderful (even if abstracted a bit, as it must be), and the implementation works quite well, especially when combined with the ability to purchase and store excess resources to drive up the price or monopolize a specific resource to keep prices low. This is without a doubt my favorite part of the game. However, many aspects of the game feel a bit contrived: turn order [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_game_difficulty_balancing#Approaches]rubber-banding[/url], the different 'steps', continual upkeep and management, etc. As a result, the game feels like a bit of a chore to play at times. The very mechanical/mathematical nature of the game does not help it feel very [i]natural[/i] (see [gameid=171], [gameid=42], etc.), and the turn order mechanism (upon which so much depends) introduces a strange 'competition for last place' that I'm not fond of (even though I recognize that it is indeed a strongly competitive element, which I appreciate). The end of the game almost always feels anti-climactic and obvious (if one player has obtained enough of a lead), or seems to depend heavily on the final power plant auction (which often makes or breaks a player's game). Power Grid offers some interesting strategic play, but ultimately I find the experience to be more oppressive (due mathematical nature of the game) and somewhat artificial (due to the rubber-banding, which shifts the focus from 'normal' competition to jockeying for worse positions) than enjoyable. (2009-03; revised 2014-02)

RATING: 8

RATING: 8
first time played at Game days with Great new friends of mine, I will say they make ANY game a full point better, but I have not added it in this score as I want it to reflect those who do not have access to my friends to play! Anyway, this one is a rare treasure, multiple layers of strategy, and fun all rolled into one, buy, provide, profit and then repeat, all the while your rival power companies do the same thing. 

The beautiful maps are interesting BEFORE you play and even more so after, that there are layers and layers of rules that can and are added via expansion that add to the overall game without being cumbersome. The layers of what to do when add up quickly, and the astute player IS in fact planning several moves for each move, in their down time. The mechanics this one teaches about supply and demand also is a marvelous teaching tool and will call me to bring young ones to this decidedly heady table, if they get it, then they are going learn a lot and enjoy themselves immensely.

If you were avoiding this one, like I have been (I knew I would fall in love with it, and have to have them all..) STOP it and go play now. Then buy a copy, and the expansions...and just get it out of the way!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Power Grid was one of the first games I became interested in, even before discovering BGG, and now that I have it, I have to say it's an extremely nice game.

The rules are quite simple, but there are many decisions, and not really any obvious one, so you have to think your way through the game, struggle to find not only the best option for the next move that also improves your overall position in the game, which is something I enjoy a lot.

It has quite a lot of tension and is extremely interactive. It is a bit dry with 3 players (I have yet to try The Robots), but 4+ people is great, everything fits together and makes a fantastic game that flows smoothly.

The gameboard has some nice Steampunk-like feel to it. Some people may argue that the art is not great, but I like it :P

It feels incredibly replayable, and the extra maps will probably make it a game I won't tire of for years.

Great 4-5 player game. 6 players are good, but 2-3 player games are far from good (The Robots improve this a bit but don't expect miracles)

My box holds:
-Base Game
-The New Plants
-The Robots
-150 Poker Chips (40x1$ - 35x5$ - 35x10$ - 40x25$)

RATING: 7
Fun economic game about running a power company. There is a luck element in the power plants tile that can be auctioned. Apart this is all about money management and decisions. A middleweight that needs a little math to optimize replenishment/line expansion option. One of the few germans to be played with 6 players.
My main critic is that it seems there is just one strategy. The game is about tactic: how to well implement that way to win

RATING: 6
Well, it finally happened. 5 years on my unplayed list and now out of my collection. Whoa, hold on, put down the torches and pitchforks. There is a lot to like in this game. I find the balancing act of managing your finances to be quite interesting. It takes some serious planning, and advance planning games are some of my favorites. There's a ton to think about in this game, and I imagine it will play out differently each time. The downfall for me is just that the game wasn't particularly exciting. If the game was a little shorter it might have kept me enthralled throughout, or maybe if it had a more engaging theme. I also suspect that the game could be a bit too punishing if a player makes a bad move early (it basically tells you this in the rules.) So I'd definitely be on board playing again if someone were to ask, but it won't work for my family so there's no need to store it on my shelf.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I found a couple of mechanisms in the game interesting:
- You have to be very sensitive to how the market is going.
- You must be follow how others are doing and what strategy they are using, this is not one of those games where you can just use a strategy you like through the whole game but adjust it according to other players moves constantly. 

I found a couple of mechanisms especially fun:
- The bidding for power plants and randomness of what cards you could bid for. 
- The turn system. I had been warned that I should try not to be in the lead but last or middle for the most part of the game, and this feels like a more important aspect than I first imagined. 

So this game is fun, does remind me a tinsy tiny bit of Ticket to ride, it's just more advanced. And because of the fluctuation of the market and turn order it felt like we were all on a trampoline trying to catch desired objects in mid air. If you are calculating enough and find the rhythm of the game you start to bounce at the right force so you'll get important stuff before others. You can't just go full force with all you got but hold your horses until the time is right and then hammer in that victory! Huzzah for Power grid!

P.s. the reason for the 6 score is the long gameplay and a bit of a clunky feeling when playing, experienced players needed to hold onto the rule book like dear life. Maybe after a couple of plays it will go more smoothly and then I'll adjust the score accordingly.

RATING: 4
If I've got 200 dollars and my ability to win hinges on determining how much I should pay for a power plant TO THE DOLLAR, that's way too much granularity.  Add to that the annoying and unintuitive "step" rules and victory conditions, and the end result is a game chock full of number crunching and not much else.   There's no GAME in this game -- it's like doing math homework for two hours.  The mechanics are neat and all, but somebody forgot to put the FUN in here. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Balance!

Our team loves Power Grid! Map may look complicated on first blush but becomes second nature after a few plays.

Lots of suspense in play due to the auction system for power plants. What we love most about this game is how difficult it is for any single player to gain a dominant advantage.

Most games are so well balanced, that no clear winner can be forecast until the final round is played out, the sign of excellent design!

We highly recommend for both hardcore and casual gamers alike!

RATING: 9
Well balanced and clever (economic simulation) game.
It is entertaining and educational at the same time. 

Buy power plants and the respective resources to power it, in order to maintain energy in the cities you have a "station".
It is all about managing your income, resources and of course your power plants.

I like the balance factor a lot, which makes it thrilling until the end. 

I would recommend this game to any (economic) strategy gamer

RATING: 10
My favorite auction/bdding game. If one of your opponents is "Good Will Hunting" then you won't stand a chance.  Power Grid is an amazing game for an Economics graduate.  The law of diminishing returns is for ever at the fore front of any strategy.  Amazinging game.  I do not share the negative comment that this game is dry.  Those that think this game is dry are unimaginative and basically need strap-ons props to be able to perform at anything.  Power Grid is exciting, challenging, and requires careful planning.  

Player Aid: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/fileinfo.php?fileid=13186

Condenses everything you're likely to forget onto play summary cards. (two cards per page; four cards for each player configuration, plus a small general rules card) Simply read the card for your number of players and the current Step of the game, and you'll never again forget to remove a plant, or how many coal to restock - and you'll never misinform and frustrate new players.  I never play without this.

Player Aid: http://boardgamegeek.com/fileinfo/15138

Player Aids: 
http://boardgamegeek.com/file/info/28255
http://boardgamegeek.com/file/info/26827  There is a reason with this game has nine pages of player aids, FAQs, and summaries. Several player aids here one the geek are very useful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is ABSOLUTELY awesome. I will always enjoy playing. The versatility of the continuous change in prices of the materials is remarkable.
The auction system of power plants adds a tabletalk element to the game as well, which is always healthy in games. There is an awesome strategy about the turn order, which changes each turn. This determines who gets to buy the resources first, the cheapest ones, and the last of the resources, which is usually very expensive, etc.

If you are just a beginner to board games, wait a while before purchasing as the rules are a little complex, but not bad so you have to check the book every round. For people who have read this game to be mathy, it really just is basic maths of adding simple numbers together. If you can add 7+10 you will be fine.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pro's:

1) The slow ramp up as your energy company grows, becomes richer and powers more homes feels very satisfying.
2) The game is surprisingly accessible despite it being relatively heavy. Even though it is quite maths heavy, all the elements flow very well together and everything makes sense.
3) The commodities market and how it interacts with your strategy. 
4) Naming your energy companies and making fun of your opponent for causing brown outs is worth the price of the game alone.
5) New players will often analyse why they did or did not win in depth. Coming up with alternatives of how to prevent this issue in the future.

Con's:

1) Paper money. First time I have ever felt the need to upgrade a game's components.
2) The tightness of the maths can be punishing. Minor miscalculation can be the difference between winning and losing though this is arguably also a strength of the game.
3) Some of the smaller rules are not made obvious enough to the point where you will entirely forget them.
4) Despite it being far from the heaviest game I own, it is one that I want the longest break from between plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love almost everything about this game -- so much so that it's easier to list the things I don't like than the things I do.

Most importantly, the pacing feels off to me: the end always comes in a rush of building 6-8 cities all at once, which is completely at odds with the way the rest of the game proceeds.

Secondarily, there is the, "Oops, I got the only 5-capacity plant that's going to come up in the first half of the game at cost because I happened to be auctioning last on that one particular turn" phenomenon.  Admittedly it doesn't happen often, but when it does, the game ends on the spot.

Would be a 10 if these were fixed.  Probably the game mechanics don't allow the second issue to be fixed, but it's possible that increasing the penalty for being 2nd/3rd in a city and/or decreasing further the marginal utility of powering an additional city in the payoff chart could fix the pacing for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
A great, nicely balanced euro with ample opportunities for interaction and screwage. Timing is everything. You really need to make that sprint for the line at the optimum point because, after a steady start, the end always comes earlier than you think.

My only slight criticism is that it always seems a little fiddly. The upkeep of the resources, counting the cash, handling the houses, the little rules that change in the different steps (and you always seem to forget one). A minor criticism of a great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I like the way the game plays out.  The sum is quite long for me to want to play often, but I like each of the individual parts of it.

Except the auction, that just kills me. There are so many variables to think about with your bid: keeping enough money to expand or buy resources; how valuable/plentiful the matching resources will be; how the plant's number will affect turn order; whether you can win with this plant or whether you will need to replace it again later; and consider all of these same variables for the person you're bidding against, too.

Plus you have to be aware of the different Steps and their significance, why you might want to expand and when. This is far from intuitive. If I'm building up normally, and at some point the game says, "OK, you're now into the next Step" and it's a surprise to all, that'd work for me. But when people know it's coming, and it's a HUGE deal when it happens, experienced gamers change their behaviour and [i]play against theme[/i] and do things that don't make sense thematically, like doing their damnedest to be last so they get first pick of the new building sites I guess. Wanting to be last at one point and first at another completely arbitrary point makes absolutely no sense thematically and makes it too "gamey" -- i.e. a collection of weird rules that lose all connection with theme and so cannot be easily intuited. (A shame, because the theming is otherwise so strong here.)

You could ignore all that stuff and wing it (and I do), but it means experienced players will pummel you. Knowing the rules aren't enough -- winning strategies depend on the subtle understanding of the game's many tiny rough edges and rule oddities and their unintuitive significance.

So, I don't know. It's very close to being a very good game for me, but it would need all those rough edges cleaned up and be a more elegant game. And then it wouldn't be Power Grid any more, so I don't know that anyone else would like it. First Sparks was good, and look forward to seeing more in that direction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game taught me what boring is all over again
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
2011: After one play, I understand the hype. Clearly-defined start, middle and endgame, scaling resources, good market mechanic. Despite the inclusion of an auction mechanic (which I usually hate), I still like this game!

2017: Played again with new people, definitely enjoyed it again. It's never going to be my go-to, but it definitely falls in the "will happly agree to it if someone else suggests it in the interests of getting to play what I want to play later, with the added bonus of actually enjoyign it" camp.

RATING: 8
I recognize that Power Grid is an incredibly well designed game, with each aspect (the futures market for power plants, the changing supplies of the fuel bank, the asymmetrical maps) adding to the tension and the challenge. RATING: 10
Wonderful simulation of supply/demand mechanics in a changing environment. At the heart of the game is the auction for power plants and this is where the game really shines: you can glimpse what the future has on offer but you can never really be certain that the next plant on offer will be the one you want.

As one part of the fuel market becomes crowded, players are rewarded if they diversify, but will the reward balance the investment in different technology? Add to this the first mover advantage on infrastructure and you have a game that will force you to consider a complex array of costs and benefits but without particularly complex rules.

On a sidenote, the rulebook is very poorly put together which makes learning the rules an effort in spite of their simplicity. It should also be added that a lot of people find this game rather dry.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2-6 players

The directions need to get more to the point, it took us so long to read a terrible translation that by the time we started playing, we weren't interested, but we played on and ended up enjoying it.

RATING: 7
If the end game didn't almost require a calculator, this would be a 9 or 10.  The complexity of the last turn or two means that accurate planning is nearly impossible, which is sort of a good thing.  Mostly I just get a headache.  My impression may be colored somewhat by the fact that I've never pulled off a win.

The complaint that the game is 'clunky' or is just a mishmash of mechanics is somewhat accurate - there is no real justification for the game phases or the "Phase 3" card other than as an arbitrary way to move the game along.  That said, it still works, and the game IS fun.  My only wish would be to figure out a way to remove the power plant auction - somehow, the auction in this game just doesn't do it for me.  Maybe I'm getting tired of auctions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Power grid is a game entirely filled with strategic thinking, planning, and very little luck. It's a very fun game if you're looking for a game of cold calculations. 

There's only one area of the game where chance is involved at all but it's used very well. Power grid also has a great mechanic to balance the players that are doing well so it's almost impossible to take an early lead and run away with the game. You can maintain a lead the whole game and win, it's just hard. 

2 hours, possibly more depending on number of people and how fast people can go. Don't play with indecisive people. 

Expansions add in new maps or new sets of power plants

Video tutorial: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xjA6pawLGxg
Tutorial covers gameplay well but not all details

This is not a simple game to learn.  Newbies will find themselves struggling to win their first few games if they make the wrong choices.  This is definitely a game which should be played in stages so as not to frustrate new players.

RATING: 8

It's a little longer than some Euros, but it's so enjoyable you hardly notice. Usually, games that are too "well-balanced" really annoy me (*cough* Caylus) because they frustrate the crap out of me. Not so with Power Grid. Over time, rating dropped from 9 to 8 as it's not made it to the table as often I think this is due to length of play & setup time (and rules explanations). Still enjoy it, though.
