=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Power Grid Base Game
Objective
To build largest network of Power Grid in the country and be able to supply power to the cities
In the game, players will bid to acquire Power Plant
Then they will build their network (represented by the 3 spots on the cities)
Purchase raw materials to power up your power plant.
Coal, Oil, Garbage and Uranium.
You will need the required amount of resource to power up your power plant and the number next to the house represent how many cities you can power.
Hybrid plant
Green power plant (does not require to use resource)
Finally you gain money in the form of Elektro based on how many cities you have powered

THINGS I FORGOT:
In the first round, player order will be re-determined based on the number of power plant.
Remove ONCE the lowest number power plant when Step 2 is triggered.
In Bureaucracy phase during Step 3, remove the lowest number power plant.
At the beginning, player do not need to choose starting city


Throughout the game each player will have a maximum of three power plant.
When you first build your grid network, you place your house on the $10 spot and pay the amount. Then the next player who want to come into the city will have to place on $15 spot and the third on the $20.  However, can only place on $15 during Step 2 and $20 during Step 3 which I explained later.  If you wish to expand you need to pay additional based on the channel cost.

When you acquire resource, you will always buy from the left side.  The more resources are taken, the more expensive it gets for the later player to purchase.  You can buy more than what you need to power up and keep the additional resource based on the number indicated on the power plant.  Show examples.  So this means you can buy more, hoard the resource, and make it expensive for other players to buy.

Lets go through the different phases of play.  Refer to your player aid.
Set Up

Player Order
In the game, player order meaning who goes first, second and so on will be determine by how many cities you have established your power grid..
If tie, look at who has the power plant with the highest number.  Show example.
So each time you build a grid on a city, move your house on this track

Auction

First player will choose 1 power plant to bid and go clockwise.  You must always make a bid that you can pay.  No loan.  There are two markets - the ready market and the future market.
Once a player win the bid.  He takes the plant and cannot enter the bid again.
If the player who choose the power plant did not get the power plant, he can choose another power plant from the ready market to bid again.
You can buy a power plant with capacity higher than the number of cities you have grid on.
Rearrange the power plant.


If in the later round, no one bid for any power plant.  The lowest number will be discarded and a new one will be drawn.

Resource
In REVERSE ORDER player will buy the resources.

Building
In REVERSE ORDER, player will build their grids

ADDITIONAL RULE
Whenever there is a power plant with the number equal to or less than the number of city player has, the power plant will be removed from the game.  Don't want that power plant to clog up the market.
You cannot have more than 1 house in the same city.

Bureaucracy (Earn Income)
Player determined how many cities they want to power up and spend the number of required resources to do so.
Look at the table to determine who much you have earned.
Refilled/replenished/resupply - look at the table.
Update power plant, place the highest number of power into the bottom of the stack and draw a new one.

STEP 1
STEP 2 - trigger when a player build his 7th city. There can be more than one player to do so.  So in the next round ONLY, player can build the grid on the city on $15.
STEP 3 - step 3 card is revealed.  Remove Step 3 card and the lowest number power plant from the game.  Do not draw replacement.  Shuffle draw stack with the remaining power plant.  Step 3, 6 power plants will be made available in the ready (actual) market.  There will be no future market.

When the game ends, look at the table.
In the game, you do not win based on how many power grid you build on cities, you win based on how many cities you can power up.
But ff tie, players with the most money wins.

RATING: 9
Excellent game based on three plays, one 5 player, two 6 player. Can be long with 6 inexperienced players. 

Upside is the thematic flow of the game makes it easy to understand after a turn or two. Also there's a great sense of reward getting paid at the end of your turn which keeps you going throughout.

Downside is a great deal of fiddly bookkeeping especially regarding the power plant available for auction and, as above, can be a little long. Mostly due to people try to figure out all the math involved in their moves.

Overall a great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very dry and caclulate-heavy. The bidding mechanism is what drives this game and adds the fun, because without that, it would be an absolute drag. But don't forget the timing. It's so important to get the player order right. I like that it's a race instead of a VP match.

You really can get screwed sometimes  because: 
1) A decent power plant doesn't come along in time.
2) You feel pressed to take a sub-optimal power plant and your closest opponent topdecks the perfect one for him/herself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
This game has the reputation of being hard to learn. My experience contradicts this. The flow is easy to follow and the theme really helps. I do play this game with poker chips making the money less fiddly (but more traceable).

In my opinion this game really deserves it high user rating. The market simulation is really brilliant and the constant search for optimum power plants to fit the urge to expand makes the game really exciting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
5 plays: 

I really enjoy playing this game. But other people I play games with don't love it like I do. The resource supply feels very fiddly to me -- I hate looking up numbers in a chart, which feels clunky and inelegant, and takes focus from the gameplay. 

There is definite analysis paralysis in the endgame. 

The player order thing feels so randomly imposed. 

Love the auction mechanic, including ability to inflate the price of a plant and dump it on someone else. Don't love the map stuff -- it feels so arbitrary where you begin, since you'd probably do better if you paralyzed yourself and did tons of analysis...

Still, somehow I do just *love* it. Switching strategies, cutting a player off -- there's a lot you can do here, and the mechanics are definitely not fiddly.

Although I think it's a huge weakness of the design that there are so many values you must look up based on the number of players.

RATING: 8
Great game where most of the strategy is deciding when to go full force and when to hold back.  Usually players feel like they are doing okay throughout the game, but the weaker strategic players get noticeably outclassed in the final two rounds.  Pressing your luck when passing on certain power plants or deciding whether to try clog other player's resources adds a lot of small intricacies in both strategy and tiny randomness.

RATING: 8.5
I may be a bit biased as I work in the utilities industry and one of the first applications I supported was also called Power Grid but this is a really great game.  The mechanics are interesting and basically simulates generation, transmission and distribution concepts.  The auction and the resource markets are a standout for the game.  The only drawback I see is near or at the end of the game where players usually collude and play king maker against the perceived leader.  This game is not good for people with analysis paralysis and will extend the game well beyond the estimated 2 hrs playtime.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Networking game (could have been a rail game), with a decent economic engine, that is driven by the auction for gradually emerging power plants (which supply power to your expanding network of cities). The number of "powered" cities will determine your income level which in turn determines your ability to compete in the auctions for new power plants and to purchase the fuel you need to power your generators. The person with the largest powered network when the game ending condition is met wins.

It all hangs together with the usual elegance of a well-designed Euro. You have to be a particular fan of auction type games to enjoy this fully. I don't mind them, but there are game genres I like better. The game is very much affected by the random way the power plants emerge combined with player order, but a lot of Euros have similar features and fans don't seem bothered by such things - my rating is more a recognition of the game's polished design than my love for it...
++++++
After a considerable hiatus we returned to the game to introduce a new player to it and I was again struck at the elegant design. The auction is an important element - in fact perhaps the key one and I prefer other devices. Still...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

Нравится, что она удовлетворяет потребности игроков разного типа - для стратегов - долговременное планирование, для любителей "живого человеческого общение" - аукцион заводов, для градостроителей - ставь себе домики, осваивай новые территории. А какие страсти кипят на последних ходах при покупке ресурсов! (особенно если минимум два игрока сидят к концу игры на угле). 
И да, отличное еврооформление (да, я люблю деревянные кубики и качественный картон).

RATING: 5
Just my sort of game - bit of bidding, bit of player interaction, lot of planning and a little bit of hidden information (power plants). Currently one of my favourites - interesting to see if it holds up to repeated plays - if it doesn't the rating will fall

** Update, well it has (down from 9 to 8), not played it for a while and I've stopped actively looking to play it. Why? Not sure, I think my enjoyment depends on the map and the powerplant deck - sometimes the game gets a 'stagnation' phase where no-one wants the powerplants, and that gives an advantage to the players with the best plants at that point. Sure the others need to do something, but why take the hit and buy a sub-optimal plant to help the others? Because of this rating has dropped a bit.

*** Update, Played it again after a long while - and definitely felt less 'wow' then when I first played. It's ok, but I now feel a bit frustrated by the 'hang just behind the leader until you want to sprint for the finish' feeling ... and the random element of the powerplants which really impacts the game. Seems to reward cautious play, rating reduced, now up for trade ...

RATING: 8.2
So ya wanna manage the power supply to Germany..(or some other country...whoa be to them...)
Fun game! This game is simply amazing as to how well balanced it is.  It seems to take about 80-90 minutes with a friendly competative feel to the game.  It can be very intense however with competition between players for more efficent power plants, placement of plants (based on cheaper connections), and lastly for resources.  

With the right people you can really have a heavy game on your hands penny pinching the nearest cent.  I like how you really have to watch spending down to the 2-3 dollar range.  The end of the game can be an utter shock when triggered and end up being just so very close between mulitple players.

The map of Germany seems a touch longer than others.

I've played a two person game one time and only one time and I believe that it is fine with two however it lacks some of the shoulder rubbing that can makes gaming seem more exciting.

Its sweet spot is 4 people I believe.

RATING: 9

I know it says 2 hours to play, but it honestly can't be that long. Time seems to fly when building power monopolies.

It is a little fiddly, but it doesn't bother me as much as it would in other games. It seems to fit the theme.

I typically don't like auction games, but it doesn't "feel" like an auction game. 

Probably the best designed game I've ever played.

RATING: 6
Played 2004 edition once with 6 players currently. Anm excellent mix of economic management, juggling income to build power plants, power lines (city connections) and buy fuel to power cities. Income which you can spend on those things is in turn, dependent upon how many cities you suply power to (which needs plants, lines and fuel).

Market prices are managed well in this game, and there are some good balances to avoid a runaway victor it seems (I remember blowing my first year budget on a nuclear ppower plant and finding I had no cash to do anything at all for another three or more turns to my dismay, but I caught up all the same once I got it connected for example!)

Still, this grame struck me as difficult to explain to beginners - a lot of fiddly interactions, and rather too long and drawn out, with a lot of down time while strategists crunch numbers to try and optimise their expenditure (needing to juggle this truns expenditure on connections, fuel and plants so that they stay in optimal harmony with no cash left at the end of the turn).

Given that, it didn't seem to me to provide the entertainment value I'd like out of those hours spent playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Power Grid is one of my few 10s, a game that is right for me in so many ways.  There is a roughly even split between long term strategic considerations (how to expand your network - which cities to build in when, and managing turn order), and short term tactical choices (the auction, and raw material purchases).  Everything matters - it is so very common to wind up a single dollar short from being able to build that last city you wanted to, each and every turn.  

The game demands that players carefully plan each turn, by projecting ahead building and raw material costs in order to not overbid on power plants.  This makes the auction a very dangerous dance as you try to make each opponent overpay for the plant they want without overspending yourself, or - worse - getting a plant you didn't want. 

The way the plants become available is sometimes criticized as too random.  I think it adds needed uncertainty.  Often, the auction forces me to choose between getting a good plant now, or waiting to see what becomes available next - a better plant might drop down, or a dud might turn up in the draw.  Yes, it's random.  If it were not, then the auction would get very boring, very quickly, since the decision of whether to wait would be calculable.  

Overall, this is a brilliant design.  It's a little fiddly, and a little long.  But what it does, it does extremely well.  Not recommended for those who find regular calculation burdensome.  Highly recommended for everyone else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
The last player to place down his first city is forced to either select his starting location for strategic balance between the other players, putting themselves at a significant disadvantage (which therefore few people will do), or place it as it is best for them, almost certainly leaving one other player with a huge advantage in the starting position.

Any game where you can usually tell who is going to win with an 80% chance after the initial setup isn't really an interactive experience, and hardly qualifies as a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent game for the competitive crowd. Constant attention to upgrading plant efficiency is required as new plants come up both in the present and future markets. At the same time, players must watch the changing resource market so as not to find themselves shorted in buying energy resources to power up their newly acquired power plants (as last chooses resources first). In addition to this, one must watch their opponents to make sure they don't get too far ahead with their network development, and that they themselves don't get blocked out of cheaper connections! The two hours goes by fast. The auction phase is improved somewhat with the expansion deck, with some new green plants and tweaks to other plant features.

Includes New Power Plant Cards and Benelux/Central Europe map.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Lo está petango en mi grupo habitual de jugadores. Un juego un tanto matemático, ya que el mayor peso del juego está en calcular cuanto dinero puedes gastar en "x" para que te quede suficiente para "y", para mi gusto con poco "alma" pero que te mantiene dentro la partida.

Partidas de unas 2 horas y buen resultado para 4-6 jugadores, funcionando también a 3 si no eres muy exigente.

RATING: 6
This is a very good game which strikes the right balance between predictability and randomness. There are multiple paths, enough player interaction without being too confrontational and (usually) no runaway leader syndrome. It can be a tad dull at times (waiting for a new stage, not wanting to be the leader, etc) and there can be quite a bit of analysis paralysis, especially towards the end, so that's why the rating is not as high as it could be.

Lowered rating since there were multiple occasions this could be picked and was skipped by vote of majority. Other games are more interesting, I suppose.

The end game can get very mathy.

The boards are dull and unattractive.

Update from July 2008 to May 2012: 7.5 -> 8.0

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
PLayed a few 4 player games on weekend for first time. Excellent all round balanced game, almost no noticeble problems. Has all the features of a good multiplayer game: Little or no luck, reasonable/high player interaction, high excitement, fast gameplay, easy to learn but difficult to master, room for great planning and analysis without paralysis, low bookkeeping and the auto balance mechanism where leader is handicapped by turn order sequence. Takes all the best things out the 1830 game and puts them into one slick condensed package. 

Edit: Showing its age a bit in relation to some of the newer Euro's. Game can bog down and bottleneck before key city expansion nodes. Playing time also slows towards end and some artifcial finishes can occur which spoils the experience.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A tense game based around a resource market and auctions for power plants. It's a nice combination of interaction and optimization.

But it's an unforgiving game and it involves a lot of basic arithmetic, which makes it feel more serious compared to other auction games. It sucks when you miscalculate in this game. 

I find it a bit strange that all the mirco-optimization that you do on the board matters so very little, except for turns where you are just short a few electrons to build another house or resource.

There is something strange about the rules (and the rulebook). For the most part, it's not a complex game, and the rules make sense. But there's many little exceptions and special situations (when to remove power plants from the market, the transitions and differences between the phases) that we always seem to forget about at least one of them. And that can really ruin a game, because these rules are needed to keep the game going smoothly. Overall it doesn't feel very elegant to me.

RATING: 8
Ah, good old powergrid.  What a fun game.   I suppose the part I'm not crazy about are the rules that encourage players to hold back and not lead. 

One other element that I'm not crazy about is that it effectively becomes a computation exercise at some point, given that there is little to no hidden information.   It truly is a game that rewards thinking long and deep about what you're doing, which isn't typically the type of game that interests me.

Still, the auctions are clever and the game is pretty fun, so it gets an 8.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
I just don't see what all the fuss is about. To me, most of the decisions in the game boil down to "six-of-one, half-dozen of another" type tactics dictated by contingencies. Yes, there are better or worse decisions to be made, but the space that separates good decisions from bad is very marginal, and usually dictated by player order and the market. To me, the game is just too scripted, with too few actual decisions, most of which are tactical rather than strategic. I feel like the game appears a lot deeper than it is - niggly math and pseudo brain-burn from trying to parse all the minimal advantages passing for depth. And it is loooong for what it is. Better than some of FF's other games, but certainly not one I'd put in the top 10, or even the top 100. I know I'm in the distinct minority on this one, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Very nice tactical game of connecting up cities to your grid while trying to get the best deal for power plants and the resources to power them.  I do enjoy the game and am impressed by how well all the different game elements fit together, but it has two aspects that I do not care for: 1) it is a long game (2-3 hours) and 2) it has mechanisms built into it to keep everyone fairly close right until the end of the game.  Many of the games I've played have ended in a tie and been decided by the tie-breaker (most money left over).  Not necessarily a bad thing, but not very satisfying.

RATING: 10
Love this game... love the building, love the consumption of raw materials, love to be forced to make decisions on quantity versus quality, love the raw material/commodities trader aspects, I even love the bidding in this game.  Instant favorite.  Can't wait for my next game.

UPDATE:  My opinion of this game has just grown more and more positive over the years.

UPDATE 2008:  I have raised the rating on this game again.  For whatever reason, I just keep finding ways to love this game a little more.  The only heavy euro I rate higher is la Citta, and la Citta is my favorite game.

UPDATE 2010:  After many years, it's clear this is a "10" to me because, win or lose, I never fail to have fun playing this game.  Hard to describe what it is about this game that keeps it fresh and exciting, but whatever that trait is, I wish more games had it.

RATING: 9
Buying Power Stations and selling electricity ... and someone has made a game about this, surely not? Yep, and what a corker it is! This is another game witha really good turn order mechanic, which always stops you shooting off building masses of city connections. And the auction of the power plants is really interesting.

My one negative is the slightly excessive maths/ book-keeping.

RATING: 8

Power Grid is catnip for the left brains in my life.

RATING: 5
I played "classic" Power Grid again recently - i.e., Power Grid with the plant deck it shipped with, and not the expansion deck which I use all the time these days - and was shocked at just how poor a game it felt like. The market was gummed up with worthless plants at various times arbitrarily screwing some players, and resource markets routinely faced exhaustion.

When playing classic Power Grid, you really have to factor these elements of game dysfunction into your play. You need to bid aggressively on good plants that show up early in Phase 2 knowing that the end of Phase 2 tends to screech to a halt with worthless plants. You need to manage your player order knowing that there is a high risk of running out of Coal or Oil, and you can lose because you were the best player on the last turn and other players bought up all the coal and oil to screw you. It's all completely unsatisfactory.

I am a fan of Power Grid with the deck mini-expansion. I would not play the basic Power Grid again.
---
Although definitely an improvement over Funkenschlag, Power Grid has fallen off a little bit with repeated play. The 6 player game turned out to be a bust, as the middle game (where all the good stuff is) seemed to be eliminated, and the game went right from early to endgame phases. Otherwise, I still like the game a fair amount, but things just seem ever so slightly out of whack - the midgame gets locked up a bit too frequently when no useful plants are available to anyone for too long. The endgame sometimes hinges more on what order the plants come out in than on player skill. And just hope you never get into the position of actually exhausting the available coal/oil resources, which can totally screw people completely arbitrarily. Now, these things don't come up a lot, which is why the rest of the good stuff in the game is still quite good. But Power Grid isn't *quite* there, and I wish it were. I think Funkenschlag had these same problems, we just were never able to play enough (due to the length) to really discover them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Lots of fun accumulating wealth and expanding your power empire! In Power Grid, players bid on power plants, buy raw materials to fuel those plants, build into, and then power those cities using their plants and raw materials.  Each power plant uses a certain type of raw materials and powers a certain number of cities, so the power plants and how much you spend on them are very important!

I really like the dynamic in this one where it often pays to lurk for a lot of the game, and then decide when to make your move for the win.  Once in a while someone manages to lead for the entire game, but it's few and far between.  A very challenging game when played with other experienced players!

A good mix of strategy and tactics in a great system.

However, after 20 plays, I do feel like the game is rather same-y from game to game, and my desire to play it has waned a lot. Still a great game design though!

RATING: 8
Update: 5/25/10.  
Played with: 2-5.
Length: 2 hours. 

Power Grid is our default "gateway" game (usually as a step up for friends who have played Catan elsewhere).  The components are nice enough, though nothing amazing.  The gameplay involves some sort of efficiency/race hybrid that I seem to be intuitively good at, but that lacks tension for me because I don't fully understand what I'm doing.  The auctions are fun, and provide interesting interaction, but unless everyone is particularly good at the game, they often result in largely random outcomes.  For now, it's a game that I will never turn down, but that I'm not going to suggest regularly.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Did not like PG during my first game. This is a train game in disguise. I was also very disappointed with the less-than elaborate commodity market mechanism, which is a contrived demand-supply system. I expected a more realistic system driven by true supply and demand.

Six months later, I decided to re-visit this game and bought it, along with the Frace/Italy board. It met my current games-to-buy-criteria. Played it again and enjoyed it tremendously.

RATING: 7
Un juego de dificultad media-alta el cual incorpora varias mecánicas en un sólo juego. Tiene mecánicas como subastas, manejo de recursos y control de territorio. 
Para la primera partida puede resultar un tanto abrumador por la cantidad de reglas pero las partidas subsecuentes se tornan mucho más fáciles ya que uno sabe de que va el juego. 
Este juego es de estrategia pero aún así una buena estrategia no lo es todo, puesto que en cada ronda el jugador que va a la cabeza tiene desventaja respecto a los otros. La parte de azar del juego está en como van apareciendo las plantas de energía y su vez esto hace en cada partida uno tenga que ir cambiando de estrategia al ver el estado del mercado y las ciudades a las que está yendo cada jugador.

RATING: 6.75
Shipped as part of Math Trade and received Giants in return

Shipping Cost: $17.36
Shipping Date: October 5, 2011
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Probably my favorite heavier strategy game. The interplay of systems in this game is fascinating and best of all, clear. Many heavier games just try to dump these complex overlapping systems onto players, forcing them to spend game after game figuring out the subtleties of how they all fit together. But here you understand how every phase affects the other pretty quickly, and the fun instead lies in good ol' fashioned optimization and mastery - but of course, there are random factors and other players that make true optimization evasive, which only serves to make the chase all the more compelling. It's all about simplicity of rules w/ depth of play, yo.

And that's not even mentioning how great the market system all on its own - there's no game that captures supply and demand so well.

Update: This is still one of my favorites, and I have a hard time agreeing to play other similar games when I could just play Power Grid again. Earned its 10 long ago.

Update: Lowering to a 9. Really, still one of my favorites but these days it DOES feel a little overlong. PG does a great job of keeping you engaged 'til the end, but I do think it goes on for about 30 minutes too long - because while the game's systems are super compelling it is largely a game of escalation; you're just getting bigger and bigger throughout the game whereas something like Keyflower is a little more dynamic so 2-2.5 hrs feels appropriate. Not a knock on the design of PG at all (everything I said above still applies) - just the length.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Decent game. I understand why people love it, and I will play it on occasion. 
However, I do have three minor problems with it that keep me from playing more often. One, the game is a little too mathy for me. Two, I find the game repetitive. I find myself doing roughly the same thing each game. Sure there are different Power Plants, but all they really do IMO is change the resources I need to buy. And three, I find that there is sometimes a runaway leader. During many of the games I played, one person got ahead and no one could catch up. We knew the winner a while before the game ended. 
To leave on a positive note, however, I do enjoy the rampy-ness of the game. The feeling of growing more powerful and being able to do more things was enjoyable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
[u]April 2008:[/u] Great game, a lot of maths but really enjoyable and good to teach newcomers. Pretty straightforward but then again not that much with the catch-up mechanics. All is about timing, I like that in a game.

[u]June 09:[/u] There is one thing I'm lame at and that's auction games. However, I like them pretty much. One problem usually with auction games is when 1 player in the game is a newb, he doesn't know the price of things and can severely unbalance a game. However, this is not something present in Power Grid and this is fortunate.
But one can't reduce PG to an auction game. There is also a big aspect of network building where competition for the cheap connections can become quite intense.
The resource track is also a brilliant idea. Basically, the more a resource is in demand, the higher the price will go. A simple touch that adds another layer of competition.
Ovrall, this is a very interactive and competitive game, and not just because of the auction as is often the case in these games. Here, the competition is everywhere. However, there is no sense of direct aggression or bashing or kingmaking. Although it can happen, it is not very flagrant.

I think the design of the game is almost flawless but I'm not that big a fan either (go figure) so I'm rating it a 7.5 which sounds quite about right for a game I feel is intelligent yet doesn't wake me up at noght. Maybe it's the theme, I don't know for sure.

[u]December 2010:[/u] Changed my rating system, the game is now rated 6.5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Math is good. However, too much math isn't, and this game can really bog down because of analysis paralysis as you're trying to calculate your moves. Many games have this element, but this one is probably the worst offender. Still, the gameplay is pleasant and it's definitely a game I enjoy despite the downtime which might occur and the need to calculate a lot if you want to win. It's not hard math of course, but there's just too much of it in the game in my opinion.

While I do enjoy it as it's a little different than most other eurogames (it's also a race and not a game in which you count your VPs in the end), it's not a game I would play very often and I honestly don't know how this game is ranked as number 6 on BGG (I understand most of the Top10/100 and overall tend to agree with most of them, but not this one).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Board play is reminiscent of Medieval Merchant. The auctions are the best bit. The rest is rather dull housekeeping and accountancy. Players who aren't strong at mental arithmetic and forward planning will generally not do well.

RATING: 7
This game sounds like a game I would take to and love.  Unfortunately, it does not live up to the hype.  The first half of the game plays beautifully with a very tight feel, but the end game is so lack-luster.  I was let down a little on my first play (3-player), but I'm starting to get it and I like it.  The game is much better with 5-6 people.  

The end-game really gets me in this one.  Its such a flurry of number crunching, game-slowing, city-grabbing. As soon as Step 3 hits, the game is almost over.  There is no time to 'ENJOY' step 3.  In fact, why even have a Step 2 in the game?  It hardly ever lasts more than 1/2 a turn. /sigh.  
--note: the 3 player game can be really tense and good at times - but there are games where the final turn is the same turn when step 3 (and 2) happen that leave me feeling very unsatisfied.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
9 rating after one play... and a two player game at that. I expect this game has a shot at a 10. Man, my brain enjoys this one!

Some observations... although it is a "heavier" game, it's not as hard as I thought. The only difficulty is in keeping the plant market maintained properly, subbing out the low or high plants according to various rules. But, the rest of the game flows very smoothly. As long as one person can maintain the plant market, everyone else can focus on the task at hand: plants, resources, and cities. 

Not as math-intense as its reputation, and certainly not the hardest game I own, but it is definitely a thinker. Really clever way to keep the fluctuating market for resources. Thinking and concentrating were never so fun!

Update after 5 plays -- dropped this to an "8". Don't get me wrong, I still like this game, but the sneaky sensation that the game is very scripted is starting to creep in. I dunno. With this most recent play, it was the first time that the ending of the game felt contrived or artificial. It feels like winning demands a manipulation of the game's eccentric flow instead of some sort of cohesive strategy. I'll be curious to see if this is the beginning of a change of opinion, or if I'm just "going through a phase" in my teenage Power Grid years.

Update: Dropped this to a "7." I'm glad I own it, and I appreciate its novel mechanics. But, as I play more games and discover alternatives, I'm struck by the fact that the endgame seems a bit lacking in drama, and it takes too long. I'll still play it, but I'll be suggesting other games first.

Update: Dropped to a 6 and traded away in a math trade. This just wasn't hitting the table. The wonky tricks with turn order and odd endgame kept me sour on this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really like the gameplay of Power Grid:  turn orders, phases of play, and so on.  It can be a real balancing act to get everything paid for and powered, which makes weighing priorities fun and challenging.  Some people call it "fiddly," but I don't see the fiddliness to be a detraction, but more of a positive feature.  The different maps (official and not) add a little variety, as does the removal of one playing area in each game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the gems of the designer board gaming world.

Power Grid is an economic area-control game about becoming an energy magnate.  You'll buy power plants, expand your electrical grid, manage various resources required to operate the plants, and collect earnings based on the number of cities to which you deliver power.

It's very heavy, with little direct player interaction.  It requires you to constantly calculate the costs of things you need compared to the benefits of procuring them.  I love this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
[UPDATE 1/16] This one doesn't get to the table much for me: as I said below, for everything PG does well, I have a game that does it just a little bit better. (Though I will give props to PG playing well for 5 or even 6 players, which Brass and Fleet don't do and Chicago Express doesn't do as well.) And many of my opportunities to play PG in my regular gaming group get bogged down in a sharks-v-minnows dynamic as the experienced players wipe the floor with the n00bs in a way that's less than 100% fun.

All that said, sitting down with a table of relative novices (namely, my wife, parents and father-in-law) with my having just enough experience to be able to keep the game moving but not enough that I instantly know how to take advantage of everyone's blunders: fun. A great deal of fun. Validating my opinion that PG is an [i]excellent[/i] game for a group of intelligent, patient people even if they're not Veteran Gamers.

---

:sugar: I enjoy Power Grid, and it has certain undeniably appealing aspects (gracefully handling a broad range of player counts, easy enough rule set, not incredibly fiddly) but PG feels a bit static and procedural, with a less dynamic economy than games like Brass (a more interesting build-a-network-and-manipulate-commodity-prices game) and Chicago Express (a more interesting auction game).

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
A fun game with a bit of luck but mainly proper planning involved. It is surprisingly fun to decide whether to expand your network or buy a good power plant to gain an advantage in later turns or to buy all the fuel you need to power all of your connections this turn. Of course, it is a lot of fun to bid on a plant you know one of your opponents wants badly but you could do without - only to get stuck with it in the end and waste the money you intended to use for fuel and expanding your network - while eventually realising buying that plant was the best thing you could have done and winning the game because of it. 

The fact that you seldom use the entire board can be a bit confusing, but it also means most of the time, you can get more variation from each board. Since the board is two-sided, you will get yet more variation! In this version, the Transformer Station is included as standard. Do not underestimate its importance in the game! You can leave it out, but it is so much fun that this would probably be a real pity.

Nothing is hidden in this game, except the stategy you come up with. The player who fares worst, gets to buy fuel and expand his/her network first. In theory, this would even the game out pretty well, but in reality, it is still possible for the leading player to stay on top throughout the game. However, it seems only fair that the game is not evened out so much that being the leading player is discouraged until the last turn.

This game is very amusing and does not contain difficult concepts, while it certainly can be taxing on your brains at times. There is sufficient interaction to prevent boredom during other players' turns yet you also have a degree of freedom to just do your thing and have a blast, regardless of what the others do. I like that, as to me this means I can enjoy a lost game more fully.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Based on one play. Rules not exactly clear and I think you need at least 4 to get a good game going.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It was love at first play. This is an outstanding game that I do not get to play enough. I think the mechanics are brilliant and it creates a wonderful amount of tension that continues to build as the game progresses. The last couple turns always take a very long time, but the payoff is always worth it, even if I'm not winning. I love the intricacies of all the phases and the jockeying for position on the turn track.

My ultimate gamer goal is to run a Power Grid World Tour League. Over the course of several months the same group of players would play a game on every map and award points based on what place they finish. The player with the most points would be the ultimate Power Grid Champion. I would definitely spring for a custom trophy of plaque for the winner. It would be quite the accomplishment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Coconut, Tony, Wesker

Because of this (or in spite of this, perhaps?) it's a lot of fun to play.

RATING: 10

This game also scales extremely well and still feels like the same game whether at 2 or 6 players.  And it is always a bonus when I can have any 6-player game without forced expansions.  

While this game seems to take some time to crank out, it doesn't seem like you spent so many hours playing it.  This game is deserving of it's high marks.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Got it a few weeks ago and have already played several times, at least once with every player count except six. I love the intensity of how simple the auction is and seeing someone bid on a plant to try to raise the price without actually wanting it and seeing them yell out in remorse whenever the others all pass. The resources portray a very basic supply and demand economic structure, but the design of it is gracefully simple. Building is one of the least interesting things in the game, but even that is incredibly entertaining as players clump up on the cheap part of the map but quickly realize they are now trapped there and forced to jump across the map paying astronomical connection fees. The game end is not always exciting, but I have had a couple games come down to the difference of a dollar as the player in last suddenly mounts a massive push and builds all the way up to where first place is at and snatches the game from under their nose. I don't mind the mathiness of the game one bit, as I actually happen to love doing math and go out of my way to try to figure out the most cost effective option for me and how high I should bid before it is no longer worth it. But just as fun is going with my gut till I run out of cash and watching other players make mistakes and just praying that I make it to the victory. I love this game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2.0 >> Interesting game of resource management and timing. The fluctuating market values for the various materials coupled with the semi-random assortment of plants available for sale seem to work well together. 

A warning to new players: initial placement is extremely critical in this game though, a poorly thought out starting location can have you paying a premium throughout the early game, which is a potential death knell in a game of exponential growth. 

I can see what others are talking about with the runaway leader issue to some degree, but am not overly bothered by it. In a game wherein luck plays a minor role, the person in the lead is there because they're doing a lot of things right, if they're running away with the game, it's likely because their strategy is working that much better than the those of the other players. I can understand the frustration because the learning curve on this game is fairly high, and for the first several games I played it felt like I had no grip on the way things meshed together, and like I had no hope of catching up; with an experienced group this is less of an issue though, scores stay tighter, and the person in 'last' is often manoeuvreing themself in for the late game kill. 

Speaking of the luck factor, I know what some will say, the plant auction can hand some very nice plants out to players who are late in the bidding, and while this does have something to do with luck, at that time, the fact of the matter is that the player who is sitting there getting the 25 at face value before the mid-game stall is there because they passed up on other, obviously lucrative options and decided to press their luck in a style very reminisent of Ra, and with similar dangers involved. I have no problem with the mechanism, and I think it works nicely in that a player who is a little back can have at least a chance at getting back into the thick of things if they can draw their way into a valuable plant on the cheap. In general, the random hand-outs of the plant market can be mitigated by knowing when to not auction things if you're earlier in the order. I will still grant the fact that players can be put into "damned if you do, damned if you don't" situations where they have to put something up for auction and pray that the last player in doesn't get a good draw, but by and large I think the "Plant Lottery" aspect of the game is brought up altogether too much, and I do not feel that it generally is enough to swing game results.

At all scales this game seems well-balanced though I prefer it at 4-5 as the resource market becomes more volatile but the downtime isn't quite as bad as it is with 6. The rating on this initially went from an 8 to a 9,  and then peaked at 9 in my ratings scheme and achieved a terminal 9 status. I think the reason that it initially became terminal is due to a mild niggling feeling that I have that the game just isn't quite as good as it could have been...I think this is mainly because of the generally lacklustre final turn or two, which ultimately create an unsatisfying finish for me whether I'm winning or losing. It's not that I don't feel that I've earned my loss or defeat, it's just anti-climatic. The journey there is always quite enjoyable, but the actual final stanza always feels flat, even when it comes down to the money, which it often does. It's undeniably a solid game, and a clear cut above most of the stuff out there, but is not worthy of being amongst my all time classics either.

(One play of Great Britain. A nice map, but I think some of the theme should be discarded in trade for gameplay. I dislike how the Natural Gas plants are ridiculously overpowered in comparison to the other plants in the game, which is a combination of the commonality of the material with their low starting prices. Bidding them up helps, but only so much. I did like the material crunch at the end and the power plant angst, but I don't know if those are typical, of if we just had a particularly tight game.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very good game. With great replayability, easy rules, big strategy depth
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is not losing its appeal.

It takes a while and always requires fresh minds. One game in an evening is plenty.

The post game analysis is always a feature.  You often have plenty of ideas about how you went wrong.  The temptation is always to launch into another game but I lack the stamina. 

2013:
Unlike Peurto Rico this game if anything is growing on me.  I think I have a firm grasp on how to play the game with efficiency and can still track my opponents options without much effort.

I have always played this game with a combination of intuition and maths.  I'm sure that this is beginning to cost me games against opponents that have the same level of experience.  I think that you need to always call on some simple algebra at key moments to consistently win this game.

When gaming I have a fly by the pants attitude that would scare me senseless in real life.  I play fast and loose but to get better at this game I will need to calculate earlier and more often.  I'm not a patient gamer and I will have to force myself to stop and calculate at the turning points of the game.

Quick or slow, calculated or intuitive I still love this game and my win percentage has nothing to do with it.

In 2014 this game was always close to another play, for the first time in a while this may not be on the menu. Simply because GMT games are starting to appear in a form that can be played in two sessions.  This game is still great and I will return.

RATING: 7
A fun game.  A good game.  An auction game.  Really, everything happening on the board is largely irrelevant.  The game is in the auction of plants - and those come up with some randomness.  Which means this game can have some pretty wonky situations... stalls or runaway wins are entirely possible.  And to make matters worse, the winner is going to keep on winning and there is nothing the others can do about it.  Still, despite these flaws a solid game.

The supply/demand game mechanic is just so clever. I also like the balance and feel that in most games, the winner isn't decided mid/early in the game, but nearer to the end (and sometimes the last round). The artwork, theme, and component quality is 10/10. I love the additional boards that can be added to mix things up. For the most part, the PG games I've played with expansion boards aren't fantastically different but are fun. 

This might be another sentimental 10 rating. This was one of the first nontraditional board games that I was introduced to and I have not stopped loving it since game 1.

I admit that my rating partly reflects my experience of playing with overcompetitive people (an experienced player who did a game changing take back preventing me from building out then deny me a takeback just after buying resources when I realised he would buy all the coal available next round, the only thing that could prevent me from winning, and another who was very selective in their answer to a direct rules question)

RATING: 7
Power Grid is a good game. With good balance, scales to any number of players, everything works correctly.
My main complaints are: 1) clunkiness of mechanics, such as, the artificial manipulation of power plant's stack, the compensatory turn order, and general need of elegance. 2) Power Grid is too "exact" and slow, it provides minimal amounts of fun and quite a big downtimes. 3) Production: I really hate the art. Cities and connexions are inherent ugly and unhelpful, the regions are poorly delineated and the colors are confusing. The paper money is just shaming. (I've seen maps with regions separed by a white line. Mine isn't :-S)
It's a good game but it's boring and much too long.

RATING: 7
My opinion of Power Grid is quickly starting to sour for two reasons:  

1) The end game bogs down to a crawl as the game encourages everyone to slowly count out and maximize every dollar by counting out various routes and connections.

2) All the things I like about the game (the route planning, the auctions) seem important but in the end I really think it's just "not screwing up" those factors ... and that the game really boils down to timing and positioning yourself in last just before the end game so you can build and buy resources first.

I don't hate it but I feel like I've played my last game of Power Grid for a while.

Update: Gave it some time off and playing it again (knowing ahead of time that it was all about the timing) was more fun. Curious to try more maps that have come out in the meantime.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my PERFECT GAME, a 10.
Why?.... It's got all the following:
Resource management similar to Settlers, path movement similar to Ticket to ride, Money management, Nice bits, Good scoring system, future market, resource market moves up and down as game goes on.  No dice, Luck does not make you win. No run-away leader.  It doesn't get any better than this game.  I think this is a game for a 9-10yr, if they are gamers and used to games like Catan, For Sale, etc they should have no problem with this game.  After further play I can recommend this game for a 7-8 yr old, we removed the "bidding" aspect in the power plant buying phase and our 6-1/2 yr old was able to play the game without a problem.  With this minor modification and maybe a little help a 7-8 yr old should be able to play and they should be able to hold their own.  I would start with lighter "auction style and resource management games like "For Sale", "Ticket to Ride" and "Settlers of Catan" befor introducing a young one to this game but if they like playing boardgames they will like this one.  Even better /Quicker on BSW

See my review http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/135192

RATING: 7
A lot of factors to keep in mind with this auction/resource management euro. The only serious detractor is the trackable-hidden money. Probably best with 4/5 players, but there's a lot of maps available so that probably varies. As I start to firm up ideas of which city sites are best to grab early and come to grips with fair auction prices I find that my opinion of this game is increasing. 

Note: be careful to keep in mind tiebreakers when bidding on power plants and when building cities.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Funkenschlag is a cruel and harsh mistress, sleek and seductive in her skintight greenish outfit, hugging her ancestral Germanic features in disturbing ways. She calls out to me softly, and expects to be obeyed. I lay her out on the table, careful, as not to upset her. She is still angry with me for making a tiny tear in one of the game boards. I keep out a wary eye for her little 'toys': money, plants, houses and a city grid. I am eager for my lesson, but she restrains me. She gives me permission to speak and briefly explain the rules. My mistress delights in making things difficult for me, and distracting me with questions when I am thinking. Sometimes she lets out a shrill laugh of triumph when I need to refer to the rules again. It's all part of my lesson.

Then my torment begins. My mistress tempts me in all ways imaginable. She moves her body in mesmerising ways when I need to caress her with a house. When she is not pleased with my touch, she immediately whips me mercilessly, so that I cannot close my fingers to hold on to the money and have to make do with small change. She lures me with powerful plants, only to deny them to me. Sometimes she is pleased with me and gives me a good plant as a bone to a good dog, but cackles frighteningly as she withholds the necessary fuel. I weep in anguish, but know my torment is not over. No, not yet.

She begins to favour those... others. My mistress laughs at my pain and tells me in that sweet, sweet voice of hers that I cannot give her what they can. She shows me in graphic detail, pointing out all the spots where I failed to pleasure her. Laughing hard at my contorted features, she pays no more attention to me. I beg, I grovel before her, only to have her kick me away brutally. The expression of her face and the sound of her voice as she turns her attention elsewhere leave my sense of self in tatters.

Whip me more, mistress, punish me harder. Perhaps next time I shall please you sufficiently for you to let me win a game.

[b]Update[/b] A fairly recent discussion made me realise that the game of Power Grid is actually in thoroughly obfuscating the game state of every player while adding hard to quantify randomness in the form of the power plant market. This causes evaluations to become unpredictable and asymmetric. Consequently it is not always clear why the winner won as he did: it can be his evaluation, or that of another player, or just having dumb luck in the market. What is certainly not the case is there being superior strategy at work: Power Grid is not a game which supports this; and what little there is, is well known (holding back, for example). This is perhaps something to be aware of if you're looking for a deep strategic game: Power Grid certainly isn't.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.25

Favorite game found because of BGG.

There are a lot of little rules in this game, but its fairly procedural.  The number of rules kept me away for a while.  To new players, I would suggest that you print out the user guides available in the file section on BGG.

Excellent game that our family has evolved to since finding BGG.  It has replaced Monopoly as our "money" game of choice.  If you know someone who likes Monopoly, this is the game to start them out with.

2009 - Haven't played this as much I would have liked last year.  Will make it a point to play this more in 2009.

RATING: 9
Fabulous! It was particularly good after my gaming group implemented a 1-minute time constraint when connecting cities, to help avoid "analysis paralysis" (and hauling out pencil/paper) in the late game. Without time constraints, kingmaker syndrome sometimes becomes very evident as well.

Edit: Just discovered that you're supposed to play with hidden money so as to reduce AP in the last few turns. Maybe that (combined with sufficient amounts of port) would replace the timer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite games in the rotation, comes out frequently, especially when we have a lot of players. This game gets everything right: very tough decisions in competition for multiple factors, including power plants, resources, and city locations, Power Grid demands a lot of careful planning and strategic thinking from the player. Each aspect is limited and mutually exclusive, so what one player gets, another does not. Did I mention the game is competitive?

The game's balancing mechanism of giving the lead players the last crack at the resources and house placement means you can't leap ahead and expand just to expand - you had better have a good reason for each decision you make. This also means that players who have fallen behind can catch up when leaders get cut off from their objectives.

One downside of the game is that a player can get boxed into an area early on and axed out of access to other areas for expansion - but this can also result in the fortuitous situation that these players build up a huge cash reserve that they aren't spending on expansion, which they are later able to spend on a great power plant and swift expansion, when it becomes available - which often results in these players winning the game, so this isn't really a game-ruiner.

Occasionally, a player with a large cash flow saved up will happen upon an ideal power plant at just the right time, which catapults them ahead for the win, which does mean that the element of chance has a distinct presence in the game, especially where bidding on power plant auctions is a bit of a gamble, given the lack of knowledge about which plants will become available next - but this not knowing is what makes the game exciting, and gives those inclined toward risk-taking a chance to play the odds while playing their opponents - and, with any luck, come out ahead.

In all, a very satisfying game, though you have to like counting and analysis. My only real complaint is that the artwork is lacking, even though design layout and components are very nice (wooden pieces!). Seemingly endless expansions keep the game fresh and possibilities potentially limitless - can't wait to see what regions they offer next. Permanent place in my top 10 for playability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very cool game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Power Grid is a very neat game of power plant expansion and power generation with a neat geographic bent to it.  I own all of the current expansions and enjoy them all.  Timing is everything in this game and working the balance between power plants acquired, geographic locations claimed and maintaining just the right amount of cash on hand makes this game a fun, sought over classic.  The power plant replacement deck is highly recommended.  Power Grid also plays very well with 4, 5 or 6 players.  Overall, Power Grid is a well designed, good euro game with reasonable replayability - especially if you own the expansions.  Power Grid and its various expansions have made my top 50 list of euro style games of all time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A very elegant game of economic warfare and network control. Though game board looks intimidating to new players, the game is actually very streamlined and easy to learn - provided that at least one person knows the rules very well. Unlike many eurogames, almost every action involves direct interaction between players; you step on people's toes with every auction, every purchase of resources, and every city you add to your network.

You have to do a lot of arithmetic in this game. I personally don't mind that (which is why I give it such a high rating), but that can be a major turn-off for some players. I keep calculators in the box as a player aide.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
This is my favorite game! Very unique game with interesting mechanics. The game gives more money to those are in the lead, but other advantages to those who are behind. Thus, you have to decide when is advantageous to pull ahead of the pack or hold back and wait for a better time. Management of your resources and money are key in this game as well. A player has to divide their resources between expanding and being more efficient. What I love most about this game is that all the decisions you make have to constantly be re-evaluated every turn. This game is all about constantly adapting to the situation at hand in order to achieve the most efficiency.

Recommended for: Those who love Euro games, who like efficiency and money management (it has a lot of number crunching), determining the value of things at auction, who like games that force you to adapt constantly.

Not recommended for: Those who don't want to be junior accountants for 2 hours, who can't stand games that hold back the leader for the sake of interaction, who want a stronger theme.

RATING: 9
This is the first economic game I played, before starting my boardgaming career and making a collection...It is one of the games that convinced me to try more boardgames and to try more euros aswell(only played thematic games before).

Really good economic game, I love the auction part....you really need to know if you absolutely must have that plant or can wait for a later one(as money is scarce) and how resource management works...I like the fact that the first in line(homes wise and game wise) is the last to purchase resources which means that he will buy them at higher prices than the others...it keeps the game ballanced and avoids a runaway leader. I know a lot of people complain about the visual aspect but I think the board looks ok and it does it's job....really there are worse looking games out there.

It doesn't play in so long a time and new players catch on pretty quickly....most new people I played it with enjoyed it.

RATING: 7
highly enjoyable game that is typically good to the last frenzied drop
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Components: Nice board, with relatively easy-to-follow pipeline connections between cities, and region demarcations (though the pipes could stand to be more narrow).  All the wooden bits, with their varying shapes and colors, add nice snazz to the game.  The power plants are depicted creatively, with each type of plant having its own style of building, which is shown grander in scale with each increase in factory value.  The dark tones on the board, and the idea of buying lots of uranium, coal, oil, and garbage are a bit depressing theme-wise.  Paper money is a disappointment, especially given how much money changes hands.

Experience: The auction phase can be tense or matter-of-fact; I enjoy recruiting the factories to my cause, trying to diversify my resource needs while being aware of cost, and deciding how much to build, and how that will affect my position in the next turn order.  Many times I find myself having to calculate exactly how much I can spend on or make from a particular option, which is a bit too much budgeting for me, but fun nonetheless. Feels like trying to balance my monthly budget.

Eagerness to Play Again: Within a year

Plays: 3
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
What needs to be said that hasn't been?  A clever combination of route-building, equipment-auctioning, and shared-resource consumption.  Money will be tight for most of the game, and the player who avoids both trying to do too much and always staying on top has the best chance of succeeding in the long run.  Replay value is not bad, and is further enhanced by multiple boards for other countries now being available.

RATING: 8
Although I've recently been finding I do quite well at Power Grid, it has too much accountancy (save a penny here to be able to afford tuppence later) to hit any kind of sweet spot for me. The endgame in particular too often descends into a borefest in which each player can take up to ten minutes to maximise his last one or two plays (generally network expansion). 
Perhaps it could use a bit more randomness to make assessments of other players' positions less precise. I won our group's most recent game by a single electro, though I'd thought I was going to lose it by the same margin.
Nonetheless, it's certainly a 'good' game and far from the worst way to while away an hour and a half.

RATING: 10
Wow! Where have you been all my life? This game is my favourite "heavier" Euro game, edging out Age of Industry only because I find it less stressful and more fun to play. I can play Power Grid anytime ... Age of Industry takes a bit of mental preparation. Power Grid I want to play all the time.

Initial rating is 9 after two plays. Odd playing time. With five of us (four first timers but with a good rules teacher) it took over three hours with some elements of AP. Three player second game wrapped up in about 90 minutes. Maybe because we knew the rules, or simply didn't waste time in auctions or with AP, or made decisions too quickly, or whatever. Still fun in both instances.

A more detailed review later but for now ... brilliant game.

Revised rating to a 10 based on BGG guidelines. Every game has been a great experience and I can not see myself ever wanting to not play this game.

[b]I own the following expansion(s) for the game:[/b]

Power Grid: Benelux/Central Europe
Power Grid: Russia/Japan
Power Grid: Québec/Baden-Württemberg
Power Grid: BGG Promo Card Set
Power Grid: The New Power Plant Cards

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love the economic tension in this game.  The turn order mechanic seems to turn other people off of this, but I think it adds to the game.  Without it, there would be no point in not building whenever you could, and so the game would come down solely to the auctions.  Instead, there is now a timing aspect.  You need to build in enough cities to earn cash, but not too many because your resources will be too expensive if you're in the lead.

We don't think it works well with 2; it always seems to come down to money, which just isn't satisfying.

Update:  With the robots, this is a fun 2 player game as well!

RATING: 8

I need to play again before properly appraising this.

-------------------------------------

2nd game was far more enjoyable. A long game but an enjoyable game of optimisation with no downtime since there are always options to consider and usually you'll be able to go with your original plan. Essentially a race, it's all about efficiency within the turns you have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great balance. Looks clunky intially, but the auction and build phases move really well as long as one person can direct the action. Fighting for good position on the board can feel like a knife-fight in a phone booth with competitive players. There is never enough money to go around as players need to carefully balance the number of cities, resources, and power plants each round.

Stay away if you don't like math or constant counting.

Expansions owned:
- China/Korea
- Benelux/Central Europe
- Brazil/Spain & Portugal
- Québec/Baden-Württemberg
- The Robots
- BGG Promo Card Set
- Taxes

RATING: 10
A personal favorite. I like building games, and in this one you create a network that expands across the map. Every addition to the network is one that someone else can't have, so that combined with the auction of power plants and manipulation of the supply market make the game very interactive. Yes, I realize that the catch-up mechanism of turn order is rather contrived and makes little sense with the theme, but I enjoy trying to work the turn order to my favor. The mathy nature of the game makes it possible to plot out the endgame to some degree, but it always seems to hinge on someone being a dollar short of what they need...as good a sign of a great game as I can think of.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
A very good economic strategy game with pretty simple but not obvious mechanics. I like it a lot, even though the style is definitely not my favorite one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
What an incredible dynamic this game has.

The task is to establish a network of electric power stations linking several cities. The stations are bought through an auction and, once they are supplied (with four types of fuel - coal, petrol, garbage or uranium) they start to produce income.
The income allows then to buy more fuel in the next rounds, to buy new and more efficient stations, buy the right to establish new stations in new cities, as also the costs of linking them to cities already part of our network.
There is a constant catch up mechanism based at the fact that the player coming in last (with less cities) is the first to acess the market of fuel (obtaining lower prices and sometimes doing some hoarding). Prices at this market also vary depending on demand, as was supposed.
The game quick becames addictive, as you try to expand your network, buy better stations, buy cheaper fuel, etc, making lots and lots of sum calculations, only to find you are one coin or two short of what you intendend!...
There are some small drawbacks: The process how new stations are coming to the aution is a bit confusing and the constant changes in the turn order introduce some perturbation to the flow of the game.
However, what i think is a bit anwkard is that, after some 2 hrs of hard play, the winner is decided through "photo-finish", as is usual to have several players with the same number of supplied stations and the tiebreak factor is just...to have a few more coins!
That is a pity because, otherwise, the game could rank even better.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wow, funnest game I own.

It makes me forget good grammar.

RATING: 7
A bit overrated, but a decent game.  I like the artwork of the board and cards well enough.  The game is intense, but difficult for the one explaining to newbies because of the fiddliness of certain rules (and difficult to remember myself).  Once you get past that, it's a pretty good game with many unique and fun mechanisms all working at once.  What I dislike about it is how easy it is for a player to save up cash and sneak up with the end-game trigger by building a lot of cities.  This game seems to be all about timing of the end-game.  Do it correct, and you win.  Mess up, and you lose.  The $1 incrimental bidding during the auction drags the game on longer than it should as well.  I don't mind some mental calculation in games, but this one seems to bring out the worst in players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[29 Jul 2017] - 7.75 (1 play)
An auction game combined with route placement that doesn't use trains! The auctions were tense in our 5 player game and the resource market really punished following along with other players. Using reverse bidding order for collecting resources and building routes made for an interesting decisions about when to become first and when to let others take more powerful power plants. The route building aspect has an interesting limiter at first that lets people build in their own region of the map before they need to compete with each other. I would have preferred to not have that safety net but letting other get started does make for an interesting mid-game. I would love to play this again. A bit lighter than the 18xx games but a very solid entry for 3+ players.

[14 Sep 2017] - 7.0 (1 play)
Thinking back to the auction in Power Grid and other auction games that I've played, I'm not as interested in this game. While the auctions in Power Grid are interesting and encourage players to go later in turn order, I don't think it's as dynamic or tense as Ponzi Scheme or an 18xx game. It is a lot more approachable to players who would rather play light to medium euro games and that's probably where it's charm lies. Since I do have the fortune to play these heavier games, I can't rate it as high. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Meaty and heavily strategic, long and serious. Extremely well designed game, though at times causes some analysis paralysis.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've played Power Grid with 4, 5, and 6 players now and each game has been a great experience overall. I like Power Grid a lot because it is complex in strategy, yet the rules and steps are easy enough to comprehend that I can teach it to anyone in a relatively short amount of time. The game is 2 hours, which may seem long, but believe me when I say that time flies when playing this game - you are constantly paying attention to what others are doing, and planning your next move even when it's not your turn. Plus, even when you are in last (which is an advantage in this game), you don't necessarily feel like there's no hope left in the game - you have first dibs when it comes to buying resources and building in cities. The auction phase is a lot of fun, too...can be a bit of a psychological battle :-). I can't wait to play Power Grid even more, and I suspect my 10 rating will not change over time for this game.

RATING: 7

2010 Update: It's fun with two players - we were just making the rooking mistakes of constantly upgrading power plants instead of far less frequent, strategic, buying. When the game is played in that manner, the two players find themselves often bidding for the same power plants. Much more fun and the game goes quickly.

2011 Update: A game is only fun if the other gamers in your circle like/want to play it. There's something missing here... I think the game requires too much bookkeeping at the end of each round for most players. We've also noticed that new players don't like the "unfair" maps. (The maps aren't unfair - it just seems that way.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Power grid is a simple strategy game with a focus on resource management.  Despite the nearly unreadable rule book (one of the worst I've ever seen), the game is actually easy to learn and enjoy from the first play.  It scales well, although turn order can become confusing in larger games.  Early mistakes can mean certain failure, as there is no "catch-up" mechanic.  This means if someone has an early lead, it's highly likely they will win.  The auction system is an enjoyable mechanic, and fits nicely with the theme.  The board design is elegant and the wooden pieces are solid quality.  The paper money that comes with the game can really slow things down, so I suggest using poker chips instead.  Biggest con for this game is the poorly written rule book.  Learn the game from someone who knows it, or watch a tutorial online.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is one of those games that I keep coming back too.  That it's on BSW is a bonus too.  I really don't care much about the theme, but it's mechanically slick.

The biggest downside is the amount of addition.  Personally, I don't mind this as I can add quickly.  However, this can really ratchet up the AP, especially with all the engineers that I game with.  When the calculator comes out, I know that I've had enough.  This game is a lot of fun to play by the seat of your pants.  It's tedious to play it when opponents insist on calculating every little expense for a turn.  I think that I'll get a 30 second timer for the game.  I'll allow one extra 30 secs once per game (since it can matter in the end).  I'm leaving the rating alone for now, but I could definitely sour further.  I highly recommend BSW on this one since there's virtually no AP.

Update: dude, whateva!  This game rocks and I love it.  Some of the expansions kinda suck, but some are sublime.  I even like the new edition.

Update 2017: I take back what I said about the new edition--it's ok, but the power plant deck is just a little too nice for my taste.
