=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2-6

Doel :

Het spel is afgelopen na fase 4 van de ronde waarin één of meer spelers 17 of meer steden hebben aangesloten! De speler die de meeste steden van energie kan voorzien wint het spel. Bij gelijke stand wint de speler met het meeste geld!

Voorbereiding:

+ Iedere speler kiest 1 gebied op het speelbord. Opgelet, alle gekozen gebieden moeten aan elkaar grenzen.
+ Iedere speler kiest een kleur, neemt een overzichtskaart en 50 Elektro.
+ Vul de brandstoffenmarkt aan.
+ Leg de centrales (03 tem 10) in 2 horizontale rijen. Sorteer hen op nummer! De bovenste rij is het actuele aanbod.
+ Schud de overige kaarten. Leg kaart 13 bovenop de stapel en kaart “periode 3” onderaan de stapel.

Speelverloop:

Iedere speelronde speelt zich af in een periode. Het spel start in periode 1! Elke speelronde bestaat uit 5 fasen:

Fase 1: Beurtvolgorde bepalen:

De speler met de meeste aangesloten steden (steden met een huisje) zet zijn huisje op positie 1 van het beurtvolgorde spoor, enzovoort.... Bij gelijke stand zet de speler met de centrale met het hoogste nummer als eerste zijn huisje op het beurtvolgordespoor!

Fase 2: Centrales veilen:

Er zijn twee opties: passen of veilen

1/ Passen: De speler kiest ervoor om geen centrale te veilen! Hij mag aan geen veilingen meer deelnemen.

2/ Veilen: Een speler kiest een centrale uit het actuele aanbod en doet een openingsbod (minimum het nummer van de centrale). Alle spelers mogen kloksgewijs beginnen bieden! Als je eenmaal past, mag je geen bod meer uitbrengen. Indien een andere speler de centrale kocht, dan mag de actieve speler terug kiezen tussen veilen of passen. In de 1ste ronde moet iedereen een centrale kopen!!

Fase 3: Brandstoffen kopen:

Deze fase wordt in omgekeerde beurtvolgorde gespeeld! Wie aan de beurt is mag zoveel brandstoffen kopen als hij wil, maar hij moet rekening houden met de opslagcapaciteit van zijn centrales. Een maximum opslag van 2x het afgebeelde symbool!

Fase 4: Bouwen:

Deze fase wordt in omgekeerde beurtvolgorde gespeeld! Een speler mag zoveel aansluitingen (huisjes) maken als hij wil, zolang hij de aansluitkosten en netwerkkosten maar kan betalen!

Fase 5: Inkomsten nemen en volgende ronde voorbereiden:

Iedere speler, beginnend met de startspeler, voorziet zijn steden van stroom! Hiervoor ontvangt hij geld (zie overzichtskaart). Een teveel aan stroom levert niks op! Als iedereen aan de beurt is geweest, vul dan de brandstoffenmarkt aan.

Belangrijke regels:

+ Een speler mag nooit meer dan 3 centrales bezitten. Als hij een vierde koopt, moet hij direct één van zijn 4 centrales verwijderen.
+ Als geen enkele speler een centrale koopt, verwijder dan de centrale met het laagste nummer.
+ Brandstoffen mag je steeds herverdelen over je centrales, je moet wel rekening houden met de opslagcapaciteit van de centrales.
+ Een speler mag niet meerdere malen een stad aansluiten.
+ Een speler moet altijd op het goedkoopst beschikbare veld een huisje bouwen.
+ In de 1ste ronde moet je een centrale kopen en een stad aansluiten.
+ Als zich in het actuele aanbod een centrale bevindt met een nummer gelijk aan of lager dan het aantal steden van de leidende speler is, dan wordt deze direct uit het spel verwijderd en vervangen door een nieuwe.
+ Als de kaart “transformatiestation” verschijnt, dan wordt het spel onderbroken voor een extra veiling. Het maakt niet uit in welke fase dit gebeurt.

PERIODE 1: 
+ start aan het begin van het spel.
+ in fase 5: verwijder de centrale met het hoogste nummer uit het toekomstige aanbod en trek een nieuwe.
+ in fase 4: Er mag maar 1 aansluiting zijn per stad! Kost = 10 Elektro

PERIODE 2:
+ start als een speler zijn zevende stad heeft aangesloten.
+ in fase 5: verwijder de centrale met het hoogste nummer uit het toekomstige aanbod en trek een nieuwe.
+ in fase 4: Er mogen 2 aansluitingen zijn per stad! Kost = 15 Elektro

PERIODE 3:
+ start als de kaart periode 3 wordt getrokken.
+ in fase 5: verwijder de centrale met het laagste nummer uit het spel! Er bestaat geen toekomstig aanbod meer. Er worden 6 centrales geveild!
+ in fase 4: Er mogen 3 aansluitingen zijn per stad! Kost = 20 Elektro
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

For that, it's perhaps lost a little for me personally, but I think it's still a very solid game, and I'd be interested to play against more experienced players. Note: I'm not the best at math, but in this game, it's needed. Fortunately, there are only a few variables to account for, plus plenty of time to run through the numbers while the other players take their turns.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
It takes a long time to play, but is totally worth it.  Rarely have I seen a game so well designed and balanced.

Plant capacity wins the game.  Being in the lead hamstrings your ability to grow capacity.  Don't pass on chances to do so.

Don't expand beyond your ability to power expecting to buy capacity in the next round.  This is doubly true if you're in the lead.

It's worth it to save money on supplies when possible.  Fuel is the one cost in the game that you don't earn anything directly from.

The game ends when the requisite number of cities have been built, not when the requisite number of cities have been powered.  This is how you push ahead as the game leader to win: grab cities first, expecting that you won't be able to supply them all, but rather that you'll be able to supply more than your opponents who have been left behind.

When the step 3 card comes up, players will be able to take the third spot in each city on that turn.  Try to stockpile money in expectation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
its awesome

RATING: 8
1 play with 4 players on map of Germany
1 play with 4 players on map of USA
Like the bidding aspect of the game.
Like how player turn order enables newer players to catch up.
Can see why people say the drawing of the plant deck increases the luck factor.
My two games have always finished very 'close' and by close I mean the small spread in the number of powered cities of each player at the end of the game.

I find this a tiny bit tedious to play. The math (really arithmetic and by arithmetic I specifically mean 3 operations: addition, subtraction, and multiplication) is annoying. The arithmetic is easy for people I play with but there's still an annoying amount of total time spent (wasted) calculating costs and change (change as in the kind of change when you pay $50 for something costing $27). The constant need to do arithmetic also disrupts the flow of the game, in my opinion. (We use poker chips instead of the paper money provided by the game.) Getting change is also annoying. Perhaps using paper and pen to keep track of money, so that we don't have to grab our change, is a better idea than using poker chips. In fact, I'll try that out next time.

Power Grid is an excellent game, and a very simple one to get into, even for newbies to gaming.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
The first playthrough of the game is a bit clunky as players don't know how much each power plant is really worth. However, once you play with 3-4 other people that have experience in the game it becomes an absolute rush. After you're about halfway through phase 2, you've had enough time to forget exactly how much money everyone has and the bidding becomes much more intense. There's nothing better than having a showdown with the person across from you for an awesome power plant that somehow slipped down to the buying row. It's almost a game with chicken of high how are you willing to pay. My only complaint is that the end of the game can sometimes be a little anticlimatic. If one person hoards money and buys 5 cities on the last turn to bum rush to 17, it can feel like a bit of a let down to other players who aren't expecting the game to end. Also, the more the merrier in this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent business/planning game where players are attempting to run power to an increasing number of cities.  Players link the cities "crayon rail game" style (or in the new edition, by simply placing wooden houses in cities on the printed power grid), via drawing on the mapsheet and run the power by picking up power plants at auction.  Money is earned based on cities powered and is used for better plants, the resources to run them, and further power links.  Great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Power Grid is one of just a handful of games that elevates my pulse and increases my blood pressure. I have so many great things to say about this game: the tense auctions, the psychology, the jockeying for turn order, the screwage factor, the spatial aspect, the resource market and resource management, and more. The only thing that keeps it from being a 10 for me is the AP-inducing connection cost calculations, especially towards the end of the game.

UPDATE: I've decided it's a 10 anyway.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Idea:
Power most cities when game ends. Get money from cities powered. Powerplants are auctioned. All about handling your playing position compared to your resoureces.

Mechanism:
Each round first bid for plants -> buy resources -> buy cities -> fire plants. Has very strong strategy as one who leads does bidding/passing first thus last player gets best chances to buy best plant cheapest and last player buys resources/cities first thus first player pays most for resources/cities.

To whom:
Classic game that really needs some strategy to keep yourself in competition. Simple to teach, very hard to master. Good with 3-5(6) players but playable 1vs1 too for quite many games

Playable online at BSW.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
I have played this game several times now (because my friends enjoy it and we can play with a lot of players), and every time I hear someone suggest we play I die a little inside. For me, this game actually gets worse the more you play it. It is too easy to get trapped by a bad area with no mechanics to overcome it.  Every time I have played, about half way through, you already know who can win and who can't. At that point, the "losers" are just playing to generate excitement, which usually means overbidding and buying resources just to drive up prices.  Additionally, the art is bad. The game board has so much going on it is visually unappealing. The concept of building power stations is a snooze fest.  And, the "alternate" maps are really just the same thing in a different country. Plus, having to isolate one region on the map is dumb and creates unnecessary decision-making strategies before the game even begins. In fairness, I haven't played it with less than 5 people. Maybe it's better with fewer people. Right now, I generously gave it a "4" only because my friends enjoy it so much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Power Grid is an oddity to me. Despite high-rankings on BGG, a strong theme and my own personal enjoyment of it, it's still one of the most dry games in my collection. Rounds are very number heavy, as you seek the most efficient way to spend as much of your money on a round, so that you can make even more for the next round. The theme tends to fall off a little as you start dealing with larger numbers.

Dryness aside, only major complaint I could level at the game is the massive snowball effect. Yes, the game is tuned so that the player further ahead is technically at the largest disadvantage, but players can get around this easily by careful stockpiling (clearly winning, but not putting it onto the board to reap the benefits of not being in front) or brute force (players who are rich enough don't even notice the disadvantages leveled against them.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
All the math going on suggests I shouldn't like Power Grid, but I do. There's some screwage going on, but most of it doesn't happen on the map, but during auctions and the purchasing of resources. Both tactical and strategical. My only complaint would be how random elements near the end can have such a big influence on the outcome of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic auction game where I’ve seen some of the most intense bidding in any game ever!  The game has several fantastic mechanisms in place to make it well balanced.  The catch-up mechanism is a work of genius and prevents a runaway leader from getting too far ahead and allows players that fall behind to quickly catch up and take the lead.  

Unfortunately, there are a few issues with the game: 
-The rulebook is, hands down, one of the WORST written I have ever seen.  We’ve had players who were lawyers and paralegals conjecture over the interpretations of some of its clauses.  The language is very ambiguous and not clear at all (nor is the layout).  For example, “We recommend one area per player”: they “RECOMMEND”; and this has caused many to believe they MUST block out certain portions of the board based on the number of players.  However the writer only says “recommend”: I wish they would elaborate on what they mean by “recommend.”  Also the terms “step”, “phase” and “round” got somewhat lost in translation as I know just about everyone I play with gets these terms confused since they are not used in the game in a way that is natural to native-English speakers.  I think when Henning Kropke and Jay Tummelson translated the rules, they tried to keep it too similar to the original German: the book really needs to be completely re-written in English that is more clear and precise to native English speakers.   

-The layout of the rules is a not very smooth.  They put some of the most important rules at the END of each section under the banner “Important” or “Remember” or “Exception”.  This is important information that should be in the main text and not added at the end of a section as if its an appendix.  You need to present data in a much more logical progression and not jumping all over the place.  In its current state, it’s very scattered.    

-the font used of the rulebook is far too tiny (did the graphic designer of the book take ANY Print Design Layout classes?)  For example, the setup of the resource market is buried in tiny text in a paragraph; did the Graphic Designer ever consider putting this very important information into a table, or perhaps even make it bold???   

-To make the game so balanced, the rules are very fiddly, especially regarding the re-arrangement of the power-plants at the end of each auction (which can start to feel burdensome at times).  That, combined with the fact the rulebook is so poorly written, leads me to think half the people out there are not playing the game correctly.  (I know the first few times I played with one gaming group, the lead-player introducing the game was un-knowingly not shuffling/re-stocking the power plants correctly).  

-Some of the maps are also not very well balanced.  Generally, Power Grid works best with the maximum number of players and with the map of Germany.  The US map does not seem as well balanced as we’ve found that players who start out by dominating the Northeast Coast always seem to win.   (The United Kingdom map seems very good, Japan not as much due to it being a long and slender island).  
 
-While I don’t think the math is as much of a problem as some of the BGG commentators have stated, I have found that some players are so good at the game that they will shut the game down early before they have technically won because they’ve worked out that they’ve already won several moves in advance and no one can possibly catch up.  To me the fun of the game is in the auctions and not the statistical calculations made to win the game in a certain number of moves.  It might be best to consider who you play this game with; some people play this game at a completely different level than others and so its best to play with players at your same level (sometimes that catch-up mechanism just isn’t enough).   

Still, this is a great game when played correctly with the right people (and the maximum number of people) and a good map, but come on Rio Grande… you seriously need to do something about that awful English rulebook!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game has a turn mechanism that is just sheer genius. That element coupled with its competitive auctions and creative supply/demand feature, make this a very enjoyable game.

[b]6.8.09 Update:[/b] Played this again recently, and was reminded just how good this game is. I love the market mechanism and balance of tension. My rating goes up a tick!

[b]9.6.11 Update:[/b] My opinion of this game has really taken a beating over the last few plays. All the math involved really begs for it to be bogged down in AP, thus resulting in a crazy long game. The length coupled with the dry math creates a very small target audience for this one. It disappoints me, because I really like it, but if it's hard to get to the table, then it doesn't matter how good it is, it's value takes a hit. It pains me to say, but my rating goes down and I'm removing it from my Top 10. 

[b]Rating History:[/b]
< 6.7.09 ~ 8.50
6.8.09 = 8.75
9.6.11 = 8.00

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
PG is a game that I like, but not enough to play all the time.  I have a bunch of the accessories, I just don't get it to the table that much anymore.  

It loses something if you play it with people who are too slow, and those who are either hyper-competitive or entirely passive.  It's not as interesting with only 3, but adding players above 4 takes the length above what I prefer.  So, you have to play it at the right time and place to get the most out of it.  
There are so many options that you only get to see each individual configuration rarely.  I can't complain too much, as I like the variety, and it's not fair to knock the 2-map base game for this.  Somehow, though, I frequently seem to wind up in games with new players, and playing the US all the time gets old fast.  

The game is very mathy, and it can end very suddenly, but it can also drag out in a big slog.  That's why I don't always feel like playing it, but I still like having it in my collection.

RATING: N/A
When I started to get serious into board gaming hobbies, I had this game for a while in my wishlist. The fact that it is using paper money and involves auction/bidding, made me put this game out from the list.
Now after a year, the game made a come back into my wishlist after a local FOLGS organized a Power Grid Tournament.
Back then, I didn't like auction/bidding mechanic but now I'm open to accept it. I was surprised that this game can actually accommodate up to 6 players, silly me for overlooked at it.

I'm planning to use the circular dicks found in Agricola to replace the paper money in Power Grid, only after I get the Agricola Goodies first.

Update1: 

(After 1st play) I have to say that I kind of like the game, not so much that I will buy it straightaway. Best features that I like from the game is that there's bidding (this is one of the best candidate as I do not own bidding game) and it can support up to 6 players. The game has won lots of awards and till now, still top the charts and poll. I may need to give this game another try. The "math" in the game didn't really bothers me, but I think, one day, I will eventually own this.

today we have Agricola, Power Grid, Pandemic, The Castles of Burgundy, Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective...
..actually Sherlock Holmes is from 1981, but I didn't know it existed until 2015.

*"Euro" games are mainly logic, strategy and management. "American" games are mainly luck and strong theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Solid, old, economic Euro game, not arguably the best design of Friedemann Friese. It has fantastic thematic background about supplying power to households covered by your company which has to acquire power plants by auctioning and compete for cheap fuel. However it is remarkably bland, almost impossible to be played competitively without calculator and catch-up mechanics force players speculate and chase the last place from turn to turn. I have low desire to play it often, but I would like to try some different maps (I've played with Germany only).

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Resource track which fluctuate from turn to turn by the laws of supply and demand. Also expensive resources (like uranium) go cheaper and cheap resources (like coal) go more expensive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The theme is well implemented and fairly concrete for non-gamers as well (everybody knows what power plants do and the importance of powering cities). The balancing is also very good.

RATING: 7
It doesn't really hold my interest. There are better games out there which are better than this one. Why would you spend time playing a bad game when you can play a game which is more worth your time and enjoyment?

It's repetitive, some luck. How economics works in Power Grid is interesting. You can actually run out of resources to buy. It's a major burn when your that player who can't fire up all his plants at the last turn and lose the game cause of it.

Rating: 5.25

UPDATE:

Lately I have been playing Power Grid a lot more since a good friend of mine bought two of the expansions. 

My overall rating has gone up since trying the expansions. The main reason why my original rating was low was because playing on the same maps is always the same I thought. Players has always the same starting areas so there isn't a different feel from game to game. Same spot, same costs from city to city. The only variation is what plants you buy.

With the expansions, its replay value has gone up from a 5.25 to 7. I guess over time and more games played, I warmed up more to the game. It's better than I first thought. I enjoy it more with 5-6 players. It`s more fun when you have access to the whole map.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I had my chance to buy this game at a great deal and regret it severely. On one play, I find this game extremely well balanced. There is a small learning curve but if you get there and make sure that everyone knows the rules to a T you will have a very enjoyable experience.

RATING: 6
This is a great auction/bidding game for multiple players, not so good with two. I believe there is a great game in here, but the design and rule explanation is terrible. I could explain this game to a degree, but felt newcomers were always at a disadvantage in the endgame, which is the most critical point in the game. I severely disliked 'blocking off' areas of the board to scale for players, it just looks ugly. Still, this is a classic and should be played by all, just make sure players understand when they are bidding far too much...

60-90m, best with 4-5 players. 5+ plays.

RATING: 8
UPDATE: It's still a great game, but I think I'd recommend Concordia over this because it gives most of the experience as PG with about a tenth of the rule set.

UPDATE: It's a good game. Yeah, there are a lot of moving parts but it's also one of those games where you can assign everyone a task for upkeep and that helps a lot. I enjoy the market manipulation as well as the area control and maintaining your own network. (Honestly, I think PG has one of the more interesting and elegant depictions of free markets in board games)

This is one of those games that I like in theory more than in practice. I think it's really well designed and gives you a lot of gameplay for the effort. I like how the markets are simulated. Also, all the expansion maps really add to the fun.

HOWEVER, this game is a really "high-maintenance" game. Lots of pieces to move about. Lots of cards to move around. Markets to replenish. Is it step three or step two? How many oil squares to I refill for a four-player game in step two? Argh. all the bookkeeping really distracts me from all the strategy (and if you miscalculate by a dollar, you're screwed). I generally prefer my games to be a little less fiddly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
An excellent game of mainly bidding and going up to the next level at the right time, in this way similar to games like "Outpost" in a way. But in contrast to these games this game sometimes rewards careful play, stockpiling of money and waiting for the right moment more, so it makes for a nailbiting experience. Played with pro gamers this is a geek fest par excellence, as you judge each bid and constantly look out for the turn order, fearing you will not be able to pay for those resources or they won't even be there anymore. Complex, without being complicated.

RATING: 7.5
This is a solid game, which is I generally enjoy, nevertheless, I don't count it as a favorite, perhaps because 

1) Auctioning isn't really my favorite mechanism,
2) There is somewhat too much luck in the power plant draws
3) The calculations can get a little bit tedious, particularly in later turns

None of these are reason enough not to play it, but they are enough to damper my enthusiasm down to a 7.5

Update 4/27/2016 - Actually, I think that I do like auctions plenty well enough. Santiago and Goa, for example, are solid 8s. So it is really the random power plant draws that take this down a notch. It's still pretty good, though, and has the added benefit of being relatively easy to teach - a good step up from Settlers.

RATING: 7
Where Pandemic requires precision in unison, Power Grid demands calculated measure of each action between you and your opponents. You really need to clear your mind and process the wisest choices to be victor of this simulated capitalist venture.

Now that I've scared off the most casual players, let me say that the game offers indelible exultation while impressing strategic after-thoughts into the wake of your following days.  For a seemingly dry theme, get any competitive individual to play a couple of rounds and he will begin to embrace the quiet viciousness inherent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Classic game, but arithmetically heavy.  General consensus is that it's a bit too mathematical/complex, and that was my experience after one play. Timing and turn order in this game is critical, and the way the turn order mechanism of this game works is brilliant (see [thread=728129]discussion[/thread]).

Great tutorial for learning the game [url=http://legacyoffun.com/gameguides/power_grid/]here[/url], plus [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/Power_Grid_FAQ]FAQ[/url], [thread=881531]setup & management tips[/thread], and [filepage=32681]printable reference[/filepage].

Takes 2-3 hours with experienced players, our first four player game took about 3.5 hours.  To play well, you need to do constant calculating, which becomes painful with AP players, and quite intense.  Great game, just not for me.

RATING: 6
A classic of the modern era, though I’ve tired of it greatly since the halcyon days of my re-entry into gaming in the late 2000s. Back in the 2000s when auctions were considered a great idea for balancing a game (the players do it themselves via the bidding!), I enjoyed the challenge of managing the tempo (on different maps). I loved it back then and played dozens of games on table and online. 

But now I find the game is fragile to inexperienced players and the way plants come out in the market. This design feels totally played out to me at this point. I'd much rather play Princes of Florence for an old school auction game.

RATING: 9
Power Grid and Funkenschlag are different (though related) games.  I rate Funkenschlag an '8', but Power Grid is a '9' because it's cleaner, faster and not quite as punitive for the player who is in the lead.  Despite the luck introduced by the order in which the power plants come out, skill matters a lot---the better players will win significantly more often than pure chance would suggest is plausible.

RATING: 8.3
Tendremos que comprar centrales eléctricas gestionar nuestra economía y abastecer al mayor número posible de ciudades.
Es un juego de reglas sencillas con una gestión económica que lo hace muy entretenido y como tiene compensación para el último es muy difícil quedarse fuera.
Dificultad: 5/10
Diversión: 8/10
Rejugabilidad: 7/10

Me gusta: entretenido, para todas los públicos, que es reñido hasta el final.
No me gusta: poca estrategia, algo de azar.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I love this game.

There is a delicious and complex interplay in the competition for the power plants, resources and building sites.  One must judge the value of each choice relative to its cost, all the while carefully managing one's money and paying attention to what the others are doing.  There is a real art to anticipating and positioning oneself for each stage and for the end game.  

The balancing mechanism, which penalizes the "leader" and is often criticized, makes for a very tight and close game and is brilliant in my opinion.

Power Grid is a great game with huge replay value and one that I will never turn down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 10
What a great game. The unofficial theme is "One Electro Short." You know what I mean if you have played the game. I love the turn order manipulation part of the game. It can be tricky to time exactly when to fall back or to leap ahead. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Based on a lot of plays.
+ My favorite Eurogame.
+ Very good theme. It actually makes sense.
+ The endgame is very exciting.
+ Clever mechanics (resource market).
+ Experience is rewarded, but game feels a bit different every time.
+ Very good scalability with different numbers of players.
- This game is NOT for math-haters. One has to do a lot of addition.
- This is not a light game. People who treat this as such, will lose. Always. Requires full concentration.

Update (in 2008, after a half a year): 9-->10. The endgame is still exciting like in no other eurogame!

Since 2007, updated Dec 2011.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[b]sold, finally[/b]
[b]gave away, then got back - still planning to sell[/b]
see comments below for why - I dislike economic games, don't really love auctions, and this one adds on a bunch of tedious arithmetic too.  It's a perfect storm of stuff I don't like in my games.  Unlike a lot of games I've gotten rid of, though, I concede that Power Grid is a [i]very[/i] good design - it's just not for me.
[b]previous comment:[/b]

I've played this more times than BGG would indicate, as I purchased it before I began logging plays, but haven't logged the usual ten plays I prefer before rating a game.

Power Grid - Excel, The Game.  I find this one massively boring.  The decisions are difficult, and the auctions tense, but only because you either slow everyone down by mathing everything out in your head, or try to guess and hope you got it right.  I do like some of the ideas - the catchup mechanisms are good and the way the marketplace of resources works is brilliant, but the actual game play is a too-long snoozefest.  Any game that is improved drastically by using a calculator is not a game I want.  Two or three hours of tedious arithmetic is not my idea of fun.

RATING: 4
It's interesting but feels a bit dated. It's dry, very Kathy and can lead to quite a bit of analysis paralysis. I would play again but I don't think I would ever suggest this...indeed I may even suggest alternatives rather than play this again.

The resources market is interesting with the price fluctuating throughout the turn and can lead to interesting decisions about how much to invest, to potentially cause those players further down the pecking order a rather expensive turn, but it is done better and more simply in crude:the oil game.

Power stations are all pretty much of a muchness, basically identical, regardless of the cube type you have to feed it to get power and the auction phase for these is very basic and very straight forward.

However there seemed to be no way to stop a run away leader, once you have more houses, you get more money which lets you buy more houses which gets you more money. Sigh

Board is very busy and gets quite cluttered making it difficult to see the various costs.

Given to university game society (2011).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Short version: 

Power Grid is a brain-burny, calc heavy, optimization game. I'm willing to play it again, but have serious reservations about the computation necessary for play. 

Longer version:

Power Grid is one of those games that succeeds at what it's trying to do, which is being a brain burner. Unfortunately I didn't find much enjoyment in the process. The whole affair feels overwrought, and the last 30-60 minutes are a journey into computational hell. While I have no problem in doing the math required in my head, I get a feeling that this game could have been a lot stronger if it had been shortened and tightened up. It feels overly muscular, to the point of distraction. The enjoyment of the first 30-60 minutes quickly evaporated as the game went on. The end game is like slogging through mud, with a calculator in one hand, and a pistol with a single bullet in the other. The calculator is used for keeping track of all the fiddly bits, and the pistol is for finishing yourself off when you realize that your chances of winning are slender. While the game we played was a learning game, 4 people and 3 hours, it was apparent to me about 30 minutes before finish that I wouldn't win. While winning isn't the major reason I come to the gaming table, I wish the conclusion had been slightly more ambiguous. When the game finally does end, it does so in a very unsatisfactory manner. There's no sense of accomplishment and the victory conditions seem arbitrary and off center. As far as I'm concerned, the number of cities needed to trigger the end game should be significantly less. Also, available cash should be taken into account in the final reckoning, instead of just as a tie breaker. I'd play this game again, but I wouldn't be very happy about it.  

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Finally played this one.  Believe the hype - this is an incredibly satisfying game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
POWER GRID: Played 10+ times with 2,3,5, and 6 players. Replayability seems better than I originally thought. Great economic/route-building game. Power plant theme very well applied. This game is UGLY, but very nice. Challenging, unique, but easy to learn and play. Don't expect a visual feast, but expect a good game. I think 8 cities is too short and 22 cities is too long. Maybe happy medium of 14? My rating history: 9|8|9|8

RATING: 7
Believe the hype: it's that good.  This game feels like a cross between 1830 and Medieval Merchant.  I can't even tell you how many different possibilities you have during your turn.  Careful planning and judicious use of money and ressources is a must.  I lost my first game because I spent too much on garbage.  However, I lost by about 10E, which shows how close everyone is to one another.  Update: after several plays, I see a pattern emerge.  There are two factors which I find will make or break a player's chances: positionning on the board and luck of the draw for the plants during auction.  The first one is something that can be controlled, or should I say policed as everyone needs to be careful not to let one player monopolize the better building spots.  Not all areas are created equal on either the German and the much worse US map.  Even more so if played with fewer than the full 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Dynamic gameplay is the crowning jewel of PowerGrid on top of a super-solid and enjoyable set of game mechanics. Every play is influenced by number of players, the order in which power plants show up, location, etc to the point where you never feel like you can completely reuse your strategy from last time. And the juggling of money, resources, and growth is extremely well balanced; there are no situations where you are fighting against a flaw or oversight in the design. The stages of the game also move appropriately quickly.

Additional maps and power plants only make an already great game more compelling.

The instructions and mixup of terms like 'step' and 'phase' in various places are confusing if you're trying to teach yourself, but gameplay itself is actually very straightforward if someone explains the game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
With expansion: Italy / France map
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I've played this game 2 or 3 times. This is an OK game that I could be convinced to play occasionally, but isn't on my top list of games I want to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of our favorites.  We love the quality of the parts and board.  A family favorite when we can play for an hour or more.  With experienced players, and with 4 or less players, I complete a game in about 50 minutes.  Several techniques can be applied to increase playtime efficiency.  Assign tasks.  Put someone in charge of the power plant market.  Another person should be responsible for the resources market.  Make someone the banker and handle payment of money when powering plants.  I have also found that poker chips speed up the game considerably, once everyone gets the denominations worked out.

I still prefer the USA map, but probably most of all because of general familiarity.  The comments I've read about the huge advantge going to those who start in the East Coast is just inexperience.  I've played about 30 games in-person and over 150 on-line @ BSW.  I've seen many many games won by starting in midwest and western states.  The France map is fun, I love the competition over Paris.

Complaints about the end game I think miss the point of Power Grid.  Of course the last turn, or often the second last turn, decides who wins.  But would you rather have a runaway leader early in the game?  The most enjoyable part of this game is the last few turns and how you need to set yourself up to be in the strongest position in almost every turn you make in the game leading up to that point.  

The most common mistake I see people make is to over-buy power plants.  I tend to minimize how often I purchase plants and spend like crazy when the plants I need become available.  

Another strategy I see misused often is to overbuy resources.  For maybe a dozen games I've seen that strategy impact the winning of the game, but rarely.  Though one of the most memorable winning experiences I had was exactly because of a last minute manuver to starve out the leader because they didn't plan it out well.  If you do not understand the game, end game will mess you up.  If you plan well throughout the game -- purchase what you need, manage your resources and money wisely, the endgame will never surprise you.

The only real issues in the game is that if you don't understand how to win and play against players who do, luck will never help you win.  This truly is a strategy game.  To win the game you have to plan and remain strong through almost the entire game.  Being in first place through most of the game usually does not win, although I've done that and won too.  Winning at Power Grid is a really fine balance of choices you make many times throughout the game.

I think the game is flawless.  It's a deep strategy game with very little luck (order of power plants is it).  Mixing casual gamers with competitive strategy gamers usually doesn't work.  But when players all have a few experienced plays of the game, it's very tight for the entire duration of play, and very much a multiple player strategy game in execution.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Thanks to our 2010 Secret Santa for giving us this! Despite its heavy game reputation, it really isn't that complex or difficult. We've accumulated PG maps irrationally quickly, and here's the order in which I'm interested in playing them (only maps we own so far):

11) Russia (hard mode - saving for later)
12) China (hard mode - saving for much later)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I've improved even more at the game and understand turn order, managing plant upgrade plans, selecting the right resources while looking at turn order, and when it's okay to be early in turn order.

The power plants and resource prices are still clever. However the game is still a fiddly Frankenstein's monster of rules, and the gameplay too reliant on combinatorial searches combined with arithmetic (the connections) - the very elements I most dislike! Additionally, decision-making is far too sequential, which limits planning ahead (and lengthening the game), and you can get burned on the randomness of the plants coming out.

I recommend Factory Manager as an alternative about balancing different elements and exploiting turn order.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[Auction, Network Connection, Economic] {6P:5, 5P:7, 4P:7, 3P:6, 2P:5} Recommended by my Geekbuddies (17 ratings, 8.38 average) - [Played both on BSW and F2F; have played with 2,3,4,5 and 6] - Power Grid is an interesting game. It looks great, reading the rules gives one a feeling of substance, and actually playing the game is interesting. However, I felt that it doesn't impart the tension and angst that the *great* gamers' games do. The mechanisms of the game feel unelegant and clunky, like they were cobbled together. The whole player order thing feels a bit "engineered". And this seems to be a game that almost always has a winner determined by the first tiebreaker (cash on hand), simply because the victory condition (cities powered) is something that more than one player can attain with a bit of planning. However, I can't deny that despite all this, the groups I played with were impressed and generally had fun. For me, it was OK, a pretty good game that I would play any time, but it's definitely not a top-tier offering in the class of Puerto Rico, Princes of Florence and Euphrat & Tigris. (On rereading - how can comments on a good game sound so negative? Oh well, maybe it was the high expectations. Not a huge favorite, but extremely versatile and replayable, especially when the expansion maps are released.) *** UPDATE: Power Grid has been getting heavy F2F play, and while it's become a favorite of some of my gaming group, it's slipped just a bit more in my eyes. After people grasped the concepts of the game, we've been falling into the dreaded "Step 2 Stall" where no one wants to connect 7 until plant capacity is near or at 17, and where the best thing to do is nothing. You can tell that several turns of doing nothing but firing existing plants makes for a really boring midgame while players wait for the "permanent" (capacity 5 & 6) plants to appear in the market. You go through the drudgery of crappy plants cycling away and no connections for several turns while players stockpile cash. Sound strategy, but freaking boring. Down to a 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Rules Complexity: :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Strategic Depth: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Luck Factor :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Negotiation Factor: :nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Amount of Downtime: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Fiddliness: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Component Quality: :star::star::star::star::star:
Player Interaction: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
"Take That" Conflict: :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:

I'm not as enamoured with this  game as many others, but I'm not exactly sure why.  There's a lot of math involved, and can be subject to some severe analysis paralysis.  The game can be strongly influenced by what order the power plant cards come up for auction.  There are times where a lucky draw near the end of an auction round can produce a huge unexpected advantage to one player, which is a little more luck than I would like for this type of a long game.  But overall, I still enjoy it and see it as a solid game.

RATING: 8
The game has, IMNSHO, changed for the better with the introduction of the new board and new rules.  The cumbersome element of drawing your powerlines has been removed and a much tighter, strategic game results from the new connection system.

Of course, when I say "better" this doesn't mean the old one is not an excellent game - on the contrary it is.  Besides this, the crayon element will always appeal more to some.

UPDATE 20DEC07:  After playing last night I am starting to become a little less enamoured by the game.  For what must be the fourth time in about a dozen games I have watched helplessly as somebody else has been handed the game.  This is a disappointing aspect, but not enough yet for me to lower it to a 7.  If I find the game continues to be prone to this situation then I might have to lower the rating.  Having said that, this is probably down to inexperienced play.

RATING: 8
I don't win often but I do really enjoy this game. It offers a depth of strategy that is missing from other simple games, and each time you play can be widely different as the evolving plant market and the choices you make can really influence how the game develops.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I really don't get the hype.  I've played a few times with a variety of numbers of players, and none of those has been fun.  The problem for me: the game really has no flow, and no payoff.  Each turn has basically 3 jerky steps: auction, resource purchase, get income.  And when endgame happens, there is no sense of satisfaction.  I usually win, but for some reason there is no feeling of accomplishment in doing so.  Maybe it's the theme, maybe it's the endless tiny bits, maybe it's the work you have to go through each turn (how many coal get replenished on THIS map with FOUR people during phase TWO??).  It seems to have an unneccesary amount of bulk (in bits AND rules) for little return.  I probably won't even buy this one just to have in the collection.  Maybe if I find it at a garage sale for 50 cents.... There's better stuff out there; I have NO IDEA how this monster is so high on BGG.

(I was glancing at some of the other reviews and noticed somewhat referred to theme of the game as "depressing".  I couldn't put my finger on it until then!  That was perfect!  I thought it was just somewhat unsatisfying, but now that I think about it, that's not the whole story.  As I play it and build stuff and collect garbage to power it I actually DO get depressed.  We joke about the brownouts when we don't have enough power for our cities, or that we have posh residents with high-end power demands when we have an abundance.  But those jokes are always tinged with bitterness.  Maybe I'm taking this game too seriously...)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very fiddly game. By consulting the appropriate chart, we see that if there are 4 players, coal is replenished at a rate of 5 units per round, then at 6, then at 4. With 5 players it's 5-7-5, with 6 it's 7-9-6. I keep waiting for someone to say, "Except on Tuesday!" Meanwhile, power plants disappear from the market at the rate of one per round, but then there's a kind of leap day at the end of step 1 where you discard another one... just to make everything work out right. Aaaaack! Much more fun than it has any right to be.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Route-building game with interesting elements like an auction round and a fluctuating resource market. Rules can be bit fiddly.

The player order system means that Power Grid is an economic snowball game in which do not really want to be first until right before the game ends, and much depends on timing. Somehow feels oddly limiting to me.

Update: I realize I'm less impressed with each additional play. The power plant auction is the single most important phase of the game, closely followed by player order considerations that get more urgent as the end of the game approaches. Considering how little game time those two things actually take it is rather obvious that the game carries a lot of uninspired excess baggage around with it. Downgrading from 7 to 6.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is my favorite game. I like it b/c the whole game from start to finish is so involving. I love the first couple rounds of Monopoly, but after that I hate it. Power Grid is like the first rounds of Monopoly, but it never goes bad. Its the best of area control with none of the bad. Love it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What an excellent game. Deceptively simple - the whole game, after all, is just buying things - but the way those three different classes of thing interlink, the way you have to time things, the way you have to know when to hold back and when to rush forward... the art is charming, the different maps FEEL different without being finicky rules-chaff, the game has a sense of slow, building progression AND an all-out exciting climax when everything you do matters and everything is on a knife-edge. One of only two games that makes me head hurt with the stress of playing it (the other is Haggis)... but it's the good kind of stress. So exhilarating.

RATING: 7
Kraftwerk als Brettspiel. Friedemanns Friese einziges und letztes Spiel als überdauerndes Lebenswerk: das kapitalistische Wirtschaftsspiel mit klassischem Geldschein, das Monopoly nie gewesen ist. Rechenexempel und Mathehausaufgabe, Setzspiel, Wettlauf, Zocken, Erdkunde. Zeitlose Old School aus der Welt der Versteigerungsspiele, im charismatischen Look von Maura Kalusky, der dem grün gefärbten Mathemann früh in der Zeit eine visuelle Identität verlieh. Man darf FUNKENSCHLAG getrost zu den wenigen Werken von SANKT PETERSBURG bis TADSCH MAHAL zählen, die altern ohne zu altern und dem Rechner als Künstler ein regelmässiges GEMA-artiges Einkommen sichern, das sich zufrieden zählen lässt. Die Energie hat sich gelohnt.

RATING: 6.7
2016
====

Power Grid is the kind of game that I've found myself drawn to more and more over the past three years -- economic auction games with simple rules and some nice tension. I enjoy the bit of randomness in the power plant deck, though it has bitten me more than once. The best for of PG for me is the bevy of expansion options currently available. For my money, I'm betting that The Robots and The Stock Companies are great fun.

RATING: 8

Nonetheless I think it is a bit overbalanced. Although some players usually follow worse strategies then the others, point-wise all our games end up very tight. But this is just a minor complaint, altogether I find Power Grid to be a very well designed game.

RATING: 10
Arrived in mail, 5/26/04. After 7 plays... This is an excellent game. However, it is still playing a bit long for us. It took 5 newbies nearly 3 hours to complete our first game. All who have played have enjoyed it, but it doesn't make it out as often as shorter games on our game night since we only have a few hours to play. However, it is undoubtedly one of the better games in my collection. I also have the France/Italy board, but have only played once (France), with 4 plays on the German board, and 2 on the USA board.

RATING: 9
Power Grid is a very strong economic game.  You really do feel like you're building a network of power lines, with real power plants running the show.  The auction phase is exciting; the resource buying and upkeep feels completely natural; the connecting to cities has a nice Euro blockage feel; the balancing and turn order mechanics are perfect.  Apart from the constant mathwork, stages/rounds/phases confusion and some last-player catch-up issues, Power Grid is an awesome game and worthy of any game-shelf.

RATING: 9

RATING: 10
My most favorite economic game so far. It's got it all - supply and demand, increasing resource scarcity, cool bidding mechanic (I especially like the "future market"), cost/benefit calculations, and several ways to screw your opponents. Plus it is very thematic - different kinds of power plants, real-world map, etc. One of the rare games that I don't think will ever "get old" for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Tense auctions, sacrificing income to switch turn orders in able to benefit later.  This game is brilliant, and the art is wonderful.  This one brings out the white knuckles and competetive nature in every one.

update: this one suffers from the sameyness feeling.  The engine is sound, but each ride feels like another.  The randomness in the cards is deceptive, it doesn't make Power Grid feel like a game built on chance but if the timing isn't in your favor then too bad.  this is often countered by a stalling in the game that can drag.  The late game mathematics also can slow this to a halt.  8 to 7.

Update:  The computations involved in Power Grid aren't complex but they are constant.  The overtly mathematical nature of this game is a distraction for me, as it really punishes players that are more intuitive in their gaming style or like a steady flow.  I find Power Grid offers too little reward for the investment made in both time and thought.  It still is a strong design, it just is becoming less the style of game I choose to play.  Maybe supplying each player with a calculator would aid in my opinion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I haven't given this enough plays to make a definitive pronouncement, but I've really enjoyed it so far.  People griping about "no meaningful decisions" puzzle me. I usually have plenty of variables to crunch through during my down time, most of them involving my opponents as well as my own state: plant placement, resource availability/hoarding, auction market, phase timing, etc. Not a lot of it spans beyond the next turn, but I don't really see that as a detraction (my brain can only retain so much at a time). The opportunism in this game is one of its most intriguing aspects. It feels satisfying and fun to my family but I guess it comes down to how much... arithmetic & opportunism you can tolerate.

Expansions owned:

[b][thing=108667][/thing][/b]

RATING: 7.5
A very good money-based simulation of (power-generation) industry, in terms of balancing purchasing power stations (capital expenditure), fuel for the stations (running costs), and cities to power (market costs). The game is well-balanced and the motif is very suitable for the mechanic.

RATING: 6

PG is balanced in a way that makes the finish always a very close one but at the same time rather anticlimactic. 

Also the game seems TOO RANDOM for a heavy 2h game because of the way the power plants show up on the market. 

In the end it feels like chance is too big a factor in determining the winner.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
A true classic in all respects. It accommodates 2 to 6 players very well (although with 2 the Robots expansion is recommended) and offers a lot of different game mechanics in about 2 hours time: auction/bidding, money management, resource management, network building. It's tense, it's fun, it features unique theme and artwork and has a lot of replayability, with or without the plethora of available expansions.
As for the components, to me the little wooden houses and paper money are a clever and revealing choice: this is truly the 21th Century equivalent of Monopoly!

EDIT: As of now (June 2013) I own every official expansion and promo cards ever released for the game and it's probably the crown jewel of my board game collection!

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Power grid plays out in a number of very logical phases (buy power plants, buy resources, build the grid, power cities).  Somehow, these pieces all come together to form something greater than the sum of the parts.  While it begins as a straightforward game of optimizing an economy, in the final third of the game Power Grid evolves into a riveting contest of psychology, timing, and aggressive bidding.  

It can tend to play a little long, especially for groups who suffer from AP.

This has gone over surprisingly well with inexperienced board gamers.  The concepts are pretty easy to pick up.

RATING: 9
This was a great game, lots of mechanics to keep people competative, lots of interaction. RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
I've only played the game twice and I've got to concur with someone who described this game as "relentless number crunching."  Which is OK, I teach math on the high school level, but 3 hours is way too long (based on a five player game...I shudder to think what a 6 player would be like.)  I don't like the positional screwage aspect of the game where you can get elbowed out of the game fairly early, and in a long game that is unforgivable.  Tight money management is too complex; Saint Petersburg does this ever so much better.

10 years later - A 3rd play confirms my original take on this game.  I could get roped into playing Power Grid again; it's not outside the realm of possibility.  But it would be such a waste of good gaming time.

RATING: 9.5
Art & Production - :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Theme & Narrative - :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Mechanic Elegance - :star::star::star::star::star:
Replayability & Fun - :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
X-Factor/Originality - :star::star::star::star::nostar:

Grand Total - 20.5/25

Pound for pound one of the tightest pieces of game design. Every mechanic flows and impacts upon each other offering one of the finest and richest concoctions of tactical depth and accessible fun. A great advert for supreme playtesting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of those love-or-hate games, I really like to play this game with a group that all really love this game... but there are so many (in my area) that simply doesn't like playing this.  Myself, I like this game, I like how the game mechanics emulates the increase cost of environmentally unfriendly fuels as time moves on and rewards those that invest in future technology.  In other words, I like the continually changing pricing system.  Very nice.  I don't like the look of the board much, not that it matters much to practial me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
WOW! Brainburning is what you will feel after a game. There are REALLY many decisions to be made and every single one matters. And all that achieved by a very simple set of rules. Another game that requires a lot of concentration but rewards you with a fantastic feeling when you will do everything right.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Pros:
* The design is very cool and retro. To me it's a great looking game.
* The energy market, simulating supply and demand, is a super idea.
* Fierce auctions where bluffing and manipulation are big components
* Managing your economy and setting aside just enough for three different areas of spending is tricky - in a very good way.

Cons:
* Refilling of energy market is way too generous. Needs tweaking.
* Lame and dull auctions if the players don't realize the importance.
* I feel that you get too much money, or maybe things are too cheap.
* Rich-get-richer, runaway leader problems.
* Player interaction is a bit too limited
* The maps have areas that in my mind are clearly better than others
* Step 3 is usually very short if it exists at all. Not a big problem, it just feels a bit weird.


Gameplay with 
2 Players: Only good as a learning experience. Would never play again
3 Players: Too easy, not enough contention. Everyone can be part of every city - which I feel is just too nice.
4 Players: This works very well. But if you feel (like I do) that there is not enough tension in the game, adjust the energy market to refill as per the 3 player rules. This makes things much more enjoyable. Solves or lessens much of the problems I have with the game. 
5 Players: Not tried yet
6 Players: This also worked well, but not quite as good as the 4 player game. Auctions are a bit more interesting but also takes a lot more time. I was surprised that the map felt so roomy even with one area off limits (6 players, 5 areas). Energy market refill rate is seriously off in this case. Even when refilling as if we were five players instead of six, it still felt way too generous.


The economy management is nice and you're always worried that the extra electro you had to spend on the shiny new power plant will actually prevent you from buying enough resources, or expanding into the economically attractive area you had your eye on.
Player interaction is limited to the power plant auction (jacking up the price of the plant you think your opponents need the most, and manipulating/bluffing them into taking plants you're not interested in), driving up the prices on resources (not always an option because there is a limit to what and how much you can buy), completely depleting a resource (thus driving your opponents out of that market), and expanding into your opponents areas (to make it more expensive for them to expand). I don't know if those methods aren't effective enough or if my group simply aren't using them enough. But in all of our games, the "leader" (player with the most cities) on the second turn has won the game. Adjusting the energy market has made the games closer, tougher and much more fun, but it is still not a big hit with me.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
It's quite difficult for me to rate this game.

On one hand simply awesome mechanics - everything works just perfectly.

On the other hand - the game is quite dry (buy power plants, buy resources, buy stations, sell - earn money and so on) and mathy (constant counting). It's hard (at least for me) to evaluate how other players are performing and what should I do to stop them from winning. I also can't calculate how many stations they can buy (in fact at the end of a game it's hard to calculate how many stations I will be able to buy), so I bid for power plants and buy resources tentatively. Because of that the final result is quite unpredictable and you can sometimes lose by a few Elektro because you bid to much. 
To sum up, during the game I'm having fun, although I don't feel I can control the game. When the game ends I usually feel some frustration.

Overall rating: 7,5/10. Hadn't it been the brilliant mechanics it would be only 6/10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
[b]Funkenschlag[/b] [i]Friedemann Frisse 2004[/i] 
Its rules are easy to learn but it is not as easy to master it. Many different options, strategies and tactics. Almost all the games are really close till the end of the session, adding a lot of tension to the game. Nice auctions, good mechanics for the reposition of the materials and a lot of interaction in the laying of the electrical substations. I love it: fantastic euro that plays very well with four to six players. Only problem: keep it away from AP players because at the end of the game they can dramatically drag it out. Expansions maps add replayability but are not a must have since the core game is enough to keep you busy for a long time (it has a double sided USA and Germany map. I only own the china/corea exp map).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Did I mention that Power Grid is fun?  Anyone for a game?

RATING: 10
A monster of a game! Though after a few turns, things get naturally in place, and rules are tweaked in such a way (turn order, resource market...) that it's difficult to run away with the lead, or to get too far back... Still, every move counts and helps you set up the end game, which is usually fairly tense. -- I've been surprised once, when after a few boring turns with everybody at 6-7 cities, a player suddendly got victory by building 8 cities at once and powering 8 cities while all the other players could only power 7 or less. D'oh! Won't happen again, grumble grumble.

RATING: 8
I keep thinking this is an intro game for non-euro gamers.
It is not.

I love the auction.  I love competing for real estate.

I wish this game was 90 minutes, and it feels like it should be, but it just isn't, unless everyone is on their game.  I feel like I need to keep things moving when we play.  A lot of - "okay, now your turn to build...."

I don't think I've ever played this game where all the people playing loved games, but I could see it as an exceptional game in that context.  Until then, it remains at an 8.  It's a game I can't seem myself ever getting rid of as long.

RATING: 8
Rewards multiple strategies, adapting to an ever-changing market of power plants and resources, and demands that players think ahead to win. Great introduction to Euro-style games. Game works best with 3 or more players. A little more challenging to teach to newcomers, but certainly not impossible.

Fantastic game that rewards multiple strategies and adapting to change. Downsides are that the mechanics don't work as well with 2 players and certain areas of the board a very unbalanced, making startup costs for one player much more expensive unnecessarily.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great economic style game with very original theme and nice network building mechanic.

Pros:
+ Very original theme,
+ Much of calculations in game, which forces people to use smooth mathematical skills (useful in real life too),
+ The game is long enough to keep decisions strategic.

Cons:
- The game end becomes quite suddenly and the players often have no time to prepare for it,
- The winner in many cases can be the most successful player particularly at the last round,
- The move order is quite fixed and motivates to be last, not lead while playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A remarkably simple game once you understand the mechanics.  It's still a challenge to manage your money.  When, oh when do you buy that new plant to replace your old ones..?  This is an improvement over the original, Funkenschlag.  Better components, and a much quicker gameplay since they removed the (superfluous, imho) route drawing mechanic.  Use poker chips rather than the paper money to further streamline the playing time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
Stolen from: http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/66085/real-games-of-genius

Today, we salute you, Overly-condescending game player

(Overly-condescending game player!)

We ask you to play and you say "Sure, I could use a laugh". Clearly your mountains of skill tower over us, but you let us marvel in your awesomeness.

(You guys can play for second!)

Even when things go bad for you, you're not afraid to let us know it was just luck. You tell us your only mistake was assuming we had a deeper understanding of the game. Clearly we witnessed a fluke.

(Come on, what are the chances!)

So crack open an ice cold bud light, Master of the Game, because without you, we might develop the false impression we were good at something.

(Overly-condescending game player!) 

Sold in Make room for baby 2016 auction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I prefer Power Grid to the 1st edition Funkenschlag because (1) the shorter length is nice, (2) it's less prone to long stagnant periods, and most importantly, (3) the pre-drawn routes eliminate the biggest headache (and waste of time) from the 1st edition.  However, the streamlining comes with a price attached.  In the original Funkenschlag there was more time and space for interesting maneuvering in the middle and late stages of the game: manipulating the turn order at just the right time, choosing how to pace yourself and when to pounce, looking for good intermediate-level power plants before you had to turn your attention to your game-winning plants.  Some of the subtlety and strategic breadth is lost in Power Grid.  Players have to start building their game-winning plants very early in the game, exacerbating the luck of the draw associated with the ordering of the power plants within the deck.   See my Spiel des Josh 2004 GeekList for more detailed thoughts.

RATING: 6
This game is very balanced - almost too balanced. Its hard to really fall behind. I think it is better to be in the lead even though you get last choice at everything than to hang back in order to get first choice, because you probably won't get that late boost you would need in order to win.

Playing the China/Korea board with the new card deck made this fun for me again. The power plants were agonizingly limited so one wrong choice and you were done for. I don't know if that was a variant or had to do with the new deck or what but it was great.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It impresses me how much game you can fit in relatively few mechanics. It’s simple, but not simplistic. It’s tense, but not because of lack of strategy, but because there can be very close a near failure and total victory. If I’m going to teach a good and a little meatier euro, this would probably be it.

I think it plays well with the number of players I have played with, which is four, five and six. It is tense with any number, but I probably like it better with the lower number of players as it seems to be less chaotic (especially in the auctions). Two maps are supplied in the game and I have played them both. Of those I think I prefer the German side over USA.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.2
I think I've had this game on this list for over 12 months now and last night I finally got a chance to play it and it did not disappoint! I really enjoy the interconnected nature of the auctions, your money, the connections between cities and the cost of cities. Someone in my group compared this game to Hansa Teutonica and I can see that comparison, but I like the greater simplicity of Power Grid more. Not having any experience with the game, it was hard to factor in what to pay for the various plants early in the game and I didn't realize how important it was to get in the way of some of your opponents to prevent them from building cities super cheaply early in the game (especially in the Northeast corner of the U.S. map), but overall this is a system I want to explore more and a game that could easily find its way into my collection at some point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played eight times, four times with four, twice with five and twice with six. I like the game, though it does have its rough edges; it scores big on theme and graphic design, but it's unforgiving and a bit labor-intensive for my taste. Also, games where one finds one's self in a position where the only sensible move is to stall are a pet peeve of mine. Some people feel like too much of the game boils down to how the plant cards show up, and I can see how that might be true.

I'm never going to play with six players again; the game just goes on way, way too long. 

Another thought: I really like having a calculator handy when playing this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm always up for a game of PG - better played on BSW to cut down on the downtime. :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A game that I admire, more than enjoy. The escalation mechanics that gradually make power plants obsolete even as new parts of the grid open up for competition are very clever. The game is essentially about solving an equation each turn, and I think the absence of a random factor or hidden information hurts the endgame a bit (in terms of excitement), but this is a satisfying game, where the players are almost always engaged, and it moves right along. Let down by a deterministic and number-crunching endgame that practically demands mini-maxing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.75
I really like this game a lot.  Every time I play it just makes me want to play it again to try a new strategy.  I like that there are multiple facets to success.  Your power plants, your resources, and your network.  The game does take time to play (I seem to average around 3 hrs with beginners), but I think that comes down if playing with more experienced players.  In addition I rarely feel that there's downtime as I've got to plan my finances, what I want to buy vs. what I need to buy.  A wonderful game.

RATING: 10
I really like this game.  I like the "bits", the cards and the fact that there is expansion boards.  

I like the money aspect and the bidding aspect as it can really level out the game between players.  

This game has a lot of good strategy and doesn't leave a bad vibe between players in the game.  Not that I am a touchy feely player or anything like that but I don't like games that can have one player announcing after 1 turn that the game is over.   Axis and Allies is the classic game where you roll bad on the first round...its game over.  And a game that takes 30 minutes to setup and 5 minutes of play and 10 minutes to take down ....in my opinion is not a good game....oh wait I should be giving my evaluation of Power Grid here.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Gameplay feels very smooth and polished. The basics of the game are pretty simple, enough that this is what I'll use to introduce new players into heavy games. The sheer depth of calculation that can be put into every choice is staggering: a distinct math-y, think-y kind of game. Interesting leader control dynamic trying to balance your own expansion with allowing your opponent more opportunities.

Only big issue I've had with this game is the time commitment, but the end tends to still have everyone as riveted to the game as the start. The wording in the game bugs me a bit as well, "phases" and "steps" always end up backwards in my head intuitively. A bit bland too, but the generic theme helps with its position as a starting point for heavier games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
All games are tight games. After a few play it's clear how one of the best strategies is just to wait and play last, amassing Elektros and build 7-8 cabins at the same time. We use a house rule setting the limit of cabin one can build in a turn to 4-5. Kingmaking can be a problem too.

RATING: 5
I won't argue against this being a great game. I just don't enjoy playing it very much. 

The mechanics and theme are fantastic, and the rounds are broken up in a way that keeps you nearly constantly engaged. I just find that every time I play I find myself wishing that it had ended about 45 minutes sooner. I'm always burned out for the last few rounds. And that's a problem because the last few rounds are where the game is won or lost. Money and space is so tight at that point that you really need to plan out your moves down to the dollar. I don't have the energy at that point, and I'm not in the mood for waiting while people with more energy spend 10 minutes doing math in their head to make the optimal play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Just got this, along with the France/Italy expansion. Have played a few full games already, which were superb, so I believe this is going to be one of my top rated games ever.

What I like about Power Grid is the balancing act that you have to do... there are effectively 4 commodities that must be balanced. Firstly Money; Secondly Power Plants and power generation; Thirdly Fuel Resources... required to run the Power Stations and Fourthly network size... Money is required to obtain the other 3, which then combine to generate money again and so on. There's plenty of maths required to play Power Grid, as well as a bit of a head for business.. and there's a very clever and slightly volatile decision tree too. Although I haven't played the game very much yet, I am just so excited by it and I can tell it's going to be one of my highest rated games.

RATING: 7
Great economic growth game.  The only drawbacks are that strategies are seldom affected as much as they should be by all but the newest map expansions, and the fairly rigid strategy involved.  More of an game of measuring cost-benefit and efficiency than thinking outside of the box, and very little sense of the thrill of risk.  I'm always engaged, but rarely surprised by any action.  I always feel like I'm in control of my fate, but don't feel much tension until the later parts of the game.  Good elements of timing, but I find Imperial to be more complex in this regard.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
best euro game I have played, although Automobile and Formula D/De are in the running.

includes France/Italy, Benelux/Central Europe, China/Korea, Brazil/Spain & Portugal and Russia/Japan, new power plant cards, and robots.

Maps:

Germany:  always a good choice
United States:  average, high connection costs
Benelux:  fast play due to plant discard
Spain & Portugal:  a pointless nuke rule
India:  resource bidding rule is glacial and the blackout special rule is pointless.
Russia:  great map, resource and plant constraints make it a cut-throat experience.

New power plants:

I do not like the new power plant cards - they are too efficient and the game is less interesting without the resources being constrained.

Robots:

robot play #1; single player with 3 robots in France.
human:  19 cities, 16 power, $138 cash
robot #1:  3 cities, 6 power, $66 cash
robot #2:  10 cities, 10 power, $205 cash
robot #3:  12 cities, 11 power, $183 cash

a single player can place all the robots right next to each other, so that probably needs some rules help.  robot #1 stalled due to bidding up to +10 on power plants and buying all resources; he was cash starved.  robot #2 was slow due to 'buys the first choice' allowed the player to manipulate him into low power and 'only supplied cities' then kept his cities low.  robot #3 was limited to 1 city in phase I and 2 cities in phase II, keeping him from keeping pace with the player, who completed the game just as phase III started.

all-in-all, I think the robots should be good for 2-3 players, while just adequate for solitaire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 6
Interesting mix of genres: It's at the same time a connection, economic and auction game. It works, but maybe too much effort was put into assuring everyone is in the game until the end. The catch-up mechanic, based on turn order, is just too strong. Although in my only play I did manage to stay in the lead most of the time and win, I felt I was much more punished than rewarded for that. If I hadn't won when I did, I'd likely have lost the game in the next round - to any of three other players. Holding back seems to be a very good strategy. Another problem is that whenever a power plant is bought in an auction, a new random one is drawn, meaning a lucky player can get a much better plant for its minimum cost.
