=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Favorite game of all time! This game just sucked me in from the first time I played it. I am really not even that good at it, but it is absolute genious. It is a medium to heavy weight euro-styled economic game. Very little luck with amazing board play. If you don't like mathy decisions, it may be difficult for you, but it's really simple equations on what the optimal move is to get where you want to get by paying the least. The game is different every time you play it because you do not use the same board spaces in every game and the players really dictate how the bidding will work. Also, there is plenty of player interaction in most every aspect of this game.  The catch up mechanic is genius so that those who have never played before, will still have a chance, but when you are playing with experienced gamers, they use the catch up mechanic to their advantage. There are many maps and promos to expand your experience and the artwork is phenomenal. This game is a great game for those people who loved monopoly when they were on the "dark-side" of gaming ;) and it was a hefty step up from the route building found in Ticket to Ride. Will play this game in most situations and won't really turn it down, even though it can be a longer game. Plays up to 6, if you're brave. Really a game that I will be growing with for the rest of my life. Go buy this game, it deserves your investment.

RATING: 8
I only played this game once and it didn't take too long to learn. It's not exactly the theme that I normally get into or gravitate toward, but after playing it I was pleasantly surprised at how much fun it was and how cool it was. I like the way the supply and demand of commodities is represented and can dictate different strategies during the game, as well as the auctions for the power plants. I like the way it balances with the last place player getting to buy commodities first. 

I guess the only thing that I wasn't sure about, is why would someone buy property out west (in U.S. map) when it cost so much and the eastern half of the U.S. was easier to build and power. Perhaps there's a reason and in only playing once, I wasn't able to see it.

RATING: 8

So far I've won every time I've played, but have seen the game come down to the last decision on the last play, or even been a run-away blow out.  Bidding on power-plants really seems to be a fine art in this game, and with the random factor of some plants not even existing in the game I can see a lot of replay value in the future.  Looking forward to trying the other varient boards in the future.

RATING: 7
Joc econòmic de subastes on els jugadors han d'optimitzar l'inversió del seu capital generant energía mitjançant la compra de centrals eléctriques (per subasta) i la construcció d'una xarxa de distribució. Les subastes son molt interesants. L'interacció ve donada (a més de per les subastes) per la col·locació al taulell i per la compra de les materies primes necessaries per fer funcionar les centrals.

Joc molt matemàtic, pot tendir al AP si es vol optimitzar al màxim cada acció. Escala malament a menys de 4 jugadors, només recomanable a 4-5 (a 6 es pot fer una mica llarg).

RATING: 9
I have played this a lot, and it has rapidly become a favourite of the games that I own. Combines a lot of elements that might make a good game on their own - auction, connection building, resource management - and cobbles them together into a coherent whole, focussed around the balancing act of turn order. Timing your expansions and when to stay static and wait to get more advantageous turn order is the strategic heart of the game, with the purchasing of connections, resources and plants being more tactical. And both are thoroughly interesting, and impact on each other constantly in enjoyable ways. 

I like this an awful lot. Have invested in the expansion maps and am on the lookout for the new powerplant deck. Consistently satisfying. Just played 2 player for the first time and it wasn't as bad as I had been expecting. Balancing turn order seemed the most important thing, money seemed pretty readily available (played on France)

RATING: 8
One of my earliest favourite games. I like the fencing-like jockeying for position to be as close to last place as possible during the auctions, but still close enough to the leader for the final sprint in the right time. This game can cause some AP because it has elements that can be counted beforehand and others that can be predicted fairly accurately.

My pet peeve with this game: Players who say they don't like that the game is against the leader. If you are at the head of the pack, you are not the leader, you are a walking casualty of the true leader behind, not even knowing that you're already lost. This is also my favourite part sometimes, because it's fun to watch people who think they're doing good and brag about it, when you just know you will be able to feed those comments back to them in the final round. I have issues, I know. :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Basically, I think this game is too random.  You win by hitting all cylinders (making a big surge in cities and having enough energy to power them) at the right time, but it's very hard to know when the ending turn will happen... you have little control over it.  I hear that Funkenschlag (the German edition) has some additional control, because the fuel resources are limited enough that you can purposefully stall leaders by buying up all the fuel.

I really don't want to play this game again.  Whether I win or lose, I just feel like I have no control.  Sometimes, I feel like I have a chance to win, but the game ends a turn early.  Other times, I feel like I'm playing for 4th place (out of 5 or 6), and then due to some small perturbation, the game lasts one more turn, and I have a chance to win.  Yes, luck is a part of every game, but it's just not fun to try and build a strong position when there's no reward, when small things *regularly* make huge differences, game after game.  The game also gets bogged down in analysis paralysis, since you want to avoid all the small perturbations. For example, if I buy extra fuel this turn, will I be a little short of money during the building phase?  What if the players before me build in an unexpected direction and I have to pay more for my builds?  All of that has to be calculated before deciding how much to bid on a power plant, and sometimes before deciding which plant to bid on!  Not fun at all.

Update Sept 2014: 7->6
I'm not sure that I'm as enamored with this game anymore as it becomes explicitly clear that this game does not favour a mix of people playing differently. In other words, this game highly favours players who mathematically grind their options -- however, this also takes a fair bit more time when players do so. Personally, I prefer games where the valuation is unclear so that a playing by the seat of your pants is not only an option, but encouraged (which in turn shapes a good game flow).  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic game, with auctions, resource management, economics, fluctuating resource prices and network building. There is a catch-up mechanism in the game, making it close to impossible to lead the game from the start to finish. This makes timing critical- you have to position yourself to take the lead just when you need it towards the end. Understanding this balance is one of the keys to victory.

The auctions can be a lot of fun, and being able to evaluate the right price for a power plant is another key to success. I was somewhat sceptical to the auction, not thinking that is would go down well in my gaming group, but it has actually turned out to be very enjoyable. 

This game is, although it can be analytical, very fun. Rules are easy to learn - what separates the experienced player from a newbie is the ability to understand the timing, balance between expansion and capacity, and power plant prices. It may sound complicated, but it really isn't- after a game or two, most players will be at a level where they have winning chances. Can be tense towards the end, and victories are typically with small margins. One of the highest rated games on Board Game geek, and understandably so. It provides some depth, without being too complex for the mass market. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Time rolls on, and opinions soften. Bumped this up to a 6. I'm not saying this is a classic or anything, but after a four year break from it, it was a nice change of pace. It helps if I don't have to be banker, auction house manager, turn order tracker and fuel market filler.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My preferred mid-weight Euro-veined game. Every single phase of every single round, you can really feel the brilliance of the tight game design! Tailor-made for a really passive-aggressive crowd, as you can always indirectly hurt someone with every single decision you make (and directly if that's what you so choose). The rubber-banding mechanic forces all the players to play chicken on being the leader, and it makes the game feel unique for it. If your group is anything like mine, you end up harrowed over competing for very miniscule increases in efficiency during the auction phases; it can get tense. Power Grid is awesome awesome awesome, what else can I say?

I really want to play again and suspect that my rating for this will go up. The only fault is that the math is so important that it could grind the game to a halt if too much time is spent in calculating options, but the rewards for doing so were obvious in my first playing. But more than anything it comes down to when to make your move, which works for me since I'm a more seat-of-your-pants player.

RATING: 9

Just a great game. The mechanisms are clunky and the game seems to lurch along like Frankenstein's monster, but like Shelley's classic, it makes for a very entertaining ride. Games come down to the monetary tie-breaker far more often than one might expect, and it always has a cut-throat competitive feel. I like how the board "grows and shrinks" and resource renewal changes, acting to keep that competitiveness alive with different player counts. The expansions only add to the variability and calculated fun of this one.

RATING: 10
I played it first at the boardgame club and i was not sure if it is a good game or not. But fortunatelly my friend told me that it will be fantastic and it turned out that he was right. It has easy rules yet really mindblowing to think and plan ahead. I like that you start with crap power plants and just like in real life they are getting better and better over time. I love the fact that we invest money into power plants, resources, and city connections and after we earn the money for it.

Pros / Cons:
-I love the possibilities of blocking each other by getting the city first, or just buy all the resources and the get rid of an opponent power plant.
-I like the mechanism so if you are in the last place you buy the best and cheapest things, but you have to feel when to jump into the first place it is like a scale.
-Low luck factor is a big plus.

-I don't like the fact that to play a game takes 2 hours, i prefer to play till 1,5 hours but after the downtime just gets big calculating how to build cities in the end.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
10-11-09
I have an odd affinity for economic games.  Not that I'm particularly good at them, but they're very enjoyable to me.  Power Grid does a great job with the system it has.  The game itself feels different each time, depending on what plants are coming up, what the markets are doing, and what is available to build.  When you are trying to calculate down to the dollar on what you should do on your turn, you definitely feel the pressure, and it's especially interesting when you screw someone else by just the dollar or two they need.

The turn order mechanism is great too.  Even if you're behind in the buildings, and not making as much money, you get prime picks on everything else that round.  It's a very delicate balance of money, resource, and pacing mechanisms that I enjoy every time.

RATING: 8.75
For a game I like as much as this one, a more substantive comment is clearly necessary...

Power Grid, the industrial-looking, system-connecting, area-control, point-grabbing game with the funky and fairly demanding auctions.

This flagship 2F game is still satisfying, no matter when it gets pulled out, no matter what country the maps are overlaid upon.

Each year the new promo maps are hot grabs at Essen, because in it's essence this is a pretty nicely interactive game that rewards good play, the supports larger groups, that demands money management, resource control, a sense of timing and good judgement.

I don't always pull it out, because I don't always want that kind of time commitment, but it is always rewarding when I do- that's the essence of true classic game, and why this is the only top 10 BGG game that is in my personal top 5 games.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Power Grid is a modern classic, which has stood the test of time (13 years is a long time now in board game years), despite its flaws. In fact, some elements of Power Grid make it less streamlined than some of its newer counter parts, but I believe some of these elements make it that much more timeless.

First, let me list some of the "negatives" about Power Grid: it has a finicky setup, unintuitive round and game phase structure, analysis paralysis/lots of number crunching in the late game, and sometimes tedious game states. Furthermore, you have to play this game often to play it right - there is a lot of rule book searching during play. That's not to say Power Grid's mechanics are difficult, but there are quite a few very specific rules about what happens when, and the way the game evolves as you play does not make these game-state changes feel natural.

That said, I think it is partly because of these negatives that Power Grid is such a tense, albeit slow game. Power Grid has so much space for decision-making, and players actions are so intertwined in that space. Furthermore, even if one stage of the round is tedious or unchanging, it just makes the other stage(s) that much more important: sometimes the auctions are critical, sometimes the resource purchasing is the difference between a win and a loss, sometimes the actual location of your network is essential, sometimes the turn order matters, etc. I have seen late-game upsets and unconventional starts turn into wins. But it always seems like the player who plays the best, wins.

My biggest gripe of Power Grid is the game can produce a lot of Analysis Paralysis. It can grind to a halt if players overthink their turns. Over time, it moves faster, and also, it really is just part of the game. However, if players insist too much on analyzing and predicting every possible outcome, it will take some of the fun out of the game. I think all boardgames are about reacting and deciding in a reasonable timeframe, and may the best player win as a result. We may not always agree on what a reasonable timeframe, and maybe some players like that over analysis. However, most players will agree that some just take too long at Power Grid. I guess just push them along or get a stopwatch.

I love Power Grid. It isn't super streamlined, and someone will need to be referencing the manual most play-throughs, unless you get the game to the table all the time. It's easy to play a rule wrong or miss an upkeep condition. Nevertheless, Power Grid is tense and has an amazing space for making interesting decisions. The importance of different aspects and mechanics can change from game to game. Surprisingly, Power Grid is not super punishing to new players, but the best player in any game will likely win. The best player is the player to make the best decisionss in nuanced situations. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Now one of my favorite games, there are so many things I like about Power Grid. The supply/demand mechanic, giving the player in last an advantage to keep them relatively in the game, the auction mechanic for plants, and others. Not real fond of closing off a section of the map at times, but that's not enough to lower my rating below a 10. Great game with many things going on at once.

RATING: 9
I haven't win this game, but I still have enjoyed playing. There's so much to discover. Every decision you make is really important and affects to a lot of things, so you have to be sharp all the time. Very interesting game.

I've been playing with 3 players and I see some problems there. There's always room for each player to be in a city, so it doesn't create true conflict in that regard. I have a feeling that the game would be far more interesting with more players as you have to plan your network more carefully. I hope I can play this with more players some time.

There is lots of math in the game but it's not that difficult (it's only addition). It can be frustrating to calculate if your money is enough for the whole round to do all the stuff you want to do, but still it's not so bad.

Itching to play this one again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Although it is a brain-burner, requires three hours, and is relatively unforgiving, it is a fun game. It was one of the first Euro games I played, along with Puerto Rico, and Settlers of Catan. The auction/future market, the resources market, and "worst goes first" mechanics were like nothing I had ever experienced in any game. This could be considered my first "gateway" game, where I truly enjoyed it on its first play (previous attempts with PR and Princes of Florence made me roll my eyes in frustration). This opened my eyes to a world beyond Risk, Guesstures, Monopoly, Diplomacy, Titan, Talisman, and other Ameritrash games.

Update (06/13/09): Taught this to four newbies (two couples) at a game day. Surprisingly, all picked it up fairly quickly--just need to get through one turn to understand how the game works--although several hints were needed throughout the game to prevent disastrous moves. All enjoyed it and considered it a great game. With knowledgeable players, a 5-6P game will take no more than 2.5 hours.

Update (02/29/10): Played a custom Great Britain board. This 'system' has a plethora of game boards of a variety of geographical areas.

Update (06/18/10): Doesn't get played anymore as people think it is too long and complex. Where's the love?

Update (11/06/10): Under the seemingly civil exterior, this game can be competitive, nasty, and cut-throat: the calculated auctioning of power plants, the resource market manipulation, boxing in players' cities, and crafty posturing of the turn order. Oh, I love it, but some people could get turned off by it.

Update (10/14/2013) 13 plays: Ah, good ol' Power Grid... you are starting to show your age. It is tough to get people to play you nowadays, with all the shiny new games coming out, but especially with the rather random and chaotic nature of the power plant market and auction. Still, a "10" in my book.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
0406
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is long for the fun I get out of it. I want to like it, but I find it too fiddly and too tedious. I keep thinking that I'm not giving it a fair shake though so my rating is still tentative.

10/19/2014 update: This is, to me, the board game version of an Excel spreadsheet, and this is coming from someone who loves euros. The bidding is fun, but I find the rest of the game far too tedious. I'd still play this over many other games, but I think, if memory serves, I prefer something like Factory Manager over this just because I get the bidding without the city building, which is a part of the game that doesn't intrigue me that much. Also, this game is terribly AP prone. I don't believe I've played a game of this that lasted less than 2.5 hours. It's a game a respect and will still play, but rarely will I pick it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[b]sweet mother of god eating a popsicle[/b]

UPDATE:  Take a sharp stick.  Dip it in poop.  Jab your neighbor in the eye.

[i]This is Power Grid.[/i]

(To keep the profanity to a minimum, I will use the barely appropriate euphemism "fudge", though the bowdlerized form ends up sounding even dirtier what with the slight connotation of fecal matter being involved.)

[i]Power Grid[/i] is one of the best Euros possible because of the endless opportunities to fudge your friends.  And, unlike the usual passive-aggressive glory-hole fudging that happens in most Euros, Power Grid lets you look 'em in the face while you go at it.

You get to fudge them in the auctions...

"I didn't want that stupid plant—I just wanted to watch Elektros fly out of your head."

Fudge them in the commodities market...

"I'll get around to using all this coal eventually.  But you, you'll be hemorrhaging debt into your underwear."

And fudge them most thoroughly on the board...

"Yeah, you're in the gimp suit until Step 2—whenever that happens."

Is [i]Power Grid[/i] really all about grudge-fudging?  Yes, yes it is.  And violence, too.  It's all sex and violence, what with the teeth-kicking and arithmetic.

I suppose we could play like little Fonzies* and stay out of each other's way... but the first person to get out the duct tape and baseball bat will win, and then it's on to machetes and AKs.  And once the groin-kicking starts, you can't go back to just holding hands.

Sure, there's the whole "peloton" thing, which is probably supposed to act as a rubber band for the stragglers, but in reality it's just a mechanism for lining up boots with startled mouths.

So if you ever want that "just fudged" feeling without taking your pants off, I suggest you sit down with a bunch of people who don't love you and play [i]Power Grid[/i].  (Board-flipping and fist-fights optional.)

GET SOME!!!

:coal::oil::trash::nuclear:

Expansions:

[thing=19319]France/Italy[/thing]
[thing=25031]Benelux/Central Europe[/thing]
[thing=37397]China/Korea[/thing]

[thing=29416]New Power Plant Cards[/thing]

[size=7]*It's called [i]parallel play[/i].  Four-year olds do it.[/size]

THIS IS THE ONE....IF YOU DON'T HAVE IT...YOU ARE MISSING OUT ON THE GREATEST EURO GAME IN EXISTENCE

And the expansions with all the changing rules - Brilliant!

RATING: 3

With a shorter victory timescale, this game would be amazing, but I don't think i'd have the patience or interest to play this in full again. And as with other games of which we no longer speak, it become very clear throughout play who is going to win and who isn't, but the game drags victory out to the final round, making the endgame a chore for most.

RATING: 7
This game is an appealing, thought provoking game.  However, there are several things that get to me about it.  One, there is a lot of bean counting in the game that can really slow it down.  Can you afford to pay one more dollar for that power plant?  What about your opponent?  Lots of potential for analysis paralysis here - and also with the all-important turn order.  Yes, you can affect the turn order, but you do that by holding back growth artificially.  This really doesn't feel like running a power company. And finally the ending feels anticlimactic.  The game declares a winner but there is no feeling of having accomplished anything for the losers.  In fact, it just becomes apparent that one player has won and the game just... stops....  There is no obvious "second place" to try for once first place is beyond your grasp.

RATING: 6
I realise that some rave over this game, but it doesn't really work for me. There are some challenges in the timing, but I can't see much value in going early in turn order. You want to be going last as often as possible as that gives you cheapest fuel and cheapest build, but doesn't stop you bidding in the early auctions.  There's also the luck element of a really juicy power plant coming off the pile for the last auction and the game can turn on that possibility. (I invariably end up thinking that the game would be massively improved if the lowest plant in the top row always came down to the auctionable row, rather than fitting in a blind draw.) Although described as an economic game, there's no parallel with reality here and that makes this a complete turn off (no pun intended) for my way of thinking.

It offers a high degree of control and a lot of really interesting things to think about--but at the same time, there is a high degree of tension that comes from not know exactly what will happen next.

RATING: 8
A good, interesting strategy game, with a few caveats.  There are always a lot of tough decisions to make each turn, and the game really requires a lot of attention to what the other players are doing, which is a good thing.  However, the endgame has some flaws which really keep it from ever getting to a 9 or 10 in my book.  First, the game nearly always results in a tie, especially as the player count increases, leaving the tiebreaker (most money remaining) to decide the game.  It feels very unsatisfying to burn your brain for 2 hours only to have victory snatched away by someone with a few bucks more left at the end.  Also, the game is great with 3 or 4, but really doesn't work that well with 5 or 6.  The luck factor involved in the power plant market really increases as player count goes up.

The game's art and style are really great.

RATING: 9
This is a masterpiece of a game. It is extremely simple to learn how to play, the mechanic is logical, but there is huge depth and scope for strategy. The balance of strategy to luck is exactly right, with the game being comprised mainly of the former and with just a touch of the latter - enough to keep the game varied and unpredictable but not so much that planning isn't possible.

Every time I've played this with people they've had an amazing time and have wanted to play it again, and with all of the expansion maps the scope for replayability is so large that it's almost a genre in itself. I understand now why this game is the institution it is.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There are some games that are great because of the way they weave together different game mechanics into a cohesive whole.  Power Grid is not one of those games - it is basically three completely separate mechanics (auction, resource market, and network building) that are played out sequentially one after another.  The reason Power Grid works is two-fold: first, that you have one pile of money to distribute among all three phases of the game and must figure out the best way to optimize the funds you have; second, the way each phase subtly informs your decisions in the other phases.  

Played with the right group, Power Grid is a lean, ferocious game that is tense all the way through to the end. I'm a sucker for auction games and resource markets, so this game really hits a sweet spot for me.  The only things that keeps this from a higher rating are 1.) There are so many other games that I just like more, 2.) some weird fiddly rules that are easy to forget, and 3.) this game is especially prone to analysis paralysis, particularly during the endgame when everyone is trying to figure out if there's any possible way they can build just one more city.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2/10/09
-------------------------------

[i]Power Grid[/i] is a game where players take the role of power companies and attempt to become the most prosperous by purchasing, fuelling, and building their power plants in order to extract revenue from the population. It does this through simulations of a resource market, auctions, and network building on a map. It is for 2-6 players, and the sweet spot would be around 3, 4, or 5.  It is highly strategic, and requires good mathematical and planning skills to be able to master.

This game contains no real single mechanism which dominates the others; it is quite a good amalgamation of several, each with its own phase. Each player is involved in each phase equally, and has a vested interest in watching what the other players are doing, as they may require that power plant they have put up for auction, or need a certain type of fuel at a certain cost, or need a valuable city connection on the board. Having mentioned the importance of being aware of the other player’s moves, I should also mention that there is plenty of decisions to make in isolation, as you are constantly making decisions that affect your efficiency in ways that are likely unforeseeable until the end of the game. This is what I enjoy most about Power Grid; the fact that you have to juggle the needs of the other players with planning your own future, and the time pressure can sometimes be quite daunting.

There is also great replayability, with variable power plant orders and different maps that can be used and different zones that can be selected on each. These all lead to quite different games and play styles. One downside that I have noticed is that it often seems to come down to however is able to get the best power plant at the end, but since I play with mostly 3 people, I cannot comment as to whether this is a major problem, or just from overplaying of a single ‘setting’. This is one of my favourite euro-strategy games I have currently, and will likely remain in that position for the near future.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Strategic depth
- Meshing of several key mechanics
- Good player variability
- Excellent decisions to time ratio
- Almost no downtime

[b]Cons[/b]
- May be too mathematical for some
- 2 or 3 players can be a bit repetitive
- Luck may play too large a part
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is a nice game of tight resource management.  The graphic design work struck me as very clean and easy on the eyes.  My one complaint comes from the heavy accounting when buying resources or building factories in cities.  It would have been nice if the whole system was scaled up to accompany multiples of five for adding purposes.  The way in which turn order was done makes it a nice mechanic as it keeps the game pretty tight throughout barring any catastrophic failures on one's part.  The game is probably one of the better dry-themed Euros I've played.

Update:  That crashing sound you hear is my rating for this game.  Power Grid in the end, for me, is too much work without a payoff in fun.  The math drives me nuts after a while and the gameplay isn't all that variable.  I'm just not a fan of this one anymore.

RATING: 3
Power Grid is a lot of fun on the first 2 or 3 plays.  However, the events and strategy of the game becomes quite repetitive and predictable on subsequent plays.  The value of the power plant variety is diminished by the need to take a minimalist approach save for big producers (6s or 7s) in the late game.  The progression of city expansion in each phase often feels the same.  On top of all this, it takes a substantial time investment with the undisguised math min/maxing.  I would strongly prefer to play most other games, even vanilla Settlers of Catan, as they are much less predictable.

RATING: 7.5
Power Grid is a different market trading game, with a neat energy theme and interactive feel that provides some lasting appeal and dynamics, especially with many players.

However, even as a mathy guy, the game often feels like it should be called Spreadsheet Factory. It is a bit too mathy to be able to just sit back and enjoy the experience.

Also, I don't think there are quite enough dynamics in the game to keep one interested. There is the energy market, the placement map and the random power plants, and that is it.

A decent title, but not great. I'll play when my friends ask, but I find it relatively tiresome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very large and heavily mathematical game.  Not recommended for families or for introducing people to gaming, but a solid game for enthusiasts.  

The main premise being to construct power stations which generate power to the grid you construct on the board, the player that is able to generate power to a set number of homes first is the winner.  I like the auction mechanics, and I have to admit to quite enjoying the many calculations that you must run through your head in order to plan ahead effectively and not run out of money or materials at the wrong time.

The only problem I had was that at towards the end of the game, I didn't have the power stations that could supply enough power to win the game, and no suitable replacements were left in the deck - although I had tons of money and resources it was literally impossible for me to win because of how the deck happened to be arranged.  This was a bit annoying after playing for quite a long time but I still enjoyed the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
2-6 jogadores
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
#areaprenotazione
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm not a huge auction fan, but I appreciate the use of supply and demand in the resource market combined with the network process. I enjoy a little more immersive theme in my games.

12/01/12 update
Moved this game up as I have played this more recently. I appreciate the subtle runaway leader penalties inherent in the game through the turn order. Between good players it reminds me very much of a tactical middle distance race where each game involves considerable jockeying for position in the first three laps while hoping for the right opportunity for the first turn on the final lap (the auction). Each power plant flip determines a likely course of action, but with a nagging doubt about what may be available on the next flip. 

4/06/14 Update
Will always have a place in collection because such a great game for five or six. It's easy for relative new gamers to pick up because all the concepts are so familiar--auctions, buying resources, building a network, being paid.

RATING: 8
OWNED SINCE 2012
This is a fun game. I have no real complaint and everyone in my family likes to play it. Especially those who enjoy Euro games. It plays really well with children ages 7 yrs up. I really want to rate this higher, but I can not think of why it deserves it. It is not an extra ordinary game; although, I like everything about it and would not change anything... I guess when I really think about it there is perhaps too little challenge and it seems all of the players get close to the goal at about the same time, regardless of the choices they made. It is nice that no player gets left behind, but still it lacks those memorable moments when players were close, and it came down to 1 roll of the dice or 1 decisive choice that gave one player just the "little bit" they needed for a surprise win. 
       I really enjoy this game and highly recommend it. Every time I play it I am engaged and enjoy the time played (be warned the game does take longer to play then the box says). My family enjoys this game and I am glad I have it. It is an easy going experience. It is not intense or exciting in any way. Perfect for day when you are looking for a game that is easy going.

RATING: 8
A well-designed game, though I don't really get why it is in the top ten.

Strengths:
The implications of turn order
The auctions, including choosing which plants to offer and when

Weaknesses:
The board play isn't particularly compelling
The game is rather dry and arithmetical, with few surprises

I don't mind tight games where everyone is trying to do the same thing and success comes from being subtly more efficient than everyone else, I just think their play time should be no more than an hour.

RATING: 9
(2-6) - 120 Min.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Funkenschlag (2nd ed) is among the heavier and lengthier German games. It does not have particularly complex rules, nor does it offer deep strategic possibilities. However, on a tactical level it really shines. In my first few games Funkenschlag seemed to be mainly about careful turn-by-turn management of resources in order to optimise your position, with some possibility for affecting other players through e.g your decisions on where to build. But with experience, I began to appreciate the more subtle tactical possibilities (which revolve around the mechanics of determining player order, the effect of player order on which power stations you can put up for auction, the mechanics of the fuel market etc). Despite a certain amount of simple number crunching, this game can generally be completed in around 2 hours. Funkenschlag has a great theme, more than adequate components, and the double-sided board adds some variety. Small gripe: electricity grids do not consist of rusting metal pipes (where are the pylons?)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
I've been winning this game a lot recently, focusing on a "get capacity early" strategy, and staying behind in the city race. Remember, while you can buy as many connections as you can afford each turn, you can only buy one plant. So early capacity can enable you to rush to victory before your opponents can successfully react (especially if they've all been gradually building up).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Initial rating after 3 games with 3 & 5 players. 

I really like the concepts and mechanics in this game and the theme is great as well, hopefully my next games will improve. I can see why the 2 player won't be as interesting but I want to try it anyway. 3 was good and 5 better although it seems in the game, you don't really cut someone off as much as you think might happen, one guy just built right over me paying the costs. Then just when someone might get screwed, the stage changes and he can build where he couldn't before anyway. I would have liked to have seen more jockeying for position, otherwise the auctions are interesting but the rest of the game just comes down to calculating for the best optimization. 

It also seems hard to stop the leader as the rich get richer, maybe there will be more area influence in my next games, more plays will tell. Punishes early mistakes, and whoever gets to pick where to build first has a distinct advantage as far as I can see. The easier to build in areas probably should pay a little less come money time to balance it out further IMO but that opinion might change. Fun game that needs more plays to know for sure...

[u]UPDATE[/u]: 8.5 => 8 I enjoy this game and think the midgame is excellent but the ending can be  determined by the flipping of a powerplant, maybe this wont happen often not sure yet but I'm not a fan of this kind of ending to a 2 hour multiplayer strategy game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Interessante startstad: vb. Bremen.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This seems to be a game of finding the right tempo, which I found pretty interesting. If you shoot ahead too early you might fizzle out and people can pass you, but if you don't stay within striking distance people can end the game on you before you get everything in place. This is all centered around manipulating the turn order mechanic, which is really clever. Near the end since things get pretty much calculable the game can slow down quite a bit as everyone tries to figure out exactly how much money they need to get everything done. But that's a minor concern for me and doesn't stop this from being a fun, interesting game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

A high recommendation for all, avid gamers and newbies alike will enjoy this game! You cant ask for more in a board game

RATING: 7.5
Good game but I don't care for it anymore. I can totally see why it's so loved though. Great theme, art, mechanics. I love the fight for land on the map. But, I think it inflicts serious and problematic AP. You must allocate the right amount of $$ to buy the right amount of resources to power all of your cites while trying to save the perfect amount to buy more next turn. All the math takes the fun out of it for me. Also, no matter how good you do, it always seems to come down to the final 2 rounds. If you don't make the perfect play then, you're screwed.

RATING: 10
Simply a fantastic game! I played Funkenschlag a while before Rio Grande put out Power Grid and I'm still amazed that they ware able to do such a fantastic job steamlining the new version. It provides the same uniqueness and excellent play as the original but also makes it more accessable to the average gamer who might shy away from the crayon rails aspect of Funkenschlag.

Update:  It's so frustrating that we hardly play this game!  I have the three official expansion maps plus at least one unofficial map. It's almost a crime that this doesn't get played a few times a game at the very least.

RATING: 6
Power Grid is a acceptable game that combines several mechanisms: area control, auctions, resource market influenced by demand, last player goes first, etc... and the end result is a very engaging game for gamers, with every game different owing mostly to the semi-random plant market. I found this a bit too "linear" (predictable), not very demanding in strategy, only calculating cheapest way. I wish it was deeper and less "solved". Overestimated.

RATING: 9
One of my favourite games and one of the most balanced boardgames I've played. Rio Grande did a nice modular design with artwork, I felt the map looked overly busy first time I played but got used to it after a while, love the colour scheme, game looks daunting at first but after initial play, comes very naturally. Highly recommend. Also, general cost of game at retail is usually quite reasonable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love some of its mechanics and concepts, especially the escalating nature and strategic uncertainties, but the game can flat-out drag--too much math combined with looking at the board ("I have $162 and there's a 17 connection... and a 12, and a ... hey, I could get a cheaper one there for 15... let me recalculate... wait, that's a 15 city..."). Play with people who know what they want to do before their turn arrives. Not recommended for non-gamers.

How the cards fall is just a little too lucky for a game as demanding as this. I've been in too many games decided by a certain plant arriving or not arriving. I'd probably give this a 5, just going by how much I want to play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun game.  Provide power to the cities on the map.  Get money for doing so.  Use money to buy more cities and powerplants and fuel for the powerplants.  Powerplants are the core of the game and are acquired through auctions where bidding strategy is everything.  Also there is a spatial strategy in what cities to buy, obtaining control of the choicest areas.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

Update: played with 4, and this game is DREADFUL if even one player suffers from AP.  A game that usually takes us a bit over an hour took us almost three.  This is particularly painful when, for the last hour, the two experienced players knew they were mathematically out of it . . .

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Even after dozens of hours of gameplay, I have yet to tire of Power Grid. The management of the three core systems (auctioning, resource management, and route building) along with one of the best catch-up mechanisms in a board game form a compelling system where each game plays a bit differently and players must constantly adjust the pace of building their energy empires. While it can be overly cutthroat and slow down as players get into minute optimizations, Power Grid has provided more than enough tough decisions and tense moments for me to keep it permanently in my collection.

RATING: 7
Back before I got into eurogaming, I tried to design an economic board game.  The first time I played Power Grid, I realized that this was the game that I was trying to design. RATING: 4
Nice, heavy and long economic game, reminiscent of both 1830 and German-style games. However, it suffers from grave randomness in the power plant auctions, as well as from a tendency for game flow inbalance, where games phases tend to either stagnate or feel rushed. A game that could have used the hand of Knizia in ironing out the little (and great) inbalances.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is far more than the sum of its parts. The different phases of the game are very simple, but interesting play emerges in the interaction between them. Deciding what to emphasize (income, power plant capacity, the fuel market, turn order) at each stage of the game is important, and there is no clear answer as to what is the right choice. I believe there are many subtly divergent paths to victory, and I like that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I am blown away at how well this game holds together. Every little piece of it fits together perfectly, and any little move you make (overcommitting to a specific resource, bidding a little too high on a power plant, spending too much of your money on building new cities before you were ready) has a real effect on how well you do, but without feeling forced. Really a masterpiece of game design, and the only downside is how long games can take. This is very much not a party game, but if you have a few hours and you have a group of thinkers, this is the game you want to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
https://thirdpersonblog.wordpress.com/2015/02/24/power-grid-review/
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a really well designed game that is always fun to play.

But the more I play it, the more I get annoyed at the end-game.  The beginning and middle are so much fun, but the last round always seems to drag out as the top two players try to figure out if they can win this turn, and usually, only one of them can, but the other guy just doesn't know it yet.  It's frustrating and anti-climactic, even if you're the one who jockeyed into position for the guaranteed victory.

It's still a game that almost always goes over well, even with people who don't play a lot of board games.  Works just as well with the "monopoly and poker" crowd as the ones who own games themselves.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great game, love playing it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really enjoy the layers of strategy and planning along with the fluctuating resource market. It has a sort of chess-like level of planning moves ahead and trying to determine your opponents' moves before they do them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Having played PG more now, I see it for what it is - a faux economic engine game where your actions are oftentimes forced by the power plants that are available, and what the other people are doing.

I've played too many games where the plants stall randomly, where buying one will always benefit someone else more than oneself, and I find those occurrances kind of annoying.

Then again, I say this because I'm good at rough, mental calculations.

Still rated an 8 because it's enjoyable, but there's too much randomness for the length.


Own via proxy (My brother has it, so it's effectively as good as mine)

RATING: 8
I really enjoy this game. Very well designed and not as fiddly as some other top ranked games..ahem (looking at you Agricola).  This is a really good economic game, and models supply and demand real well with the resource market. 

Very very streamline design!  


I can't help but to think to myself this is almost like a train game but with power plants.  Powering up your power plants is like "pick up and deliver".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love Economic games! I love Auctions! I love wacky rockstar German Designers! I LOVE POWERGRID!
So good, and the maps so far I've played all rock. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Love the game. The resource market is not simply dice determined, like what you get with Settlers. It is determined by supply and demand. Really neat way of looking at adjusting your resource needs according to what you predict others will need or want.
Like it a lot, but can be a bit slow without the newer power plant cards included.

The decision to buy power plants or resources by opponents, determines your strategy. Once played quite an easy game to play again.

Also with the rules their are limitations on the number of general land areas to use, meaning that for 3 player games, on the USA map alone there are 12 different game areas that can be played.

The more I play it, the more I like it... It is definitely a re-playable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
2013-07-25

Initial rating: 6.5 (December 2010)

As Power Grid is one of the better ranked games here on BGG I was expecting a great game, I didn’t like my first play, or my second for that matter. I really wanted to like it, but (sadly) I don’t. So today I gave up my pretense for the game and rated it according to my real feelings.

The game components are ok, the theme is awful but the gameplay is boring and uninspired, if I want to play an Euro I go to superior games. Most of my games had a clear winner from 3 turns (or more)  before the end so I find the endgame to be extremely unsatisfying. Too long for what if offers. Awful art and cover. I don’t find it heavy enough as its reputation would have me believe.

Bottom line, a very boring game. I would play again if requested, but I will try to resist it, fortunately, almost all of my game buddies share my views of the game.

Current Rating: 3.5

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After four plays I'm not finding this as good as I hoped, but better than my very 1st impression. Room for on-the-board strategy seems limited in 2P. I saw BGG comments saying "stockpile resources to drive costs up for other players" but haven't seen a situation where that's relevant, in as much as if someone had somewhere to keep the resources they usually wanted to fire the plant. In the end game buying un-needed resources seems to cost you more than it takes from your opponent. The competitive bidding aspect requires we have more experience of the relative values of the plants.  All in all I think there's a bit of repeat playing before we can get the most out of this ok-seeming game, but these days I don't get many options for repeat playing with the same multiple players.

RATING: 8
The bash-the-leader mechanic is a little clumsy, but there are quite a few innovative elements to this game, especially in its blend of positioning tactics with economic optimization.

I think the resource market really makes this game.  Players who can effectively manipulate the turn order and resource purchases gain a decided edge.

For awhile I had the base game rated lower than my favorite expansions, but they're really inseparable.

RATING: 5
I like the game.  It is interesting and different enough that it really feels fresh.  

With 5 players we play that you need to power one extra city.  This makes it harder to get a big enough plant early that you never have to upgrade.  We also toss out the lowest plant at the end of each round because we were ending before it got to phase 3 (this gets us to phase 3 before the game ends).

Update 12/2011 - Dropped the rating from 8 to 7.  I much prefer Power Grid: Factory Manager.  I know that it is a different game, but the underlying principles are similar even though the mechanics are not the same.  Given a choice I would always choose PG:FM.

Update 2/2017 - Tried to give this another shot.  Dropped the rating again.  My kids, now adult, dislike it enough that it will not get to the table.

RATING: 10
Man, do I love this game. It is very fun. My only complaint is that the end can often leave you feeling very unsatisfied. The end is almost always rather anticlimatic. 

This has been a real surprise hit with my non-gaming friends. They sat there with bored indifference while I explained the rules and I feared that it would be a complete failure with them but 1/4 of the way into the game they started talking amongst themselves about how much fun they were having. 

Some tough decisions to be made. Some fun auction action. Not nearly as "fiddly" as people say and the "math" that everyone seems to be complaining about is simple addition...not sure what the problem is.

A great game with little luck involved. Everyone is always in the game and always feel like they have a shot all the way to the end.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
- Classic game. Old version is just as good as the new one.
- This game has so many great elements: board positioning; power plant auctions; resource market... Soo good.
- I love the decisions as everything is a trade off. If you push too hard for board position, you probably won't have the money you'll need to buy the best power plants and/or the resources you need to power all your cities. On the other hand, spend too much on power plants and/or resources and you won't have the money to expand early enough on the board. You have to toe the line and take advantage of opportunities just at the right time.
- I like how the value of plants and resources depends on what people are doing/using. If any one player is on to a good thing, then other players are encouraged to join in, which makes it not as good a thing...
- It is quite mathy in that you regularly need to sum multiple numbers in the teens, but it's not that bad. I actually enjoy the mental arithmetic.
- Fun with pretty much all player counts, though 6 can take a while. 4-5 players preferred.
- Teaching is not that hard.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game will demand the best of your husbandry and mathematics. Whilst the resource management aspects can become mechanical (optimum choice is a given), the power station auction adds a good degree of player interaction and, it has to be said, luck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
Fantastic game.  I think the best of the Eurogames.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Given the time to play (with experienced players I would estimate 20-30 minutes per player), this is an outstanding longer game.  WARNING:  It is fairly math-heavy, and players should get in the habit of pre-calculating costs of building and estimating costs of materials.  

Of course, this is precisely why I like this game.  The flow is fairly natural after becoming familiar, and decisions can hinge on the production/cost of only a couple of elektro (dollars).  Two levels of interaction (bidding on plants, and racing for network access) make this a tight, highly competetive game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
good longevity here - game doesn't get tired, in part because of variant maps.  clever balance here between efficiency and knowing when to pull out the stops and expand rapidly

RATING: 10
Maybe the first game where I really fell in love with the mechanics.  I love the auctions and rudimentary route-building on the board but for me this game is all about the resource market.  The way it simulates supply and demand and changes the balance of power with the turn-order is so well executed, I honestly cannot think of another game that blends it all together so well.  I also love all the maps that were added later, each changing the game ever-so-slightly.  It's just a beautiful game from a gameplay/mechanics perspective.

RATING: N/A
[b][url=http://www.spieldesjahres.de/cms/front_content.php?idcat=8]2005 Spiel des Jahres Recommended[/url][/b]

The object of Power Grid is to supply the most cities with power when someone's network gains a predetermined size. In this new edition, players mark pre-existing routes between cities for connection, and then bid against each other to purchase the power plants that they use to power their cities.

Players:   2, 3, 4, 5, 6
Time:      120 min
Mechanics:  [property=2012][/property], [property=2081][/property]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a great game with an interesting marketplace mechanic.  As you purchase more of a resource, it becomes more expensive.  Unique way to determine turn order.  Paper money is a common gripe for many, but I don't mind it as much as I probably should.

The built-in mechanic limiting the frontrunner from running away with the game is very frustrating when you are the frontrunner, but appreciated when you're losing.  Power Grid gets very tense towards the end, and it almost seems best to accelerate slowly at the start of the game and come on aggressive mid- to late-game.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is such a very cool game.  Buy power plants, buy fuel for the power plants, buy connections to cities, then use the fuel to power your plants and sell the energy to your cities for profit.  It's so satisfying to build your little economic engine and gobble up the map.  The fact that everyone else at the table is trying to do the same thing and there are limited resources makes for some great tension.  The only down side is that the game takes a long time to play and a lot of that time is spent in analysis, contemplation, and calculation.  Avoid at all costs if you're the type of gamer who simply cannot hold it together while someone else spends 3-5 minutes silently staring at the board and counting on their fingers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Played very often; I love it, but less than Age Of Steam...
With time passing, Funkenschlag stays as a classic, while Age of Steam fades away.

2017-07-19 - This game is still great. I'm raising my rating to an 8.

RATING: 9
A very 'tight' game.  It comes down to the wire.  Lots and lots of different decissions.  No bluffing.  But this game just works very well together. It's often very hard to 'cost' the best option for yourself.  But it's so much fun to try.
2014: update the big difficulty is the learning curve on the game.  I don't get to play enough to overcome that.
2015: Still really enjoy this, I have two friends who play this with me enough I got an expansion.  Still very good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Rio Grande Games edition.  A very tense and calculating economic resource-management game with subtle layers of sub-games/mechanics.  Bid for plants, buy fuel, connect cities... repeat, all while dealing with increased cost in resources and changes in turn order.  Game length is a bit long for us.

Note:  The Rio Grande edition includes a B&W photo copy of the rules that are just awful for the first time player.  I strongly suggest you first familiarized yourself with other help-aids posted on this site, then play a shorter version of the game to the end of Step 1.  -enjoy!

RATING: 2
My rating is for Power Grid. It's nice that the fixed routes exist in this game since it seems that Funkenschlag bogs down while each player is counting out routes in order to find the cheapest one. PG simplifies that and in a good way. A good economic game that can be played in 2 hours.

Update: I'm done with this one. I've really come to hate the stall that happens with players as you get further into to game. I feel that with experienced players the winner is going to be determined by the way the power plants come up and who gets the most "keeper" plants at or slightly above cost.

RATING: 9
The more I play this game, the more my respect for it increases. The game only gets more interesting as it progresses and the end game can be fascinating. The game IS money management. If you enjoy calculating exactly what things are worth and what you can afford, you WILL love this game.

I'm discounting it a bit because I don't think the rules/mechanics are as smooth as they could be. There are a lot of circumstancial rules that are difficult to remember. It's klunky, but that's part of its charm. This game is heaps of fun, despite its short comings.

The GERMANY map is probably the best basic map in the game. The USA map is mostly played in the east and midwest, as connections to the west can be prohibitive. Not as balanced as germany, but still fun.

RATING: 7
Este juego va de comprar recursos para centrales energéticas y alimentar a tantas ciudades como se pueda en cada turno.

Para esto necesitarás dos cosas: centrales energéticas y ciudades. Tendrás que pujar por centrales energéticas en la fase de subasta, cada una de ellas consume un tipo (o varios) de recursos. Tienen un precio de salida, cuanto más alto sea el precio, mayor es su potencia.

Por otro lado, también necesitas alimentar ciudades. Empezando con una ciudad, tendrás que expandir tu red energética a través del país, pagando el coste de tuberías y emplazamiento en las ciudades. Una vez que tengas centrales energéticas y ciudades, sólo necesitarás los recursos adecuados para hacer que todo funcione.

En mi opinión, es un buen juego. Su núcleo está en la fase de subasta, debes de saber cuando tienes que presionar a los otros jujgadores y cuando tienes que retirarte. La expansión de tu red energética es también muy importante para cortar las redes de otros jugadores.
[color=green]
LAST PLAY: 2011
[/color][color=blue]
This game is about buying resources for your power plants and feeding as many cities as you can in each turn.

For this you will need two things: power plants and cities. You will have to bid for power plants in an auction phase, each  of them consumes a kind (or several) of resources. They have a starting bidding price, the higher this price, the better its power.

On the other hand, you need cities to feed too. Starting with a city, you will have to expand your network across the country, paying costs for pipes and city placement. Once you have power plants and cities, you only need the right resources to make everything work.

In my opinion, this is a good game. The core of the game it is in the auction phase, you need to know when you have to put a little bit of pressure on the other players and when you have to have to retreat yourself. Network expansion it is also very important in order to cut other players networks. 
[/color]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Hmm.  There is a lot that I like about this game.  I like the tile placement elements of making connections and "blocking", the supply-demand model with the resources, and the resource management challenges.  What I dislike is the endgame.  You can manage to have a ton of cash to do what you need to win, but ONLY if a useful powerplant gets put out during your auction phase.  Powergrid seems to demand too much time and work to position yourself for what may ultimately come down to luck of the draw at the end.  At least thats been my experience in the games I have played.  If someone outbids me on a powerplant I need to win - thats one thing, but for me not to even have a chance because no good plants get drawn on my turn is very frustrating for all the time and effort invested in it.  Its like playing a marathon chess session where you can only win if you also draw a better poker hand after checkmating your opponent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
 To win, you have to manage your resources in three categories:  (1) purchasing power plants; (2) purchase and manage resources; and (3) connect cities on the board.  A major screw-up in any one of these categories and you are in serious trouble!  Manipulating the turn order is another important tactical factor that gives the game its flavor.  Also, efficiency is rewarded and really the major luck factor is who gets that juicy power plant on the flop for face value versus having it bid up if there is competition.  Games can be one or lost by spending or fail to spend the extra dollar for resources.  Finally, accurately predicting what turn the game will end and planning for it can be crucial.  Every game is a tense struggle, filled with gut-wrenching decisions throughout.

   Update:  October 2007, dropped the rating from a 10 to a 9 given that in recent games, it seems to come down to one player getting a nice power plant for face value.  Then, often the power plant market becomes jammed, making it difficult for other players to catch up.  The only map this seems to be less of an issue is Benelux, given that there's a more rapid trip through the Power Plant deck.  Hopefully, this issue will be addressed by the new Power Plant deck, which is due to be released soon.

  June 2012:  Dropping the rating to an 8.  While I still think it's a fine game and enjoy a play from time to time, it's not one I am seeking out today, and generally will look to play newer titles if given a choice.  Power Grid was in my all-time top 10 for a long time, but today I replaced it with a much newer and lesser known title, Village, that has received alot more play recently.

  Dec. 2015:  Rare for me, re-rated for the third time, dropping the game to a 7.  Will play but not as enthused as others.  The new DeLuxe version from a year or two ago has breathed some new life into the game, not sure that the Stock Market version from this past Essen adds all that much, however.

RATING: 7.5
Outstanding game, but the components fit together a bit awkwardly - the auctions, supply and demand driven pricing and area control mechanisms all operate fairly independantly, but it still works.  Catch up mechanic SEEMS very strong, but experienced players will always beat new players.  There really can be a runaway leader but it takes several plays to realise this - new players will genuinely think they are doing ok until the game ends, which can be a sudden moment.  This is one of those games where you can win or lose and still not be sure what you did right (or wrong).  It really can come down to just a few dollars of money so every decision is crucial.

Update:  Power Grid is a good game, but the downtime can get a bit much, especially with 5+ players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Old Comment:[/b]

Fun economic game with intriguing resource market that actually responds to supply and demand (oooo!, neat!). Nice art style / sense of humor. Can be very competitive. 

The game isn't all accounting, but for me (and the majority of people I've played with), turn after turn goes a little too much like this:"I have X money, so I can afford up to Y for a new power plant, leaving the necessary Z for resources and Q for infrastructure, netting me P in profit." That's a lot of repetitive arithmetic over 120-150 minutes. Still, good game. Will continue to play. 

[b]New Comment[/b]:

It's taken me a long time to warm-up to Power Grid. Like Agricola, I think this is a game that has an almost deceptive "broad appeal" that deflects you from its intrinsic "hardcore gamer" qualities. Power Grid has only opened up for me after many sessions of supposedly heavier economic games like The Scepter of Zavandor and Indonesia. 

What I find unique to this game is that you must master a kind of strategic amplitude. Approaching the game from a mere efficiency standpoint (buy more, make more) won't get you very far. Instead, you have to time your powerplant and network upgrades with precision. You want explosive expansions followed by deliberate (and highly profitable) lulls. In a game that feels so clearly calculable, there are always tough decisions regarding board position, opportunity cost, timing, etc. 

The more games I try, the more I see the [i]enduring[/i] quality of Power Grid. It is a clunky, ungainly game that continually produces situations that are both absurd and somehow engaging. Potentially frustrating yet navigable. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A refreshingly different building game.  Easy enough to teach and play immediately and yet challenging for players of any experience level.  Before knowing anything about the game I was put off by the theme, but now, after playing, I feel that the theme is spot on - building power stations is fun!

RATING: 7
This is an auction game in which you are buying various types of power plants. The plants generate money which is used for the auctions, to by resources for the plants, and to buy new city connections. The value of the resources changes with market demand so one must consider the market conditions to decide on what power plants to buy. There is also a network building aspect as you look for the cheapest routes to connect your cities. People tend to call this a mathy game. I suppose there is some of that, but I enjoy playing it at a more intuitive level.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
9/10, -1 point for the nit-picks given below.

I've played this once, against a single opponent. I enjoyed it very much; I plan on playing it with my gf and, if she likes it, buying it and playing it often.

* The potential turn-offs, if you're not like me:

There's a lot of math. Like, each turn you count your money, plan out how many houses you'll buy and what your resources are going to cost, to figure out how much you can spend in the auction phase. You should also consider what the supply and demand does to the price of each resource, and how much more money you can earn by getting bigger power plants that let you power more cities, and how much that costs.

That's a lot of math. Like, seriously, a lot. I like math. It was my favorite subject in school. At university I minored in math. I sometimes read math articles on Wikipedia for fun. Using math to find the most efficient power plants, house layouts and connection prices in order to win at board game? Sign me up!

The artwork uses many different colors: cement grey, steel grey, smoke grey, overcast dark cloud grey, power socket grey, smoke black, coal black, oil black, coal brown and soil brown, spiced up with a little bit of construction truck orangey-yellow. Lots of earthy colors and a drab, industrial look, which goes great with the theme of the game, but some might find this boring and lifeless. The power plants look a little bit... cutesy, I guess, but in a way that preserves the "hardhats and bean counters" tone. It's all well done, crisp, easily readable and inoffensive to the eye, but you only taste some of the rainbow.

Also, it's long. My game lasted more than 3 hours. That's a lot. It's a lot of fun, yes, but it's also a lot of time. The opportunity cost is 2-3 games of Pandemic, 3-5 games of Dominion, or ~50 rounds of Coup. I'm sure it speeds up as the players get familiar with the game—Adam Horton claims it can be played in under an hour (source: GIYF).

* The nitpicks:

There's a board divided into regions; you never use all of them at the same time. The game doesn't come with anything to cover up the unused part, or indicate where the separation lies. Whatever the solution is, it would've been nice if it came in the box. You can probably improvise something use the rulebook, some reference cards and money, but it's never going to look all that great.

How much money you have is something you're allowed to hide, even though it can be calculated by everyone given only all the public information; that adds busywork which is strategically relevant at high-level play.

The paper money is flimsy and doesn't feel all that awesome to handle. Maybe the choice is informed by making the quantity something you're allowed to hide. Some people suggest using poker chips instead if you have 'em. That sounds reasonable to me.

* What makes the game work?

Here are some of the elements of the game which I think help make it fun: there's a reasonably clear goal: build houses and power them. There's a reasonably clear notion of the best means: buy plants, fuel and houses cost-efficiently. You can plan a few turns ahead reasonably well given just the public information, and the nature of the player interactions imply that you ought to. That invests you in your turn-by-turn decisions.

* Some facts for those who don't know.

The nature of the competition is such that you can never* deprive your opponent of an opportunity, you can only make that opportunity more expensive for your opponent. Money is part of the win condition, so doing this can pay off. It's a general truth that if I hurt myself and hurt one opponent more, that's a net win in 2-player games, and 2-player games only; hence the 2-player version can be more cutthroat than with more players. Overall, the money part of the win condition is influenced by accruing many small efficiencies; each micro-fight matters, but none of them decide the game on their own.

(* it's possible for resources to fully dry up, e.g. for there to be no more coal. That happens more often the more players there are in the game, or so I hear. There is a maximum of three houses in each city, and each player can have at most house in each city, so in 4+ player games some cities can become unavailable to you.)

There is an element of randomness. There's a deck of power plants that's shuffled at game start. Eight of them are in the market at any point in time, but you can only buy among the cheapest four. After each player buys a plant, a new one is drawn from the deck; if its cost puts it in the cheaper half of the market, it'll be available for purchase, but only to those who haven't bought a plant in the current round.

You can minimize the impact of randomness through strategery, by positioning yourself later in the bidding order. You can also estimate the probability of lucky draws ahead of time: there's (at most) one power plant at each list price. If the market boundary is between the plants with list price 22 and 23, you know that 23 will be available to the other players if you buy 22. If the boundary is between 20 and 27, any plant between 21 and 26 might show up and become available.

There's a fixed initial market, and the number of plants towards the end of the game is small-ish, so the random variability occurs most often around the mid-game, leaving you enough time to catch up by outplaying your opponent if you get screwed by their good luck. Luck matters, but it's not game-decisive and you can play towards low variance (or make the luck benefit you).

I benefited from this element of luck at least once. Maybe that's why I won my first game, against an experienced opponent, but I think part of it also had to do with me driving up the price of coal when he went for an all-coal lineup, and getting a good contain around his Essen-centered network, almost reserving both Hamburg and Berlin to myself, circumvented only by his very expensive long-distance expansion into my territory. I hear that it's not completely uncommon for new players to win their first game.

* Political messages in (and not in) the game.

There are eco-friendly power plants (windmills). They don't require resources, which makes them cheap to operate, but they power a small number of houses. Ultimately you'll want the dirty ones for their greater capacity, but you'll happily take the green ones mid-game to help you make money. The game never says "eco-power rocks" or "eco-power sucks", but the differences in benefits implies something about the attractiveness of eco-power.

Also, apart from the auctions the price structures are nowhere near perfect competition. They resemble oligo-/monopoly/-psony (few/single sellers/buyers) a lot more; I assume the money you earn from not powering any houses is a government subsidy; and the house construction rules imply heavy licensing requirements and discriminatory barriers to entry. In this fashion, the game might subtly normalize cronyism and interventionism over competitive markets—or, much more realistically and probably worse, conflate the two in the minds of a lot of people.

By Power Grid's nature as a competitive game, one person's victory implies every other person's defeat. Commerce is almost always mutually beneficial, and the exceptions typically imply unethical behavior on the part of at least one party (for example, fraud or other forms of deceit).

The individual auctions are turn-based open-exit English auctions, similar to poker-bidding with only "raise" and "fold"; the fact that you can only buy at most one power plant each round makes the auction system differ from institutions that are socially efficient in ways I don't know the exact implications of—though I suspect that selling two power plants in a VCG auction, which are efficient, could result in one party buying both, and this can't happen with Power Grid's auction system.

If you are seriously concerned about any of this, you should also worry that playing Axis and Allies will turn people into Nazis, that playing Twilight Struggle will turn people into commies, and that playing Monopoly will turn people into real estate speculators.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What I like about PG is turn planning. You have to budget for expansion and resources with plans A and B in mind then determine what you can afford to spend on a new power plant. Opponent's desires in all phases are important making player interaction very high. You have to find the rhythm of expansion and optimization which I really like in economic engine games.

We never play with more than 4p because the game has too much downtime. An AP prone player can really drag the game into the mud. Sometimes your ability to do well feels crippled by other's moves, this is unavoidable with such high player interaction. Part of the game is avoiding this, but when it does happen it can feel very shitty. There is also the possibility that the person screwing you over is playing sub-optimally which really sucks. To some extent this can be avoided with the right group, but this dependence on group type for enjoyment is the biggest flaw in the game IMO.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

However, after consistently seeing it in the top 5 ranked games on this website, I decided to give it a go. It is a heavier economical game, with various mechanisms carefully intertwined. And surprisingly it worked for me, as for a large portion of the boardgaming community. This game is incredibly tense and exciting. Not only spactial tactical placement of your houses, but also clever bidding in the factory market, and buying resources at the right moment: this is one of the best games available.
