RATING: 9
Running a power company? Perfect topic for me. Much better than the 100th medieval game. 

The mechanisms of auction, resource management and network building fit together to make a smooth and challenging game. While I'm not too fond of auction games in general, it doesn't disturb me here. The resource market is modelled in a great way and feels true. The network aspect is a bit in the back.

With more play, the leader balancing mechanism might become disturbing as it feels gamey for me to stay intentionally behind to leap forward in the final moves. Not as bad as Masons in this concern but could be bothering.

The graphic design is among the best I have seen and support the theme.

Looking forward to playing this again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Del orden de 10 partidas sin loguear.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game balances so many elements in logical and clean ways. It holds attention throughout, and it is packed with strategy at each different action (though there is usually a somewhat clear BEST strategy). I'm also impressed at the design of the game board and the fact that it is double-sided. It feels like a great value.

I was surprised at how much my wife took to this game. I thought it may be a bit complex, but I think she was able to follow because of how much sense the system makes. Doesn't hurt that she is good at it, too.

Update: I'm sick of playing this with new people as I keep seeing the same arc throughout each game. The auction just doesn't have enough to separate it from any other auction game. The rest of the game is mired by a dependence on turn order manipulation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
5 July 2009  Just played this one last night.  Was a little wary because of some of the comments here (too maths heavy, dry, etc).  Had a blast! 4 player. Loved the auction, the commodities, building and connecting to cities.  Loved earning the filthy lucre at the end of building.  We groaned when we made a mistake in the auction, laughed when our friends made one.  I nearly won after having lagged behind all game.  Couldn't detect a runaway leader problem.  Had plenty of opportunity for catching up.  This one is 'heavy', in that you have to be aware of what's going on all the time and you have to watch your cash a lot or you'll get left short but this was a plus for me.  A nice break from Puerto Rico. I'm off to buy this one, this week. :-)

9 July 09 Played a 5 player last night.  Great time. My friends tend to stay away from wind power cause it's a little weaker than coal/oil. I didn't and had enough to win the game. Yay.  

2 Aug 09 I'm bumping this to a 10.  Love this game.  Even when I lose I've had a great time.  (Note to self, never get caught up in a bidding war). Favourite map so far - Poland I think.

23 Jan 11 3 player game. A real blast. Lagged behind all game and then came thru and won right at the last. We love the bidding element of this game. It's great driving up prices on each other and trying to get a bargain in the meantime. My favourite player number is 4. This game is so good because everyone's had a great time at the end of the game whether they won or lost.

2 Jan 2013 - For some reason this game got boring. No-one wants to play it anymore. Have switched to First Sparks as it's shorter and more fun.

RATING: 7
Seems to lack catch-up opportunities, as the main contenders ar evident by mid-game. Up to that point, the game is anything but boring. I'd rate this higher except that if you fall behind early you are in for a long difficult game. I also think that the accounting is high maintenance, perhaps the reason I find this game so tedious. There's too much money exchange with the bank over the course of the game.

Update: Hmmm... just finished a game in which I made a heck of a late game move to finish 2nd. Lost the tie-break by $10. I felt cash-poor compared to the leaders, but was stingy as hell and made sure my power plant upgrades were significant and had staying power. Playing from behind isn't horrible, but you have to stay as close as possible in network size so the money doesn't seem so overwhelming.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It met my expectations: it's a fairly math-heavy game where the focus is on efficiency optimization and maximizing profits. There's an auction mechanic which felt a little awkward to me (decreasing number of participants). The mid-game felt a bit sloppy (there were several mid-game factories, but it didn't seem to be efficient to buy them; players who leapt to end-game factories scored much better overall). But, worst, I didn't feel there were all that many interesting or exciting decisions in the game. ...Basically, choosing whether to do this or that came down to two questions: "will this net me a profit", and "will this block another player's profit?" I didn't find the game particularly immersive. Table-talk was essentially along the lines of "well, you could go _here_ and block _that_, but _this_ is your cheapest build, and you'd net X more money for going there..."[shrug] ...Not the kind of gaming that I find especially exciting.

I would probably play the game again, but it's not on my "want to play" list... and, unfortunately, it seems to be one of those games you need to invest time into before you're good enough to be at all competitive, and I'm not sure it's a game that's as enjoyable for those with less skill than other players.

RATING: 7
I should really like Power Grid. It's just the right weight, including just the right kinds of elements (network building, auctions, timing). And for a long while I played quite a lot of it, especially on BSW.

But too often it comes down to a power plant lottery: whether something is a good buy or not depends too heavily on what the next card drawn is. And it really sucks to be playing for 2 hours, and have the game essentially determined by a coin flip at the end.

I'll still happily play it any time, but I also can't help getting the feeling that it's way, way overrated on bgg.

RATING: 8.5
A game of managing power plants and fueling them to provide electricity to the cities you control. Very nice elegant game, and I find that most non-gamers are enthralled by the game. The game is fairly simple and intuitive and leads to a deep and stategic game.

The game has bad rules translation (minor, because you eventually figure out the Step and Phase thing) and those "triggered-occassionally" rules which are so easy to forget. Probably best with 4 or 5 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Interesting economic game.  However, I do not like the "drafting" aspects of the game--you need to avoid being the leader in order for you to position yourself to sprint to the finish.

My main complaint about Power Grid, which could be considered controversial, is that it is too luck driven for the amount of time it takes to play.  In my opinion, there is about as much luck in Power Grid as in Settlers or Ra, but it takes much longer to play.

On the outset, it doesn't seem like there is that much luck in Power Grid because there are all these calculations and planning that is necessary to play the game.  However, I believe that those are secondary to winning the game.  The key to winning is if you get lucky and get the good (permanent) Power Plants.  If there is a good power plant in the auction and a great power plant in the queue, that's where the luck factor comes in.  Do you bid high and risk that the great power plant goes comes up, or do you pass and risk that an awful power plant is drawn.  To me, this type of decision determines the game, and happens two or three times a game.

Also my group tends to be slow and a game of Power Grid can lasts up to 3 hours.

RATING: 8
A very good game.  I enjoy playing with the base plants, but the expansion power plants do help keep things fresh.  Interesting optimization decisions, but not overwhelming.  The reference files on the BGG are helpful in keeping track of the different game phases and stages.  

I may prefer the analysis of the early game.  In my experience the end game can feel a frantic at the end and the winner can often be decided in the last round by the chance draw (or missed draw) of a particular power plant.  Just part of the fun I suppose.

RATING: 4
At first glance this seemed to be a game where whoever able to put his or her stuff on the board fastest wins. However, we soon discovered that a high level of tactical skill is needed which is typical for train games. Everything works smoothly and nerve control is important. All of the good things come unfortunately crashing down because turtling is the only way to play. Yellow vs. wooden houses are a slight minus in darker lighting. There's also way too much downtime included while  others are doing the math considering what you get out of this. Therefore the process of the game isn't fun.

RATING: 10
The reason why this is my favorite game is the tension arc it has: the stranglepoints and following crashes, the phase transitions, and the threshold-based end game... makes for an intense experience everytime.

While I usually hate auctions, this game does them well. Each small mechanism is a great fit. Particularly love the threshold game end, and the scoring, which feel so different from anything else.

Multiple maps coming with different rules are nice, as are the different promos for it when used sparingly.

RATING: 6
On the plus side, the game evolves nicely and the resource market model is brilliant in its simplicity. On the minus side, the ending was anticlimactic after the game accelerated heavily beyond stage 1 and the leading player couldn't be overtaken. This is a game where players who insist on checking and re-checking their (hidden but trackable) funds against a number of possible chains of events are actually justified in doing so. Not one for the non-gamers. It felt odd that with the maximum number of players, the whole board wasn't used. Rating feels more likely to go up than down.

Update: I like the beginning and mid-game, so it's currently the endgame holding the rating back. And using reversed turn order for everything important still makes a mockery of the common understanding of turn order.

Use poker chips. Keeping money totals hidden [-]may be[/-] is a complete necessity, however. Yes, triggering the end of the game can (and has) become a crapshoot, but the alternative is far worse.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An excellent, enjoyable, thinky, tightly designed and well-thought-out resource-management game that is both absorbing and remarkably addictive. The design is elegantly balanced and – most importantly – leads to a game that is fun to play. The theme, which might seem dry and unappealing, turns out to be fascinating and well complemented by the mechanics.

It takes about 2 or 3 hours to play, which makes it hard to get to the table as often as I’d like, but because it demands concentration, the players always seem surprised at how the time flies by. 

The board is double sided, and made of heavy cardboard. The art is unique – bizarre at first, but engaging as you quickly begin to associate it with the fun of playing the game. 

The rules are clear and well-conceived, but it’s sometimes hard to find what you’re looking for. I find the “phase” and “step” nomenclature counter-intuitive. To me a step is something granular, while a phase is more regional, so I keep wanting them to be the other way around – steps part of a phase, rather than phases part of steps. 

It’s easy to learn to play the game, but until you’ve played several times, hard to understand the game’s rhythms. I’m still discovering lessons in strategy each time I play. The depth of the game gives it high replayability.

The components are:
- simple coloured wooden bits, which are adequate. The yellow, black and red players’ houses are the same colour as the tokens for garbage, oil and uranium, respectively – which is a pity, but not a problem. From some angles, in certain lights, I find the blue and green pieces nearly indistinguishable. I’d expect colour-blind people find the game difficult to play with the standard pieces. 
- simple but communicative illustrations of power plants on stout square cardstock. They convey information immediately, look good, handle well, and suit the theme perfectly.
- coloured paper money, which I don’t like and have replaced with coins.

Things that would have been useful but aren’t provided:
- thin cards of the shape and size of the areas that are excluded from play. I overlaid a translucent polypropylene foam sheet on the map, outlined each of the areas with a sharpie (having made sure first that it didn't bleed through to the surface below!), marked each of the areas with an arrow and an N for North, and cut to shape. Polypropylene is anti-slip, and stays in place throughout the game. Waxed paper or baking parchment would work at a pinch. 
- a separate card with the replenishment schedules would reduce wear on the rulebook.
- synoptic player aids with a succinct summary of the rules and play phases.

The housekeeping (bank, resource and power station replenishment) is best shared between the players. 

In many cases, players may find themselves short by a single “electro” (the unit of money in the game) for something they want to do. This means that meticulous banking is essential. That seems to rule out any way of keeping track of money except for exchanging with the bank – which is the closest this game gets to being Monopoly.

The game is shaped throughout by strong interaction between the players, and each time it’s your turn to play, you’re faced with another decision – and often it’s one that will impact your choices, and those of other players, later in the game. The game’s strongly interacting mechanics are designed to keep the players constantly close to one another and to allow trailing players to catch up. 

The players themselves influence almost all the elements of the game. They control, to a greater or lesser extent, which power stations are in each player’s hand, how many cities are linked in to a player’s grid and which are made unavailable to other players, and the cost of fuel for the power stations and, later in the game, its availability. Perhaps the most crucial element under players’ control is play order, which becomes increasingly important as the game goes on. There is often a race to the finish in the final 2 or 3 rounds, and play order is usually vital in this sprint.

The game clicks from a first phase (confusingly called a step) in which money is extremely tight, power stations generally inadequate, and space to expand increasingly constrained, to a second phase in which the earlier constraints on space vanish for a while, and power stations become increasingly efficient. The focus in this second stage is largely on generating greater capacity to power cities. The game then clicks into a third and final step in which the focus changes again as money becomes more available, the end heaves into sight, and players prepare to race to the finish. The three parts to the game have distinctly different characters, and while the two clicks aren’t “in theme”, they are well conceived in terms of how the game works. 

The endgame, while tense, plays out rapidly and without fanfare. For this reason, new players, who haven’t enough experience of the game to know when to ramp up, may find the end of the game anticlimactic as they abruptly lose. 

The game design means that each game is different and there is a high replay value.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A design I admire more than I usually enjoy playing.  

I really like the auction rounds for the power plants, the supply and demand inherent to the resource market, and the ingenious turn order mechanic that combats the runaway leader problem and adds all kinds of tactical nuances to jockeying for "last" place.  

On the other hand, I find the rules to be inelegant - it's telling that there is a phase in each round called "bureaucracy."  You have to restock the resource market each turn - but to determine how many resources of each type are added, you have to consult a chart on the back of the manual (not on the board), with the amounts changing by both the player count, and which of the three "steps" the game is in.  This is a bit too fiddly for my taste.  I have difficulty remembering a lot of the more unintuitive rules for triggering the different steps, removing power plants from the market, and how many cities ends the game. 

After a session of Power Grid, I usually feel it was time well spent, but it's not a game I'm itching to play again soon.

approximate number of plays (pre-2017):  10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've only been able to try this game a few times, but I have liked it the few I've played of it.  It is a fun game that the jury is still somewhat out on though, so my rating is rather tentative and subject to change.  

So far the two main things that keep it from being a ten are the fact that it doesn't seem to scale well with different numbers of players, and that the deck of power plants can do some very swingy and odd things to make some games play very weird.

*Edit* I've just dropped this rating to an 7,  The game takes a long time, and by the end of it I get sort of a feeling of "Is this over yet?"  Since I'm a person who usually enjoys long games, that is a problem.  Also it isn't really "rules-light" for newer players, yet I don't feel that the depth of strategy is really all *that* incredible.  It seems like you just try to manage your risks and take the best options of power plants when they become available for sale.  I feel like there's more too it that I'm missing though, so I'm going to give it more chances and try to dig deeper into the strategic options of this game.

*Further Edit*

I finally had to sell this one.  I liked it well enough, but my normally Euro-game loving family just didn't dig it.  I'm not sure why really, may have been a bit to "mathy" for them I guess.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is the most popular amongst my game group.  That group is basically my wife, my friend, his wife, and myself.  The game invokes pretty deep thought and AP is ALWAYS going on.  However, since we all know each other, we get to make fun of the tense math happening all over the board.  The game has a pretty abstract way to gain advantage that isn't summed up in a single sentence.  It can be said you can win in many ways with many approaches.  We keep going back to this game because everyone "thinks" they finally got "it" only to find out that what they have planned didn't really help.

I got this game as a gift from my friend after they got a few plays of Kingsburg + expansion.  I quickly got all the expansion boards for the game due to the popularity.  The only reason why I vote it an 8 and not a 10 is that I do tend to win this pretty much 80% of the time, so my enjoyment of it isn't as "high" as when I first started.  Especially now because I "see" when I'm losing and the surprise is gone.  However, the game isn't lower than an 8 either because it brings a "good time" with my game group and no matter how good / bad a game is, if you aren't playing and having fun, then what's the point?

There are games I like but others don't, I rather have it the other way around.  This game gets an 8 for being one that I would gladly suggest to friends and play on a regular basis.

RATING: 10
Beautiful game. So well balanced, it runs like a freshly oiled machine.
2 complaints:
1) too much math
2) with the evr changing board/position/turns..you can spend all the time you want preparing for your turn, but when it's your turn, everything you were planning on is changed...leading to "analparal"

UPDATE:
Complaint 1 – solved by adding calculators to the set up
Complaint 2 - with more plays under our belts, this is hardly the case anymore.

RATING: 8.5
You'd think this game would be dry, but it's not. It's always a hit with everyone -- gamers and non-gamers alike. Of course, I have to "emcee" everything very actively to keep things moving along and so the players don't get bogged down and confused by all the fiddly stuff that has to happen.

It's really hard to put my finger on just what it is about this game that makes me always happy to play it.  It's just... cool... 

This would be my #1 pick for the next board game they should release on xbox.

~25 plays

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wasn't overly impressed by the game.

I understand there are multiple strategies to winning:  do you stay one step behind so you can get the resources cheaper and stockpile money for a hidden strike, do you bully your way through, buying cheaper cities, but getting last pick of the more expensive resources effectively netting the same as your more efficient opponent?

As such, the game has a built in anti-kingmaker policy. 

So why wasn't I impressed?  I certainly don't mind the rubberband effect in a shorter game like YINSH, but fighting for a marginal lead for 2 hours felt like wasted time.  In the end, I felt as though the game was so systematic that it played me...the harder I pushed, the more it pushed me down (and the opposite for my opponent; as long as his bar was to stay one step below me).

In the end, it just felt like I was along for the ride, a victim of the system, and my efforts were moot since I couldn't pull away.

-----
Upping my rating to 8.
Beginning to enjoy the subtelties of the rubber band effect; some turns it's better to jump ahead and be more productive, others you should sit it out and buy all the resources before your opponent.  Each game is completely different as you adapt to available routes.  I played more middle ground than my first time, which led to more strategic options.  You definitely don't know who's going to win until the end.

RATING: 8
Includes the Expansions:
Power Grid: BGG Promo Card Set (First edition) (2011)
Power Grid: Russia & Japan (English first edition) (2010)
Power Grid: The New Power Plant Cards (Rio Grande English Edition) (2007)
Power Grid: The Robots (2011)
Power Grid: Taxes (2013)	
Power Grid: Supply Contract (2011)

There's a reason this game always hovers near the top at BGG. The gameplay hardly ever lags, and because there are always decisions to be made, every player is always engaged. Proof that a game with virtually no luck in it can still be insanely fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I need to play more to make a final decision about rating. I really like the mechanics of the market, which imitate a real market surprisingly well. Balance of power station capacity, player order, ability to block/interfere power lines and winning conditions add a variability of strategies.

The game's only con - and I've seen this commented in reviews as well - is that it could, depending on the players, become a math  exercise. Still it probably depends on how serious you take the game.

RATING: 8
What a great little game.

The mechanics are simple and the length (four player varient) is less than 2 hours so can get 2 or 3 games in in an evening. It just flows well with you trying to maximise output for minimal investment whilst avoiding getting pinned in on the board. (In which case it costs more to supply cities) - Good invention.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is likely the best game I have ever played. the mechanics are very interesting and being in first place isn't always a good thing. I like the way balance is brought to the game play, keeping even the last player in the running all the way to the end.

Strategy can be used very effectively to give yourself an advantage, but this game is so easy to catch on that non-gamers will enjoy it from the very beginning.

The randomness of plants and playing areas always keeps this game exciting and a real challenge. Do yourself a favor and pick up a copy today!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

That is, you don't connect the plants to the cities.  Should have called it something different, though that may just be an English translation issue.  Still fun, though.  The German map is probably the best.  USA and France are OK, but I think Italy is too narrow.

RATING: N/A
2-6(3-6)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Power Grid is an awesome and unique game. Using money management as the common thread that ties the elements together, this game manages to intuitively combine a connection building game, an auction game, and a fluctuating resource market that is affected by supply & demand. It is a masterpiece that is more than the sum of its parts.

My one complaint about this game would be that there are a few rules details that are easy to forget and the main rules are not laid out well to serve as a reminder. This is easily remedied by printing up a good rules summary to have on hand. I like this one: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/32681/power-grid-players-aid-set-up-guide
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After many games, this has become my favorite game and keeps getting better. Lots of bizarre rules that somehow work to create a genuine masterpiece.

RATING: 8
A truly great planning, auction and resource management game that plays well with 2-6 players. The variety of maps and cards adds to the replayability.  Has a slight learning curve, with a good balance of location, capacity, value and planning all being important. Also a clever turn-order catch-up mechanism whereby the leader in cities has the worst position in each round.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The three intertwined mechanisms of this game (bidding for plants, buying resources, and the positional game) and the crucial importance of turn order combine to make it a satisfying challenge.  Though a newbie can skew things, a win is generally well earned in this one.  The go-slow phenomenom in the middle game can be exciting but is sometimes just boring.  The dark and misshapen design scheme gives me the creeps though others seem to like it.  In my view, more fun (though more chaotic) with 5-6, when you can find that many.  Three or four players is more chess-like and unforgiving.  I find playing with two players pretty pointless.

- One of the few games that can be played in 6 players
- Players interaction
- Longevity

RATING: 8
There is one obvious strategy to be the winner - at the end get last of the game order so you can take the best power plant... and so power the most cities. A pity that such a cool game with really nice mechanics has such an endgame... in most times it does not matter what you reached before, it only matters that you are last in gameorder and take that best power plant... (and that you are located in the middle field throughout the game, but you never need to reach for the lead). But the theme is very interesting and gaming is fun nevertheless, so it's a solid 8.

RATING: 3
[size=12][b]Top 300 or higher board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I like Power Grid:[/b][/size]
+ The route/network building mechanic was implemented better in this game than other games. 
+ There is decent replayability
+ The game requires meaningful decisions to win. 

[size=12][b]Why I dislike Power Grid:[/b][/size]
- I find the bidding somewhat tedious, especially with 5-6 players to the point where I'd rather play another game.  
- I am uninterested in the theme. 
- The game is about as exciting as the box cover. 

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Not willing to play this game[/size]

RATING: 8
2007-02-24

37,80 English version bought. It is quite possible that i will Buy the german extensions. There is a great price difference.it is said to be a very mathematic game. This i like. but it also means that it can suffer from some slow play.Have testplayed it myself. Based on that I give it 8.5. I believe this rating can only go up. The game seems very unforgiving for slow starters. The mechanisms and turn order are very balanced.If you get behind in three turns it seems likely that this is your own fault because there is no hidden information. Except for the start of phase two (removal of the lowest card with one from the stack)This new information is however for all there to see. And all that this can mean is a serious bidding war.Very high expectations. And not  uncertain about them.

Update :
Best game I have ever played. Seriously thinking about purchasing another copy.

Update feb 2008. Got my second copy. Just played a session at BSW made a real mess out of it due to not knowing the interface. It is a good interface though

RATING: 7.5

Fantastic game that rewards multiple strategies and adapting to change. Downsides are that the mechanics don't work as well with 2 players and certain areas of the board a very unbalanced, making startup costs for one player much more expensive unnecessarily.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game is full of complex interactions among the many phases.  The wide variety of game mechanisms provides for a lot of tinkering and planning, but the game still seems relatively approachable for new players.  The balancing mechanisms are very helpful for maintaining a tense, close game.

We have bumped into some kingmaking situations, because of the victory conditions.  Sometimes, a player with more money may be limited in his final purchases by the preceding players' moves.  This probably won't be much of a problem in a fair game, but the connection cost distributions may cause some almost arbitrary differentiation at the end of the game.  There can be similar problems with resource shortages and plant availability, depending on the particulars of a given game.

RATING: 9
Rating is for new version.  This is one of my favorite games right now.  Unlike many German games, this one does NOT give you a few VPs here and there for doing certain things.  There is a goal that you build up to.  I prefer that sort of victory condition.  Very neat interwoven mechanics.  The key aspect of play centers on buying the right plants for the right price, but the resources and map building play their key roles too.  Wonderful balance and scales well for any number of players.  Great game to play online at BSW since the program takes care of the tedious bookkeeping.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I've played Power Grid many times and even with almost every expansion there is AND I've to admit, that the game is one of the best games I've ever played!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The object of Power Grid is to supply the most cities with power when someone's network gains a predetermined size. In this new edition, players mark pre-existing routes between cities for connection, and then bid against each other to purchase the power plants that they use to power their cities.However, as plants are purchased, newer, more efficient plants become available, so by merely purchasing, you're potentially allowing others access to superior equipment.Additionally, players must acquire the raw materials (coal, oil, garbage, and uranium) needed to power said plants (except for the 'renewable' windfarm/ solar plants, which require no fuel), making it a constant struggle to upgrade your plants for maximum efficiency while still retaining enough wealth to quickly expand your network to get the cheapest routes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
If you don't smell smoke, then you're not playing the game right! This is not your typical light-n-fluffy Euro game. It requires serious concentration (can you say planning ahead?) and the ability to perform numerous arithmetic computations mentally. Don't get me wrong these features are not a put off for this game, in fact, they add to the flavor of this game (and considerably so!). Also, don't think that all you need to know is math to do well in this game; that is but one aspect of this 'must have' classic. With power plant auctions reminiscent of Princes of Florence, market-based raw material procurement (with the ability to deny your opponents the resources they require), and turn-order positioning adding to the strategy required to play this game, it's no wonder this game is rated so highly! Without a doubt, Power Grid is one of the heavier (non-wargame) Euro-style games currently available. If you like thinking during your games, then this game will charge you right up! [Bad pun intended.] 

:star::star::star::star::star:

RATING: 3
Extremely dry auction and wall-building game. Surprisingly luck-driven as the power plants that appear are so random, it makes planning for the future very difficult. Positive feedback loop almost always assures that a player who emerges ahead in the first turn or two will dominate the rest of the game, making for a predictable and boring experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Although the theme of this game might lack the sparkle, the flow of the game is really enjoyable. The mechanics are simple enough that almost everybody can quickly get the idea of the game. There is enough interaction between the players and downtime is negligible. There are also a lot of different maps available with special rules, so the game won't easily turn boring.

Best played with 4-6 players. 
Takes about 30 mins per player. 
Basic math skills required.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
LIKES:

* expandability with the numerous maps and power plant decks make this game slightly different depending on the map (but not nearly as different in most cases as many Age of Steam maps).
* Game is easily explained and follows a few easy steps.  Playing well may not be so easy, but gameplay is straightforward.
* This game is all about timing - when to go for big power plants, when to go from slumming and charge to the front.  Wait too long and you lose; jump the gun and you lose.

DISLIKES:

* As much as it can be a strength, the game play is also quite repetitive and the downtime can get quite annoying, particularly as people are trying to add the costs for buying into cities, buying resources, and buying power plants.  Make a misstep with your money, and your game could be lost.
* Early expansions didn't add much to the game.  The last few have been better in making the game a different experience.

===========================

Not sure but I find myself grading this one lower over time as it has gone from a 9 to a 7 and I rarely look forward to playing and now I've sold my copy and am finished with the game - rating it a 5.

RATING: 4
A tábla elég szép, a szabályok pedig nem túl bonyolultak: már az első játék is élvezhető ha akad aki ügyesen el tudja magyarázni a lényeget. A játékban a fizetőeszköz gyakorlatilag írólapra nyomtatott papírpénz, ami roppant sérülékenynek tűnik, ez nem tetszett.
A játék témája nem fogott meg (erőműveket vásárolni és hozzájuk fűtőelemeket, majd a megtermelt árammal ellátni a településeket, és beszedni a szolgáltatott áram árát, amiből újabb erőműveket lehet építeni és újabb településeken elkezdeni az áramszolgáltatást). A játékosok cselekedetei elég nagy hatással vannak egymásra, de nem lehetetlenítik el egymás játékát. Megfelelő mennyiségű és nehézségű választási lehetőség elé állítja a soron lévő játékost: nem egyértelmű, hogy mikor épp mi lenne a leghelyesebb lépés (azaz a játékos nem csak statiszta szerepet tölt be), de nem is kell perceken keresztül gondolkozni a kiválasztásán (azaz nem várakoztatja sokáig a többi játékost). A kelleténél szerintem többet kell benne számolgatni.
Nem tetszik benne, hogy a játéktáblán az ország bizonyos megyéit le kell takarni ha nem maximális számú játékos játssza. Folyton megtévesztett, mert a piacon lévő erőmű-lapokkal takartuk le a nem használt térképrészleteket, ami nem tökéletesen takar és emiatt többször is olyan városokon kezdtem el gondolkozni, amik épp nincsenek is játékban, valamint zavaró az is, hogy az erőművek alatt egy zsúfolt térkép van háttérként.

Szóval így elsőre: könnyen elsajátítható kiegyensúlyozott játék kicsit száraz témával és sok számolgatással.

RATING: 4
Several plays on BSW.  Had me remarking on how clever some of its facets were.  The varying power plants and auction system -- clever!  The turn order mechanism -- clever!  The raw materials economy simulation -- very clever!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Interesting subject as a game.  The game is a simple business game in that one acts as a power giant looking for expansion across U.S. (or any other continent) the power network, bringing light to the cities while collecting revenues.  

There are a lot of good ideas integrated in the game and they generally working very well with one another.  For example, building a power plant cost you a sums of money but it is a fixed amount across all different cities and you can only build a maximum one power plant in a city.  So you have to expand to the neigbouring cities.  Other latecomer to the city can build the second and the third power plant at an incrementally higher cost.  

There are different power plants to choose from, mainly they vary in the type and amount of resources used to generate power and the no. of cities that could be served by a single plant.  In turn, you can only serve the cities that you have a power plant in.  Hence, rapid purchase in the power plants doesn't guarantee you big profit and you have to purchase power plants in cities to catch up.  You can only have a maximum of 3 power plants and so you have to gradually replace the old one with the more efficient one.  Every power plant in the market is up for sale in an auction after a player declare his interest in a plant.  People would bid for it according to his strategy in future development.  People would generally pay more for more efficient power plant.      

There are 4 types of resources to generate power; namely coal, oil, garbage and uranium.  I quite like the mini system on the economy where supply and demand of resources would change the cost of each unit of resources.  There are limited supplies of resources in the market.  In one 3-player game, many players go for the same resources and therefore resource prices go up as the restock of each type of resources according to a constant rate grows relatively slower than the demand.  

Cities are connected with transit costs.  You can only expand your power network to the adjacent cites with a connection.  The first place you decide to build your power plant upon is therefore important as you naturlaly would like to expand to the surrounding cities with the least costs.  for example, cities in the east coast of U.S. are generally less expensive to connect while it cost you a huge fortune to connect the west from the east across the central part of U.S.     

To balance the game, the leader in a turn is the first one to pick up the plant for purchase but the last one to purchase resources from the market.  To win the game, a player who powered the most cities in his entire network in the end turn with sufficient resources.  If the power plant is not working due to no resources, the no. of cities by that plant doesn't count.

Overall, I generally like the game.  It is not as abstract as many other Euro-type games whereas it is realsitic to a certain extent.  It is also a competitive game when people begin to cross to other player's sphere of influence.  The game can be completed quite quickly and is easy to teach to kids. The game is not meant to be an exhaustive business simulation and so serious gamers might still hungry for more.  For example, the game focuses more on the supply side of the economics and the market demand side of electricity is not modelled.  Demand for electricity in each city is constant.  But then, that could be another game Power Grid 2.0.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is was one of the first games I saw the rules for on [url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=35]Board Games with Scott[/url]. To be fair, this episode did not impress me very much. The game seemed dry, fiddly, and more complicated than it needed to be. Needless to say, the game was not on my radar.

Move to a few months later when a gaming buddy brings over Power Grid. Well, I will try anything at least once. The game moved slowly because we had to reference the rules often, but I found it interesting regardless. Although Power Grid is basically a network connection game, the dryness did not bother me. The game is fiddly, but we found ways to deal with this issue, which also helped remember some of the more obscure rules. Also, I won which helped me to like the game!

After playing a second time, here is what I have learned:
-- Initial placement is very important to expand quickly and build up monies for your infrastructure. 
-- Along with initial placement, initial expansion is also important. If you are cut off early, it will be difficult to recover.
-- Put someone in charge of the Power Plant auctions. It is too much for the game explainer to run everything. This is an easy way to get the others involved. Further, they can remember the oddities of the auctions (i.e., removing high/low power plants) freeing you up for other rule issues.
-- Put someone else in charge of money for many of the same reasons as above. Actually, we just put the money in reach of everyone to do their own banking.
-- Turn order is important.
-- Money is the tie-breaker. Some people think the game is broken because too many games end in initial ties. I think the money tie-breaker works well as you have to plan for it the entire game.

The game is actually relatively easy to learn despite all the mechanics going on. My only concern right now is about initial placement. This aspect is so important that I worry it will dictate who the winner will be.

Final thought. Bring a calculator. You will probably need it.

---
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/item/386336#item386336]online resources[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Very intensive game involving simple math, complex networking and strategy, and understanding your opponent's strategies as you play against them more often.  This was my first board game after Catan and I was amazed at the gameplay and resource system.  I love how everyone can go from buying minimum resources and letting the market cheapen to crashing the market in one fell swoop.

I find almost every match -win or lose- a rewarding experience.  I can usually pinpoint the exact turn I screwed up and try to make a note in the future. I also love how often our games have ended where the winner is decided by $4 or less

A couple of gripes: the game becomes less stragetic with 3 players as everyone can build on every city. Even with the slingshotting, I've rarely played a game where the last place person in stage 2 comes out victorious.  It usually takes the combined effort of each opponent to bring down the leader to 2nd place. It is a very laborious game, after two matches we rarely have the willpower to play another.

These are minor and finicky.  I feel the auctioning, the resource market, the strategic play order; it all makes for a very enjoyable 1.5 hours.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Power Grid still sat on the shelf for a long time due to its poor 2-player reputation.  At some point, we looked into getting [thing=108667][/thing], since it seemed like that might make the game better for two players.  However, what finally pushed us over the edge were the revamped two player rules found in [thing=155873][/thing] ([b][url=http://riograndegames.com/Game/1282-Power-Grid-Deluxe]Rulebook[/url][/b]), which we just took and used with our regular copy.  These rules set up "The Trust", essentially a streamlined dummy or robot player.  What was nice, though, was that rules and maintenance for The Trust were very straightforward, so we finally gave it a shot.

Besides the poor two-player reputation, there were a few other hurdles we had to get through first.  For being a classic Euro game, the rulebook was very confusing (and it's not a surprise that there are so  many questions on the forums here).  Even once we had an idea of the gameplay, for a streamlined Euro game, there were a lot of fiddly rules that had us constantly checking the rulebook (how many resources should you restock when, how much money should you get, when to take or not take cards from the power plant deck, etc.)  I was also a little worried that it might be similar to the Crayon-rails games, and we really did not like [thing=168][/thing].  One of the foreboding aspects was that it did seem like you were doing the same things over and over again (buy power plants, buy resources, buy cities, get income, rinse and repeat).  Would it stay interesting?

Despite all that...we actually really liked it!  Even as a two-player game!  The Trust really does simulate competition for the power plant auction, resources, and especially the board networking in a very easy way with little upkeep.  At first, the power plant auction, the resources, and the city networking felt like separate processes, but quickly we found they all intersected with money driving the engine.  Figuring out the optimal point on the curve between all three is a challenge, particularly while at the same time gauging what the other players are doing.  The end game and winning conditions are a little weird, so the first half of the game feels like a prolonged setup to maneuver your actions last few turns, but we remained engaged throughout.  It was after our first game that my wife's eyes lit up---she had managed to build into enough cities to trigger the ending and thought she was in for an easy win, but I was able to (with the help of The Trust) buy up all the resources to prevent her from actually running her power plants!  The possibilities and consequences of your actions reverberate through the entire game.  It really tapped into our fondness for building and optimization games.

That being said, we've since tried this as a five player game with a few friends, and it was amazing.  You can see how the different economic engines converge and how the actions of the different players really drive how everything plays out.   Yes, with more players, the interactions between the players dramatically increases and it's far better than with just two.  On face value, the economic engines look fairly straightforward, but the human element is fantastic---the amount of interaction in [thing=2651][/thing] is almost a complete shift from the multiplayer solitaire aspect of more recent designs (e.g., Feld games).  Initially, we were worried that just going through the same set of actions over and over again would get boring, but we felt engaged the whole time [i]because[/i] of the human interaction, with each player trying to manipulate the game state (not only the auctions, resource market, and territories, but also things like turn order).  I suppose [thing=2651][/thing] really is a classic for a reason.  

Still, even with two, it's not so bad and it's something that my wife and I have played when it's just the two of us.  So far, we've stuck with using the rules for The Trust, but as we become better at the game, we'll give [thing=108667][/thing] a try---we have a copy, but the rulebook (again) seems very confusing.  Maybe it's just the language that we're not getting.  One advantage with The Trust is how easy it is and how fast it goes (you really don't have to deal with exchanging any money or bidding with The Trust), so even for now we've been pretty happy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
This is a awesome game ... one of the best I've ever played. The way the market for resources works is so very inspired and is alone responsible for a lot of strategic thinking.
Must have in every collection I guess.

RATING: 3
This game feels like a collection of solitaire games clumsily hacked together into an atrocious kludge.  The only real interaction with other players comes when bidding.  The scarcity in the commodities market is itself scarce.  The game seems largely determined by the randomness of the power plants showing up, and this means the strategy of the game is to sit in last place so you have the best shot at getting one.  The game could probably be fixed if the prices for commodities and earnings from powering cities were both raised, but that would take some play testing, and probably wouldn't eliminate the solitaire feel of the game.

RATING: 6
I love the theme, the resource management mechanism, and the board and tokens are fun to use. The dynamic *should* be intuitive and smooth flowing, but even on our 5-6th play, it progresses painfully slowly, since we are always thinking and rethinking who is going first for which action, and why. Also, all the niggly number juggling for maximum strategizing makes it a bit too carry-the-one for me to really enjoy play. Even the rate at which resources are renewed for each turn is impossible to memorize because it changes from phase to phase and depending on the number of players. We consult the charts in the rules about every 2-5 minutes in this game, which slows it down and gets in the way of the flow. Maybe I'll enjoy the next game more if I play it with a calculator and notepad.

RATING: 4
Played only on BSW.  I decided to downgrade to a 7 from an 8 for the time being because I just don't feel myself drawn to play the game, even though it is very good and I enjoy it when I play.  Some of it is that the game suffers from an awkward dilemma.  The game doesn't really start to get interesting (for me) until you play with 4 players, which creates the possibility of being completely locked out of a city, but with that many players or more I begin to find the downtime a little annoying.

UPDATE: I've dropped this to a 6.  The downtime is too annoying, and the interesting decisions just aren't frequent enough.  This feels like a one hour game that runs much too long (note, it plays faster on BSW, but to be of more use, I'm putting my comments in FtF terms).  I'm sure I haven't plumbed the full depths of the strategy and tactics of this game, but I don't feel drawn enough to go deeper.

UPDATE: Dropped another 2 points. I never feel a pull to play PG any more, and often try to wriggle out of it when others suggest it.

It just bores me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very interesting resource management game with a lot of opportunities.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
While this game is very number-crunchy, it combines Euro-quality mechanics with a large amount of interaction and a unique theme I highly enjoy (energy). 

This is through the value that you should bid for each power plant varying drastically depending on the current game situation, shrewd money/resource management (while my first 10 games I rarely saw resources go above cost 4, I have learned better, and now I've played games where people were unable to win because all the coal or trash were bought), and the person in "last place" getting better turn order placement preventing a runaway leader while leading to some interesting situations where you you don't want to build up to max capacity.

Blocking off people to claim a territory for yourself and jacking up the prices of resources are the main methods of interaction. However, I like that while you can definitely hinder someone greatly, it rarely occurs that you can screw someone over so badly that they are basically out of the game.

As I said I love the energy theme and I think it is implemented quite well. My only gripe is I feel like some of the renewable plants are quite under powered.

The US board is by no means regionally balanced (East coast of the US has much cheaper connections); however this does not mean the game as a whole is unbalanced, as you can face less competition if you start closer to the west, and I wonder if it was intentional (you can also have a slightly shorter game by choosing only regions with low connection costs).

I think this game is best with 3-5 (yes everyone can build on every city with 3, but by that point the game is almost over anyways). 2 players makes Step 2 a bit anticlimactic and devolves the auction mechanic, and 6 players works but is a little bit unwieldy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It seems to promote inaction. Odd feel to the game IMO.

RATING: 7.91
Comments entered on 10 Feb 2010:

Power Grid has a fantastic mix of building connections, creating infrastructure, and managing limited resources. The number of official map expansions provide a lot of different puzzles to figure out.

There have been several games that I have played now where more than one person has achieved the number of cities required to end the game, both are able to power them up, and the game is decided by the remaining cash on hand.

I have purchased the base game as well as the France/Italy, Benelux/Central Europe, and China/Korea maps. I have not yet purchased the newest map release of Brazil/Spain & Portugal. I also purchased the Power Plant 2 deck.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An economic game.  The power plant auction is fun, which pits your needs for power generation and supply of available cash against your opponents'.  I also like the supply and demand of the fluctuating resource market--this is where Power Grid is sheer brilliance.  The importance of turn-order makes for some interesting decisions.  I am not particularly good at this game, but that's ok.   Does not work at all for only two players, contrary to the recommendation on the box [2-6].  But this makes for a good and tense economic game with 4 or 5 players.  Comparable in feel to other economic games like "Steam."   Do Not Forget the "often forgotten" rules carefully pointed out at the end of the rules, particularly the four conditions whereby you must remove a plant from the auction block.

TTFN

RATING: 10
Pretty friggin' marvelous.  Hard to imagine a better fusion of mechanics that don't necessarily go together.  Ready to call it the best auction game, period, and that's on top of having cool area control and market manipulation stuff going on.  Challenging choices, constant player interaction, frequent reassessments of who's really ahead... I'm engaged all the time, and almost never feel like I'm out of it, even if I might be.  Yes, the last turn is a grinding math-fest; I can live with that.  But the game has tension, it has ebb and flow, it has a lovely balance of strategy and tactics.  All that might make it a 9.  But for me, it's the truly distinct, ugly-on-purpose aesthetics that seal the deal, complete the package, and put it over the top.

RATING: 8.25
Nice components.  Seats 3,4 and 5 players quite comfortably, gets pretty darn cramped with 6 players though.  Otherwise, the game scales very well.  A lot of thought has been put into varying the set-up per the number of players, and per each map (I own the expansion, so have played on the US, Germany and France maps so far... have yet as of 5/2006 to play on the Italy map, which looks brutal).This game is an easy enough game to play if you want to stay in the running and not fall miserably behind, but is a very, very difficult game to win.  Comments such as "my brain hurts" and "but do I want to do that?" and "it's more complicated than I thought" can be heard around the table.  At the same time, the auctions are a lot of fun, and so is watching your network grow.  

One thing is for sure... download and use some of the player aids here on the Geek.  I found the "restocking templates" to be particularly useful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Sleeved
49 x Fantasy Flight Square

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great economic game where you need to carefully balance your power plant capacity, cost of inputs, and expansion of your network.  The game is very well designed and if you like economic games, you will love Power Grid.  The game can be "mathy" but that is part of the appeal of many economic games.  It does seem like you are the CFO of a power company trying to determine how best to invest your resources to optimize your network.  The game is a reasonable 30 minutes per player.  It may be a little too complicated for children under 12 but definitely good for older kids.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A Brilliant game, full of hard decisions and clever moves.

RATING: 3

The board seems like kind of an afterthought even though by appearances it should be a more integrally involved part of the game.  I don't really like the victory condition.  The luck of the draw of power plants seems too important for a game that takes this long to play.  I'd rather play a more streamlined auction game for the most part, say Ra or Modern Art.

RATING: 9

This is a big contrast to St. Petersburg (the one other game our gaming group likes a lot).  The only reason I won't rate Power Grid higher is because I will never be able to play it with my "less hardcore" relatives.  So while this is a great game, it certainly isn't for everyone.

After a few more plays, the rating has gone up one more, I love this game.

This is evil... after replaying my last game in my head, I find myself wanting to play just one more game.

RATING: 7
The best replacement for Monopoly.  Takes about the same amount of time, maybe less, but is so much more balanced, you are able to come back from being in a bad place, there's no dice determining what and where you can go/get, and even interactions with other players is balanced nicely and not much more than an inconvenience that you can work around with just a little more cash.  I never felt slighted by the game, nor completely out of the race because of either my bad decisions or luck, and the player's in last place are always given the advantage at every step.

Abigail owns it, so I'll never need to. Plus, First Sparks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Outstanding game with excellent mechanism! Leaves a strong desire to play it a lot more often. Every turn feels like a tightrope act... don't go too far! And for those who have fallen down/behind there is a built-in safety net (catch-up mechanism = turn order). I love the different ways it has been played during our sessions. This game is a big hit!

Attention: It needs a few games to get all the details and Power Grid can easily exceed two hours playing time. Not recommended for family gaming.

RATING: 6
(Math Trade: Got it for [boardgame=55427][/boardgame] in [geeklist=99364][/geeklist], 2012-01-26)

Solid game where players must deal with buying power plants, buying resources, and buying new city connections. The trick is to know when to do each of them to position yourself for the turn orders for buying at the right time. The game seems to drag a bit in Step 1, and picks up a lot in step 2. It also isn't as diversified as many other great games, so could be repetitive.

RATING: 6
I had the first edition of that one, but when I tried out the update I knew that I needed it. I think this is Friedemanns homage to the 18xx style games. Very clever bidding and resource management game, with lots of depth and high replay  value. The second edition got rid of lots of ballast and made the game so much more pretty (for a economics game that is ...).

Update: downgraded to a 6. With equally skilled players the game is too much dependent on luck of draw in the plants pile.

RATING: 8.5
Really like this game. Love the auction mechanic and the resource supply/demand is wonderful. 

Even though measures are put in place to prevent a runaway leader, it seems like usually 1 or 2 players pull ahead and it can be difficult to catch them. The early game is important for keeping up and giving yourself a chance to win. Even if you play poorly at the beginning you usually feel successful and are having a good time as long as you're powering a few buildings and making money. Plus you're still somewhat powerful in the auction, even if you're behind. Of course, this can lead to some kingmaking once you realize you're losing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
蠻像是複雜版的Ticket to Ride
除了建築路線之外，另外還加上要有足夠的資源才能產生電力
這樣的變化性會更加提高一些，挺適合長時間遊玩的中度策略遊戲

不過初次遊玩會對於發電廠的價值錯誤評估，可能玩過一輪之後才會比較知道該張卡片的價值，進而在競標的時候調整出價

另外遊戲的計分方式有點太單調就是，單純最後一回合的發電力，感覺可以增加其他的策略性任務，整區佔領加分等等，不然會淪為Greedy去進行遊戲，沒有長期規劃
而且遊戲過程中會發現蠻偏向滾雪球，發展好的人拿到更多資源蓋更多東西，但是卻沒有其他可以逆轉或是牽制的動作可以進行(大概只有競標的時候可以去針對領先者)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I love Power Grid! The auction system and resource management components are awesome. We spend far too much time in each play of this game, but it is really enjoyable. 

I like to teach this to people who have played Ticket To Ride but are looking for something more. While it is very different, it has the same connections kind of idea but without the having to fulfill a series on a card that you drew. Add in buying plants and resources, and you've got a really great strategy game.

I have picked up an expansion map, the Robots and the new card deck. We'll see how much depth that adds to the game.

I don't think that we have played enough to really have a perfect strategy figured out for the base game - this keeps us wanting to play more so that we can work on maximizing our potential.

Anglais
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Power Grid is a mixed bag. 

On the one hand, it is beautiful; it's a really well designed game that manages to be both on the heavier side while managing a pretty good pacing with an experienced crowd. The different phases are well balanced and you'll be making meaningful choices the whole way. On it's best day, it manages to be dynamic and fun,. You're walking a thin line, however, since bad decisions made early can seriously impair your ability to compete on the long run. This, of course, might lead to crippling player paralysis. 

On the other hand, Power Grid's biggest flaw, in my honest opinion, is math centrism. It a cold and calculating world at there (at least before you put the power on). You don't play Power Grid as much as you calculate it, which reduce player interaction to near zero as everyone is silently counting while wishing for a TI-85. It's kind of the reverse party game, as people find themselves heavily isolated and focusing on their own calculations. Don't expect to enjoy company as much as the cold reality of an energy magnate.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great Euro-game that combines elements of auction and economic supply and demand mechanics.  Perhaps the best feature is the constantly changing turn-order, which forces players to evaluate carefully how quickly they expand their power empire - least they end up having to pay premium prices for the raw materials necessary to run their power plants.  The multi-step round process also helps ensure that all players stay engaged and cuts back on the likelihood of that 'one player who takes forever' killing the game's momentum.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Can be quite thinky.  If you you want to make the very most optimal moves you can there is actually quite a bit of information in front of you, but you gotta crunch some numbers... consider your current amount of cash, how much resources are and will be, how much money you will make in the next phase, etc. etc. etc..

If you're set on doing the best you can possibly do, there is no escaping it.  I find myself not wanting it to be so prone to analysis, but then analyzing anyway because I want to compete.

I do like it though... just not one of my favorites.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The new version makes that game play more smoothly and is quite enjoyable.  A four player game (with one new player and three that had played the old version once or twice) took just over two hours.  Much better.  The power grid version components are very nice.

The only thing that really bugs me about the game is when the power plant queue bogs down and/or the game is thrown out of whack by a plant coming out at just the right time to provide a major advantage for one player.  

My opinion has diminished over time because I've played in several games where the flow of the power plants has lead to an anti-climactic step 2 end game.

10+ plays

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Some people despise the turn order shenanigans this game engenders, but those people are missing the point.  That game of musical chairs is not an unintended consequence of this game, but rather a deliberate design choice to give the players pause when it comes to how they approach each round.  The game wants to punish those ahead, and help those behind.  A good player makes sure they are helped when they are not actually behind, and the only ones punished as those not already ahead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.75
Descriptions of this as math-fussy really turned me off from it, but I've played it a few times and really liked it. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A solid game that manages to be fun and a bit of a crunch at the same time. 

Likes
-No player really can run away with the game in the beginning, allowing for play to stay challenging and competitive until the last round. 
-The auction mechanic can be fun when people are competing for similar power plants.
-There are three distinct "steps" that force players to change strategies as resources shift in their abundance.

Dislikes
-The rules are written terribly, like oh my god why is the rulebook laid out like this.
-The art is a bit bland and repetitive, as everything just looks roughly the same with minor differences.
-The paper money that ships with the game is terrible, this will be the first thing I will need to replace, and at the rate they're deteriorating, the paper money will be useless in about 5-7 playthroughs.
-The game can feel a bit slow at times, as there isn't much to do at points.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
At first I liked this game much. But After several plays it went down. The reasons are:

1. Plant distribution is too random. It has various effects:
i) If good power plant don't come out long in the middle of the game, game play stalls and gets boring.

ii) It is not uncommon that someone can buy good plant cheap by luck, while others fought over a good plant before. Obviously the former gets huge advantage.

iii) In end game, plant draw often determines who is the winner.

In short, when experienced players are there, the winner is determined by luck of plant draw.

2. Game plays are not very different, even if map changes each play. Strangely, map changes don't provide significant and satisfying alterations in game play. Well, random power plants give significant and unsatisfying alterations.

3. With that amount of luck, it would be good to play this lightly. But it is hardly possible. It requires much arithmatical work every turn, and it is a bit too long for a light game.

UPDATE July 2007:
Rating down to 4.5. I don't want to play this again. It just doesn't reward your careful plans and agonizing decisions, because of random power plant.

RATING: 9
No idea why, but I avoided this game for a long time. Son gave it to me for Christmas, and about midway through our first game a feeling came over me that hadn't happening in quite awhile.  1830 has been my idea of the perfect game for a long time (even though because of its length it doesn't get played), and I truly miss the days of playing that remarkable game. Power Grid gives me that same feeling.  The mechanics fit together well, the game is tense, thought provoking, and when finished with our first game my son and I both wanted another game. (a little too much math for my wife) Superb game that I can't to introduce to others.

A la tête d'une entreprise d'électricité, les joueurs vont développer leur compagnie en implantant des relais dans diverses villes allemandes ou états-uniennes, en acquérant des centrales toujours plus productives (centrales à charbon, à recyclage de déchets, nucléaires, éoliennes), et en cherchant à alimenter efficacement le plus de villes possible.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
Mi primer juego, a siete ciudades. Le doy un 10. Quedé encantado con el juego; con gusto a poco...ya deseo volver a jugar. 
Es, en ciertos aspectos parecido a construcciones de caminos o líneas férreas, y de bloqueo de puntos en un mapa, como Ticket to Ride, pero con mucha más estrategia, combinada con remate de bienes (bastante sencillo en todo caso), y decisiones de compra de recursos.
Bastante interacción en un juego de 5.
Veremos cómo evoluciona y si mantengo la nota.
Mis comentaristas favoritos de este sitio, y que he puesto en mi lista de "Asesores", GeekBuddy Analysis, le dan a este juego un total de 7.85 puntos, uno de los más altos.
UPDATE: Tras el segundo juego, con 5 jugadores y a 17 ciudades, donde llegué segundo con 16 ciudades proveidas, mantengo la calificación. Estoy esperando jugar de nuevo.
UPDATE:
Los pros del juego:
1.- Muy buena interación entre el tema del mismo, ampliar la red de una Empresa eléctrica (que es a la vez generadora, transmisora y distribuidora) con el mecanismo de juego. Se aparta de la mayoría de los juegos "alemanes".
2.- Interesante interacción en cuanto a que las decisiones de  uno afectan a los demás: al momento de rematar una planta; al momento de comprar los recursos, porque la compra de los demás afecta el precio; al momento de comprar las Distribuidoras en las ciudades, ante un eventual bloqueo; en el orden de juego (el primero es castigado porque paga más caro por los recursos y compra al final las Distribuidoras).
UPDATE: dos nuevos juegos a dos jugadores; excelente nivel de estrategia; el más mínimo error cerca del final, cuesta la partida. Con dos buenos jugadores, el nivel es muy parejo. Sigue en 10 para dos jugadores!
3-1-07: Tras varios juegos más, me está aburriendo toda la burocracia en el trámite. Mucha suma y resta al final; si alguien se ubica mal, puede quedar rezagado y sin chance para el resto del juego. Baja a 7.

ENGLISH
My first game, to 7 cities. I give it a 10. I was charmed with the game; i want more ...i wish to play again as soon as possible.
It is, in certain aspects seemed to constructions of roads or strong lines, and of blockade of points in a map, as Ticket to Ride, but with much more strategy, combined with auctions of goods (quite simple), and decisions of purchase of resources.  
Enough interaction in a game of 5.  
We will see how it evolves and if I maintain the rating.  
My geekbudies gives to this game a total of 7.85 points, one of the highest.  
UPDATE: After the second game, with 5 players and to 17 cities, where I arrived second with 16 supplied cities, I maintain the qualification. I am hoping to play again.  
UPDATE:  
The pros of the game:  
1. - very good interaction among the topic of the same one, to enlarge the net of an electric Company (that is at the same time generating, transmitting & distributing) with the game mechanism. It moves away from most of the German games. 
2. - interesting interaction as for that the decisions of one affect to the other ones: to the moment to finish off a plant; to the moment to buy the resources, because the purchase of the other ones affects the price; to the moment to buy the Distributors in the cities (represented by little houses), before an eventual blockade; in the game order (the first one is punished because more expensive pay for the resources and purchase at the end the Distributors).  
UPDATE: two new games with 2 players; excellent strategy level; the most minimum error near the end, costs the departure. With two good players, the level is very even. Continue in 10 for two players!
UPDATE JANUARY 2007: after many new games played, I think there is too much downtime, AP, specially in the last rounds. If someone is blocked at the begining of the game, it's a very boring situation for the rest of his game, with almost null posibility to come back. 7.

The second time we played with 3, and it went more smoothly--though it still took 2  hours, the action keeps moving and there is no down time.  I would like a player aid to help keep track of some things.  For instance the board is kept language-neutral, which unfortunately makes it almost "information-free."

RATING: 8
One of the more heavy games in my collection. Lots of subtle strategy in fairly simple steps and is somewhat self balancing due to the turn order system and auctions.

The only downside is the large amount of mental math and management involved in the markets (adding new resources and tiles to the board) which can be tedious in a fairly long duration game.

RATING: 9
Rating of 9 based on two plays.  This game has easily become my favorite eurogame.  I love the supply and demand aspect of the fuel resources in particular, but all aspects of the game have so far hit the right buttons with me.  While there's no direct confrontation, there's plenty of indirect actions that just verge on direct (buying up resources an opponent needs, bidding up plants, temporarily blocking map areas) that make this game more than simply a race to the finish as in so many other eurogames.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I think this might be my favorite Euro -- I can't believe I waited so long to get it.

I was put off a bit by all the reviews that talked about how fiddly the three stages were and by how much math (arithmetic, really) there is, especially toward the end.

But as it turns out, those factors (though true -- the stages are kind of odd, and klunkily named, especially when you also have 'phases') don't really matter much at all. This thing's near the top of the charts for a reason.

It's the first game that I've purchased since re-entering the hobby that I wanted to play again [i]immediately[/i] after the initial session. Don't worry about the calculations, if you generally like Eurogames you are almost  certain to enjoy this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
I do not tire of this game.  So much fun. Strategy and auction together makes it really interesting.  Forward planning is essential for playing this game well.  At home we play by hiding cash, it might seem unsportsman like at first, but it adds the extra element of having to be aware how much your opponents are earning and spending.  It is important to know exactly how much cash you have, but working out the real value of cards available at auction is ultimately an art, and makes the game what it is.

I take a mark off though, the player mechanic of leader going last means that games remain so balanced at the end that luck from cards drawn from the stack is augmented.  It is really useful to have a player mechanic that makes games  go to the wire, but its not uncommon for someone to have done a lot of hard work in the game to build an advantage, only for there to be a lucky draw for an opponent who can then go on to win the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
This game is "shockingly" fun. The addtionnal maps add soooo much more to the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Its all about being power hungry... literally! In Power Grid, you have the opportunity to delve into the lucrative power industry and bring light to those in the dark. 

Bringing electricity to the whole country isn't that easy (and its never cheap) as you need to purchase efficient power plants and sequester the resources needed to power them. Once those are in the bag, you'll need to establish a foothold in the market by building and connecting your power network across the country. Expanding will certainly help you get closer to being that magnate. But its not about having the most cities, but having the most that light up when you flip that power switch. You can't call yourself a successful power mogul if your network is wrought with frequent blackouts. 

The balance of power in this game doesn't seem to stay in one place. The changing player sequence, the laws of supply and demand and the various changing game stages are some of the mechanisms that provide very interesting twists to the overall game play. Power Grid beautifully depicts the economics of power generation and can bring out the aggressive expansionists, and the business conspirators, among your friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Game with auctions can never be completely dry even though Power Grid tries hard with it's industrial theme and paper-money. I'm half-kidding, because Power Grid really isn't dry. True, there are players who play this with calculator and calculate every step, and I'm happy for them, but really, you don't have to be such player to enjoy this one. At the end of the day it's a nice, streamlined medium euro with great replayability.

2-Player Comment:
* Power Grid is very disappointing game as it doesn't come with any variant to make auctions work with two (despite promising 2-6 scale). With Robots expansion it's very good 2p game, but managing the Robot does take lots of extra effort.

Expansions:
+France/Italy map expansion
+Benelux/Central Europe map expansion
+New Power Plant cards
+Promo cards
+Robots expansion

RATING: 7

Which really means that it's a game about timing. One of the best games I own nevertheless.

Plus there are expansions up the wazoo, which is always a good thing.

RATING: 7.5
A very solid game, but not one I feel the need to play often or have in my collection.   

There is alot going on in Power Grid.  Timing and turn order are very important and something that needs to be very carefully managed.  As does the timing of when to buy resources, and the type of plants to build, and how much to pay, and where to expand on the map to block others.  

Difficult for casual play against more regular players as they will be able to more accurately judge the value of the plants up for auction - and manage all the other things.  Would reward repeated play.

The feeling of winning a plant for less than its perceived value = priceless.
