=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great concept and theme. Nice production and rule book. Scales well and I like the resource management, different power options and the different phases. 

However, it’s a bit long and I hate primary auction mechanics. The problem with auctions is that new players never know what to value something at, and since the game takes so long, you’re not going to get a lot of plays in for new players. I like that the cards are pre-printed with values and that does help in many cases, but not enough. 

Edit: Played a few more times and still same randomness of the auction ruins it. Always ends up being a splash down of cities to win. And if after every game every says "well, that was just a weird/bad/unlucky power plant draw", then the game is simply not good enough. 

The randomness of the draws is interesting, but perhaps too random as well. Played a game once where a 36 made it to the auction block while still in the teens really. Definitely changed the game. Though rare and I suppose you could house rule a few things to prevent, especially for learning games. 

Still, a good, tight game with tough decisions, risk, and tension.  If you had some good learning game variants and ways to chop some time down, it would be great.

RATING: 10
Played 8 times.
Last Played March 15, 2009

I played it as a 3 player game and we found it very interesting and very fun.  I liked all the catch up mechanisms built in so you never felt like you were totally out of the game even if you were a little behind everyone else for a little while. 

We had to end the game early due to time constraints but at the end we all had 14 plants and 14 powered so it came down to who had the most money.

Second game was with more players but still had to end it early.  I need to buy this game so I can play it with out running out of time.

Finally bought it and played a full game.  I was way in last place but still enjoyed myself, which is a mark of a good game in my book. :)

Just played it as a 2 player and it was quite good.  The game was close the whole time, and If I had just been quite about my planning rather than mumbling aloud I could have won by powering all 21 when my husband could only power 20, but because I was vocal, he managed to play the auction to his advantage and was lucky that a 7 power plant came out.  So the tiebreaker he sconked me on, $3 to $76

This game is definitely rising on my like list.  I could see it hitting a 10 if I could ever win it. :)

I finally won! :)  Barely... thanks to having the monopoly in Trash and Uranium.  I could only power 16 cities, but nobody else could power more and I had more money (4 player game)

I must be getting better, I just won again and this time pretty hands down. :D

RATING: 2.5
Overrated 

A game is no longer fun when you have players taking out calculators to try and figure out the best move.  This is especially true if their sole purpose of doing so is to prevent a single player from winning in an effort to prolong a game that has already gone on for twice as long has it should have.  Yes, this actually happened.

The game has some positive aspects and is well designed in some ways, but if playing a game feels like a "day job," then it is no longer a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
This is a very good economic modeling game.  The power theme is cool and is well built into the game, but the mechanics could work for anything.  It plays very well with 3 and though it doesn't scale that well to 2 players, it is still interesting.  A lot of people comment about problems with the end game and a kill the leader issue, but I really don't see that.  The game rewards good planning in three areas: 1. setting up connection routes (before other players) to lock in cheap connections and potential for cheap expansion. 2. Fuel market calisthenics - making sure you get a reasonable price when purchasing fuel (and also balancing your plants so you're not totally dependent on one fuel.  3. Money management in a tight economy - including having reserves for bidding and doing auctions as smart as possible.

All in all, a very nice game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We keep playing this... I am waiting for a game that doesn't end with "huh? its over... um ok" It isn't that we don't see the ending coming it just feels so anti-climatic. I seem to have problems conveying this to big fans of the game.. they keep telling me they are so good they know the ending is coming up, blah blah blah, yes, so do I, stil has a "ok I guess we're done" feel.

I like the actual game play itself.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
(Note: the play count might be a little low as I usually credit any in-play expansion used rather than the base game.)

World's greatest subtracting game!

I love Power Grid, I'd give it a 9 if I really thought it was a game.  But with three things (plants, resources and connections) that need to be purchased each round, and needing to look closely at the board to determine their costs, it becomes like a math exercise, and very much like the business simulations I did during my Business Administration days in college.  It's the only game I play with pencil and paper.

The endgame can get quite fiddly and result in some strange auctions for plants depending on what resources are available and what plants are still in the draw pile. (I played one game where the only chance I would have had to win was if I had over 100 Elektro left to buy the 34 plant. Too bad I could only bid 80!)

I find this more fun to play every time I get the chance. I've got a friend who has all the expansions, so we play on a different map each time, and my analysis paralysis seems to be abating with experience. The rating should only go up!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
02/01/05 Played a six-player game once, which was 3.2 hours of excruciating number crunching. The game looked nice and I liked its theme, which is why I initially said I’d play it. But I had no idea I’d be doing almost nothing but math for over three hours. So, if you have an accountant type mind, you’ll probably like it. If not it will be as much fun as: doing your monthly budget, your kid’s high school math homework, and your taxes all rolled into one. Oh, and if you get behind, don’t expect to catch up, or hurt the leader. Even all this wouldn’t have caused me to rate it this low if it had been shorter. But after 3.2 hours of it I was mentally exhausted. I won’t quite say I hated it, I reserve that for Age of Steam and Java, but its real close.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.1

RATING: 9
Okay, I'm convinced. This is a thoroughly enjoyable game that seems to scale well and strikes the right balance between development and resource management. It only became that after I played it with people who'd worked through the rules and played it a lot though - in my previous attempts it was shocking (pun not intended) because the rules as written are shocking (okay, intended that time). I still think the arithmetic is a bit of a chore, and the resource market is really fiddly - I recently played someone else's game where silly little skinny bits of dowel were used as uranium rods. They constantly fell over and twice rolled off the table. My copy has the new octagonal rods and I'm grateful for that.

A triumph of good game over poor rule book.

RATING: 8
This was the first game I played with the local gaming group.  This was my introduction to the world of hobbyist gaming (well, I had played Settlers of Catan once prior), my gateway game.  I was hooked.  As such it retains a special place in my collection.  I still enjoy playing it periodically.

Nice economic game.  Bidding, resource management, turn-order management, and building on the map.  All good stuff.

The game is all about timing, really.  Realizing when that final turn is coming and preparing for it.  The game almost always ends on the $ tie-breaker.

RATING: 8
As Euro as Euro comes, Power Grid features auctions, resource management, wooden blocks and maths enough to make your phone's calculator bleed. In spite of a bunch of buch of mechanics and rules changing when eras change as the game goes on the game manages to reasonbly and abstractly simulate a cutthroat competitive energy market are retained streamlined gameplay and adequate elegantness. The main draw back is the long session times, especially when playing with AP players, do not expect less than two hours. Recommended with three players or more, probably best with four.

RATING: 10
Wow!  It's been a long time since I've fallen in love with a game before I'm halfway through with my first play, but that's exactly how I felt with Power Grid.  I've thoroughly enjoyed the experience thus far as I never feel overwhelmed by any of the numerous decisions that are made throughout the game, and the steps necessary for victory are often easy to see, while not always easy to execute.  I love the numerous mechanics that have to be carefully balanced, including auctions, resource supply-and-demand, and area control.  It feels like an incredibly deep game with unending replay value, without every feeling overly complex or confusing.  I love this game so much; it's easily another 10 for me.

RATING: 9
Excellent game with many layers of thinking, planning and possible strategies.  This one will have you wondering about what you should/could have done long after the game is over.  It's a long(ish) game  but the time flies.  One small downside is the rule book that could have been a little more clear on the first reading (with confusing use of "turns,"rounds," and "steps" terms.)  Plus there are a bunch of minor money calculations, so be aware of your play crew.  Teaching the game was actually fairly easy.  Not a bad ramp up time at all.  Lots of levels of player interaction.  "Thicker" than most casual games, but very, very enjoyable.  Do buy some poker chips to replace the paper money.  It will speed your play time tenfold.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A pretty fun game.  It forces you to make some decisions during your turn.  My only complaint is that the person in the back can catch up too easily.  It seems to make the decision of when to step in the lead an important one because being behind has its advantages in getting resources and putting on new houses.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Game in a Nutshell: Almost purely economic game of bidding, resource collecting, and development/expansion in order to power the most plants when the end game is triggered.

Played as: 3 (practice phase) and 4,5 (full game) player

Played with: Power Plant Deck 2 and base deck

Pro: I like the combination of all the different game mechanics and surprisingly stays superbly balanced. Maybe one game that includes an auction and doesn't necessarily feel like it decides the winner.

Cons: Low interaction. Seems like there's way more number crunching then actual strategy and it's easy to botch a crucial play just by forgetting to carry a one or something in your arithmetic.  On top of that, no one seems to be enjoying themselves when this is on the table as there's no real sense of tension or excitement... just people concentrating on their math test.

Other notes: I'm serious when I say I don't really like this game. Despite that, there's a challenge to it that mocks me and a sickness that makes me want to keep giving it another try.

Best Use: I'd say people that would like this the most are ones who like a logic challenge and willing to sacrifice interaction to get it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I've played it a lot.  It is a good game, but I'm not sure it is a top 5 game.  First, there aren't many distinct strategies, just shades of the same one, driven by timing and jockeying for turn order.  Second, the topological element isn't that important; it can almost be ignored.  Certainly it's much less a factor than turn order, cash, plants, and fuel (even on the Italy map).

There's a good deal of arithmetic, which to me is a drawback.  

OK it's top 25.

RATING: 8.5
Fantastic game. Lots of tough decisions - could be prone to analysis paralysis with some groups (particularly due to the extremely tight money situation).

Have played it with 2, 3, 4 and 5 players. Not so great with 2, OK with 3, excellent with 4 or 5.

Mechanics (particularly related to the three Steps) are a little clunky, but serve the game well in maintaining the game's pace.

A gamers' game - unlikely to go over well with non-gamers or new gamers.

Thoroughly recommended.

RATING: 8
This game is significantly more simple to play than it first appears, though introducing new people to it can be painful.

(+) Dynamic resource market adjusting prices to demand
(+) A tense game where generally about half of the players are threats to win at the end
(+) Building connections is fun

(-) Perhaps over-rewards those with fewest stations - very hard to maintain any lead
(-) Can be very, very long - especially with those who haven't played before and those prone to AP.
(-) Terrible as a two-player game

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played once with three players on the France expansion map, once with four players on the Belgium expansion map, and once with three players on the USA map.  Players bid for power plants, buy resources to power those power plants, and buy networks that connect cities that they provide power to (and thus earn money).  Just about everything in the game is limiting (power plants, resources, city connections), and there are many excruciating decisions to make on each turn.  Unfortunately the game includes a tremendous amount of budgeting at every point (budgeting well is _key_ to victory), which slows things down and makes it less enjoyable than it might be otherwise.  Scoring occurs solely at the end of the game (which is of indeterminate length), which is a neat mechanic, but it means that the entire game revolves around how you perform on one turn.  This is a bit frustrating for many reasons, not the least of which is that it seems like the optimal strategy may be to try to lag behind and surprise everyone else on the last turn (and it also means that predicting the timing of the last turn is crucial, yet it's very difficult for unexperienced players).  

While I enjoy the meatiness of this game, I'd like it far better if it only took 1-2 hours to play instead of 3-4, and if there was more to the scoring than just the last turn.  

[Added after my third play: I'm realizing just how important experience is in this game; in my third game I played with people who were similarly unexperienced, and enjoyed it far more (even though I still lost).  Just like with chess, this experience requirement results in a game that's not much fun until you put the time into it to learn all the minutiae (unless you only play with players at a similar experience level).]

[Note: score lowered from 7.5 to 6 after the second playing]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
In “Power Plant,” players acquire (through auctions) and manage various types of power plants and try to power as many cities as possible. It’s played in three “steps” and at the end of the game the player who powers the most number of cities wins. The rulebook is somewhat badly written, which was cause for initial concern. However, I’m happy to say the game is solid! There are lots of bits to remember and do (I suggest printing out a reference sheet) but it's defiantly fun and engrossing. A great resource management game in the medium weight category. Recommended!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Buy power plants in auction, buy resources to use them and expand your network to supply most cities with power.

Plays: 1.
Type: VP engine = a game where you build an engine to collect victory points most efficiently.
Complexity: Medium.
# of players: See BGG.
Playing time: See BGG.
Player interaction: Competition for scarce resources – power plants and cities. Competition for unlimited resources for plants. Auctions. 
Randomness: Almost none.

Replayability: Medium. There is depth to explore.
Fun: In spite of being a (almost) perfect information efficiency engine, I don’t immediately hate it. I think I would hate it if available power plants were also perfect information. That slight uncertainty is enough for me to consider this number crunching a bit of fun. The interaction in auctions is also a bit exciting.
Memorability: Low, it’s a VP engine that doesn’t create stories.

Thematic integration: Strained.
Components: Functional.

Who will like this: Strategy gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.25

Sold during my auction.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great economic euro a little more on the heavier end of things.  Have had a lot of fun in the few plays I've had.  There is a real issue with the sandbagging/leader-punishing mechanic, but I knew that going in, and it really IS part of the game, so if you play to it, I didn't see it as a problem.  Still would have been nice to not have that "meta-game" at all, and for the designer to find a more creative way around those issues.  But that's pretty much the only complaint I have. Love the auctions, planning ahead for the cities you want, upgrading your power plants, the supply-demand mechanic; none of it is new or unique, but it all works quite well. I have not played 2 or 3 player, so I cannot comment on the scaling there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Interesting theme, simple rules, good lenght (3 to 4 hours), good number of players (4 to 5 is good). But...not enough interaction for me! Still willing to play most of the time since my group is thrilled with this one. They compete a lot so i can't stay behind. Only won once though, in many games played.
AFTER A FEW MORE GAMES: still fun, but has the same problem as many german longer games, like Wallenstein, which is to make you think a lot and for long. Brainburners like these come less often off the box. Anyway a great simulation and good fun.
UPDATE2008: again it is a great simulation and has very good mecanics. Too heavy for the casual eurogamer inside of me. Tremendous collective headache in the final hour of play!
OVERALL: 3 hours doing stuff and 1 final hour (2 or 3 turns only) hammering your mind for an optimized solution.

Ebben a témája sem segít, nehéz beleképzelni magunkat egy áramszolgáltató mindennapjaiba. Nagyon komoly, nagyon összetett, kvázi nulla szerencsefaktorral, ez viszont az élvezhetőség rovására megy (szvsz). Lásd még analízis-paralízis.

Szóval jó-jó, de nem az igazi. (Vagy csak én játszottam keveset vele.) Ettől még persze biztosan sokaknak ez a kedvence, amit mutat az előkelő BGG helyezése is.

Eladni persze nem fogom, mégis csak egy klasszikus és még az is lehet, hogy megszeretem...

UPDATE (2016.12.19.): Nem rossz ez, csak "szokni kell". Kipróbáltam a szóló módot, de az igazi valószínűleg minimum négy játékosnál lesz. Remélem egyszer alkalmam nyílik arra is.

RATING: 6
Very good economy game. The auctions are tough, but in general the game is more forgiving than Age of Steam, my other favourite money-making game. The new version is superior to the old one. The basic game is the same, but the components are better and the game is more streamlined.

Yet, I ended up trading this away; I needed the money and felt that I'd probably prefer Age of Steam in the rare cases I have time for something like this.

Indifferent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Power grid has fallen a tad in my rankings. Obviously it's another Euro classic, but I am finding a few issues in continued play:

1. The indirect effect of starting position makes too big of a difference amongst good players. Once near-optimal play is occurring, randomly having to spend an extra 10-20 on the final turns makes a huge difference.
2. Each metagame has a clear best value for each plant. Most of the skill of the game is knowing this information going in and executing, or getting lucky when you are up for last pick.

Obviously there is a lot of skill and dynamics involved in the game, but personally I find other Euros more engaging at this point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun game.  I had previously only played the card game version.  Actually needing to purchase the rights to move into a city added extra strategy to the game.  I eked out the win, but could have lost.  In the card version of the game you simply must have the ability to power more--late in the game I gave up a decent plant to buy another that only produced one more in order to tie with another player's maximum amount.  That's a must-do in the card game, but in the board game you must also consider the need to buy the city rights.  If I had passed on the plant purchase, I would have had the money to be the first and only player in the round to power 17 cities, which is a win condition in the board game.

RATING: 6
Alright! Finally got to play this, albeit in an aborted session. Definitely intriguing. Highly computational. I was doing the "maths" the whole way through, [-]and it seemed like I was going to dominate, but I have no idea what the endgame has in store.[/-] (According to comments elsewhere, "dominating" early is a recipe for disaster later on.) That said, we stopped right around the point I grow bored of computational games, so the full game might not have fared very well. My interest is now piqued in Medieval Merchant, often described as a quicker version of Power Grid without the resource market. Definitely interested in playing again, but I don't see this becoming a favorite of mine.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
As a big fan of 18xx games, I tend to like the heavyweight, theme-rich, German offerings such as Die Macher.  This game fits into that category and gives the same grand feel of running a major nationwide operation.  The rules are actually much easier to learn than expected.  How best to spend your money is the hard part.  After just one play of this game, I am now a very big fan of clean burning power plants. :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
Playing power grid isn`t complicated. The phases are logical and it is possible to play this game intuitively. Still it is strategically one of the deepest games I know. It is all about timing, resource management and also reading other players intentions. Some might claim power grid is too mathy, but I think a 10-year old should be able to do the math required in the game. It is completely another question if the tactic you picked was right in that current situation.

Wonderful game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My favourite of the long playing euros we've played, although I find Power Grid flows well (once you first decipher the rules) and the time flows on by very quickly.

I love the market mechanic, the auctions , the reverse order for the last place and selecting where you connect. Many cool mechanics all used together to give a realistic feel to an economic game. Games are close and there is a strong "race" feeling which keeps a great and building level of tension. Auctions and power plant cards give a randomness to the game which adds to replayability.

The maths, well hey a little basic arithmetic never hurt anyone.

Plays fine with two (we've tried US and Benelux), if not a little long. I can't see that it's as bad at all for two as some have said.

I'm hoping the other maps and even the new power plant cards coming might make a quicker game and maybe have some extra features for 2 player games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very fun Eurogame. It has a small element of randomness which spices the game in a better way.. unlike Imperial above, that game became a mathematical formula which makes your head explode.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I love most the catch-up mechanic, and how it in itself becomes a legitimate part of strategy/tactics rather than something to help weaker players. I also love the way the auction phase functions, how you move across the map trying to both build up some income as fast as possible whilst also trying to subtly set yourself up for the end game (all the while trying to predict where your opponents will move as well since this directly impacts your choices), how the three phases function, how the whole game revolves around setting up your final turn (this was a tad disappointing at first, but the more I play the more I like it: every action you take has to take account of where you want to be at the end of the game). The only thing which isn't amazing is that the calculating linkage costs between two cities can sometimes be awkward, but it isn't too big a hassle considering how rewarding the rest of the game is. Also the game is sometimes be easily lost depending on where your opponents place their initial building relative to yours.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
2004 Funkenschlag.  The fiddly paper money aside this game looks great.  I just love the 50ies design and typography.  The board is just gorgeous, and doublesided to boot.  One side is Germany, the other the USA, and both maps have their own things to keep in mind, so games on either map will be quite different.  As for the game itself; very deep, lots of parameters, easy to play, hard to master.  And, plays great with 2 as well as with more.  Great addition to my collection and deserves its top ten spot here on the Geek.  Hint: Play with Kraftwerk music in the background!

RATING: 8
This is a great game. The rules are a little more difficult than games I typically like to play. There are several special case rules and the rules change depending on the number of players. This keeps the game consistent and balanced. I think I would prefer a less consistent and balanced game to have to remember fewer special cases. If you can get past that, it is an awesome game with beautiful components. If you play with similarly minded people it is very fun.

RATING: 9
I really like PG. This may sound strange...but it feels like a game pulled out of the 1970's and a modern Euro game rolled into one. I really like the feel of the mechanisms in the game...and if anything...I actually enjoy the "fiddlyness" of the rules slightly. I like the flow of the game and the balancing mechanisms in each phase. I even like the fiddlyness of how power plants are constantly removed as it keeps the game moving along and interesting. I haven't played this enough to evaluate whether it will be a long term success but it's certainly one of the best "economic" games around. Definitely a game I look forward to getting on the table. I still want to play this with a full complement of 6 players to see if that stretches the limits of the gaming system somewhat.

RATING: 9.5

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Power Grid seamlessly combine several good mechanisms for an intense and interactive game. The players compete both on the market, by bidding for plants and buying resources at a fluctuating (but predictable) price, and on the map, by connecting own plants and blocking competitors' access.

I particularly like the rubber band mechanism, where the leader is bidding first and buying last, giving him or her less favorable market conditions and keeping the game open to the very end.

The game may feel slightly too repetitive and long but the development of more efficient plants and opening of new sites for them add some variation. Power Grid deserves its good reputation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

2016er Ausgabe
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great idea for a game...real fun for economically oriented builder types and planners...beautiful maps...neat auction system for power plants with current and futures market...this is a very good game for really any number between 2-6 from my experience....now I like the 2P version as well but didn't at first...moving rating up again to a 10 after repeated plays...there is a real shortage of good economic games but this hits the spot perfectly.  The game is a delicate balance between turn order, plant capacity, the race for cities on the map, the luck factor of "the flip" of power plants, the auction mechanism and finally supply and demand for the four resource types.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game has some nice touches including the ebb and flow of the availability to expand one's networks.  But the game falls flat for me because the auctions and plant placement only occasionally get interesting.  The cost of the power plants escalate consistent with their value.  While this makes for a balanced game, it lessens the importance of the auction.  The purchase of resources becomes a chore and the placement of plants on the board rarely takes much thought.  Most of the game involves performing math correctly so that you can spend appropriately in three areas.  I think the game either needs to be more difficult and involve a threat of insolvency (a la Age of Steam) or provide players with excess cash so that auctions and expansion are more fun.  To clarify, we have only played with 6 players.  Perhaps more cash is available with fewer players.  This may move my rating up slightly, but this is a long game for the limited level of decisions that are made.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.99
The best strategic game I have played.  Just with the US map every game will be different depending on regions selected, power plants that drop, and locations players go.  Then, every map can play very differently from all the rest.  The thing that makes this game stand out is the balanced game play through the plant auctions and the turn order system.  If you get ahead in cities, then you buy resources last, so knowing when to surge ahead and when to hold back is crucial.  The hidden money prevents anyone from being sure who is going to win most of the time, as well.  This is a masterpiece of a game, even before considering expansions and the Deluxe version that is now out.

RATING: 7
Overall comment: auction game that requires good money management and the ability to value the plants available against network expansion.  Game plays very different with various groups.

Ratings:
Initial(wow factor): 10 (everything looked great coming out of the box)
Family: 7 (bidding has to be modified to get it played - rarely requested)
Game group: 6 (not enough happening to make the game interesting - AP has pretty much shut this game down, no longer requested)
AP effect: 3 (this game is brutal, way too much downtime with serious players)
Solo play: 8 (#4 SoloPlay - very interesting and no AP, mimics the core game elements and produces a satisfying and quick result)

When purchased: 2006
Luck factor (1-10high): 6 (new power plants entering the market can cause a high luck factor expecially for the last to buy a plant)
Recommend expansions: Yes (initial boards get old quick)
Age range: 8+ with alterations to acquiring plants, 10+ otherwise

Reason purchased: Geek analysis

Pros: good components, interesting game design and mechanics, solo play has saved this own from the "never play it again" bin
Cons: AP deathblow, very little variance between games (expansions add a bit), game does not flow well consistently, too much posturing for turn order with experienced players so there is very little expansion and almost no step 2 except in the solo game

Recommendation: Marginal (needs expansions which increase the cost of the game to make it interesting but Power Grid enthusiasts don't like playing anything but the base game)
Replay rating: Below average
Game value (play/cost): Marginal (solo play saved this one)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fantastic gamer game for 4 - 6 players.  What I mean by that is that the game is more about an interlocking set of mechanics than about theme or modeling a real-life problem.  Let's face it, the mechanics are somewhat arbitrary.  Why does the last place person in one turn get to bid first the next?  Because it makes for an interesting game.  Why does the plant market not move in a linear fashion (as opposed to repeated rearrangements based on price), because it makes for a an interesting game.  Why are some paths between cities expensive and others cheap?  Because those numbers make for conditional situations that are interesting.  Why does the energy market for uranium, etc. replenish in the manner given, because that produces an interesting long-term decision. Etc.

What I'm getting at, is that on one level, PowerGrid is dry.  On another, the decisions that it puts into play are incredibly interesting.  Also, the mechanics are very quick to grasp after a single turn or two.  As some reviewers have pointed out, this produces a game that is very easy to learn, but very difficult to play well.  

On the whole, I'd say that PowerGrid earns immediate respect from me as a game, but I doubt that it will generate the joy that I experience with certain other games.  It's an interlocking set of puzzles, and a rather brilliant design, but lacks the thematic drama that I need to catapult a game into my top-most tier.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
"I was told there'd be no math..." Well, you were told wrong. Lots of counting up your money in Power Grid to make sure you have enough to do everything you need to do. Great looking game, interesting mechanisms, but to me it hasn't yet delivered the thrills a great game should.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Players bid for power plants that either use coal, oil, waste, uranium or wind for power. Resources are bought at a certain price scale (and replenished at the end of a turn at a certain quantity). Interesting game in that the most advanced player goes last in buying resources and connecting cities, creating a lot of ebb and flow in the game. Fairly long game, more than 3 hrs each time. Engaging, but not particularly satisfying since there are some factors in play such as opponents trying to build and potentially cut you off (playing Kingmaker), if you buy a plant and are out of the auction, a better plant might flip up, opponent may buy up resources even if game is ending just to deny you. It's all right, I think you have to be in the mood for this one.

RATING: 10
Excellent game! Requires a mix of long term planning and dynamic responses to what others are doing and how the power plant market changes. However, can go a little long and end abrupt when someone builds 5-6 houses in one hit. This just requires more economic calculations, particularly of other peoples ability, but also reading what they will do. Being behind on the leader board (last in turn order) has its advantage but is not key to winning: I have won while staying in the lead all game and also while staying behind all game. Its all about management!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Resource manipulation and management is the best I've seen in any game - it truly resembles supply and demand, and the market can even run out!

The math crunching feels good in my head, and I love how luck/chance plays such a low role in the game. There's almost never an easily seen optimal move, and the rubber-band advantage the last player gets is great for not letting anyone fall behind too much. The double sided game board is a great value for your money, and I've heard great things about expansion maps like Korea/China.

Some small issues keeping it from a 10: game can be a little long (2 hours+ for beginners), some rules/slight exceptions can be difficult, its a little fiddly getting the resource market set up (I heard the Deluxe edition has better resources), and the game can move slowly sometimes (also supposedly improved in the Deluxe edition)

Amazing euro game

Plays: Many (10+)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Variants for PG /PG Exp:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Reduces waiting times during bidding considerably
 One player registers an initial bid of at least the plant's number.

 Other players bid, out of turn, without waiting for players to bid or pass. 

 The last person to bid gets it if he is not outbid within about 10 seconds. 
Player order to break any ties.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
When we play with the EXP deck, we refill the fuel at the rate of one fewer players than are actually playing to increase the now dull competition in the resource market due to the higher efficiency of plants in the new deck.

~~~~~~~~~~~~
Use the entire new plant deck (46 plants). But in addition to normal setup and game rules, and "step 2 and game end" rules, consider these changes:

2 players—Players may only have 3 plants. Remove 12 random plants. Step 2 occurs at 9 cities.
3 players—Remove Plant 60, and remove 11 random plants. Game End occurs at 19 cities.
4 players—Remove Plants 60 and 57. Remove 6 random plants. Game End at 18 cities.
5 players—Remove Plants 60, 57, and 54. Remove 1 random plant. Game End at 16 cities.
6 players—Remove Plants 60, 57, 52, and 52. Everything else as normal.

~~~~~~~~~~~~
For the purists:
Note I am assuming all plants up to and including #13 remains in the game and in order. I guess you could spice things up a bit by increasing the current plant market to six plants up until #13 appears on the futures (after the third plant has been bought). At this time, remove the two lowest plants without replacing them (reducing the current market back to four plants again). This means that if the first three players do not buy the #1 or the #2, the game will run exactly like if #3 was the lowest plant, like in the base rules.

So far, we've got:

#1 3 Oil -> 1 City (new plant)
#2 1 Garb -> 1 City (new plant)
#3 1 Oil -> 1 City (new plant)
#4 2 Coal -> 1 City 
#5 2 O/C -> 1 City 
#6 1 Garb -> 2 Cities (expansion)
#7 3 Oil -> 2 Cities
#8 3 Coal -> 2 Cities
#9 1 O/C -> 1 City (new plant)
#10 3 Coal -> 3 Cities (new plant)
#11 1 Uran -> 2 Cities
#12 2 O/C -> 2 Cities
#13 Eco -> 1 City
#14 3 Coal -> 4 Cities (expansion)
#15 2 Coal -> 3 Cities
#16 2 Oil -> 3 Cities 
#17 2 Uran -> 3 Cities + 1 Uran (new)
#18 Eco -> 2 Cities
#19 2 Garb -> 3 Cities
#20 3 Coal -> 5 Cities 
#21 2 O/C -> 4 Cities
#22 Eco -> 2 Cities
#23 1 Uran -> 3 Cities
#24 2 Garb -> 4 Cities
#25 2 Coal -> 5 Cities
#26 2 Oil -> 5 Cities
#27 Eco -> 3 Cities
#28 1 Uran -> 4 Cities
#29 1 O/C -> 4 Cities
#30 2 Garb -> 5 Cities (new)
#31 3 Coal -> 6 Cities
#32 3 Coal -> 6 Cities
#33 Eco -> 4 Cities
#34 1 Uran -> 5 Cities
#35 1 Oil -> 5 Cities
#36 3 Coal -> 7 Cities
#37 Eco -> 4 Cities
#38 3 Garb -> 6 Cities (new)
#39 2 Uran -> 5 Cities + 1 Uran (new)
#40 2 Oil -> 6 Cities
#42 2 Coal -> 6 Cities
#44 Eco -> 5 Cities
#46 1 Uran -> 6 Cities (new)
#50 Fusion -> 6 Cities
#52 3 O/C -> 7 Cities (new) 
#54 3 Garb -> 7 Cities (new) 
#56 2 Uran -> 7 Cities + 1 Uran (new)
#60 Fusion -> 8 Cities (expansion)

"Correcting game length: A straight-forward solution is to note there is six more plants than in the base game (effectively four if you apply the house-rule above) and then simply removing four more random plants than usual (four instead of zero for a five player game, for instance).

On the other hand, you might think this makes the game a bit too random - especially for games that already remove random plants (four players or less). One idea then is when preparing the deck when starting a game, you put the new top plants (the #52, #54, #56 and #60) under the "Step/Stufe 3" card already from the beginning. This keeps the number of plants until Step 3 begins about the same."

RATING: 10
The game that has improved most steadily (and stealthy) in my game riddled mind over time. Is clocking at 10 at the moment, as rating it will not lose very soon. As a 4-6 player game it has few competitors. I love the aspect that every decision feels crucial, a slight brainburner but is not annoying in any way. For a euro game it's easy to learn and easy to teach, everyone (from seasoned players to beginners(!)) I've played with has got a hang of it after the first round. The only minus is that as a 5 and 6 player game it can last for quite a while (3 hour sessions have not been uncommon) if you've got non-seasoned players participating. Disliked by none in my gaming group.

Does NOT work with 2 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[--- What I like about it ---]
I love the theme.  I like the supply and demand mechanic.  And I like that you have the ability to think and plan a couple turns ahead.

[--- What I don't like about it ---]
If you end up with a runaway game, then the very last turn of the game is almost pointless in playing.  Once someone builds in the last city and you see that they can power them, you can pretty much look at the other players to see if anyone is a contender.  If not, then you almost feel like stopping early and declaring a victor.

[--- Other comments ---]
The English translation of the rules are not written in the most fluid style.  But once you've played a few times, then you get past that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I like math-heavy games, (Kingdoms) but not when they take this long. I rated it an 8, because it's playable online, but I don't think I'll play again Ftf. (1 play FtF, 5+ online)

RATING: 8
Amazingly good game with plenty of depth.  3 games at once (area control, power plant development and resource management).  Very tight games, and everyone seems to enjoy and be willing to play again.  Seem to have a good winning record so far, but expect that to change.  Just watch out for those deals and push the envelope on saving money.  Games always come out far closer than you expect at 5-6 players.  2 player game not really that enjoyable, lacks tension.  Can't wait to see the expansions!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Finally got a chance to play Power Grid and: Wow, what a great game! I haven't nailed down the mechanics yet (they are a tad complex), but we had a blast playing it. This looks to become family favorite. 

edit: It is official. At least for me, starting on the West Coast of the US board is a death curse. I think I've ended up a distant last place each time I start my cities in the western purple region. 
Still, what a great game!

7/12/10:It seems to be a general consensus in the family that the endgame of Power Grid kinda stinks. Great theme and mechanics on the way to the end, but then it just stops. The most recent game came down to all 4 players counting money to determine the winner.

RATING: 6
Fun game.  Has a real "anxiety" feel to it, especially when bidding on the power plants.  I enjoy being able to see the future market, but it turn out to be nothing more than a tease as they might not come up (or even go away).  The one downer for this game for me is that I just don't like the theme.  If the theme was more solid, this would be a great game.  It's still a very good one, and I will definitely (and want to) play it again, but that is why the rating suffered some for me.  A lot of fun with 5 players.

The resource market is a very well developed game mechanic and I would absolutely love to see other games implement this style of resource management.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fantastic game for any number of players between 3 and 6, with an acceptable amount of downtime between turns and some clever mechansims built into the game to keep things close without totally hosing the leader. ***UPDATE*** The new version, Power Grid, is a great improvement to an already awesome game. The biggest complaint of Funkenschlag - the components - has been addressed beautifully, with a gorgeous board that replaces the old charts, as well. The reduced playing time is welcome, as the feel of the game remains almost exactly the same. This is how updates should be done - great job Friedemann! ****UPDATE 8/13/04*** Open mouth, remove foot - that's what happens when you judge a game based on only a couple of plays, especially one with the depth of Power Grid. With Funkenschlag, I found myself enjoying the game more each time I played it. Power Grid is just the oposite. With each play I see more things I just don't like about the game, most notably its pace. Unfortunately, I doubt I'll convince my group to return to the aesthetically inferior, but gameplay-superior Funkenschlag.

RATING: 9
Oh man, the cover always gets to me! :D
A rather dry theme; you buy power plants, build a network of cities and provide them with electricity. It certainly is a fun challange to do so effectivly though.

Love the bidding rules, it's always fun to watch other players agonize as they try to decide to bid for a powerplant or not.

The rules to avoid runaway leader are nice to, making the leader go first on auctions for power plants but last when buying suplies and conecting to cities. Perhaps the most balanced game I own.

Increased the score 8 --> 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Ok . . . instantly one of my favorite games.  Once again, I think I like complex strategy with limited unecessary detail.  The mechanics here all help to balance out the game, and they work so well that by over emphasizing your stratgy, you actually tilt the game play in the favor of other players . . . just a brilliantly concieved game.

Although the mechanics have unique twists, these differences exist for a purpose . . . that is . . . to balance the game.  

Now that I've played this 30 some times, it is losing a little luster.  I know which plants to buy, and when.  Also, the game sometimes boils down to a count fest.  Also, the occational run on resources is something that I've learned to watch for.  Still a great game, but others are catching my eye more often.  With it on the web, I don't tend to pick it out at gaming events.

RATING: 7.5
A very nice auction game, although takes a session or two to understand how the game works.

Extra maps really aren't necessary, as you have plenty of replay value and variance from the base game. They do add some interesting tweaks to the rules though, and thematically it's fun to "visit another country" after you've played the base map a few times.

Expansions owned:
* Benelux/Central Europe (2006)
* Brazil/Spain & Portugal (2009)
* China/Korea (2008)
* Québec/Baden-Württemberg (2012)
* The Robots (2011)
 * Fabled Expansion (2017)

[b]Best game of 2004[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Power Grid is an excellent economic, resource management, network-building game with some auctioning thrown in for good measure.

Power Grid has been labeled 'Mathy', and it is, but the math skills involved are those that every adult needs: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and the ability to budget. Application of these skills is not so heavy that playing Power Grid becomes a chore, and for most players will be 2nd nature. By the end of the game's 2+ hours though it will feel like everyone has gotten some brain exercise.

There is a flaw in the game though: In Step 1 it is possible to cut one or several players off from expanding their grids. This can really slow the game down and cause those players to abandon hope of competing in the rest of the game.

Although the board is too busy, the rest of Power Grid's artwork is clean and reminiscent of Tintin comics. I will not be upgrading to the Deluxe Edition specifically because the new art-style is terrible.

Power Grid is worthy of its high ranking on BGG.com. Its not a 'fun' game, but definitely is a good one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Felt broken with clean energy options.  Its possible I wasn't doing something right, but just didn't hold my interest to try again.  With that said, overall it is a fairly interesting game aside.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Deep engaging strategy game.  Auction off power plants to power your cities, buy resources that vary in market value, broaden your city limits, power your cities, earn cash from powering, rinse and repeat.  

This game is so finely tuned many games are lost because people are one dollar short of doing something that will take them out of the game.  A bit unforgiving, so for people that must win it could be frustrating.  Engaging game though, that really is fun and I am still learning about mistakes I am making 10-15 games deep.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Buy power plants in the auction phase, and buy fuel for them, buy houses and power them up in the action phase which earns money, that you recycle in the process. Once you bought a certain number of houses the player who can power up the most with his available power plants will win. The game is about planning efficiently for the last round. Highest rated game on BGG from the year 2004.

RATING: 7
Power Grid is really popular, and I can see why - it's pure strategy, with victory or defeat hanging on the edge of a single dollar. The money mechanics are deep and the strategy really difficult. On the other hand, to me it was kind of a one-trick pony and it's trick just wasn't really my thing. It's most significant sin, in my opinion, is that its mechanics aren't deep enough for the long play time, especially since it becomes obvious to some players how the game's going to turn out long before it does.

RATING: 6.5

The player-driven resource market is elegant, if a little fiddly on occasion.

I dislike the overt punish-the-leader mechanics that result in what I call the "Power Grid two-step", where players alternate between being last and first.

RATING: 9
Best with 4 or more players, but lacks a little intensity with any less. When I analyse Power Grid I always find myself wanting to rate it lower. Initially it seems counter-intuitive with clunky balancing mechanisms. Then there is the fiddly maintenance each round. And finally there's the laborious task of calculating your spending each turn. However, when I start playing these reservations soon fade. After a few plays it becomes more intuitive and you realise the turn order and the phases are a big part of the game's appeal. With some experience the game flies along and the calculations make for a really tense end game. Final scores are usually very close with a few micro decisions having a big impact. I always have a great time when playing Power Grid and would find it very hard to drop it's rating below a 9. (7)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good, but requires more math and mental record-keeping than I like in a board game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Sleeved and organized.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

Tra le varie mappe consiglio l'Italia, ingolfata ma chiara e strategica, e il Giappone (con possibilità di partire da due siti differenti). Nella versione originale troviamo le carte Stati Uniti e Germania: di queste due prediligo decisamente la seconda.

RATING: 6.8
I can't for the life of me understand the enduring popularity of this one. To anyone with any sense of profit and risk it's reduced to merely making the right decision at the auction phase and a lot of bean-counting. The phase transitions are too uneven, and the game finish invariably seems to be deeply unsatisfying. Plus, there's niggling rule alterations depending on how many players you have, which strikes of poor design. The board is plain ugly, and there's no box insert! Not even a poorly-designed one! Shameful!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2006.  Spellenbeurs in Essen.  Ik had mijn lijst vooraf opgemaakt en bovenaan stond Funkenschlag (ook bekend onder de naam Power Grid).  Nog nooit gespeeld, maar wat surfen op websites leerde me dat dit wel eens een topper kon zijn.  Geen spel voor doetjes, maar een stevige klepper die voor de nodige uitdagingen en strategien kon zorgen. 
De verwachtingen waren dan ook hoog gespannen.  Sommigen zetten Funkenschlag bovenaan hun lijstje, naast Puerto Rico en Caylus.  Wat zoekwerk leverde uiteindelijk een 3-tal verschillende vertalingen op (met dank aan www.boardgamegeek.com) en ik kon meteen aan de slag.  De speluitleg is duidelijk (hoewel niet correct vertaald vanuit het duits) en na een 2-tal rondes valt het spelsysteem duidelijk in zijn plooi en wordt het 'routine'.  Maar vergis je niet, elke stap of zet kan belangrijk zijn.  De doos bevat een aantal houten stukjes (huizen in 6 verschillende kleuren en grondstoffen in verschillende vormen en kleuren) een aantal kaartjes met energiecentrales, geld en een dubbelzijdig spelbord.  Het spelbord heeft aan de ene zijde een landkaart van Duitsland en aan de andere zijde Amerika.  Die landkaart is verdeeld in verschillende zones, met elk heelwat steden die onderling verbonden zijn met pijpleidingen.  De bedoeling is om jou steden met elkaar te verbinden en die te voorzien van elektriciteit.  Zo kan je geld verdienen, en opnieuw investeren in nieuwe, betere energiecentrales (max. 3 per speler),  Wie als eerste een aantal steden heeft verbonden (bij 5 spelers is dit +15) en die ook allemaal van energie kan voorzien, wint dit spel.  Het leuke is dat iedereen bezig is met zijn strategie, of beter gezegd met de aanpassing daarvan.  Niet elke stad kan zomaar op zijn netwerk aangesloten worden, meer nog: dat kost geld, veel geld.  Maar hoe meer centrales en aangesloten steden, hoe meer inkomsten.
Toch nog een woordje over de layout.  Een grote doos, omwille van het spelbord, wordt onderaan niet opgevuld met materiaal.  Spijtig, want wat opbergvakjes zou dit spel nog aantrekkelijker maken.  Wat ik ook mis, is een schermpje.  Alles is van belang: wie welke centrales heeft, welke grondstoffen hij daarvoor nodig heeft, maar ook hoeveel geld die nog in handen heeft.  Een klein schermpje is handig om zijn geld daarachter weg te stoppen.  Niets dan lof over de cover van de doos: de tekening in de jaren 50-stijl doet het wel, alleen nog de vraag of centrales op uranium, windkrachtcentrales en fusiecentrales toen al bestonden.
Helaas was de spellendoos die ik kochte niet volledig (4 kolen ontbraken).  Ik heb dan ook een tijdje terug de uitgeverij gecontacteerd, tot nog toe zonder resultaat.  Ik blijf hopen dat 2FSpiele me alsnog de ontbrekende stukjes opstuurt.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
My degree is in Economics... Enough said...
(I LOVE this game)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Strategic! A game I really enjoy...but just don't have enough players to play when time permits...Wait...not anymore...the new 2-player expansion "the Robots" saves the day. A game that sat on the shelf virtually unplayed for far too long, now comes to the table much more often. Many claim this is a game in the gateway category. I still have to disagree, the length of play and complexity of calculations all make it a bit more of a Medium heavy game for our game group. Games typically take 3 or 4 hours to play. Games like Ticket to Ride, Pandemic, 7 Wonders, Dominion, Settlers of Catan are definite games that easily bring non-gamers into the hobby. This game is really the next step up. I would place it amongst games like Puerto Rico, Agricola, Twilight Struggle etc.

This is a very tight game. The auctioning for power plants is fun and tricky. The market of goods is predictable, but not too predictable. Should I stock pile goods early or should I wait until they are cheaper. Should I buy that glorious new garbage plant this turn or wait...there are two other players holding garbage plants right now, maybe I should get the Coal Plant and diversify my goods selection for the future. So many choices and tough decisions. But then there is the board, I need to be building cities to make money. Do I buy a power plant, goods or cities...tough and fun decisions every game. 

One interesting dichotomy is first player vs. last player. In this game the first player has a significant penalty at times when buying a new power plant. Sometimes nothing good is available and you will have to risk auctioning something you don't really want or pass for the entire round. Also, in buying resources, as first player you will be choosing last from the leftover resources in the market. Costs will be higher inevitably. Holding back a little with building sometimes allows you to be in a better place for better prices. 

The mechanics, board and components are all great quality. Color blind players do have some trouble with colors at times in this game. The expansion boards are all unique to the countries they represent and have minor adjustments to the setup of the game and usually the goods market. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
erw.1/14,1/11bs,5/04,
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great!  So much to balance each turn.  Value of plant to you vs. value of plant to opponents, value of new plant vs. immediate new connections, value of new connections vs. stockpiling cheaper resources, probable moves/purchases of your opponent that will alter those values next turn...  

My wife said she liked it better than El Grande.  (Not quite there for me, but still great.)  I am looking forward to playing with different regions and different maps--another great feature of the game!  

Finally tried 2-player and we were pleasantly surprised.  Plays great, although it is almost impossible to build a sizable lead.

Tried 6-player and liked it OK.  All the new players had fun.  It slows down the game, but it ends in fewer turns and the plant auction was not as competitive with the lower victory condition.  This may not be a problem with a more experienced group gunning for a victory beyond the 14 cities required.  WE found that the SW (the blue area) is not viable at all if the NW (the purple area) is excluded.  That is probably true for all numbers of players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

So I'm only giving it a 8. 
But definitely deserve a 10 if I'm smarter. :)

RATING: 8
Great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Purchased April 2011 from Gauntlet Games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Power Grid has great replayability due to the fluctuating fuel demand, which leads to different levels of demand for each power station, which has a feedback effect on fuel demand, etc.

Combine that with the geographical element (placing houses) and the jockeying for turn order position and unusual victory condition and you have a great game.

The rule book is difficult to learn from, so my first game was a bit of a struggle, but after you've played it once it is much easier. Expansions further increase the replayability but are by no means essential. It's also an easy game to teach, as only one player needs to know the fiddly rules, so it's a good "next step" to try with casual gamers.

Jun 2010: This was my favourite game at one point (for at least a couple of years), but more recently (since 2008) I have got slightly bored with PG and don't play it as much. I'm always up for a game if someone brings their copy, but I'm not likely to put my own copy in my game bag when there are so many other games I'd prefer to play.

Bought Spring 2005
Sold August 2013 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

BENJAMIN

France and Italy board
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
50+ plays. This game has seen tremendous replay over the years. With experienced players, the game can often come down to a decision you make towards the end of the game - whether to bale out of a high priced auction in the hope that (as the last player) the new card flipped will be big enough to suit you and you'll get it cheaply. The game is rich with auction and purchase decisions throughout however. I think one of the main attractions is the nice leapfrog feel it provides, as you surge ahead to get cheap buildings on the board, or fall behind to get best choice of power stations and cheap goods. Very few games have captured it, and it induces a strategic feel which is appealing. They myriad of expansions provide minor tweaks to the rules and provide enough variety for those who need it. This will be in the rotation for years to come. It's only downside is that too many games get decided by the chicken-out decision - do I big higher on this ok card because the next card is going to be crap and I can't afford to wait any longer to build my capacity, or will I get lucky with the next card and get something even better and potentially game-winning for cheaper?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Never played. Game has been opened, bits have been bagged.

RATING: 10
Fantastic! This IS my favorite game! I love playing this, though I rarely win. So many elements about this game, yet it boils down to a sortof neck-and-neck horserace to the end. Many oddities about turn order and auctions rotation in the game turn away a few people, but it is these very oddities which I and many love about Power Grid.

Heavy replayability through different maps, varied regions played, number of players, auctions, and promo cards.

Best to learn how to play from someone directly. Plan on about 30+ minutes per player for the game time; much more if a learning game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
What I like:
- Auction mechanic (although I prefer the once-around format)
- The way the resource market loosely models supply and demand
- Theme
- Graphic design and art on the power plant tiles is gorgeous and very functional

What I don't like:
- The turn order mechanic, which should be a minor part of the game, is the primary focus of the game
- The rules force a lot of contention on the map (I prefer "friendlier" games).
- The winning condition seems artificial and "gamey", and puts too much emphasis on the final round.
- The stages are horrible, resulting in stalls and spurts of activity.
- The ability to completely deplete resources, preventing your opponents from firing those plants
- Length (it should be a 60-90 minute game--and on BSW it is)
- The BSW UI does not allow you unclick a building if you change your mind!
- Graphical design and artwork on the map is neither thematic (pipes???) nor functional.

The 3.3 weight seems a bit high. I'll go 3.1. You definitely have to be ok running a lot of addition in your head. I can imagine a lot of AP with some players.

It's not a bad game, but aside from being a bit long and overdone for my tastes, it just doesn't work for me. After my first game, I wanted more. After 4 more plays on BSW, I think I'm done. The game has too many drawbacks to overcome its appealing elements. Specifically, the jockeying for turn order dominates the game, whereas I want the game to be about powering cities.

RATING: 9
Yes this game as many have said can feel like you are doing accounting homework, but I still love playing it. The auctions, board position, and resource management all come together in one brilliant package. The rules are not well written or organized so watching a video or downloading a rewrite of the rules is highly recommended. The deck of power plants features several plants in the medium range that are not worth buying so the power plant deck expansion is also recommended. It is easy to screw up the steps needed to manage the plant deck during the game, so attention to detail is needed. But once you have the flow down, the game is quite smooth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game takes some concentration, but it is worth it.  Lots of arithmetic is involved as you add up the prices of resources to see whether you can power all of your plants, and then again when you add up the cost of connecting new cities to your grid.  How much can you afford to bid on the new power plant you need?

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Durante l'adolescenza ci portavamo Risiko in campeggio. Probabilmente oggi il gioco sarebbe Power Grid. Friedemann Friese sfrutta un tema insolito, apparentemente poco interessante, e crea un capolavoro grazie a un mix di meccaniche semplici ma ben azzeccate unite a una bellissima veste grafica (dell'artista-feticcio Lars-Arne "Maura" Kalusky).
L'asta, che da il via alla corsa tecnologica, regala momenti di ilarità quando qualcuno fa il passo più lungo della gamba (comprando centrali che lo fanno rimanere senza soldi). Il mercato delle risorse è un piccolo capolavoro della progettazione di boardgame: un esempio perfetto della dinamica domanda-offerta. Senza dadi, il fattore culo è quasi del tutto azzerato: sei responsabile di ogni stupidaggine che fai. Osservatori superficiali bollano Power Grid come gioco con poca interazione: con avversari esperti la vittoria si costruisce non solo scegliendo il tracciato più economico ma ostacolando aste, esaurendo risorse agli avversari e "murando" le loro vie di espansione.
Un gioco estremamente longevo: l'ordine di uscita delle centrali (unica concessione al Caso) rende ogni partita unica. Mai fatte due partite uguali. Concludendo, uno dei migliori boardgame a cui abbia mai giocato: da giocare e rigiocare all'infinito (anche grazie alle numerosissime mappe a disposizione). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Really clever game design, but bring a calculator!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The economics of the game are a lot of fun. The resources you need change over time as well as resources other players need. This can increase or decrease costs uniquely to each game played. You also have some territory grabbing like Settlers of Catan, Money distribution based on territory akin to Risk's army distribution, and Improvement bidding like Monopoly's property auction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really love how the power plant market works, everyone ends up with different plants, and how they behave for the rest of the game depends on which plants they get.  You need to simultaneously try to work toward end-game plant capacity, while at the same time trying to get the cheap cities before others do, while trying not to jump out in front of everyone.  I love the art, too.  My only complaint is that if you get significantly behind the curve, you probably won't be able to catch up even with the turn order helping you out.

(5+ plays)

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A good time... played twice with 3 players, once with 5. Having lost all three, the 3 player games to a total rookie.

 Update: Okay, I won a 4-player game finally. It was won on tie-break, and some of the subtley of this one is starting to appear.

This game is pretty heavy. It takes quite a bit of concentration. It is somewhat fiddly. You must have someone who knows the rules WELL to teach it, as there are many phases and card turns that you can get wrong in the heat of a game thumbing through the rules.

It's good, but it's high rating surprises me (3rd all-time as of 10/24), especially due to it's length. Will certainly appeal to the groups that enjoy the other top rated games (PR, PoF, E&T).

12/17 okay, are there any MORE strategies to learn in this game? We had our first game with the "7-stall" plant effect, and my opponent bought 11 power plants in one turn, powered 13 of them, and won. He had over 230 bucks on that turn - we never saw it coming. 3/06: This came out multiple times at our biggest event of the year, and I had no desire to get in and play. Partly because I don't enjoy seeing newbies get crushed, partly because I didn't want to get hosed by a newbie's poor play, partly because... I'd rather play PR, or San Juan, or a bunch of other solid Euros. New maps interest me slightly. In one year this is going to be a 5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
BGEve

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pros:
+Fun theme even though it doesn't look like it would be at first.
+Pretty easy rules to explain. Not a ton of little details to explain.
+Beautiful board and cards have a fun, light artwork on them.
+Moderate length of playtime.
+Very strategic.
+A slight bit of screwage, but can be overcome unlike Settlers.

Cons:
-Tough for new people to win. Learning the balancing act of springing forward to first player takes a few games.
-Paper money sucks.
-Some plants are pretty worthless.
-Can cause AP in some players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An excellent auction-economy game, where you power cities in various areas of the world. Players have to balance money, income, resources and turn order as well and emerge as the most successful electric company. The game simulates in a very clever way the supply vs demand in the resource market, as well as the increase of prices when the demand's high.

Plays greatly with 3-4 players, 2-player version interesting as well, but the auctions lose their power as the game's key element.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
TRY Jun/04 (BSW, as Funkenschlag): good fun, even if the parts are disjointed (auction for plants, purchasing of limited goods at varying prices, extension of power lines to new cities, and decision of how many lines to power).

Very nice that it handles changes from 2 thru 6 players easily, and comes with 2 different boards (USA, Europe).

RATING: 7
March 2011

Power Grid was an easier game to learn than I was expecting, and a lot of fun. Definitely less dry than some of the brain-burner Euros I've tried before too. I liked this one.

Update February 2014

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A masterpiece. I truly enjoy every game of Power Grid.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
EDIT: From an 8 to a 7.5

Strange game: the rules are fiddly and takes some time to get in to. And a game explainer that have not played Power Grid an awful lot, has a busy time introducing it to PG-newcomers and at the same time remembering all the steps and turns, refuelling resources, once-used-rules and card manipulation throughout the game. 

But you know what - this game is very intuitive and most non gamers/casual gamers I played with found it very logical and easy to comprehend. People that were still a bit confused by mid-game the first time they played Pillars, thought PG was crystal clear. And if you don't play with people afraid of doing a sub-optimal move, the game is exciting and will not drag that much. 

It is a bit on the dry side, but with a couple of beers and friends that challenge you in the bidding of plants you will have a good time. The building and buying resources phase is also great moments when you interfere directly with each other. 

Don't be alarmed by the weight rating on BGG if you prefer somewhat lighter games. Sure, it is a difficult game to master and it takes some time to learn it by the rule book, but with a good game explainer (that also manages the cards) the game is closer to Hacienda/Thurn and Taxis in weight than Puerto Rico/Imperial (Ok, PG is a bit meatier than T&T, but it is also a lot more intuitive). 

Only downside is that slight repetitive feel that sometimes occur, a couple of times in the game you also feel that there is not much interesting plants to buy. The game is also a bit "to long for what it is". Still, good to decent replay value.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The fluctuating commodity price market mechanic works brilliantly. 

The variable power plant efficiency makes the auction phase interesting and provides differing strategies that can lead to success.

The end-game condition provides the opportunity for a come from behind victory, allows players to control the tempo of the game somewhat and puts the cash flow/power generation versus network building phases of the game into a nice balance.

Well deserving of its lofty place in the BGG rankings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Combines nicely auction and resource management. The art of the gaming board is beautiful and the cards follow. It may take a while to see where it would be best to locate your first houses, but after this the only problem is the other players. In this game, a fellow player can do a lot of harm to the others. Block their building routes or bid higher on auctions... At the end of the game we had a lot of calculating the most optimum places. It was hell, but maybe it's because of these games that I can still count without calculator.
Definitely a game which a true gamer would appreciate. I like it too, but I need more games to give my final opinion!
Looks good though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good economics game, though much more maths heavy than Age of Steam.
In AoS you only add numbers like 1,2,3 whereas in this game you add 17,31,24 and ~12-15 for resources. Ouch, if you are a bit tired from a few beers.
Best part with this game is how you should avoid being in the lead! Avoid being in the lead at all cost but still play good enough so that you have enough money and a good board position for the great final. Usually the last turn someone builds plants in a lot of cities.
The America map is not as good. It is too expensive to connect the western and eastern parts of the map. So those starting at different coasts never meet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
No game deserves a perfect 10, because no game is perfect. This game isn't perfect (maybe) but it does deserve the 10.
Why? Not because it ticks all the right boxes for me (it does), not because the theme is strong (it's very good), but because of it's interaction. All the things other players do affect you in a meaningful way. I have no trouble in keeping track of what the other players do, in this game it just comes naturally. And that really helps in making decisions, It's even fun to be outplayed, because you can easily follow wthat's going on. If you win this game, you know why. And if you lose, you also know why and probably even what you need to do next time to avoid it. 
And then the next game, you'll learn again.. 

This game is great. Surprisingly, I really hate all the other FF games I've played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I like network building, economy building, civ type games and this is one of the best - just as long as I don't want to spend my accumulated wealth on an army to wipe my opponents off the map!
I'm not a great fan of auction games but the auction in Power Grid works well. It allows the cost of a power plant to vary depending on the map, current resource availability, and how many cities each player needs to power and I find that I can calculate a maximum price to pay. With most auction games I find that I am just guessing an amount, usually the wrong one.
To stop me getting bored, there are different combinations of networks on each map, a different game as the number of players changes (although I'm not happy with 2-player) and the power plant availability changes as well. Then there are new maps with small changes to make things interesting but no need to work through the interactions of half a dozen different expansions.
I don't own this but I do keep my friend, who does own it, supplied with new maps.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I can see why many would like this game. However, it has the same problem of Colosseum. Most auctions aren't auctions, simply because what anyone wants is normally radically different from the other player's present goals. Any elevation beyond that is primarily 'screwage', or another form of pushing one's luck to dimish another player's returns for acting on their intended strategy. Yes, auctions are a good mechanic, but not when they're used ONLY and SPECIFICALLY for this purpose. I never felt as though more than one player genuinely needed the same factory, simply because the game dictates that you need to pursue the factory types that no one else is going for. The game design itself ruins the auction mechanic, in my mind.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Painfully dry.  It's basically a weighted graph of profit opportunities you purchase and maintain by spending different resources at rates dependent on the efficiency of the cards you've bought at auction.

I must admit, though, I get impatient when people playing for the first time make bad decisions.  I don't yell at them or anything, I just curse in my brain.  I particularly enjoy the timing that has to be made on the final charge.

Very interesting game with some minor flaws. RATING: 10
This is my favorite game.  far superior to puerto rico.  If you think it's not a good two player game, you're playing it wrong.  it may not be as good with two as it is with 4 or 5, but it scales better than any other multiple player game.  With 6 people, it's a little short, so i would avoid that route until they release and extended rule set for the new deck.  with 6 maps, and only a select portion of the maps in play each game, it is sure to be different every time.

RATING: 7

Despite this frequent  annoyance, I found it ok. I'm glad I own it and will play it from time to time, but it will never become my personal top ten favorite since players strategies are kept on a very tight leech that is dependent on bidding.

RATING: 9
This is what euros are all about; Power Grid defines a truly elegant gaming experience.  The rules are remarkably streamlined, and after a couple of rounds, it's pretty easy to get into the groove.  The only random element are the power plant cards; like my other favorites, success depends on balancing your major plans while also being flexible when things go awry.  

I've only played with 4 or 5 so far; both have been excellent.  Maybe not the best gateway game, but a must for gamers with even a little euro experience.

RATING: 7

Also I've had a couple of games with lots of dead rounds mid game where none of the plants mattered to anyone which caused everyone to just hoard up on money until decent plants came along or we hit phase 3. Those dead rounds when they happen are enough to kill the game and make it feel like a chore.

RATING: 7.75
Definately time to update the words on Power Grid.

Flat out - a great game.  Lots of interaction, lots of decisions, lots of fun.  It's especially great to me that it's flexible with players.  I think the game would be a little better if the paper money were replaced with chips or something, but otherwise the components are good and plenty.  The game is part auction, part area of control, part empire building.  The theme goes hand in hand with the actual gameplay and components. Also:  a pretty good Euro-Introductory game from fans of A&A and Risk.  Will always be a great time when the PG comes out - but - doesn't see a lot of play in favour of newer games in my collection.
