RATING: 7
Extraordinary game, with an eye for decent amounts of realism.  Simple, well-thought out rules, but realize that it will take a lot of math to be good at this one (no calculus, just a lot of + and -).  The variable turn order makes players want to stick to the back, but not so far back that they can't catch up.  Very interesting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.61
Excellent game with many different elements that work together well. Clever rules concerning turn orders in various phases to maintain balance, and each player is kept involved through each phase (little down time).

Rules are actually fairly straightforward, although not all that well written, containing some poor word choices (steps/phases). It isn't very hard to teach new players. Everyone can understand the basics due to the well-integrated theme.

Scales well to various numbers of players & actually works fairly well with 2 players too (but with less competition for plants, resources & connections, particularly in the later part of the game).

Nice components & artwork. Double-sided map for extra variety.

For faster play with less fiddling I would definitely recommend using poker chips or similar instead of the paper money - especially small numbered chips that can easily be concealed in one hand!

RATING: 9.6
yosef
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Update: My fondness for this game has 'oscillated' over the years, but I think now I can settle on the facts that some of the fiddly management of the plant market and turn order, the unfamiliar calculations of placement and the 'increased cost' hampering means this will deter the casual players. However, I would be fine to make up the numbers amongst the fans of the design.

A connection game in which you pay to link and place buildings, and as a result of some unweildy maths this mechanic alone slows proceedings as players work out (and often ask others to help) the running costs. 

Yet despite this offputting element in the design there are other features which I still find interesting. First off is how power plants are auctioned off. Only the cheapest 4 in a display of 8 are up for bid, so the other 4 are a taste of what may come up next so long as an intervening value plant doesn't step into the top 4. This is a tense tease and I sometimes feel that the drawpile can screw a player over hoping for the fifth plant to move up. Is it a gamebreaker, I don't know yet.

Another interesting element is the turn order is determined by how far ahead a player has built, so that player bids or passes first in a round (so can't bid again). Also that player buys resources and builds last in a round which can get expensive, so all in all a neat catchup mechanism which I haven't seen elsewhere. There is some consideration in jockeying for the best position to set yourself up to build the required number of stations first. What is unique here is that although you may have built the required number, you need to have resources to qualify your score.

- still seems to be as random as monopoly are (but it is hard to notice)

RATING: 8
-

A great mix of resouce management and tight decision making. A couple of minor issues: There is less than adequate player control during the auction phase in the form of luck of the draw, and sometimes one might benefit (or get harmed) during the initial placement of houses through no fault of one's own.
Great game overall.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A serious game for serious gamers. It is long, there is brain drain, there is some math, there is influencing other players(auction play), there is a lot to this game. It's mechanical functions are complex(who goes when, multiple turn segemtns for different elements of play, restocking the board, banking, etc.). You will not play it right the first time through I can almost assure you, it's learning curve is a near vertical wall. But if you like to press your brain to the grind stone, in an unforgiving game where your choices are the weight and luck is a minimal factor, I almost can't think of a better game. It's worth it. It's 10 in my book, but is hard to approach, so for the general public I got to drop a couple points.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[floatleft][ImageID=909801][/floatleft][b][u]Initial Impressions:[/u][/b]
One of the earliest games I played and it is still a favorite.

[b][u]What I like:[/u][/b]
I love the fluctuating commodities market and the increasing efficiency of the power plants. The struggle for finding maximum efficiency while competing over limited resources is what is so enticing about PG.

[b][u]What I dislike:[/u][/b]
I think most people would agree that the phase changes are a bit wonky. 

[b][u]Overall:[/u][/b]
I can understand the arguments against Power Grid (PG) such as the game is a bit disjointed and there is some tedium in the fiddly phase changes. Despite all of arguments against PG, it is still a great game. I have tried to collect every board. 

[i]4 production plants are a$$holes.[/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Awesome game! Lots of tension in every step. Will I win the power plant I want in the auction? Will there be any oil left in the market, and if there is can I afford it? Will someone build me into a corner? 

Every game is different... I've had games where the price of fuel was high throughout the game, and others where everyone went green and the prices staid low. 

The only downside is the mind-numbingly bad manual, but you can download some great payer aids that make the game go much quicker.

A 'must have' game.

RATING: 9.2
P: 2-6, T: 1-2 hr, SdJ-R

+Great Gateway: easily teachable. Very minor luck elements, game play feels entirely driven by player decisions and markets. Player position mechanic keeps every game fairly close to the end; new players aren't punished until they learn the rules. Multiple maps and power plants keep things variable through multiple plays

=Not too cutthroat, but some can get frustrated by blocking. Little direct interaction, more passive aggressive competition

-Not as good with 2 players (robots expansion may improve this) Power plant availability and auctions can seem like the only real pivotal decisions. It's nice to have a calculator nearby

RATING: 8.5
FF's masterpiece for most people is well appreciated by my group.  The art is a little one-note compared to games like Landlord and Funny Friends (probably by necessity), and it has a few rules that are fiddly and easy to forget, but the game is rock solid and can create some really great tension between players. Shame they departed from the "F" nomenclature for this game, too.  Makes my collection look weird.   
Overall, Power Grid is an undeniable triumph, but I like FF more when he's exploring weird corners of the gaming universe rather than making vanilla-style Euros.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm tempted to say that this game is over-rated, but I don't think that would be fair.  This game does an excellent job at what it's trying to do, and I can't think of any other game that scratches the same itch. 

For beginners the problem is that the endgame seems way too sudden.  With experience, players start to recognize what the endgame looks like, and this problem becomes negligible.

For veterans, on the other hand, the problem is the static map.  Cancelling out a particular region only adds limited variability, and soon everybody knows the strongest board positions.  Fortunately, this can be solved with official and unofficial expansions, if you're willing to invest the time and/or money.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A solid multi-faceted euro with a bit too much mental calculation for my taste. I like the auction for power plants, and how it ties in to the subtle struggle for the best turn order position. I also like the fuel market, with its simulation of supply and demand and the interaction it forces between the players. I don't particularly like the main board though. Usually I enjoy having a spatial aspect to gameplay, but it doesn't feel like it adds all that much, and I find myself constantly adding up multiples of 5 to optimize my network on the board. Making it worse is the fact that many of the numbers you need to read from the board are pretty small, and the money you're using to pay for all the calculated costs is flimsy paper money that is annoying to deal with. I can see why the game is so highly regarded, but its annoyances mean it's not top-tier for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Nice auction, supply&demand game. Only two things bother me about it. 1. The resource costs are fairly linear and not significant enough to influence ones actions (up through 4 players). 2. Power Grids (in the US anyway) are not deployed via underground pipes. Transmission is nearly universally overhead while Distribution (intracity) is a mix of underground and overhead.

Had a chance to try a variant which was much more aggressive (new plant cards) - renewed my interest in this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
People crap on this game for being too "mathy", but that's the one aspect I really enjoy. The only randomness is what order the power plants come out of the deck in, and it affects everyone equally. Thus, the interaction between players during each phase of the game is what drives people to play differently, not luck. It does encourage players to take a "screw you" approach to hosing people out of resources or connections, but I'd rather have that than getting hosed by RNG.

There are a few problems with the game, but they're mostly map-specific. For example, the US map is really awful with more than ~4 people, because being forced to start on the west coast (which you more or less have to do going last in a 6-person game) pretty much guarantees a loss. So play Germany if you have a lot of people. Also, the power plants can be very lopsided in strength: the hybrid (coal/oil) plants are so much better than the others because you can pick and choose between the two cheapest resource markets.

If you're able, try looking at Power Grid Deluxe where these issues were at the very least addressed. I haven't played it enough to tell if the changes are strictly better, but they definitely do improve the experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
An okay game, I found it way too long, especially towards the end when it comes down to number crunching and you pretty much loose touch with what is going on around you, at least I did. I does not help that the theme ins painfully dull and boring. Still, one of the better Euros out there. I cannot help but think that the game will play pretty similar every time as the natural balance of progression in this game is pretty linear and you will never have many tactical options and usually one obvious strategy to go for in each round and that is something I find rather uninteresting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
December 2015: I don't want to play this game again.

January 2015: Bought this game for my aunt because she requested a 4-6 player game that was "strategic."

What surprised me after not playing this after six years is how relatively light this game is compared to Euros of today!

I played two 2-player games with my non-gamer aunt and cousin to teach them the rules. It went surprisingly smoothly! Now I think I'm more confident suggesting this game others new to Euro games!

Now, to me Power Grid is just a card drafting game!

Upgraded from 5 to 6.

2009-04-28: I tried this game again with six players, the new deck of power plants, the expansion board that features The Netherlands, and alternate rules that shorten the game.

I preferred this game over my last playing because the game did not drag at all.

It seems that the winner is the one who doesn't screw up rather than cleverly manipulating your opponents.

Way of screwing up:
* Paying way too much for a power plant
* Choosing a part of the board too hotly contested
* Ending up focusing on a commodity that everyone else wants.

What I like:
* The planning: It's a bit pathetic how I play this game. I require small bills so that I can group them into small piles representing each city I want to expand to, the commodities I want to buy, and my budget for my next power plant purchase.
* The way which power plans of increasing power come into the game.

What I don't like:
* The game's interaction is a bit too subtle for me. It's difficult to directly attack people in the lead. It's risky to attempt to screw an opponent over in the commodity market because that means you'll have to compete directly in the same commodity, which is risky. And it's difficult to effectively block opponents on the board (but that might change depending on the board you pick, and which sections you choose to include in the game)
* Personally, I don't like auction games very much.

RATING: 8.5

-The most perfect game I know even though it isn't the one I most like to play. It gets the higher rating because of that. It's because of how well it does everything it proposes to do and how everything seems so smoothly interlocked.
-Extremely inducer of table talk, threats, bluffing, like boardgames are suposed to.
-The resource market making you pay for your turn order sins, by changing princes accordingly to how much a resource is sought after.
-The range of power plants is enough to make several strategies work, either based on resource types, or resource quantities.
-The catch-up mechanisms.
-2 maps in the box provide somewhat different experiences.
-Selecting which areas to use in each game is also nice for replayability.

The downside:
-Mathy for those who have a problem with it. But its nothing really big and only become an issue later in the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Power Grid is ok.
It's decent.  It's fine.   There's room for skill and strategy, and a handfull of interesting decisions to make.
And yet... I was bored out of mind.  

The auctions that form the game's beating heart are banal and predictable, while the rest of the game boils down to simple arithmetic and action optimization.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
After reading, hearing and seeing this game for YEARS and people going on and on about it being so balanced and perfect in design, I just knew that one day I would be disappointed in its gameplay.
Well, that day finally happened (4/16/11).
What shocks me is how blatant the flaws are in this game, and makes me wonder what the hell people are using as rating criteria for these games.
The powerplant track is by far the worst design flaw in Power Grid, since it so drastically affects the entire flow of the game - if all the plants are low numbers, than the game just CRAWLS to a halt, with multiple turns basically spinning wheels until someone wants to get that 7th city and trigger the 2nd stage and then get the privilege of being screwed by going last.

And that leads to the 2nd major flaw - it is SUCH a penalty to trigger the 2nd stage & go last, it's no wonder that people deliberately try to hang back and wait, building up their money reserves until the sucker triggers, and then they try to buy up everything in that mad dash after the 2nd stage is triggered. It reminds me of how in Colosseum, people didn't want to be in first place and did whatever they could to hang back - a clear design/pacing flaw.

The game is SO slow in buildup during the 1st stage, and then literally there's one turn in the 2nd stage!
Then there might be 1 turn in the 3rd stage, and the game is over!

That right there shows a SERIOUS pacing problem, that should have disqualified it from getting the ratings necessary to be #5 best game on BGG.

sidenote - I was VERY surprised to see the community-building exercise when buying cities in this competitive game. Since when do Euro players actually help the other players find the most efficient way to place their cities? I haven't seen that in ANY competitive game in MANY years of playing - what an odd side-aspect of Power Grid, that people view it as a collective puzzle!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

At the end it sort of came down to kingmaker, but any decisions made at the time would have swayed it between the top two. It actually could have ended before the 3rd Step started, but the next pull started it. The final auction phase was what determined the final outcome, which ended up being in my favor.

RATING: 7
DT Secret Santa 2010
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a tough game for beginners, but it's a great game overall.

When I first introduced my friends to this, it took a few plays to get the hang of it.  There are many exceptions to the rules that need to be followed correctly; don't be surprised if you find yourself missing rules the first few plays.

Once you get the hang of it, it seems so easy, yet it's very challenging.  At any given time there aren't too many decisions to make, but there's definitely a strategy to every one.  Do you make more cities and get more money or do you sacrifice money to get a good turn position?  Do you buy a less efficient plant now or hold out for another one later?  How long do you keep bidding on a heavily contested plant?  Do you buy out the resource market to block other players or do you buy only what you need to keep prices low and use your money to buy better plants and more cities?  Every decision matters, but you always have good visibility into what's happening at the moment on which to base your decision.

The only problem it has is that the math can be daunting.  Later turns can become long as players count up the cost of routes to buy cities and making sure they have left enough cash when buying plants and resources.  Turns can be slow and it may be a while before you get to play again.

All in all, it's a great strategy game with a strong theme.  It even has some subtle lessons to teach about long-term investment, competition, and scarcity of resources.  There is no king-making, no runaway leaders, and despite not having a lot of direct interaction between players, players are always interacting indirectly through the power plant, resource, and city markets.  It a competitive game, but I've never seen it cause fights like many other games (e.g. Settlers of Catan).

I highly recommend this game for anybody looking for a deep, challenging strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I thought I'd enjoy this more than I did.  All of the people I played with had played before and they were very outspokenly critical of my moves.  Maybe it was because one player's rash moves can affect everyone's play more that they were so critical, but it left me with a bad experience of Power Grid.  I'd like to play it again with less hard core gamers or maybe even just a different set of people to see if my rating would change.

I thought I would really enjoy the turn order handicapping the person in the lead, but when I got into the game, it seemed artificial.  The people who were in the lead weren't really in the lead and they knew it.  Each player (the good players) spent more time playing the system than they did playing the opponents.  To me, it was a strange way to go about playing an auction game, even if it was effective.

******Update******

I raised my rating to a seven after a second play with a different set of players.  It improved because the people were more fun, but I've come up with other reasons that I'd prefer other games. Power Grid is too mean!  The best way to optimize in many cases is to ruin your opponents chances at doing anything worthwhile.  While many people dearly love this type of game, I absolutely don't.  

Also, I am someone who prefers games where it's okay to make split second decisions without calculating every little thing.  I am not someone who is generally AP prone.  Power Grid gives me AP.  I hate that feeling that everyone else wants me to hurry up and take a turn already.  I do see that it's a great game though and that many people find a lot to love about Power Grid.  If you are the sort of person who loves Power Grid, good for you! 

***Update***

Rating Lowered back to six because the thought of playing Power Grid kind of fills me with dread.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
28-11-2017
After years of hiatus finally I managed to put this back onto the table and I found it way better than I remembered. Considering that I also used the game as a more serious gateway game for the newbies, it did its job perfectly. 
The rules are generally straightforward, except when it is not: some minor rules make this game difficult to teach, especially those involving the removal of most expensive/cheapest power plant card on the market and the different steps and their effects in the game. Plus, I also forgot, that the game actually ends when you purchase the right to power the 17th city (in a 4-player game anyway), not when you actually can power it. This casued a bit of a headache for us and also a bit of backtracking, so it was a bit annyoing for me. 
Somehow I hate to teach this game to the public. Although the basic rules are simple, these exceptions and always-changing small details make it difficult to oversee a game. 
But even after the first game in years I already can see, how intricate the system is and how the different layers of the game (especially how the player order is determined and how it effects everything) interlocking with one another. 
Also, the fluctuating prices AND the availability of the resources makes the game very intriguing: it was a freightful realization from me at the last round, that beiing in the first position, after I bought a coal-based power plant, my opponents actually could deny me the coal I needed. 
And I had a lot of these kind of aha moments: you are better prepared for the last rounds with sufficient power plant capacity, so that you don't depend on the mercy of a card flip. You also should have a coherent plan from the very beginning, so that you won't waste expensive resources when you discard an obsolate power plant from your tabloeu. Also, you should also keep an eye on the future market and keep in mind, how the market works - sometimes it is better to forgo buying a new power plant, when it just hands a better option to your opponents thereafter. 
Playing with and around the turn order track is difficult but very satisfying puzzle on itself and for me this is the most important mechanics, that elevates this game from simply beeing a good one to a great (and evergreen) one.

RATING: 9
Superb resources-management game, perfectly spiced with a gnawing auction system that governs Power Plant purchases. Doesn't suffer from dangerous-looking "race leads", as precise money management opens the way for turning unfavorable tides. Excellent design and visuals, elegant rules. The only reason this game does not get an overall 10 is because I'll have a hard time playing it more than once a night. A game as good as this begs for two plays in sequence, but its unassuming depth (brain-burning factor) precludes this.

RATING: 8
A game that is less about efficiency than about timing, which is a bit weird for a business simulation but makes it an exciting game.  I think it is possible to play well and do clever things.  Such play is not invariably rewarded, mainly due to how the power plant cards fall in the auction round.  I find this acceptable as this is the only major randomness in the game and it injects considerable tension and fun, at the cost of making the ultimate winner be determined a bit randomly.  I am not convinced there is a run-away leader problem.

RATING: 10
Favorite game on my shelf. Lots to do and the expansions all add little twists. The rubber banding makes this very accessible to weaker strategy players too
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I was unimpressed with this game.  To counter act the "rich get richer" problem in most economic games the weaker players get so many advantages that the bicycle strategy of 'drafting' (being careful not to take the lead too early and taking advantage of another player's draft and jockeying for the lead at the last moment) plays a huge role in this game.  This bugs me on a game that 'simulates' energy policy.  It is also unrealistic, in that vast amount of the time, economies of scale favor the leader.

90% of the games victory conditions are decided in the last two turns.  This makes the early game is basically meaningless providing you don't fall vastly behind.  (And this is not hard to do.)  So effectively, you could start in the mid-game with no loss.  Not good design.

The game is so unrealistic in other respects (for example, you could increase the cost of uranium 100 times and the price of nuclear power would increase by 1%) that it is a turn off if I want to introduce someone to a game on energy policy.  There is no penalty for power plants that produce CO2, (which will be driving the change to cleaner power plants in the near future), which is another critical failure of the game.

Another problem is the game does not play well with 3 players.

The game does have some nice points.  I do like the mechanics of how older power plants have to be replaced, which feels very natural.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
for family gaming

Good game but I found it starting to drag a bit as time went on.

Please, please don't ask me to play Power Grid. Seriously.

RATING: 9
I really enjoy this game.  The decisions each round are tough, but not too difficult to think through - a fine line for a game to walk, and I think Power Grid does it nicely.  Beware of trying to bid up plants you don't want, however.  I got stuck two times last time I played and it destroyed my game.  

With more plays however, I have downgraded my rating slightly - I still think it's a great game, but I always feel that it goes a little longer than I'd like it to.  Maybe that's because I'm usually out of the running in those last few turns -- I'm sure to play this more, and I'll try and pinpoint that feeling some more.

RATING: N/A
2-6 players, best with 4-5.  120 min; weight 3.29
Auctioning, network development, resource acquisition, and a tight balancing act to maximize the efficiency of limited resources and take ownership of the most strategic positions on the board. You must keep a close eye on what your opponents are doing and find ways to dissuade them from selecting the tiles you need most. Not nearly as complex as the poorly written/presented rules would indicate. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Power Grid was one of the first few games I played when introduced to modern board gaming.  It was a bit too much at the time.  Now, it's great.  People say this game is "mathy".  It's just basic arithmetic.  If you can add 20 + 7 + 20 + 5 then you can play this game just fine.

This game was more confrontational than I would have expected.  Not directly, but you will find yourself fighting for position on the map with other players.

I've found this game to be more fun with higher player counts - one of the few games I can say that about.  Generally I find fewer player counts makes for less down time, which keeps you involved more and ends up being a faster gaming experience.  Power Grid is one of the few that I think is better with 4+ players.

:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: [b]Components[/b]
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: [b]Artwork[/b]
:star::star::star::star::star: [b]Mechanics (general gameplay "fun")[/b]
:star::star::star::star::halfstar: [b]Rules (well written and easy to learn/teach)[/b]
:star::star::star::star::star: [b]Replay Value[/b]
:star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: [b]Player Uptime[/b]
:star::star::star::star::star: [b]Meaningful Decisions (luck factor)[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My favourite game. Even after numerous plays, assigning different values on  power plants during auctions in dependence of the game state is most fun and never gets old. The whole ressource market and the goal to cost-efficiently generate power is just very thematic... and fun. 

Altough PG looks a bit like a train game, the map and expanding your network is only one and certainly not the main aspect of the game. Tightly connected to this is the turn order mechanism. Sure, turn order is really important in PG and you should consider not to expand too early and forego some income. I like how this is integrated  in  the gameplay and I prefer this very much over a separated auction or spending an action (as in many worker  placement games).

However, being efficient is only a means and not an end to the game, since PG has a very unique game end and victory condition (network size triggers  game end; winner is the biggest power supplier in the last round). From the mid game on you try to get into a good position to make a move for ending the game. This may be that as a leader you expand your network beyond your capacity and surprise your opponents with an early game end. Or you try to maximize your capacity, which often leads to fierce auctions in the last two rounds.

There are some overpowered plants (25&26), so a randomization of plants would make this game perfect for me (of course without making the game more fiddly ;)). This game can get mathy for AP prone players, who try to calculate everything down to the last electro. However, apart from auctioning very good plants in the beginning and the costs for your final 6-7 cities (tip: just look at the average costs per house), there is no need for big calculations. Many actions have a subtle but complex impact on the complete game state and a pure cost/benefit calculation could never grasp this. So play by intuition instead of calculation! 

The game has an incredible replayability, since each game depends on map setup (cheap or expensive connection costs) and even much more on the power plant draw (good plants in the beginning and then a stall or only mediocre plants in the beginning leading to a rather tight ressource market). In total this Euro really has it all. Thematic ressource conversion, turn order manipulation, map/network mechanisms, auctions, unique winning condition and some luck with the power plant card draw (which may be even removed by the variant to reveal the top most card of the power plant deck).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
When it was first suggested to me would I like to play a game revolving around running a power company, building up your infrastructure, and powering up cities, I was already taking a few steps backwards. When I was informed, "Oh, it's a German game", I started looking for cutlery lying around to stab myself to death.

Despite my initial reservations, Power Grid is currently my favourite multiplayer (2+) game because of how the theme and mechanics work seemlessly to produce a clean, streamlined and fun game with a good balance of strategy and interaction, and being engaged during other players turns.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
(9/15/07) - Purchased

(1/30/07) - [9] - After three plays on BSW I finally understand the rules and have experienced the game. This is a game unlike any of the others I own. The theme and gameplay integrate with each other flawlessly. Specifically, you need to run your grid at maximum efficiency or you will lag behind your rivals. The resource market is amazing in that it is simple, but accurately depicts swings in the demand for a certain good and the subsequent price shift. While there is a lot more math in this game that anything I've ever played, it does not detract from the game's brilliance. Playing on BSW is especially enjoyable because of the reduced time for a game and the system taking care of the boring stuff like placing resources and shuffling out plants. This game deserves its place in the Top 10!

(7/21/08) - [7] - Further plays of this has warranted a re-rating. While this is still a good game, it doesn't feel as mind-blowing as it once was. Maybe my tastes have changed, or I've found other games I enjoy more. Either way, I'm dropping my rating to a 7.

(02/08/11) - SOLD

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I think that this game is a perfect example of a "6".  I like it, and it really gets the gamer side of my brain going but it has its downsides.  First is game length.  Clocking in at 2 hours this can be a detriment if you want to get more than one game in on a short evening.  The second, and my main reason for making this a "6" and not a "7" are some pretty fiddly rules.  Take this card out, add this card to the bottom, if step 3 occurs during phase 2 do this, if no one purchases a plant do this, etc.  I'm sure that the rules won't seem AS fiddly with a few more games played, but trying to explain this (or trying to comprehend some of the ambiguous rules yourself) can be pretty daunting.  So, in conclusion, I like the game and will play it if I'm in the mood for something heavy and engaging, but wouldn't pull it out every game night.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
By themselves the auction, resource, and building phases each play like unfinished kernels of other games, but they mesh together so well that the whole becomes greater than the sum of its parts. 

The math involved is trivial, but the number of calculations required slows down the game.

Additionally, luck of the draw can significantly affect the outcome. I've often seen a player buy the most efficient and productive power plant available, only to have another, even more efficient plant replace it, which is promptly acquired for the minimum bid by the auction's last remaining participant.

So, does a player buy the most efficient plant available at the moment? Or abstain from the auction and hope a better one becomes available?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Eigenaar Roland

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
http://www.ronkkonen.com/boardgames.html#Power
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What's nice about empire-building games is the story you play out--poor little company starts with meagre resources and manages in time to create a congromerate spanning the continent.  It's kind of like life--that expensive guitar you really wanted when you were in college, you now can afford easily, and it's nice to see how far you've developed over the years.  That's the Joy of Power Grid.

Power Grid is free of many drawbacks typically associated with empire-building games:  (relatively) short playing time, no long waits between actions, no runaway leader, fairly simple rules (particularly if someone else is handling the power plant market).  On the minus side, there is more adding up of little numbers than I can comfortably handle.  Arithmetically-challenged individuals may wish to use a calculator with the game.  (I realize it may be hard to convince non-gamers that a game that involves using a calculator can be fun!  But you may wish to try--it seems to be a perfectly fine game for the analytically-minded, engineer-type non-gamer.)

Enjoyment is also due to the interesting things that are going on in the economic model: market-driven fuel shortages and surpluses, sporadic (but partly predictable) progress in  technology, the stepwise deregulation of the power grid.  Also, each link in the chain needed to supply electricity has its own interesting quirks (fuel prices are volatile, the available power plants  improve over time, the power grid must be developed with an eye on logistics).  Though it's a lot of little pieces, both in terms of rules and the amount of thinking required, it's all quite intuitive.  All the little pieces mesh together well to make a satisfying full dinner of a game.

RATING: 9
NL

OMSCHRIJVING: Sterk strategisch-mathematisch, economisch bordspel.
De spelers zijn energieleveranciers in een wedloop om zoveel mogelijk steden van elektriciteit te voorzien. Investeren ze hoofdzakelijk in energiecentrales die elektriciteit opwekken uit steenkool, olie, bio-afval of kern-energie? Of kiezen ze toch liever voor meer ecologisch verantwoorde windenergie? Elke spelronde worden er nieuwe energiecentrales verkocht aan de hoogste bieder (als die er is). Wie uiteindelijk het meeste steden ook effectief van energie kan voorzien, wint het spel.

--> 2 tot 6 spelers

RATING: 8.5

Definitely recommended, but for more serious board gamers.

RATING: 8
Power Grid is a straight-forward economic management game. The challenge of the game is to find a solid balance between having the best power plants or having the advantage in auctions and resources. Its a heavy number-crunching game, but if that's your thing, then sign up for Power Grid.

To add to the whole package, Power Grid is also just fun to look at! This game has a really cool look to it that sets it apart from other board games.

RATING: 9.3
There is very little I don't love about this game. I love the way the market works, the power plants, future market, balance of building routes and powering cities, money management, auctions, player turn order, limited building options which expand as the game goes on, plenty of strategy interlocking with tactics, ability to complicate things for other players without direct conflict... everything I like about games is here- all in one package. I have some minor issues with this game, mostly because I played Funkenshlag several times before and I like some of the elements from it a little better- specifically drawing and planning out routes from city to city, and a more robust Step 3- but overall I'll take the more streamlined Power Grid. There isn't much at all I'd change in this game. If only the game was shorter so I could get it on the table more often.

RATING: 5
Tries to improve Funkenschlag but makes several key errors:
-  The payout chart is too rich, which allows fuel to be hoarded & sold out (something which can unfairly toss the game to other players.)  It also means instead of 3 phases in the original, too often the has extremely short 2nd & 3rd phases, because players have enough income to build to several cities per round. 
-  The removal route building takes away some tactical touches--how to build to retain access to cities you'll need later.
-  The US map is highly unbalanced.

RATING: 9.5

FUN! now i own a custom resource set and a ton of maps. i can't get enough of this game! FUN!! it's actually surprising to see i only have 10 plays because i recommend it eeevery week. i think part of my drive to purge my (admittedly creaking) shelf of lesser games is so that there are fewer things between me and my next game of Power Grid.

RATING: 8
I like the mostly non-random nature of it.  The first few times it takes a long time, but experienced players go quickly, and 2-player (we play that way at home, though it's not as good 2-player, and most people seem to not like it at all 2-player) is often under an hour.

But gameplay is longer than I prefer with a large group, or with newbies.  And newbies can be lose terribly from a single early mistake, then suffer for a long time.  Game length and its not being as good for 2-player is the main reason I don't rate it even higher.  It's a very cool interesting game.

I created the [[Power Grid FAQ]].  Please read before playing or posting rules questions!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the most enjoyable games out there, imo. Players purchase power plants and the necessary fuel and then build networks of cities across America. Earn more and more Electro bucks by powering more and more cities. More money means you can purchase additional power plants or upgrade existing ones. Be careful because the price of coal, oil, garbage and uranium changes with supply and demand! Pretty easy to learn and lots of fun to play with some clever nuances you will only figure out after a couple of plays.

RATING: 8.5
One of the classic economic games, with a mixture of auction, market management, and area control.  I'm not a fan of the randomness of plant draws during the auction and how much the game focuses on vying for lower places on the turn order, but that's just part of the game - it's often better to hold back mid-game in city building, wait to get a really good plant and then bust out with lots of cities.  If you like this, I strongly recommend Wealth of Nations.

RATING: 10
Not exactly a "fun" game, in order to play this properly meticulous calculations are needed.  Despite its heavy tones, Power Grid delivers a unique experience both in terms of game play and theme.  The game mechanics of determining the price for resources and the auction system for power plants are nothing short of brilliant.

If you and 3-5 friends are looking for a serious challenge, then Power Grid is the board game for you.

RATING: 7.7
--2Sept2004--  Has much of the feel of a long-distance bicycle race.  The fellow in the lead has the disadvantage, and there's a sprint to the finish after a short while of husbanding the energy for the final push.  Nice dynamics.
--Oct2006-- Demoted to 7 on comparison with its peers; it still seems that there's too much fiddliness (and this from someone that likes Antiquity!) for the payoff.
--Oct2012-- Fun to revisit; it was much more appealing this time out:  I suspect my tastes have changed somewhat in the interim.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
reddit comment: "I haven't played it recently but I love Power Grid. In Power Grid you take the role of the owner of a power company trying to power more cities than your competitors. The number of cities you can power depends on the size of your power plant. During the auction phase, you engage in out-bidding your competitors for ownership of larger power plants. Additionally, your power plants are powered by a variety of fuel. Some fuels are more scarce than others which leads to tension as players race for control of the fuel.
I recommend playing with poker chips instead of the paper money that it comes with."

RATING: 7

It reminds me of Dominion in that way, which I don't care for for the same reason. I didn't really enjoy my first play, but the second play was markedly better. I think this is a game that could use a few more plays before I know for sure how I feel about it.

RATING: 10
Az általam ismert legjobb stratégiai játék. Hihetetlenül jól modellezi a valóságot (a kereslet hatásai hogyan változtatják a nyersanyag árakat), gyönyörű (bár egyesek szerint "ipari") a kivitelezése. Végig nagyon szoros a verseny, köszönhetően a mechanizmusba rejtett "esélykiegyenlítés"-nek.
Egyfolytában topon kell lenni agyilag, és egy számológépet sem árt bekészíteni játék során, de remek szórakozást nyújt a hosszúnak mondható játékideje ellenére is (amely azonban minden percét megéri).

RATING: 7
[color=#CC0000]

This game just gets better each time we play it.  Remarkably tight, keeps the scare up, plenty of ways to affect the outcome of the game.  The production quality is sufficient but not plush, but let's face it -- you buy Power Grid to play the game, not admire the pieces.  This is just plain a good game.

Late Update -- after playing many more game titles, it is becoming apparent to me that the throttling mechanisms in Power Grid control the game too much.  Poor players often finish in the money due to the deadly embrace of two players that played significantly better in the first half of the game.  That's all part of the mix, but in PG I think the level of control exerted by the rules is a significant percentage of the level of control exerted by the player's actions.  Therefore I'm docking my prior rating by a full point.

[/color]

This game keeps everyone in it 'til the end - the balancing mechanism of the game is flawless.  

I have played this game many many times, and I still love it and want to play it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Sometimes you play a game so much that all of its little eccentricities stop being liabilities and start being assets. This is how Power Grid is to me. In the Venn diagram between me and all of my gaming buddies, the trashers, the Euro players, Power Grid is the game that lies closest to the middle. Sure there's some arithmetic, but you're managing a power company, what did you expect? Sure the turn order mechanic is gamey and an obvious catch-up tool, but knowing that creates some amazing subtleties between players. 

And besides that it's the kind of game that opens up with every play. It requires you to play with your eyes up, watching the other players. It forces you to plan several moves ahead, since the best move now could be catastrophic down the road. It's the sort of game where literally every dollar counts, and every decisions will produce consequences, both good and bad, that you will have to live with. It's my favorite economic game, one of the best there is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Power Grid has players trying to power the most cities.  Power plants are auctioned off each turn, and each power plant consumes some number of some type of resource to power some number of cities.  Players buy power plants, "build" into cities, buy resources, and gain an income determined by the number of cities they power.  The first person to "build" into at least 14 cities triggers the end game, the winner being the person who powered the most cities (money being a tie breaker).

This game has an interesting negative feedback loop: the player in the lead acts first at auctioning off a power plant (usually the worst position), and acts last at building into cities and buying resources.  Resources have a sliding price, so the more that are purchased the more expensive they get.  Great depth of strategy, especially in balancing your income as money is only a tie-breaker.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is a Euro-style economics game more suited to those who are interested in numbers and wealth accumulation and distribution. It takes a couple of hours to play with 3-4 players, but can take longer with more players or with slower or new players. It is a very popular game, although I personally find it a bit too dry for my tastes. I prefer party games like Resistance/Dixit/Telestrations or broad interaction-based games, like Diplomacy, which power grid is not. The resource market is quite nifty (it mimicks a real market's supply and demand) and I like the components to the game (again, very Euro-style, wooden). The game initially comes with US/Germany maps, but I hear that the Benelux expansion is worth getting for a quick game or for new players. Worth getting if you are not me!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Funkenschlag with crayons: Auctions are fun. Buying resources is fun. Runaway leader problems can make it all a bit predictable if the game end is still a long way off. Plays very different with four than with five - there just doesn't seem to be the resource shortages. I'd really prefer a scaled down version playing to say 12 cities, with Settlers type roads on a proper board, less points on the board (to speed up game-play), lower value of power plants, etc. - all so it could be played in less than 90 minutes.

And then there was Power Grid. A great improvement with the pace vastly improved without having to draw on a board. My rating above is for Power Grid - which should have its own separate entry because it's just not the same game- while Funkenschlag is rated two points below this mainly due to its dragging length. I think the new double-sided board is great. Now a word about theme: I've had some gamers say to me that they think the theme of this game is very weak. My opinion is that this is one of the better theme matched to game system games out there. There's not many other themes you could paste on that would make much sense to me. (It's no Web of Power - which could really be a game about pizza franchises.) If fact, the game seems to do a very good job of simulating the power company deregulation that took place in the late 90's and first decade of this century. I look at each of the plants as smaller energy companies being swallowed up by the RWEs and the like as they gobble up the energy infrastructure and service contracts for cities and industry. I suppose there could be a gas and water expansion for Power Grid one day. I'd buy it.

After more plays I'm starting to think this should be rethemed as a cycling game - go out hard or stay at the back of the pack saving your energy and waiting for the perfect breakaway opportunity.

In any case, the sameness of each game has dropped this a point in my ratings after 15 games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
The ultimate gamer's game.  The rules are fairly short and this game has little chance.  The strategy is based ultimately around money, and hence resource management.  Auctions, knowing when to take the lead, and cutting off your opponent make this game more aggressive the more players are added.  Add to this the fact that falling behind early can really ruin your chances of winning, and you have a game that seems mean-spirited, but acts more like a light-hearted criterion race.  All-in-all, a well thought out bidding/buying war with plenty of strategy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A game where all elements - auction, resource management, area control - come together.  Timing in each of your actions is key.  Do I bid more for this plant this turn, or save my money to expand and go for a (hopefully) better plant next time.  Build now or go for firing capacity.  Equally important is where you place that first plant, looking ahead to connections in upcoming turns - and the potential to block or be blocked - resulting in higher connections costs.  Plus, the all important impact on turn order as you must consider whether you want first crack at the plants or resources and building.

RATING: 5

I don't know.

3+2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
-a 2012 early Christmas gift for Zack from Julia-

OUR IMPRESSIONS: This is the best teen and adult friendly Euro-styled economic, auction/bidding, and resource management game we have played to date.  My wife Julia's favorite board game has always been Monopoly. She is the most calculating Monopoly player I have ever met.  Now, Power Grid is her favorite board game because it's everything Monopoly wishes it could be.  

As an economic gaming heavyweight, Power Grid's mechanics/components not only include cash currency (Elektro)and valued property cards (power plants) but also features painted wooden city tokens for route-building (i.e. Ticket to Ride), real estate auction/bidding/bluffing (i.e. For Sale), and a resource market with fluctuating costs for various energy commodities (painted wooden tokens as coal, oil, garbage, uranium) that require careful resource-management (i.e. Settlers of Catan).  Thematically, the game has an gritty electric aesthetic with crisp graphics that depict a gamut of energy production facilities: from fossil fuels, nuclear materials, and recycled waste, to emerging renewable resources like wind and solar power.  As a hefty Euro styled game with minimal luck involved and a narrative without violent conflict or player elimination, we find Power Grid to be very engaging, quite challenging, and overall more fun and replayable than mainstream 20th century American economic games like Monopoly, Life, Pit, or Pay-Day.

Of the 60+ games in our home, this is THE game that we go out of our way to plan ahead for and play together as husband and wife or with our gamer friends.  It's best played with 3 or more players but with the Power Grid: Robots expansion that adds "AI" 'robot' player(s), we can have the strategic depth and unpredictability of a 4-player game yet are able to play with only 2 human players (my wife and I).  

***

GAMEPLAY: The game is divided in duration by 3 overarching successive STEPS and in gameplay, each round consists of 5 sequential economic PHASES. The winner of the game is the one who succeeds in achieving the game's goal of powering the most cities built into your energy network by simultaneously owning the most efficient combination of power plants and having enough purchased raw materials in your resource supply to meet the economic demand for energy from the linked cities in your energy network. This sounds complex, and it can be at first, but the game flows very well in a consistent and calculating manner.  

STEP 1 is the opening step in the game and it's main function is to enforce a rule that a player may only build cities into their network if they are vacant for a cost of 10 elektro + the connection cost (the number value listed between adjacent cities on the map board).  

STEP 2 is initiated after a player builds the prescribed number of cities and thus adds more intensity and higher costs/risks/rewards for the players. Instead of building only in vacant cities, now players may build into single occupancy cities to make them double occupancy for an increased cost of 15 elektro + the connection cost. 

STEP 3 is the final endgame process that is initiated after the STEP 3 card is drawn from the Power Plant deck in between rounds or during the Phase 2 bidding/auction process. In STEP 3, the auction market from Steps 1-2 with the 4 lowest choices from 8 total plants arranged in descending order on display (the remaining 4 higher cost plants are the future market) is increased to a total of 6 plants available for bidding on the auction market with NO future market. Also at the end of each round in Phase 5, the lowest plant on the auction block is discarded and removed from the game, forcing frugal players to reconsider their strategy if they want to win. 

PHASE 1) DETERMINE PLAYER ORDER: First place player is the one who has presently built the most cities in their power plant network.  Note: First place position players do not always win the game after STEP 3 is initiated; some players tactically decide to be in last place during rounds in order to be the first to buy raw materials and build cities.  

PHASE 2) BUY POWER PLANT First place begins the Auction/Bidding process for acquiring/upgrading ONE more efficient power plants by spending one's Elektro. (Depending on the number or players, each player may only own and operate a maximum of 3-4 power plants during the game and must discard the least efficient plant from their energy network with each upgrade.) The game begins with each player having 50 Elektro for start-up costs.  The power plants range in minimum bids from 3-50 Elektro and can power from 1-7 cities using single or multiple types of raw materials purchased from the commodities market. Note: In Steps 1-2, there are 8 visible power plants on the market arranged in descending order of cost for a minimum bid. The 4 highest valued power plants are not yet up for auction but 

PHASE 3) BUY RAW MATERIALS: Last place is the first to purchase available energy resources from the commodities market using their accrued Elektro currency; each proceeding step in the game effects the surplus supply and costs due to the changing demand for each energy resource. Note: a player may only purchase up to a personal surplus of 200% raw materials of only what their owned power plants require. (i.e. if a player had a power plant that powered 3 cities for 2 coal, then the player can only purchase a maximum of 4 coal from the market.)

PHASE 4) BUILDING: Last place begins the process for building new cities into one's expanding power plant network; these cities are powered by the combination of purchased power plants from phase 2 and raw materials from phase 3.  Note: during the opening round, ALL players must purchase and power 1 or more cities. Also at the start of the game each player will choose to begin building their network in one unoccupied colored region on the map board; the number of players determines how many adjacent regions are accessible for the remainder of the game. In subsequent rounds, the building of one's cities in their own network will spill over into adjacent regions so long as their network is one continuous connection to the origin city selected in the first round of the game. Conflict in the game arises between players in the rare occasions when someone builds from an advantageous location near multiple adjacent cities of other players' regions; so I guess there can be a mechanic of area control in the STEP 1 rounds of gameplay at work.  

PHASE 5) BUREAUCRACY: This concluding phase is where risks/costs are rewarded with profits and the market for power plants and raw materials are adjusted accordingly with each succeeding STEP (from 1-3) in the game.   
- A) GET MONEY: Here, beginning with first place, each player decides how many cities they want to or are able to effectively power using their acquired power plants and raw materials at hand and thus, are rewarded with Elektro profits allocated according to the number of cities they decide to power. (i.e. if a player who had built 6 cities in their network, but only had a power plant that powered 4 cities for 2 oil, then they could only power 4 cities maximum, and discard 2 oil from their resource supply into the energy surplus pile and receive 54 Elektro in return according to the game's earnings chart.) Note: all used raw materials for powering cities are discarded back into a surplus pile.
- B) UPDATE POWER PLANT MARKET according to STEP 1, 2, or 3 that is in effect during the game.  In Steps 1-2 at the end of each round the highest power plant in the market is removed and placed back under the power plant card deck.  In Step 3, at the end of each round, the lowest power plant in the market is discarded and removed for the rest of the game.
- C) RESTOCK RAW MATERIALS in the resource marker according to the table listed on the back of the instruction manual (which also lists how many cities need to be built into a player's network to initiate the next STEP).  Each succeeding STEP has different ratios of return for depleting energy resources simulating the market effects of surplus, supply, cost, demand, and inflation/deflation as the raw materials components are placed and displayed on the resource market (see Phase 3) on the bottom/side of the map board.  The Round is now complete and go back to Phase 1 to resume gameplay until the game is complete.      

***

PROS: Power Grid is an excellent game for decision-making and strategic thinking skills. It requires maximum player involvement so that each person gets to work and play through until the its conclusion. It has a back-and-forth momentum from its mixed mechanics that allows a person in last place to have opportunities to gain fresh momentum that can change the pace or trajectory of each game.  The component quality is fantastic with hundreds of colorful painted wood pieces and a great double-sided board.  There are also multiple moderately priced expansion sets available as double-sided map boards of different geographic locations with new power plant cards and special localized rules.  My final pro is that this game seems to be unrivaled among other economic themed games and even among the heavier cult-hit Euro games we have played or heard about; it really stands out on our gameshelf and hasn't had the chance to collect any dust.

CONS: This is not a con from our perspective but it might be for others: there is minimal luck (if any) in this game; there are no dice, but only a shuffled deck of the remaining power plant cards for the auction phase (1 of 5) for each round.  No decision is without consequence and no opportunity can be wasted if you want to win the game. This is what some gamers call a "BRAINBURNER."  It is a mathematical, systematic, sequential reasoning kind of game that takes 2 hours to play. Now for some legitimate cons that we see to be easily reconciled with patience.  For new players or for very analytical over-thinking folks, this game can bring on symptoms of "Analysis Paralysis" where it feels like another players turn seems to take longer than it needs to and thus, the morale of the group playing can diminish. It's not the easiest game to teach without first playing through a game to understand how it fits together and I could see how impatient players or those who avoid conflict in terms of games that have limited number of resources, might not initially enjoy this game until they become more confident with its deep strategic gameplay.  

The pros far outweigh the cons in our book. 

***  

TEACHING TAKEAWAYS: As a parent and pastor, I like how this game can teach and simulate sound economic principles and reasonable resource stewardship for intentional sequential decision-making. I appreciate how a game like this one can demonstrate how your decisions directly effect the decisions of other players and vice versa. Personally, as a lifelong learner with ADHD, games like these help me to focus and make tactical decisions wisely by following a one-step-at-a-time process while remaining aware of the long-term strategy with an end goal in perspective.  As for my wife, she really likes the mathematical/probability/statistics learning curve this game presents kids and adults who take the time to play this game.  Finally, good map-based games (i.e. "Ticket to Ride") like this can foster basic geography skills with learning city locations in various countries/continents. 

GRADE: We rate POWER GRID a 10 out of 10 --- OUTSTANDING!

RATING: 9
One of my all-time favorite games!

Pros:
-Easy to learn/teach
-Strategy is easy enough that new players should have no trouble making long-term decisions relatively early on. -Very little element of luck (one deck of shuffled cards/other player choices).
-Player order mechanics ensure that players are rarely ever out of contention before end-game.
-Game scales well for multiple players but 3+ is recommended for auction mechanic.

Cons:
-Not good with 2 (Robots expansion helps)
-Round oil barrel pieces often roll away (small gripe)

RATING: 6.5
What was I rambling about in my old comment?

Anyhow it's an engine building game with an auction to get engine parts and then other stuff (like resource market and building the electric grid). On board spatial part means some blocking is possible. Best thing about this game is  how intuitive the theme works - buy a plant, then a fuel for said plant, then build a network, then burn fuel in plant to supply network and get money. And dramaturgy of the game is also interesting even with it's funny catch up mechanisms (this is how we run economy in Europe).

Problems: 
- Bureaucracy. There are some fiddly rules governing the flow of the game that should be damn highlighted in the rulebook! There's a bgg file that helps with that, so print it ouot. 
- Art. I still don't get. Retro, but depressing and brown? Uhm. I love retro, but for me this would mean socialism with it's bring utopia of industrial rebuilding and dirty skies. The anniversary edition is basically what I wanted, just not sure if I love this game so much. 

Why I've traded it: I got 3 plays in 5 years. Ok I was playing other people's copies as well. This gets played so rarely which is a bit of a shame as I find it much better than most current euros (but when it will get played, somebody is bound to own a copy). It's also a bit long - I like similar style game Fleet better just because it's shorter.

RATING: 7
Good game, with lots of think about. However, the auto-balancing mechanism is a little forced.

Six players is too many, unless they are not deep calculators. Very mathematical at the end, and too many games decided on tiebreakers. The game can thus be repetitious as you calculate every turn in roughly the same way.

And one more thing: too much depends on what plants get flipped up. An excellent fix is that the next four upcoming plants are made known before they become available.

RATING: 7
I played this for the first time this past weekend and came away very interested by what Power Grid brings to the table.  Almost the entire system of rules is designed to prevent a runaway victory by one person which really serves as a great way to keep the game interesting as it enters the late phase.  The Resource Market adds an interesting element which can force a player to adjust his current strategy because of financial concerns.  

It seems like its a better game when there are more players and when everyone enjoys the auctions.  If you're not a fan of the auction mechanic, you won't like this game.

Otherwise, pretty good fun and I look forward to playing it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[22 plays] Have really enjoyed this game very much with all numbers of players, from 2 on up to 6. Update 6/4/11: As I cross beyond 20 completed plays, I will modify to say that I don't rate the game a "10" with just 2 or with the full complement of 6 player. I do think it is simply outstanding with 3,4, or 5 players.

This game is an excellent deeper game, and I personally enjoy the mechanics of the power plant market and the resource market of which others have been critical. I don't think they're fiddly, I think they are cool and the unique mechanics make the game.

Power Grid is all about the plant auctions. What to buy and when to buy -- based on the resource market, the current and future demands on resources by the other players, and watching the number rank of the plant if turn order is still of high concern. I absolutely LOVE that mechanic. It wraps me up and makes my gray cells burn in a most delicious way.

Controlling auctions as best you can, controlling your place in the turn order to your best advantage, and calculated grid expansion decisions on the map are all critical. Minute decisions can mean the difference between win and loss when playing with sharp competitors.

Most recent play Aug '17.

RATING: 5
Not a terrible game, but not a great game either. Of the few times I've played it, my feelings of Power Grid were: 

1st - Interesting game. Could be fun. A little drawn out in the middle.

2nd - Okay game. The game seems to slow down too much during play.

3rd - Good God this game takes forever. And I lost by not being able to buy ONE barrel! The first 2 players bought extra to block me and even though I had the most $$ I'm stuck. There should be a reserve rule. Seems like bad game design to have all of those unused barrels sitting in the reserve if you can't buy them. Even if you had to pay $20+ or a penalty it would make more sense. Talk about a horrible way to lose the game. KINGMAKER GAMES SUCK! Can you tell I'm bitter?

4th - How did I get talked into playing this again? I'm still bitter from the last game.

RATING: 8

This one also takes a bit more time than expected.  Both games I've played seemed to have the "Oh, this is going along smoothly" moment about an hour into playing, only to have another two hours before completion.

RATING: 5
I really like Power Grid, although the rules booklet is bloody awful - more examples required and less waffly text. 

My criticisms of it are that people sometimes can't tell WHY they won or lost - there's no specific strategy or event to pin it on... it's more the result of a string of small successes or mistakes - an electro overspent here or there. 

Also, it's quite fiddly and requires quite intense "management" of the board, cards, materials and money. Played on BSW with all the work done by the computer it flows a lot better, but then the auctioning side of it is sterile. I need to play much more to fully grasp it and will revisit my score of 8 after more plays.

EDIT:  Revised to a 7. I like it, but with my group I have to micromanage it intensely and it becomes less relaxing and fun.

EDIT AGAIN:  I don't like Power Grid.  I just don't like it, OK?  Too mathsy. 

Sold on eBay!

[2010-09-01]
Nekem a jól kitalált mechanizmus, ami a lemaradókat segíti, kimondottan tetszik. Igazán jó gazdasági játék, bármilyen játékosszámmal. Egyszerű szabályok, feszes, végig izgalmas játékmenet. Kimondottan előny a sok játékos lehetősége. Bár azt kell mondanom ketten is jól játszható és úgy teljesen más stratégia lehet a nyerő. Egyetértek azokkal, akik szerint a puritán kinézet illik a játékhoz és nem is néz ki rosszul.
Egyedüli negatív dolog, hogy egy kicsit száraz a játék a nem gémerek számára.

[2011-10-15]
Úgy tűnik nagyon gondolkodós is lehet egy-egy parti. Nem gondoltam volna, hogy 3 és fél órát is elhúzódhat egy négyszemélyes játék. Ennyi parti után nagyon úgy érzem az utolsó 2 kör a vége előtt jó játékosok között túl sokat számít. Az a szerencse, hogy végül milyen erőművek kerülnek ki a pakliból véletlenszerűen az elején, döntő dolog is lehet. Ettől függetlenül továbbra is zseniális játék.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I love this game - it has some minor game play issues but on the whole, one of those classics.

CONS: the instructions are reeealy difficult to interpret so make sure you check out the simplified versions on bgg. The 2 player game was not so good in terms of how to end, but further info  suggested to only play 3 regions which simulates larger player groups so you need to fight for space.  The end in my opinion should be not only how many cities you have but you should have to power them otherwise some aspects/mechanics of the game play becomes a bit one dimensional even though the overall game is quite multidimensional.  Again, the only thing I am a bit unimpressed by is the powering of areas, it seems like it should be tied in more with winning rather than simply providing income because when you get closer to the end you aren't motivated to spend extra power up cash and this part of the game languishes. 

PROS: This is such a superb game overall, with some ironing out of the very flexible rules to your own liking, this is such a classic. Very cool industrial revolution style cards and nice over reaching dimensional game play  ,fun and certainly good for beginners if an experienced player can explain the rules or you have good "rule reading skills". Basically, Power Grid is one of my partners favorites - very nice solid economics and resource game. I LOVE the resource rarity mechanic - as resources become popular they become rarer driving up the value so you can't always count on resources being worth a particular amount.  It throws a nice element of variation into repeat games. 


It is a pretty good game and recommended plus the theme is super nice and a breath of fresh air in what my partner describes as the usual eurogame themes of stale medieval hogwash. (I beg to differ but there you go)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Still a very solid game, but not quite up there with my favorites.

RATING: 10
Power Grid is has become an unstoppable favorite.  Since this has come out it is one of the few games that never fails to hit the table with frequency, never fails to excite me, and consistently challenges me without frustration.  This is also the only games that started as a 7 in my mind and grew to a 10.  I held out on the 10 rating for a long time as the potential irritation of the phase 2 stall was too present, but I so frequently want to play this and intensely enjoy the design that I've stopped caring about brinkmanship.

The market, the value rotation of the plants and the simplification of the connection system from funkenschlag make this game a modern masterpiece.

Early mistakes can be costly and on the starting end of my personal learning curve, I tend to spend a lot of time going through the motions after I've screwed up in some way; just watching as other players finish up. It's one of those games that's at its best with a table full of wily veterans. The good news is that I'm invested in getting myself into that category.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I picked up Power Grid sight-unseen. It is definitely an excellent game. There's a small bit of similarity to Ticket to Ride with the map and the limited access to cities. I've heard that it could be very slow due to analysis paralysis, but I didn't have a problem. The choice of cities to go to was usually straightforward, and the only tough calculation was coming up with a fudge factor if you're not the first person building so that you know how much money you can't spend on a power plant and resources. The only downsides are that there are a few fiddly rules (that were still easy enough to figure out as we worked through our first game) and the rulebook isn't the most clearly written example.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
There's a lot to like about Power Grid.  I enjoyed the auction stage, I really like the management of money for the three stages, and I like the graphics and presentation of the game.  This is a serious winner for me and I can't wait to play again!  With 3 I found it quite fun, with 6 it is enjoyable, but there is a lot of waiting between turns.  Certainly bad to be leader in a 6-player game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

An ok game but the decisions seems somewhat too obvious to me. On the positive side it seems to scale well. I dunno if it's the people I play with but the auctions never tend to be that long or fierce.

RATING: 9
Because of the 2hrs or longer time frame to play this game, this game isn't played as much as it normally would be in my game groups. However, it is played quite a bit and is a big hit in my game groups. This is a really fun game. One of my favorite boardgames. Anyone interested in the Euro strategy type games will love this game. Even those who aren't really into euro strategy type games or just not really into a lot of boardgames will love this game. My gf isn't really into playing board games a whole lot like me but this is her favorite game! She loves it because its easy and simple enough to learn and play but still provides enough of a challenge to enjoy this game and not get bored with it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
once the novelty of the auctions wore off after the second play, this one fell flat.  not enough interesting decisions to make and too harsh and impersonal an endgame.  feels like one move can win or lose you the game late on, regardless of how well you played in previous rounds. fun artwork and clever resource market mechanism. also dig the china/korea market variation.

had a decent enough time, but would rather play any other game in my collection.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Power Grid is in my favorite category of game: the very accessible medium weight game.   I've had no trouble teaching this to newbies, and it's gone over well with just about everyone.  
Pros and cons:
Gameplay is clunky at first, but the included player aids give a very useful Turn Summary.  Power Grid involves a lot of addition, especially in the late game, which can lead to slow turns by some players.  Money is hidden, so the lack of perfect information helps to encourage best-guessing over min-maxing.  
In my experience, PG scales well from 2-6, but 5 is the sweet spot.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

UPDATE: I think that three (or at most four) players is what's needed for this one.  Finally played it again and got in a tense and fun three-player game that was actually fun.

UPDATE #2: Played a dynamic six-player game and actually liked how it seemed that the game situation was pretty fluid, elevating my rating just a bit more. Still remain unconvinced that it's amazing, but it's growing some on me.

UPDATE #3: In thinking about this, I think much of the game is encompassed in the auction, and there are better auction titles out there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a train game in disguise, but there are enough train games already, and the theme works. It may be a bit more luck-driven than Wallace's Steam, and it's a bit fiddlier, but not intolerably so. For an accessible introduction to economic games, this one is hard to beat. The dedicated fanbase is a testament to its longevity. It's a good game.

For me, Power Grid's major detraction is the turn order manipulation, which is both "gamey" and too forgiving. I often feel as if I'm playing against the system more than the other players, and the system protects any one player from getting beaten too badly. Especially in longer economic games like Power Grid, I've come to value swingier economies with fewer safety nets. Against experienced players I win most games I play or I come very close. That's a symptom of the larger problem, which is that Power Grid has become routine. I don't find myself discovering anything new about the other players or the game. Instead I do the same kind of calculations and execute a variation of the same plan game after game. If I didn't do well, it would be because I got lazy, not because I was outwitted. It's all a bit rote.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Bidding for power plants, buying resources from a changing market, and network/area control mechanics all interlock to make up one superb game. It deserves to be ranked as high as it is. The expansions are icing on the cake.

So the beginning of the game is very enjoyable, and then somehow near the end I would think "Oh well, whatever, yes I could score two more point if I did this or that, maybe I will think over each move for ten minutes...".
