=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A classic game which should be in every game collection. Very clever economic strategy game but can be a little bit dry.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Components - .9/1 Box is nice. Board is solid. Resources are pieces instead of tokens. The cards all seem very reasonable. The rulebook is generally laid out well, though unless playing with 4 when reading through the rules, it wasn't the best at calling out the differences for more/less players. Artwork although isn't amazing fits the theme fine.

Fun - .9/1 This is a very enjoyable game. There's a fair amount to plan out and think about when it isn't your turn, so you're always involved. As common in euros, the decision optimization syndrome can overwhelm almost anyone towards the late game, so there are times where turns need to be sped along to keep the game moving. This is mostly dependent on the people playing, but does take away a little.

Replayability - .7/1 The different power plants (after the initial setup) are random enough that people are generally forced to change their strategy, which in turns changes how the game plays out. The maps can get a little samey after many plays, but they are still enjoyable.

Strategic - .9/1 Only random element is the available/futures market for power plants. These can greatly influence what people are playing. You need to keep track of what resource everyone needs, as well as the number of cities they can power. Lastly the auction phase allows for a whole different element in the game. The only knock is that the city purchasing phase (after the initial placement) almost always has a single option to go, and the strategy is almost always whether to buy or not, rather than which to buy. This is only one phase, and isn't an always the case.

Theme - .9/1 Definitely feels like you're handling (a very simplified) market for power/materials. The concept is nicely executed. The game element that draws me out of the theme is probably the actual current/futures market on power plants. From a game perspective it greatly enhances the game experience, it combined with some smaller minor stuff just draws me out of the theme enough to warrant a small deduction.


Personal Rating - 4.5/5 I really enjoy this game. The euro balance is well done and many times people who we thought were done halfway through came back and won the game. It's obvious weakness is that the group has to be willing to not spend forever analyzing every move they're going to take to keep the game moving, which really is the games glaring weakness. Obviously this hasn't swayed my opinion of the game much, because I still rate it very highly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
JH
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I was very pleasantly surprised by this game.  I usually avoid games like Brass and Steam because the whole economic engine component of them don't really seem like my thing.  I've never been that adept or interested in math or economics so I wouldn't think I would enjoy it in a game.  I did want a game with a better auction component than something like Medici or Ra though so I picked up Power Grid.

The game is incredibly well designed.  The supply and demand engine of the resource market, the nuanced auction market, diminishing returns in the power network, everything blends together smoothly and works well without too much flipping back through the rulebook (which is short, concise, and well-written by the way).  I will say that playing with a casual group, like I did, is probably better than playing with more hardcore gamers though.  We played with hidden money and while everybody balanced their money to adhere to their plan of buying plants, resources, and networking cities nobody held the game up with AP trying to build the most efficient economic engine every turn.  That method would probably win you more games at the cost of fun, especially for everyone else at the table.

All in all, amazingly well-designed game that I quite enjoyed despite my predilections for non-economic board games.  I may look into playing others now, as long as it is with the right (read: more casual) group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
1st game 2 player with wife to get a feel for the rules. She went from sceptic to complete fan girl in about 10 minutes. Enjoyed it so much that we skipped the Rules advice to just play the first step and went all the way through. 

Why do i like this game so much? It has the rhythem of a middle distance race where its in your interest to be conserving energy, slotted just behind the leaders. The key to the game is 1) Manipulating your position 2) Efficiency - and 3) knowing your relative financial position vis i vis opponents.

The raw materials market is genius, and i can't think of a better, or simpler way, of gaming supply and demand.

The auction is superb as well, with just enough randomness to mean you need to play the odds a little as what Power plant will fall out is not known (apart from the China map)

I very much doubt i will ever tire of this game. 

February 2013

I am in a minority of one who plays the game by instinct rather than calculation. The end game math is almost eliminated (other than how do i get to 17?) if you concentrate on the simple building blocks of efficient power plants that, cheap power stockpiled, keeping out of energy sectors others are in and cheap and roomy early connections - the game then does the work for you

Reading 'Characteristics of Games' has made me wonder if the catch up mechanism (i.e turn order) is actually what makes this game great. As if the part of the game that is inserted to balance it is actually the fulcrum of decision making. If it were a design intention it's a stroke of genius

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An excellent economic game.  Everything seems to work well even if it is stitched together by rules exceptions which are thrown in to maintain game balance.  The end result is extremely rewarding.

The only knock I can think of is that you might as well call it "Profit/Loss Statement: The Game."  The game is very heavy on crunching numbers every turn in order to try and achieve the best build possible to end up with the most money by the end.  Some people just hate this.  Being an economics major with an accounting background, I find it quite fun, but it can burn you out after a few sessions.  That's the sole thing keeping it from being a 10.  It's a good burnout, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It plays differently every time, depending on map selection and which plants come up for auction.  Our 9 year old can play this with no rules modifications.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I very much enjoy it.  I'm not fantastic at it, either, which is refreshing, since I'm often the winner in heavy games.  I wish the play on the actual map was a little more significant or interesting, but that's a minor point.

The interesting parts are the power plants and associated resources.  I enjoy the tension between efficiency of plants and their capacity.  If, for example, you can grab a good wind plant (capacity 3 or 4) on the second round for not too much, it will give you a substantial edge because you're spending less for resources than the other players.  However, investing in that same plant on turn seven is totally counterproductive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Cédric
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Update: played some more, and I must say this game does have appeal. It's still fiddly and and overtly mathy, but is some fun kind of way. Would like to play again, I guess.
****
This must be one of the most overrated games in the history of BGG. Power Grid is a typical 'calculation game', in the vein of games like Caylus and Java, that most eurogamers seem to prefer. Not me, although I'm a real eurogamer. Power Grid is already pretty long by itself, but it has all kinds of rules to further slow it down. 
First, there's the constant arithmetic of calculating how much you need to pay for your resources, how many houses you can afford and what you want to save for the next auction. 
But more important, the game rewards inaction: to get the game moving along, you have to build houses. But build the most, and you're suddenly shut out of buying resources, or only at insane prices if you're lucky. So nobody is inclined to build houses, unless they're sure they'll end the game with it, winning in the process.
I don't really mind playing Power Grid, but it's several leagues away from being a great game for me.

RATING: 6
Has a wonderful market "system" but the game has definite lulls in actions which are low-points.  We've played this a lot over the last 2 years and it's a great bridge game into more in-depth eurogames, but it is decidely lackluster the more we've played.  Rather than building in excitement to the very end, it typically is decided before the final move except in the rarer money-tie-breaker.  Over all there are many games which are a much better excitement to time-spent value.  Tyros, of course, comes to mind but also Tower of Babel, Samurai, Arkadia, Santa Fe Rails.  If you've got 5 players, Oasis and Santiago are hard to beat.

Horrible punish the leader by as obvious a method as possible--literally, it's as bad as "if you lose your queen in chess, remove random 3 pieces from opponents side as well"

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
So I finally got a chance to play the venerable Power Grid for the first time, and I was surprised by how rules-light it was given its long-time high ranking on BGG (rightly or wrongly or somewhere in betweenly, I tend to associate high BGG ratings with extremely dense, long-lasting, Euro-style brain exercises).  But despite the beginner-friendliness of the game, as with many of BGG's highest ranked game, I thought it was okay but will not go out of my way to play it again.  As a whole, it's quite a clever game, but I personally don't tend to enjoy auction-oriented games all that much.  And outside of the auctions for power plants, I didn't think that there was much in the way of meaningful decisions to be made, since the route-building was usually pretty obvious (take the cheapest routes that allowed you to get in the way of the other players the most), and the purchasing of resources generally involved buying all the resources required to power your plants for that turn, but not much more (unless the price was particularly good).  The physical components are okay, with the illustrations giving the game a fun, stylized look.  So overall, I admire the design without being personally thrilled by the game.  (Still, I'd be interested in trying out "The First Sparks" if given the opportunity.)  Game design: 3.5/5  Personal enjoyment: 2/5  Total: 5.5/10

RATING: 9
[Several plays]  A solid game.  It has player interaction as people get in each other's way on the map and bid against each other in auctions.  It has built in ways of throttling the leaders with resource cost and building order.  It has a theme the makes sense for the game.  It is not super long to play.  I just have enjoyed this game each time I have had the chance to play it.  Definately a top calibar design.  The really kicker that pushes it up to the 9 rating is the supply and demand mechanic with the resources. The more I have played this game the more I like it.  The expansion maps and cards add variety as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[RGG 2004 Edition] {Economic; auction, connection, variable-player-order, resource management; optimal 4-5p} Power Grid is a decent strategy game. It is unforgiving and brain-teasing due to the multifaceted development system. Because of its complexity, PG needs a long learning time. PG is not very confrontational for 3-4 players but is highly confrontational in 5-6p! 

PG is a rich game. It provides players many tactical options and rooms of strategic planning. It has good player interaction as well. It's quite engaging because of the strong competition of cities, resources and power plants. The system PG is well-balanced - no run-away leaders, no leader bashing and no king-making; it's very good.  There is a learning curve in PG.  Players need a few games to understand the game well.

PG is a rich game but not an elegant game.  The theme is not convincing, though existent. It is not intuitive because of the exceptions and the artificial rules; therefore, it's easy to get confused when it is firstly played and player aids are necessary to avoid errors. PG is a little bit fiddly - power plant markets, resources, different phases and stages, etc. 

PG is not very suitable for newbie because players have to consider many things in the game such as the price of resources, the distribution of the network, the power plant, etc.

RATING: 7.9
Niek
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
2-6 / 12+ / 120'
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is almost always challenging and intriguing to play. I love trying to out-maneuver the other players in order to reap the benefits of cheap, efficient fuel. Of course, in order to do this you have to not only pay attention to the raw materials market and your set of power plants, but also player order (dictated by cities you have built in), the power plants currently owned, and the future power plant market. Everything just seems to hang together so nicely and the game has a wonderful rhythm to it, and trying to read that rhythm to predict the ebb and flow of the various commodities is great fun. Also the auction mechanic provides a welcome, more confrontational aspect than other popular euros such as Puerto Rico and Agricola. This game falls in to a similar bracket for me as Settlers of Catan, in that despite lots of play time I have yet to hit on a sure fire strategy, which is great as it stops the game from becoming an algorithmic exercise and promotes meaningful play.

Dropped rating slightly as it's a bit too heavy and math-sy for repeated plays now. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
No crayons - thank goodness! Some concerns regarding catching the leader but enjoyed re-acquainting myself with the mechanics

RATING: 6.75
Fun game, but it punishes the leader too much. You really have to just edge behind everyone and jump ahead at the last second.

Besides its flaws it is still a very fun game.

Update: Still a good game, although a little mathy at times (especially on the last 2 turns). The main reason I've dropped my rating from 7.5 to 7 is because of the duration of the game for new players. Plus, you're always doing the same basic thing every turn. No real thought process in my opinion. I really wish there was some hidden information element, like secret cards that people could play to cause special events. As is, the game is getting too bland to be a top tier game in my eyes.

Update 2: Just way too mathy and AP prone for my tastes now. Still a classic that I'll play from time to time, but not a game I'll ever seek out. Wish there was more hidden and random information than simply math calculations going on.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is very close to being an excellent game but a few infuriating flaws prevent it from being quite as good as its overall rating on BGG suggests. The main problem I have with the game is that it tends to end anti-climatically, where it is apparent who the winner is going to be for quite some time. Once a player takes the lead there's very little the other players can do to haul them back in. This makes playing the remainder of the game rather tedious as it often lacks any real form of tension. It's also a game that's pretty unforgiving on errors. Therefore, you can make a mistake on your first turn and spend the remainder of the game waiting for it to end because you don't really have an opportunity to rectify your error. Basically, it feels as though the gameplay was worked out perfectly by the designer only for him to run out of ideas when it came to how the game should be won, which is a shame. I also find the theme of running a network of power plants a bit dry for my taste.

RATING: 5
Tried a few two-player games and it's worthless. You must be at least three, and with four it becomes much better. The idea is to expand as much as possible but stay smaller than the others (since beeing smaller gives you the best power plants, cheapest resources and easiest expansion). In one round you go "all in" and expand past everyone else, ending the game. Timing this means to calculate the cost to succeed without anyone beeing able to respond. These "calculate the last round"-games are not that fun though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Efficiency is the name of the game! A mathy game of auctioning for and building power plants. Players need to balance their cash between the auctioning of power plants and the subsequent rounds of buying resources for said plants, and building a network of buildings to be powered by the plants. Quite prone to AP, especially towards the end. Income has diminishing rates of returns and those behind in points have an advantage in the markets, thus managing turn order is important in this game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I wanted to love this game, and at first I was convinced that I did... but now I'm not so sure.  I like the thought that's necessary for placement on the map and the whole blocking thing.  I like the resource management challenges, too.  I think the mechanics try too hard to achieve balance.  I don't like how if you get out in front early, you're penalized the next time you buy resources and build.  I dislike that plant draw can theoretically determine the winner.  It's gotten too formulaic for me... I'm not saying that any one combo will win the game for you; it's just that I've managed to figure out a very simple way to always end up in a decent position at the end, and that's as good as I ever care to get at Power Grid.  Bonus points, though... the game lets you burn garbage!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
Amazing game! The decisions you have to make each turn are always meaningfull and the different aspects (resource market, map, power plants...) are beautifully tied together. This makes for very intense interaction between players, which is not only limited to the obvious area control aspects and the auctioning, but can be through the resource market and the brilliant player position meta game just alike.
I agree that it can be a bit mathy towards the end, but its not that bad. In fact we find it tons of fun to watch people getting so involved, that they start pulling their smartphones to use as calculators.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Interesting, but not that much fun...

Update: Having played it again after a long pause (and a whole bunch of more games), I still think it's an interesting design. It's not perfect and the catch-up mechanism feels a little forced, but played in the right spirit (quickly and without too much analysis) it's actually decent fun. I'd play it under these conditions, but not with people who take it seriously...

Further update: I'd forgotten to mention how much the final draw of power plants seems to determine the game. With a group of competent players, this seems to be the main deciding factor.

Rating up from 6 to 6.5.

RATING: 8.5
EGY parti után a véleményem:
A játék jó, de számomra mindig egyértelmû volt mit kell lépnem, nem állt elô az a helyzet, hogy sok lehetôség közül kellene választanom, mindig csak egy maximum két választásom volt. Ugyanis megvan a pénzed, a játék elején egy, majd késôbb két-három várost szeretnél egy lépés alatt bekötni, ehhez megnézed kell-e erômûvet venned, megnézed mennyi nyersanyag kell, kiszámolod a lóvét (nyersanyag ára, bekötés ára), ebbôl már tudod mi az az összeg amit maximum erômûre költhetsz a licitálás során, azt kész, ennyi, leléped. Hármas partiban ez mindannyiunknak sikerült, nemigen kellett taktikázni, csak pénzt számolni, ami mindig elég volt.

Az még fontos lehet, hogy a térképen honnan indul az ember.

Második parti után (4 szem.) Most nem volt annyira triviális a dolog mint az első játékban...Nem tudom, még mindig azt állítom, hogy taktika nemigen kell hozzá

Három+ játék után. Nos eddig azt hittem az a jó, ha a ze ember mindig elkölti azt a pénzt ami a rendelkezésére áll, pontosan kiszámítva, hogy mi mennyibe kerül. De rá kellett jönnöm , hogy ennél ez sokkal összetettebb. Nagyon figyelni kell a többiekre!

Szerintem a PG nagyszerûsége abban is rejlik, hogy komoly a játék a szabályai viszont aránylag egyszerûek és így könnyen elsajátíthatóak bárki számára, nem kell sok apró szabályrészlettel bajlódni és megjegyezni.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
10->9

One of my favorite games. It`s dry, but very emotional (usually i stand at the end of the game).

I love the mechanic. You want to be the last, than uou choose last a plant for bidding, buy first resources and build first houses. But you don`t earn so much money, so be last for the hole game is not good. You should have the same houses, like your capaticity of your plants. But you must by better plants. The question is when. Sometimes there is a problem. You don`t bid for a plant, and hope, the next plant will be interesting, but than the next plants can be very bad. But i think thats not bad. The luck factor with the plants is ok. Without that the game would be too shematic, and with less emotions.For some players the game is too mathematical (the whole game you count how many money you have) . The markt mechanism is interesting. You must choose how many resources you want buy. Great economic game for at least 4 players. 

Edit 2014: Still a great game, but the rating drops to 9. The game could block - if you realy need a new plant and the`re no good out there. And during the finish is a risk of kingmaking.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
02-Mar-08: There's a reason why this game is in the Top 10. Tense turns, agonising auctions, screwage in resource buying. There's so much happening in this game and so many ways for things to go pear-shaped for the leader. The only thing that bogs this down is the calculations; after a heavy game like this, you feel like you've just sat through a maths exam!

25-Aug-08: Had a games night on Sat night. Played one long game of Power Grid. Man, we were stressed out by the 2nd hour :-p We've all played before, so i think that was the problem - we were all trying different strategies and not concentrating on building new cities which prolongs the game.

24-Feb-11: Played Power Grid a couple of weeks back at work during lunch. By the end of it, my collegues were so brain-busted that they wanted to go home! Very mathy game this.

8.0 -> 6.5 (I think there're better games now)

RATING: 9
Power Grid is a masterpiece. The auction phase is a blast, buying cities is very satisfying, powering your cities and making money is even more satisfying, and competing for resources is cutthroat. Excellent game, my only criticism is that pretty often it can feel like the outcome is known about 20 or 30 minutes before the game ends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Fiddly. The last turn overwhelms the rest of the game once you get the timing down, so zero staying power as a game. You may as well just deal some random power plants, give people a lot of money, and skip right to the pain of the last turn. Then endure the last turn.

Additionally, the game fails as a realistic simulation [b]or[/b] an interesting playing experience for so many reasons. The fuel market has an unreasonable limit which can allow a player to king-make (or king-veto) when it is "better" to play towards his own interest. A poor player has too many opportunities to destroy other players' games. Far too many, "Acceptable compromises for playability," lead to complete idiocy. Auctions are far too long a period of "team counting"--insipidness does not begin to insult this game as much as it should be insulted.

I feel no success at winning; I feel no failure at losing. I feel a total waste of time. Worse: playing two-piece jigsaw puzzles for the same period would be a better use of time. Contemplating the lint in my navel would be a better use of time.

I may actually loathe this game more than blah-blah-blah-magic-carrot, as difficult as this may be to believe: I'm having difficulty devising an adequate way of gaining pleasure from burning PG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great design.  My love for the topic probably blinds me to limitations in the game.  It is fun to rule the electrons.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I played a 4 player of this game last night.  If it wasn't for all the hype about it I wouldn't have investigated the title.  I found the general theme looked boring (and it is for the most part).  While the retro style box art and colour choices make the game look a little uninteresting and overtly complex (in the board design).  The game really is better then its first impressions give.  It's a cleaver little game of decisions, with a healthy dosage of tension.  

Gameplay general revolves around resources management and expansion but the over all scoring is based on the economy and money. The game has a relatively low learning curve but seems daunting the first round. I did notice there was little interaction and high down-time causing the game to drag out longer then I felt it should have been.  The playtime started off slow, got more interesting toward the end but ended up feeling drawn out.  The final few rounds are what make the game interesting (if the over all play is sort of boring).  The ending comes as a bit of a surprise, in some ways anticlimactic but the fun in the last few rounds is what makes it entertaining.  The choices you make through the game jockey yourself into your spots in turn order and there in lies the over all strategy.  The rules themselves seemed to be rather poorly translated and generally unclear, I would have hated to play this without an experienced player present. 

The mechanic I liked the most was the fuel market system.  The over all supply and demand of the market makes for interesting choices when it comes to plants and financial quandaries when it comes to market costs.  Generally when taught by someone who has played it before the mechanics are generally clear and simple, often seeming like they rely on you having to think a round ahead.  Generally I liked this game but I think it could get tiresome after awhile.  Not a game I would play often but would be nice on rare occasions.

Perhaps the turns run long or I just don't care about the outcome. Not my favorite, although our gaming group loves this.

RATING: 4.3
I appreciate Power Grid as a resource management game, but often it feels like it's a graph optimization problem (and people who haven't been prepping for software engineering interviews will tend to attempt the same style of analysis, except more inefficiently). So it really comes down to how much you think others are willing to spend. I'm sure there's also some heuristic pricing of the value of a power plant or whatnot. It's a challenge, and I don't dislike it, but I feel like there are less arithmetic-heavy games I'd rather play.

RATING: 8
Seems to take too long for what it is. A two hour game for three players is quicker than the first version?

So far I haven't liked the endgame in every game of this I've played.

Maybe it's just that we're new to this game and aren't playing it the best. The resources start to run low and the lights start to flicker at some of the cities. One type is eaten up as another might start to replenish. Then after one type is completely gone players switch to a different type and do the same thing. It's interesting to see it happen, but sucks when you're on the receiving end of it. 

In the last game one player did a final push for 17 cities and ended the game not far in to phase 3. No one was close to competing at that point. It was a disappointing ending to a long game.

RATING: 8.5
Happy bits, weird auctions, and a situation where you almost always want to be in last place, until the point where you don't.  Sometimes a bit too mathematical - everyone needs to decide ahead of time whether you want to play this as a lighthearted thing or if you want to pass out calculators.  And that's Power Grid.  Electros away!

Revised in 2007 - after introducing Power Grid to the new game group I rounded together, consisting of a 'true gamer' and a collection of 'non-gamers', it has become one of the most requested games.  It is tense, fun, lots of talking and laughing.  For a game heavy on theme, that is also very strategic, and filled with agonizing decisions, it is remarkably accessible.  Upgraded from 7.5 to 8.5.

A very worthy addition to anyone's collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The designer's ability to interweave all of the different mechanics in the game is stunning. By the end of most games, I'm on the edge of my seat, and yet Power Grid still remains approachable to new players. Some complain about the turn order mechanic, but I find the decision point about when to hold back and when to surge ahead fascinating and exciting. Power Grid is about balance. Like a long distance foot race, the game forces you to keep up with the pack while maintaining enough resources in reserve to strike when it will hurt your opponents the most. The one blemish on the game is the auction mechanic for power plants. The random card flip can often give an unpredictable and therefore unfair advantage to one player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There are things I like about Power Grid, such as the supply and demand nature of the pricing of the raw materials.  That is brilliant.  But, it really seems like it takes too long to play to me.  And, there are some moments where a lucky flip of a power plant can really make a huge difference, particularly to the player who meticulously worked his way into last in the turn order.  So, I'm torn on how to rate it.  It doesn't make my top tier (8, 9, or 10), but it's a solid 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Initial impressions are a good euro. Auction element, resource management and property control, which are all well-implemented.

RATING: 6.2
Highly overrated. I have played this game many, many times and while not a bad game and initially very fun, I don't think there is as much here as people give it credit for. There are no hair raising choices, and it's often obvious what to do. I don't find the bidding terribly fun, it's a very standard mechanic and as loose as say, making deals in Monopoly. There is some strategy in the bidding but more about maths than anything else. The final turn is the only real tense part of the game, other than early blocking which is kind of like a bad Take That game really (sometimes it's unavoidable after set up). But the final turn is super mathy. I don't hate it, but I would be ok with never playing it again.

RATING: 7.8
A fantastic game, with just the right level of complexity. There's a satisfying level of interaction between the players, from grabbing cities that your rivals obviously want, to the power plant auctions, and even screwing opponents over by cornering the market in a particular type of fuel. The game is full of nice touches, like the mechanic for who ends the game (connected cities) versus who wins the game (powered cities). The turn order mechanic is one of the cleverest I've seen in a game, and can really reward a player deliberately hanging behind till he's ready to make his big move. To top it all off, the retro design aesthetic of the game's artwork is very satisfying.

RATING: 8.8
Very well balanced game. The resolution of the game feels a bit random at times, almost as if only the last turn really matters. The strategy here is a bit more subtle that other games because it really is all about setting yourself up to either end the game a turn earlier than everyone expects, or to be in the best position on the last turn. 

I almost wish there were more than one way to win the game in the end, but it's tough to complain when the game is pretty nice.

I would like more maps.

While Power Grid will reward smart, experienced players who like to think, a good teacher will make this game enjoyable even by newer gamers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game has a great bidding system.  Unlike Goa, say, you can somewhat easily look over at your opponent and get a sense for what they want.  This makes the bidding similar in feel to Ra.  I also really like the way sometimes the right move is to not start a bid.  And the balance of getting more efficient powerplants but not buying too many.  I also think this is my favorite spirtual recreation of Civ (the computer game) as a boardgame.  I know, they seem nothing like each other, but a lot of the joy of Civ is trying to get in a grove where you are able to expand your empire quickly and efficiently.  Powergrid does this best of the games I've played.  Downside: being careful about your math really does play too big of a role in the game.

Apples and oranges, probably, but for me this is a game focused on meticulous optimization of a non-exciting theme.  Of course I'll play it again, but it's not one I'll be suggesting very often.

RATING: 7

For one, the cheap costs of the East coast leave no reason to go West, young man. You'd be better off paying an extra $5 to set up shop in a town occupied by another player than spend the $25 expansion costs of the Rocky Mountain area.

However, I am a sucker for any game that allows the players to interact with each other (i.e. auctions). It brings in a lot of business strategy- buying players out of the coal market, for example.

[b]Possibility Space Landscape (Exploration=Fun)[/b]
:star::star::star::star::star: Challenge (Depth) Fun derived from analyzing and predicting the optimal path to take through the possibility space landscape.
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Variety (Width) Fun derived from trying out a large variety of meaningful paths through the possibility space landscape.
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Atmosphere (Height) Fun derived from the experience or anticipation of encounters along a path through the possibility space landscape.

[b]Gaming Skills Employed[/b]
:star::star::star::star::star: Analysis
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Tactics
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Strategy
:star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Direct Player Manipulation (Diplomacy)
:nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Indirect Player Manipulation (Bluffing)
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Player Reading/Prediction
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Luck

:star::star::star::star::nostar: Components

[b]Comments[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very good game, that I enjoy playing, but never have "fun".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good game with 4-6 players. Doesn't work with two players (even with the Robots expansion), and just play something else with three players.

I like the gameplay and the simplicity. The stock market is straightforward and the different phases of the game are easy to understand. Upgrading your power plants to be more efficient gives you a real sense of progression. The game also tends to be pretty quick, with even a five or six-player game taking around two hours.

On the downside, there's a lot of luck in the game and it's very mathy. The luck is in the form of what power plants are available for auction each turn. Sometimes you just can't get the thing you need, and other times a player goes last and gets a great plant for cheap just by pure luck of the draw.
The mathiness isn't too big of a problem, but the last round or two can go for quite a while as players run through all of the different calculations to determine the best move.

[b]Player Count Verdict: 4+[/b]
The game needs more players because of the auctions and the buildings. Without competition for those, the tight economy changes for the worse.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game would probably be a true "10" if I could play it more often.  For some reason, my friends and family don't often request this game so I've probably only played it 3 or 4 times.  However, I love the auctions and the unique balancing of turn order, prices, etc.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Interesting game and slightly reminiscent of Thurn and Taxis but with an economic system and more in-depth strategy.  Definitely worth a play.

RATING: 9
Oh Germans, the only people in the world that can make a game out of bureaucracy and utility services.  That said, I really enjoy this game (maybe I'm secretly German); great balance between map expansion (buying connections into cities) and "elektro-generating" engine upgrades (i.e. better power plants).  The game's premise, however, makes it difficult to convince others to learn and play, unless they're German or über-geeky.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Finally got another play in after a long silence. Its just as great as before. Very tight, very competitive, and every single decision is make or break. 

It is interesting however that trying to get first place and coming up short will almost always ensure you get crushed in placing (E.g. I could have secured a guaranteed 3rd place but would have had no shot to win, but I went for 1st and got last). Very few games seem to have this, and I'm not complaining, just find it interesting.

RATING: 8

Only the rules to move from one game fase to another feel rather artificial (I always have to look them up) and the game involves a lot of calculations. For those reasons it takes a bit of effort to get the game on the table, but once it's there it's always a very enjoyable ride.

RATING: 9

With higher numbers of players there can be a problem with down-time, but you can always use this time to consider your plans and adjust as people make their moves.

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 6
I find this game to be particularly unintuitive.  This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but getting a feel for the real value of the power plants and the inflation of money takes some time.  Given the length of the game compared to how much sheer fun I get out of it, I'm not sure that's time I'm willing to invest.  Also, the numerous fiddly rules that are easy to forget (mainly for removing power plants at various stages) don't help matters.

On the plus side, the idea of polluting the world with coal and garbage is quite appealing.

RATING: 9
Really well balanced game, it is always really close at the end.  The game becomes harder for the people in the lead, and easier for the people lagging behind.  This has lead to the interesting strategy of lagging behind on purpose and stocking up on enough resources to jump to the lead at the last moment.  

Good playtime, roughly two hours.  

Downside:  Lots of math.  Continually adding, subtracting, and dividing.  Not a game for a tired mind.

RATING: 8
Brilliant game.  The various mechanics -- auction, resource market, network building, turn order manipulation -- work seamlessly together.  Because of the different maps, different regions used, and different order of power plant appearances, each game plays out differently.  The only part that can get a bit scripted is the opening auction, but the considerations there change somewhat based on number of players.  I've downgraded my rating from 10 to 9 mainly because I now consider some other economic games to be at least PG's equal.

Ratings by number of players:
2 players: 5
3 players: 8
4 players: 9
5 players: 9
6 players: 8

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This one pains me a bit. The theme is so cool! The way the price of the ressources change depending on supply and demand! Very awesome!

However!! There are some unfortunate downsides.

-In a competitive game, you are never ever going to get or see the most expensive and cool power plant. It is way to easy to end the game before this and if you waste your time saving up for something good - you've already lost before you even get to buy it. 
-The money, oh God the money. Paper crap and fiddleliness. If you don't like simple calculations - all the time - you are not going to like this one.  

Not sure about this one - I wish a more balanced game with better management of the money would come out, otherwise it's a great great game.

RATING: 7
Is it a fun game?  A lot of decisions to make.  The game's decisions must be made off of the other players inside of the frame work of the game.  The supply and demand dictating the prices of the game have left me quite impressed.  Although impressed, I don't have a fire in my belly to play right away.  I wish there was more of playing the players instead of playing the system.  There is auctions, but it just don't feel like my   place in the finish is based off my reactions to the other players, and its more based off of my reactions to the gaming system.  Nice solid game, but I think I'm missing on how this could be someone's favorite, unlike other highly rated games I'm not gaga over.  Can have brutal downtime.

I've had really good experiences with this game... and really bad experiences with this game.  Most of my issues with the game(downtime, overly fiddly with the money, counterintuitive end game) seems magnified with six, and a bit with five.  

I know its a feature and not a bug, but the end game situations where the player has no resources to buy always deflates the entire experience for me.

RATING: 4
SOLD (11/15/08) --- This game was #1 on my wishlist during the spring of 2005.  I was eagerly looking forward to getting it after reading everything about it available on BGG.  For some reason though, while I certainly respect it as a well designed game, I don't find myself enjoying playing it.  I think it has something to do with both the pieces and the rules being particularly fiddly.  The game seems rather dry, and is a lot of work to play from round to round.  Finally, I severely dislike the "catch-up" mechanism for preventing a runaway leader and ensuring that every single game is extremely close.  Nonetheless, I give this game an 8.  This is somewhat analogous to how I respect the works of Mozart and Beethoven, but don't enjoy listening to them.  This game certainly isn't on that level, but it is a great game, that I just don't personally like to play very much -- UPDATE: Lowered rating to a 6 after another play that I didn't enjoy.

See my review to read more at:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/136370

Purchased: July 30, 2005

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Just beautiful.  I love this game.

The board is beautiful, and two-sided to boot!  The cards have cool graphics.  And the game is just brilliant.

The idea of reversing player order for different phases is just fabulous.  It makes the game more even, but more fun too.

The auction system is fun.  Do I buy a plant now, and give the next better one to another player, or should I wait and bid on the next one?

Balancing money between three systems - power plants, city expansions, and resources - versus returns (powered up cities), adds depth without needing more rules or complexity.

Brilliant in its simplicity and depth at the same time.  I'm not close to discovering everything about this game yet, and I think that's what I love the most.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An elegant game, one of the best auction games.  The way buying resources, auctions, turn order and building power plants works is nearly perfect.  It can be mathy, initial turn order can screw someone, and it can be a little dry.

RATING: 7.5
[b]Power Grid[/b] rose in my preferences, going from a 6 to a solid 7 after more plays, as my first experience wasn't a good one. However, once the proper rules were in place and the mindset was correct, the game flow is very good.

There is tension throughout the game, in almost all parts of it: the bidding for power plants, the acquisition of resources and the building of plants. Everything has a weight to it and must be taken into consideration, as the game doesn't allow for much room to mistakes: usually, once wrong purchase can be enough to lose the game, as more than one play was decided by some measly bucks.

And smart game, one that I reccommend easily.

RATING: 8.5
3.29
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A wonderful resource and money management game, the rules are quite straight forward and easy to learn. You buy power plants and the resources to power them to supply cities with energy; whoever can supply the most cities at the end of the game wins. The whole reversal of turn order for the resource buying and city building sounds a bit illogical at first but it all makes sense in the end and adds to the strategy. The tone is very industrial and gritty in which it is paramount to keep up with your rivals and define your presence on the board, although generally we find it is usually quite close between all players at the end of the game. There is a lot of strategy here and there is increased opportunity for interaction in cock-blocking on more than one front. It's great that the game comes with a reversible board meaning at its base there is more possible variety on offer. There's nothing quite else like it - a really fun game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 8
Some people I used to play with called this "doing the taxes", but I don't think that's fair. Sure, there is optimizing, but it's much more interactive and engaging than other games of that sort. After playing more on BSW, I can see how a snowball effect occurs - one early misstep can end up costing a great deal. It's also very nice how it can do a lot of the calculation for you, one time-consuming part of the board game. Playing the resource and power plant markets is enjoyable, and trying to position yourself just strong enough is a fun challenge.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The object of Power Grid is to supply the most cities with power when someone's network gains a predetermined size. In this new edition, players mark pre-existing routes between cities for connection, and then bid against each other to purchase the power plants that they use to power their cities.

However, as plants are purchased, newer, more efficient plants become available, so by merely purchasing, you're potentially allowing others access to superior equipment.

Additionally, players must acquire the raw materials (coal, oil, garbage, and uranium) needed to power said plants (except for the 'renewable' windfarm/ solar plants, which require no fuel), making it a constant struggle to upgrade your plants for maximum efficiency while still retaining enough wealth to quickly expand your network to get the cheapest routes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
An decent exercise in "lumpy" investments that is marred by too many worthless plants during the early midgame and, often, too much luck in acquiring the winning plants in the late mid-game.

If the odds favor several good plants showing up but they don't appear, the person who went all in on the only worthwhile plant at the start of round lucks out. 

Alternatively, if a good final plant happens to get turned up late in a round and you're still able to bid on it, then you often win. If not, you lose.  

In the roughly 25% of games where the final plant arrival order doesn't determine who wins, then you often get an endgame with lots of AP and calculations (if money is open) or accidental Kingmaking (if money is closed).

Some of the expansion maps (e.g. France) improve this by making a wider range of the early midgame plants viable, but it doesn't solve the latter problems, imo.

To be fair, I did enjoy exploring Power Grid; I would have rated it a 7 or 8 during my first dozen or so plays before I lost interest in it due to the above issues.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This Friedemann Friese classic balances short term gain with long term planning. The strategy of this game reminds me of Chess. Well-known chess strategies divide chess turns into the opening, middle and end games with different approaches to each. You want to gather resources and expand without ruining your turn order for the opening turns. In the late turns more focus is on the power plants and continuing expansion.

RATING: 8

UPDATE: Played a game in which one of the six players was unable to close the gap between her and the rest of the players from the first half of the first phase. Pretty annoying if you still have 2.5 hours to go. Hope it was a fluke.

RATING: 9
08/2007:9.5
What a joy to play this game! Great game with a great theme. Mechanics are a little clunky with prepping the power plant deck and at times, there are runaway leader issues, but game play is tense.  Always a popular game with friends. 

Upon more plays, the game remains a popular favorite. Placement of plants is key to winning the game. Runaway leader issues become less apparent with more experienced folks playing the game.

Still find the power plant deck finnicky. If you screw up the setting up phase, the game is shot.

040511 Still one of the best games around. After multiple plays, this game has withstood the test of time. New game boards and maps will keep this game fresh.

RATING: 6
Very, very solid game. It's a bit dry in comparison to other, heavier euros, but it's very elegantly executed.

Edit: Every time I play this, my esteem for it grows. Every time I play it, I find out new strategies. Even my parents love it!

Edit: After diming the base game, I'm starting to slow down on it. Much of who gets a good lead is determined by where they start on the map (though I did have some really interesting games where I came from behind by controlling the market, that was intriguing!). Who is able to get their most efficient power plant without breaking their bank also feels a bit luck based. 

It's still an extremely elegant game, and very well made. I'm simply cooling after exploring most of what it has to offer.

RATING: 8
Taught by BeyondMonopoly and others at PrezCon 04.  Is it possible for a game to be too tight and balanced?  This was a mighty close game, especially with two novices in it.  I heard one player comment that games are always this close.  Is the game so balanced that it plays itself?  I don't think so.  We played with generous people who gave us good advice.  Without useful hints about value vs reward in the game, I do not think Terri and I would have done nearly as well.  After one game, I suspect that Power Grid offers meager but meaningful reward for good play, and I look forward to finding out more when we get our copy.  P.S.  My relative success in my first game was definately the result of good coaching, and not any degree of over-balance.

RATING: 7
I like the concept of upgrading the plants, but I dislike the fact that players deliberately build less cities to stay in last place, just because turn order is so important. I consider games where turn order is so important to be flawed. I also dislike how toward the end of the game, it degrades into computing connection costs repeatedly in order to find the cheapest way to place 5 or so cities on the board. I enjoy tense, strategic decisions, not tedious mathematical exercises with an optimal solution. It makes my head hurt--- not in an enjoyable, cerebral way with agonizing decisions, but in an annoying way that is most similar to taking a long, pointless math test.

Edit: I played this again more than two years later and raised my rating from 4 to 7. Most of my previous concerns were significantly less significant than I remembered them, but what's more, I actually had fun! Although I am pretty sure that I was praying before with some of the rules wrong, Power Grid seemed like a completely different game.

RATING: 8.7
For those who love investment and auction game, this is one of the best option in the market.  With a very simple mechanism and an outstanding ounce of realism, you find in this game a framework trying to simulate the energy generation market. 
 2 to 3 hours of pure economic stress. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Power companies compete to connect electrical networks. Players balance their bankroll to buy power plants at auction, fuels for their plants, and connect cities to receive income based on the number of cities they can supply. Incorporates a clever supply & demand mechanism for the fuel market and turn order is modified each round to penalize the leaders, keeping games tight. The winner is the player that can supply power to the most cities at game end so money is just a means to an end (but can serve as tie breaker). Theme integration is superb. A medium complexity "gamer's game" that forces players to carefully plan their expenditures from round to round. The low amount of hidden information can be problematic when playing with Analysis Paralysis sufferers. I find it best when the game flows along with players going "by feel" instead of deeply calculating - using hidden player cash reserves helps this along. High replay value is provided by the 2-sided board with multiple areas - expansion boards can also be purchased.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I have only played this once and it was fun, but I think we did it incorrectly. I will have to play it again to reassess my rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game monopoly wishes it was.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Soooo much greatness.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A great multiplayer game that changes based on the number of players (certain conditions change).  Based on the map you use (and you should have more than just the base map), the rules change so it doesn't feel like playing the same game over and over.  There is a slight random element for a few maps (really only the power plant cards), but not enough to make this not a real strategy game.  The game also tries to adjust itself for players who are losing to give them advantages.  You have to get into a mindset that while playing this game it might become clear that there could be a winner early and adjust to prevent this.  You have to balance purchasing power plants with buying resources, and expanding your grid - and to know when to be aggressive and when not to be.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I love this game, an "efficiency engine" where you keep upgrading your power plants to power more cities with fewer resources. I rarely play the game because it is so long, and takes 2 hours. However, there are some tips online to get the game down to a reasonable 45 minutes, making it a game I want to play more often again. See the tips to shorten the game to under an hour here: http://forum.dominionstrategy.com/index.php?topic=7676.0

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
Absolutely one of my favorites.  Every time I play it I enjoy it a little more than the previous time.  High levels of interaction, complex series of choices, and many different game elements to keep track of at once make this game my favorite pure linear efficiency game.  Despite the fact that you're doing essentially the same thing every game, i.e. building the most efficient power grid possible, the different maps, random region selection, and randomization of power plants give the game massive replayability.  This one is a true classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A decent game, though the heavy end-game math is very heavy on the Analysis Paralysis.  This can make the last turn or two drag pretty badly.

My enjoyment of this game has been inconsistent - sometimes I have a lot of fun with it, other times I don't really enjoy it.

RATING: 6.5

I'd play it again if others wanted to, but don't think it's one I'd ever desire to play on my own.

Also, the components are feeling dated.  Mainly the paper money you have to try and keep a secret.

RATING: 7
The game is fiddly, remembering to manage the markets is annoying. However, this game is fantastically brilliant (if you don't mind a little arithmetic) and managing all your connections, resources and power plants is challenging. The artwork brings a little fun to a drab theme.

There is a ton of tension in city connections and power plant auctions, and some of the bidding wars are surprising. There's usually a lot of interest in what plants people buy, where they build and what resources they buy, since it usually has a strong effect on your plans.

Includes: Australia & India, Benelux/Central Europe, BGG Promo Card Set, Brazil/Spain & Portugal, China/Korea, France/Italy, New Power Plant Cards, Robots

Kevin

RATING: 10
The game that got me gaming.  Bought it for an economics class I teach, and fell head over heels into a hobby I never knew existed.  PowerGrid captures nearly every major element of a capitalist economy and boils it down to a wonderfully playable game, where the winner can claim TRUE monopoly and the losers have only themselves to blame.  With four playable boards, an increasingly relevant theme and drop-dead cerebral gameplay, it simply gets no better than this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A simple enough game to entertain people who are new to strategy games, yet dense enough for the most seasoned gamers.

Two observations that can make this game so frustrating and paralyzing, but also make it such a fun challenge:

1. You must always be performing cost-benefit analyses - it may be more beneficial to only power 7 cities than to power 11! It may be nice to have that efficient power plant, but do you really need it for the final turns? If you buy just one more resource, will it paralyze an opponent from powering as many cities as he wants?
2. You must always be thinking of positioning. Building into too many cities may cause you to be first in turn order, and, therefore, last to buy resources. But if you don't build now, will you be blocked off next turn? But maybe you also want one of the plants in the "Future Market", so you don't want to be first in turn order? 

SO MANY DECISIONS.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Whaddaya know, an economic game that's not so dry that all the life is sucked out of it.  Really a masterpiece in design.  Every little bit of this game seems thought out, and the overall game flow mimics a real developing power network.  Themed perfectly.  I'm not so nuts about the high granularity of the money, as change gets counted out frequently, and it gets a little silly counting out amounts of $100+ to the dollar, but that's a small nitpick.  Quite a solid design.  After several games, the strategy of when to lead from the front and when to fall behind is still nonobvious.  I'm not sure that I will ever figure it out.  I do know that I enjoy trying.

RATING: 8
I prefer the game online, where there's no moving of pieces and paper money around and the game goes faster. I'm definitely wary of playing this with over-analyzers who feel compelled to number crunch down to the last dollar at every single decision point (which isn't really necessary most of the time). The new power plant deck addresses all of the "issues" with the original. Of course, some of those issues came to characterize the Power Grid gaming experience itself. I like both decks although for beginners I'd definitely pull out the new one.

RATING: 6

3 plays: 6 players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Jogão. De início, a temática parece não empolgar muito.

A moral do jogo é construir as cidades, ou subestações ou sei lá, e conseguir suprir todas com energia. Não só isso, deve suprir mais que os adversários.

A sequencia dos jogadores é organizada de acordo com quem tem mais cidades, quem tem a usina melhor, quem tem menos cidades e quem tem a usina pior. Isso determina em cada passo quem começa jogando.

A primeira coisa é a compra de usinas via leilão. Cada jogador pode comprar só uma usina por turno, e cada vez que uma é comprada, entra uma nova para venda. Então vai depender um pouco de sorte, um pouco de quanto de dinheiro tem disponivel para gastar e também da estratégia.

Cada usina tem uma quantidade de recursos necessários para gerar energia e um valor de cidades que abastecerá. As mais baratas gastam mais recursos para abastecer poucas cidades, enquanto que as mais caras gastam pouco ou nenhum recurso para abastecer várias.

Depois que cada um comprou uma usina, ou não quis comprar, o próximo passo é comprar os recursos. São divididos em carvão, óleo, lixo e plutônio ou alguma outra coisa radioativa.
Há uma tabela no tabuleiro, que marca os preços dos recursos. O carvão começa cheio, o óleo quase, o lixo com metade e o plutônio com bem poucos. (Isso no jogo para 6 pessoas) Cada jogador pode comprar somente os tipos de recursos que utiliza em suas usinas, e cada usina pode armazenar até o dobro do que necessita para abastecer as cidades. Por exemplo, se uma usina precisa de 2 carvões para gerar energia, é possível armazenar nela 4 carvões.

Depois que todos compraram recursos, é hora de construir as cidades. O valor pago é o valor da conexão entre uma cidade que já possui e uma outra cidade, que não precisa ser vizinha, pode passar através das cidades sem contruir, pagando os custos das conexões. Não há limite de cidades que podem ser construídas.

O próximo passo é consumir os recursos para gerar energia. De acordo com a sua usina, e com os recursos disponíveis, cada jogador abastece suas cidades e ganha dinheiro de acordo com a tabela.

Alguns recursos voltam para a venda, de acordo com a fase do jogo que está ativa. A usina mais cara na mesa vai para baixo da pilha. A sequência de jogo é organizada, e mais uma rodada começa.

Eu gostei muito, a parte do leilão vai de acordo com que o jogador já está pensando, podendo não gastar dinheiro para deixar para comprar cidades, ou recursos. A capacidade de estocar poucos recursos também é interessante, já que eles não são muitos.

Por fim, ainda quero jogar muito esse jogo, que é bom, e com mais aprofundamento, parece ser melhor ainda.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
It's not so much a game as it is 2 hours of intense mental thinking.  A real brain burner.  If you love Excel spreadsheets, or take adderall then this game is for you!  When playing it for the first time it will take about 3 turns before you understand what is happening, and seeing a new players face light up as they suddenly understand how all the prices and power plants fit together is very rewarding.  Great game for teaching kids math and planning ahead! 

Also, I would highly recommend the expansion maps, as they don't just change the map, but often the entire rules of the game, creating a new experience for those familiar with the base game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
The object of Power Grid is to supply the most cities with power when someone's network gains a predetermined size. In this new edition, players mark pre-existing routes between cities for connection, and then bid against each other to purchase the power plants that they use to power their cities.
\13\\13\
However, as plants are purchased, newer, more efficient plants become available, so by merely purchasing, you're potentially allowing others access to superior equipment.
\13\\13\
Additionally, players must acquire the raw materials (coal, oil, garbage, and uranium) needed to power said plants (except for the 'renewable' windfarm/ solar plants, which require no fuel), making it a constant struggle to upgrade your plants for maximum efficiency while still retaining enough wealth to quickly expand your network to get the cheapest routes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is my favorite quote about Friedemann Friese and it sums up what I like about Power Grid rather well. "If Knizia is a mathematician, then Friese is an engineer. If Knizia is the master of theory and logic, then Friese is the master of rigging and patch-work." [i]From:[/i] http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/392410/steampunk-abomination

It seems like the entire game has been cobbled together from spare parts. The way turn order jumps around, the weirdly wordy and complicated rules for beginning Steps 2 and 3, the need to add and remove various plants from the auction row when certain conditions are met and the ebb and flow of resource availability all function to force a tight game. It seems so clumsy that you almost have to believe the final game evolved from a mountain of playtesting and Friese constantly hammering out fixes by the seat of his pants..

That's not to say that the game doesn't move smoothly. Part of what I like about Power Grid is that you almost have to play it by feel. There is a certain rhythm to the game that can't really be taught. You have to know when to lay back and when to surge ahead. It's a great vibe. There's some validity to the complaints that for most of the game you are actively competeing for last place and that Analysis Paralysis can set in during the closing rounds. I figure that slow playing for the lead is just a viable strategy of the game, not a flaw. As for the AP, what deep economic strategy game doesn't incur it?

A great game that I wish I got play it more often!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Great light game that a skilled player can reliably win at.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Quite bring and monotonous.

RATING: 7
What's not to like? It's beautiful, it's fun, it's competition in its sharpest. The market, auction system and worst-player-goes-first are feature I like and work very well in this game. 

Have not yet played the full 3-rounds game, but I have the feeling it will only make me like it even more. Perhaps this is a 9.

Will only pass the chance to play this if I have the chance to play a new game.

RATING: 9
My favorite modern boardgame (I guess defining "modern" as "in my lifetime"). I love virtually everything about this game. The auction, resource management and area control aspects work seamlessly together and all feel fully realized. Even manipulating turn order is an important strategic consideration. There's just enough randomness to it to ensure a different experience each time, and the regions concept makes for the least static non-modular board I've ever seen in a game. If there's anything I don't like, it's that the last turn often takes forever due to the small calculations each player has to make (and the nature of the game means it's not practical to do these during the downtime), but this is a very minor gripe with a wonder of a game.

RATING: 9
Three simple mechanics converge to make a deeply engrossing game that requires subtle manoeuvring, careful decision making and perfect timing to win. I love this game! It's also easy (but not easy to master of course) and only takes two hours of enjoyable time to play.

A played first sparks recently, it is virtually the same game but with perhaps a little more appealing theme and its also a little more forgiving. I still prefer Power Grid and the games are two close to have both in your collection (although obviously I'm tempted!).

New Power Plant Cards

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great number-cruncher.  Despite it's relative complexity and weight, this one always seems to be a big hit with non/casual gamers as well.  I guess people just like buying power plants and burning garbage.

Mechanically, the game is really clever.  The way the resource market works is really cool, and I love how you can get a glimpse of plants which may hit the market soon, but you can never be completely sure when they will be available.

One huge failing graphic design-wise, I think, is not having the market replenishing numbers or the "Step 2" and "Step 3" conditions and actions printed anywhere but in the rule book.  It's a bad sign when you still need to refer to the rule book after a dozen plays.  I think there are some good reference card solutions here on the 'geek, so it'd be worth checking those out.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A classic economic euro game with a very interesting market mechanism. The rules are rather straightforward but the decisions made during the game aren't easy - you have to carefully manage your resources and money and know when to expand and modernize your infrastructure.

The downside is that Power Grid needs 5-6 players to reach its full potential, don't even bother playing it with 2 or 3, it just doesn't work (4 is an absolute minimum). Another issue I have with this game is its length - it can exceed 2 hours and sometimes it overstays its welcome, especially when you have AP prone players in your group. Other than that - it's a classic for a reason. Definitely give it a try.

[b]/update, January 2018:[/b] Downgraded from 8 to 7. I really like this game, but it's just too long and there's too much upkeep with all the different phases, especially when it comes to replenishing power plants and the resource market. I have to check the rulebook every time I revisit this game. Power Grid is a bit too procedural when compared to some other economic games. It's a good game, but there are simply better ones in the genre with similar playtime (Brass replaced it completely for me).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Neat game - currently my favorite "heavy" boardgame.  Very thematic.   Tons of math,  and lots of jockeying for turn position.  

Box is big,  with a large, colourful board and lots of wooden pieces.  Insert is basically a big well, and all the tokens are in two large bags that actually don't take up much space, so when you open it up,  you don't actually see all that much (in comparison to opening up, say, Arkham Horror or Lord of the Rings.   Only 5 reference cards for a max 6 player game is an odd decision.  This will definitely end up rating high.  

Every action is simplified,  but feels true to the theme - auctions for the power plants,  the increasing price of resources ,  the route building / blocking on the map.    Using money,  although true to the theme,  does make the game a bit fiddlier than it might have otherwise been.   Only things left would be trading (maybe after/during the resource purchase phase,  people would be allowed to trade - resources?  power plants?  cities?) and maybe a bank loan/city mortgage for those times you're a buck short.

Playing to 7 cities (and planning for it!) isn't actually a bad compromise when you want a shorter game,  although only seeing the big power plants and never getting to buy them is a bit of a tease.

Only caveat with this game is you need someone experienced and meticulous for the fiddly bits - the five million special cases on starting Step 2 and Step 3,  and the power plant cycling is a little annoying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Tras varias partidas online y alguna en tablero, puedo decir que es un grandísimo juego para 4 o más jugadores. Gestión de recursos, economía, subastas y conexión de ciudades. A destacar con una excelente fase de subasta, una arriesgada fase de compra de recursos en un mercado variable y otra fase de conexión estratégica de ciudades, Alta Tensión es una de las mejores opciones para 4, 5 o 6 jugadores. Reglas y estructura de juego sencillos, pero con una estrategia y profundidad únicos. Muy matemático y psicológico en determinados momentos. Con mazo de Nuevas Centrales Eléctricas, el Condensador de Fluzo y el Mapa de Brasil/España y Portugal. Con fundas cuadradas tamaño 70x70mm.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent planning game with a very fitting and fun theme. Explaining the game using the theme really makes it easy. Note that playing with people who count every possibility can lead to some downtime. The rules can be a little fiddly and I recommend postponing some rules (when to remove a plant at certain steps) until the actual play when playing with new players. Although this is a gamer's game, I think non-gamers can grasp this game fairly quickly. This is a game that really needs a quick overview sheet. I recommend either http://www.boardgamegeek.com/fileinfo.php?fileid=15138 (PowerGridInfoSheet.pdf) or http://www.boardgamegeek.com/fileinfo.php?fileid=13186 (Power Grid step-based game summary.pdf) here on BGG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Another fun game along the lines of Ticket to Ride. This one would rank higher were it not for the confusing bookkeeping that you have to do between rounds.

Definitely need to play this one more too.

Initial rating: 9
[b]Update:[/b]New rating 8. I fear that the rating will go down, since I really loved it the first time I played it, yet the second one didn't even nearly fulfil my expectancies of replayability. The combination of luck (as the power plants come) and rather stubborn mathematical optimization with little interaction and high down-time, low learning curve. Moreover, we had a king making problem in our second play.Will try again soon and see if this second time was rather an unfortunate play or if it's in the game...
[b]Update:[/b]New rating: 8.5 My fears did not come true. Subsequent plays convinced me that it's not stubborn mathematical optimization, it's more subtle. However, king making is still a bit of a problem and it's probably not the perfect game for my standard group.

RATING: 10
Intensely involved game which sees all players partake in a charged hustle to outmaneuver, outbid, and outwit each other. NOTE: No time for lollygagging here. You must succumb immediately to PG's move-plotting mania or else you will fall behind when building and linking your power plants. Warning: This game is high energy. Win or lose, the inevitable brain drain you will experience by game's end is all worthwhile.

My only negative comment: The game's graphics, which have a cartoonish Simpsons-esque quality, don't quite match up to the game's high-powered theme. Although they have grown on me...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Don't let this game's boring 50's style fool you.  Think of Fallout 3: 50's style, awesome game!  What I really love about this game is that it's super easy to understand.  Unlike many other board games, you open the box and it's ready to go.  No punching hundreds of gold, terrain hexes, food, buildings, or any other cardboard pieces out of a few dozen sheets the first time you open the box.  This game is all strategy with few rules and complexities.  And the game isn't over until it's over.  The person in last place for most of the game can win it in the end (which is actually a top strategy in this game, since the person in last usually goes first each round.)  The rules are simple, the expansions are simple, there are few moving parts; this game is just fun and ideal for new gamers.

RATING: 7
My wife beats me at this every time we play; it's getting embarrassing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a great, thinky, heavy game about building a power grid.  Players compete to buy power plants in auction, build a power grid, and buy fuel for the plants.  The game is essentially a race to get a number of cities connected to your grid and to power as many of them as possible.  A game of supply & demand, competition can drive prices sky high.  

A brilliant part of this game is that players in last place are given some specific turn-order advantages for buying fuel and extending their power grids.  This feature makes timing a critical component of the game, and helps disadvantaged players to get stronger.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Man, I wish this game had a better ending. It's such a great design that plays so nicely right up until the very last couple turns. I really dislike the leapfroggy conclusion for such a long game.  I've had plenty of plays that have left me salty.  I'll feel like I'm doing the right thing the whole game and staying behind and piling up my money only to get screwed by a city placement, resource that sells out, or lack of 7-value power plant on the last turn.  

It's possible that I'm just bad at this game, but I think I'm done with it unless someone really wants to play it.  Both Power Grid and Copycat have infuriated me with their end game.

RATING: 8.3
Finally got to play this. It was as good as I had expected I guess although I found it to be very unforgiving for people learning the game as falling behind too much (not 'that' much) means that it feels impossible to catch up and it gets to the point where there is no point in continuing as you know there is nothing you can do. I prefer games to feel a bit more tense until the end and with people who don't necessarily have much experience with the game. I know there is a 'catch-up' mechanic in the game but I feel that only helps if you consistently stay within sight of the people in front. I suspect that a number of plays would be required to help alleviate this and I can't see that happening for me (as I don't tend to focus on just one game enough).
I also only played with 3 players which may change things.
It's still a great fun game that despite struggling to get to the table often, I'd still rate highly.
On a side note, I am not the biggest fan of the components. Cards are flimsy and ugly and the board isn't very nice but this only shows how much of a difference good gameplay is. I think I would prefer the deluxe version despite my research on which version people recommend having put me off it in favour of the original; but only if I could get the deluxe for not too much more money than the original.

[Color=#9900CC][b]Category:[/b][/color] Network building game.
[Color=#9900CC][b]Parts:[/b][/color] Board, cards, wood bits.
[size=7]----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/size]
[COLOR=#0000FF][b]Commentaires Personnel:[/b][/COLOR] Un jeu ou le calcul est une partie importante de la partie. J'aime bien l'intéressante façon de nous mettre constamment sur le qui-vive afin de déterminer nos besoin pour élargir son réseau le plus rapidement possible. RATING: 10
Very engaging.  Players have a great degree of freedom without being overwhelmed by choices.  Very little down time.  Well balanced.  Great but simple supply and demand system.  You feel that you are really matching wits with your opponents:  What is the best way to manipulate the market?  How much can you bid on that plant and still execute your expansion plan?  Is your opponent bidding you up, or do they really want that plant?  Some arithmetic is necessary to do well.

Power grid is an awesome economic game.  I love all of the dynamics in the game and the balancing act of buying new power stations, more resources, and getting new cities.
