RATING: 9
An engaging network building game with money and resource management. Like many/most economic games, it can be arithmetic-heavy as you figure out what you can afford to do on any given turn. The rules are tricky and easy to screw up but flow nicely once you get used to them. The rules to simulate a regulated, competitive market add indirect interaction (in addition to the direct interaction of the power plant auctions) as well as clever maneuvering and come-from-behind victories.

RATING: 9

My only complaint is that it's got a lot of fiddly rules that are easy to forget when you haven't played in while, and which aren't sufficiently emphasized in the rules, for instance discarding the highest-valued power plant after each auction phase during Step 1.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
{ P - 3 [4] [5] 6 }

Goldilocks: The Board Game. It seems like once every blue moon I play the game Power Grid was intended to be, where nobody gouges the supply/demand economy (increasing the price for everyone reliant on the resource) but remains at the bottom of the lineup, and the map doesn't produce overcrowding at the start - effectively eliminating those players - while allowing backyard properties for others (prefer France, U.S. with Brown/Yellow/Red/Green, Benelux, mostly hate the rest), and some crap pull doesn't stagnate the power plant market, usually trash plants or low plants after a glut of high ones - and players sit around with little to do. (Especially bad if someone lucks into a 5-6 THEN the crap hits, more or less giving the game away.) Even the instances where those three elements coincide still seem problematic. Every game I can remember has always had a must-gamble-to-win situation; because players are always aiming for the best/highest plants, low ones accumulate near the bottom and sooner or later every replacement is gambling. There's also a fiddly dilemma where players are required to "know their roles" in order to play a good game, and if someone doesn't realize he or she should be the person pushing the enevelope when it comes to city expansion the game can balk while waiting for Stage 2. (Many times, nobody wants to actually trigger Stage 2 for fear of getting blocked in, and as money accumulates this fear only worsens.) Still probably the best gateway game ever, unless you think Settlers and Carcassonne actually qualify as games.

RATING: 8.25
Cool game. Nice mechanics and clear instruction manual. Quite streamlined. Only it's quite a lot of calculating once you get near the end. If you want to plan ahead to figure out your win options, be prepared to crack your brain. 

The strength definitely is that it's not a race, but balancing out and plan when to build your power plants, your connections and when or what resources to buy on the ever changing market.  

The artwork is a bit mwoah ... doesn't really appeal to me. But the new (special) edition is even less interesting.

RATING: 8.9
Great and fairly simple game.  There may be a decent amount of options, but they are all fairly light decisions, making this a nice, quick game to play between those extra heavy games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
For a game that I enjoy as much as I do, and one that is as streamlined as it is, I don't know why I haven't played this one more? I love how all the steps in the game play out and how the game itself evolves from beginning to end.

How the initial auctioning of the power plants affects who buys commodities first and then placement of the cities is genius. And how the market changes over time and you have this ebb and flow of grabbing commodities, flipping of power plants and then grabbing of new cheaper commodities is great. The game tends to have these kinds of bursts of expansion as cities get built, blocking what others can do until certain stages in the game, and then the floodgates open and the cycle continues.

For a game that is as simple as it is mechanically, it evokes so much strategy. And while the setup is slightly variable in the way that the cards come out and the initial placement of each individual's cities, I think that it's just enough to keep it fresh and interesting. The fact that you can get so many maps for the game and that the player counts can have a drastic effect on how you play, makes this something that I think I'd never get tired of.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Really my plays are over 100 for this one. We played almost daily for two years in prison on a self-made board and cards that was illustrated from photocopies of the original that my mom sent me. This has one of my favorite economic models, a straightforward auction mechanic, and lean area control. Easily accessible for new players, but deep enough to keep you coming back for more. Over and over. Expansion maps only add to the success of this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The design of this game is very intuitive and much akin to reality. The improvement in efficiency/technology in power plant designs over time, the increasing cost of raw materials if one enters the market later, and the additional costs for entering a city second or third largely makes sense in real life and that makes this game more realistic.

The auctions of power plants, rush for raw materials and blocking potential when building cities creates tension in the game and much player interaction.

The only bit about the game I dislike is the handling of money (My Significant Other and I bought poker chips to replace the money). It can also get quite numerical when one plans ahead and this may turn off some players who prefer something that does not require so much addition and subtraction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game, a bit punishing so you have to be careful with turns in order to make optimal play since it's hard to catch up if you get behind.

RATING: 5.5
Mildly impressed after my first playing, but almost seems too "mathy" and analytical for a Euro. Can easily get lost in mathematics trying to optimize your turn. Sometimes it felt that the best move was an equation to solve instead of a strategy to employ, but the integration of all the components and rules is very impressive. Definitely warrants additional playings, but I'd want as few people playing as possible. More people adds far, far too much downtime and the game drags considerably. I don't think I'd ever want to play this with 5 or 6 again as it could easily stretch into 3-4 hours, or longer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm usually not much of a fan of auction games, as they tend to take many repeat plays to come into their own. The players must sort of get comfortable with the economic system of the game in order to correctly value their bids. All this definitely holds true for Power Grid, and leads to my hesitant 7 rating.

I have fun playing it, but simply haven't grokked the game to a level where I can play it well enough to compete. On the other hand, tight scoring games such as this, where it tends to come down to tiebreakers to determine the winner is also a bit of a weak point in my mind, as they can induce massive analysis paralysis. I can see future plays with longer, and longer Building Phases as it is so critical to have a few extra Electrons at any moment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
This game has 2 features I love.   A power plant market up for auction and a resource market for S&D.  The built in supply and demand purchase system ensures a handicap for the trailing players which means that auction bids and smart resource mgt is what ultimately determines the winner.  This is my favorite game by far...highly recommend.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
OK, first of all, I don't think this game deserves the high ranking here on the 'Geek. For that the game simply lacks elegance. It has too many housekeeping rules, and several clunky, gamer-y mechanics, such as the constantly changing turn order mechanic, which, while a crucial part of the tactics of the game, feels just unnatural and contrived. Furthermore, there's just too much downtime and a too long playing time when played with six players.All that aside, at the core this is a very interesting game. I enjoyed building up my network and the balancing act of purchasing plants and acquiring raw materials to power my cities. I just wish that somehow the game was more streamlined to bring the interesting stuff more to the forefront and keep the extraneous stuff to a minimum. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Finally got to play this gem recently, and the experience was made even better by being taught (rather than learning it myself) as well as having a full complement of 6 players.  Lots of strategy and manuevering.  When to purchase and when to pass, when to upbid and when to give up.  Each choice you make have reprecussions that will affect you later on.  It is one of those games that you wish you could've, would've or should've done afterwards.  I most certainly will own this eventually, however, since it play best with 5, I probably will not have many chances to get it to the table unless during holiday gatherings or at the boardgame club meetings (it is just hard for me to find 4 other people on a consistent basis).

RATING: 8
Rating based on one playing: I came very close to winning my first game of Power Grid (lost by 1 Elektro or whatever the currency's called) so that helps the rating. :)  Concerned about the unforgiveness of the game; does a slow start mean you have no chance of victory?  Time will tell... Rating update from 8 to 9 after three more playings on BSW: I like this more and more the more I play.  A slow start doesn't necessarily mean that you're out of the running, from what I've (now) seen.  A wonderful design that I like playing a lot. Update again: back down to 8, due to the very unforgiving nature of the game.  If you get behind, you can play out the second half of the game without having a chance to win.  Where's the fun in that?

RATING: 9
Awesome game for gamers.  No random chance, great design and simple rules.  A must play for math guys and gals.

Editor's Note:  I want to drop this game to a 3 rating.  I've played 9 games, finishing 2nd 8 times (and somehow getting obliterated once).  I'm like the guy in the "you will never win Power Grid!" palm reader cartoon recently posted on BGG.  Knowing the circumstances of how you will lose three turns before it happens while you have a huge lead is heart-wrenching.

Second editor's note:  I finally won!  However, it took playing Korea and China... both of which I can lay claim to an undefeated record (1 win in each, 0 losses - hah!).  Try to play Power Grid with the new power plant cards, though.  It's a much better game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Was my long-time #1 game, but I think it might finally start falling back a bit. Brilliantly put together game with elegant supply and demand curves that just happen through game dynamics. Last few turns always crescendo nicely, and the game has a good catch-up mechanic. Only downsides are the paper money and the futility you might feel when you know three turns from the end you're in a no win situation. The puts people in behind in a king-maker position, where they can ramp up the cost of a powerplant out of spite, ensuring another player will win. But still, it gives people who are essentially out of it something to do!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
个人观点，BGG前十位中最名不副实的游戏，属于精算类游戏，游戏绝大多数时间在算个人账。然而各种地图扩展的不同特点提升了游戏的耐玩性，作为入门级经济游戏来说还是不错的，对其频繁的找零纸币有点厌倦
【关键词】燃料市场，拍卖电厂，绿色能源电厂，三个时期，不同时期限制，发电/不发电，玩家顺位变化，游戏结束条件

【推荐度】中高 【网络经济，中度德式爱好者

Debes administrar muy bien tus recursos energéticos y tomar buenas deciciones para construir suficientes casas, iluminarlas y ganar. ¿Qué tecnologías comprar? Ir a la delantera durante la partida o al inico del juego puede ser tu perdición.

RATING: 8
I particularly like the resources system with things in demand getting more expensive and unpopular resources getting cheaper. Very nicely designed
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is THE favorite game of multiple members of my gaming group. 

Power Grid has everything a good meaty game should have. High skill/luck ratio. Varied play, lots of player interaction, relatively low downtime, and proper handicap that assists lagging players to keep the game even.

The unique theme and solid materials makes the game feel high quality. 

Even after many plays, we come up with new strategies for winning, and available expansions keep the maps fresh.

The only downside is the higher learning curve and amount of rules. This is a barrier that scares off non-gamers and this game has to be worked up to. Its meatiness is both its greatest strength and weakness. Be prepared for 2 hour games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'd give this a 9 or 10, but it's a bit weak with two players, and there's a lot of initial rules explanation to get new players in.
